Name:  ___                       Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: NEUROSURGERY
 
Allergies: 
No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions
 
Attending: ___
 
Chief Complaint:
Leg weakness
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
N/A

 
History of Present Illness:
Transferred from ___ with MRI finding of 
C4/5,C5/6 stenosis and cord edema. Patient has intermittent 
right arm weakness and pain that radiates from his back 
posteriorly to his mid foot, a few episodes of urinary 
incontinence, some saddle anesthesia, normal bowl function.
 
Past Medical History:
Per consult note
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
noncontributory
 
Physical Exam:
Discharge on Exam:
=================
Patient left against medical advice and wasn't able to examined. 
Please refer to last documented note for exam
 
Pertinent Results:
Please see OMR for pertinent results
 
Brief Hospital Course:
Transferred from ___ with MRI finding of 
C4/5,C5/6 stenosis and cord edema. Patient has intermittent 
right arm weakness and pain that radiates from his back 
posteriorly to his mid foot, a few episodes of urinary 
incontinence, some saddle anesthesia, normal bowl function.

An MRI of the Tspine was ordered and needed to be completed 
before the patient could be discharged safely and follow-up in 
clinic this week to schedule elective surgery. However, the 
patient said he had already had plans and would be leaving the 
hospital by 5PM regardless. He said he was going to talk to his 
wife for 10 minutes, but did not return to his hospital room. 
During the discussion about the importance of obtaining the MRI 
Tspine, we discussed him following up in clinic this week to 
schedule elective surgery and warning signs/symptoms. He left 
the floor at 1:15PM ___ against medical advice and did not 
return.
 
Discharge Medications:
1.  Acetaminophen 325-650 mg PO Q6H:PRN Pain - Mild  
2.  Gabapentin 300 mg PO TID  
3.  Methocarbamol 750 mg PO QID  

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
C4-6 Stenosis

 
Discharge Condition:
Per last note

 
Discharge Instructions:
PATIENT LEFT AGAINST MEDICAL ADVICE AND BEFORE FINAL 
RECOMMENDATIONS COULD BE GIVEN.

Avoid strenuous activities
No need for collar
Call Dr. ___ ASAP to schedule a visit as soon as 
possible
 
Followup Instructions:
___

text:
Name:  ___                       Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: NEUROSURGERY
 
Allergies: 
No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions
 
Attending: ___
 
Chief Complaint:
Cervical stenosis and myelopathy
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
___: C3-C6 laminectomy and fusion

 
History of Present Illness:
Ed is a ___ year old male seen in outpatient clinic on ___ 
for follow-up of an MRI finding of C4/5,C5/6 stenosis and cord 
edema. Patient was evaluated in clinic for ongoing intermittent 
right arm weakness and pain that radiates from his back 
posteriorly to his mid foot. He has had a few episodes of 
urinary  incontinence, and some saddle anesthesia, but normal 
bowel function. He presents for elective C3-6 laminectomy and 
fusion.
 

 
Past Medical History:
None
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
noncontributory
 
Physical Exam:
UPON DISCHARGE: 
He is awake, alert, and cooperative with the exam. He is 
oriented to self, location, and date. 
Motor:
TrapDeltoidBicepTricepGrip
Right 4         4      4       4      4-
Left 5   5      5       5      5

IPQuadHamATEHLGast
Right3 4-      4-      2      2        2
Left5 5       5       5      5        5

[x]No Clonus [x]No ___ 
[x]Decreased sensation to right side
[x]Incision is clean, dry and intact with staples and suture at 
drain exit site
 
Pertinent Results:
Please see OMR for pertinent imaging and lab results 
 
Brief Hospital Course:
Ed is a ___ year old male who presents for elective treatment of 
cervical stenosis and myelopathy.

# Cervical stenosis and myelopathy
On ___, the patient underwent C3-6 laminectomy and 
fusion. The procedure was uncomplicated. A JP drain was left in 
place. For further procedure details, please see separately 
dictated operative report by Dr. ___. He was extubated in 
the operating room and transported to the PACU for recovery. 
Once stable, he was transferred to the floor. He is to wear a 
hard cervical collar at all times. On ___, his neurological 
exam remained stable. JP drain output was high and remained in 
place. Foley was discontinued. He was ambulating to the bathroom 
with a walker. On ___, JP drain output remained high. On ___, 
JP drain was removed without difficulty. Post-pull xray showed 
no evidence of retained drain. His pain was well controlled on 
oral medications. He was tolerating a diet and ambulating 
independently. His vital signs were stable and he was afebrile. 
He was discharged to home.
 
Medications on Admission:
acetaminophen PRN  
aspirin 81 mg daily 
Gabapentin 300mg TID
methocarbamol 750mg QID
 
Discharge Medications:
1.  Diazepam 5 mg PO BID:PRN pain 
RX *diazepam 5 mg 1 tablet by mouth twice daily as needed for 
muscle spasm Disp #*10 Tablet Refills:*0 
2.  Docusate Sodium 100 mg PO BID  
3.  OxyCODONE (Immediate Release) 5 mg PO Q4H:PRN Pain - 
Moderate 
RX *oxycodone 5 mg 1 tablet(s) by mouth every fours hours as 
needed for pain Disp #*60 Tablet Refills:*0 
4.  Senna 8.6 mg PO BID  
5.  Acetaminophen 1000 mg PO Q8H  
6.  Gabapentin 100 mg PO Q8H  

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Cervical stenosis
Cervical myelopathy

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Surgery 
Your incision is closed with staples and sutures. You will 
need suture/staple removal. 
Do not apply any lotions or creams to the site. 
Please keep your incision dry until removal of your 
sutures/staples.
Please avoid swimming for two weeks after suture/staple 
removal.
Call your surgeon if there are any signs of infection like 
redness, fever, or drainage. 

Activity
You must wear your brace at all times. You may briefly take it 
off while showering. 
We recommend that you avoid heavy lifting, running, climbing, 
or other strenuous exercise until your follow-up appointment.
You make take leisurely walks and slowly increase your 
activity at your own pace. ___ try to do too much all at once.
No driving while taking any narcotic or sedating medication. 
No contact sports until cleared by your neurosurgeon. 
Do NOT smoke. Smoking can affect your healing and fusion.

Medications
Please do NOT take any blood thinning medication (Aspirin, 
Ibuprofen, Plavix, Coumadin) until cleared by the neurosurgeon. 
Do not take any anti-inflammatory medications such as Motrin, 
Advil, Aspirin, and Ibuprofen etc until cleared by your 
neurosurgeon.
You may use Acetaminophen (Tylenol) for minor discomfort if 
you are not otherwise restricted from taking this medication.
It is important to increase fluid intake while taking pain 
medications. We also recommend a stool softener like Colace. 
Pain medications can cause constipation. 

When to Call Your Doctor at ___ for:
Severe pain, swelling, redness or drainage from the incision 
site. 
Fever greater than 101.5 degrees Fahrenheit
New weakness or changes in sensation in your arms or legs.
 
Followup Instructions:
___

text:
Name:  ___                  Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: MEDICINE
 
Allergies: 
morphine
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
abdominal pain
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
None

 
History of Present Illness:
___ h/o endometriosis, appendectomy with chief complaint of 
suprapubic pain and pain with urination. Symptoms started two 
weeks ago and was given a course of macrobid by gynecologist. 
Was tested for STDs at that time per patient and was negative. 
Pain progressively worsened associated with nausea and diarrhea 
as well as constipation. no fevers/chills. No CVA tenderness.  
She has had intermittent vomiting, no blood. No melena or BRBPR. 
 She states she has a high tolerance for pain medications and 
the only thing that worked for her in the ER was IV dilaudid.   

In the ER: Pelvic Exam: blood discharge. Sent GC/Chlamydia. no 
Cervical motion tenderness.
 
Past Medical History:
s/p ovarian cystectomy
s/p pregnancy termination
s/p knee surgeries
IBS
PUD
s/p appendectomy
depression
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
not relevant to the current hospitalization
 
Physical Exam:
VS: Afebrile, VSS
GEN: NAD, AOx3
HEENT: MMM, OP Clear
ABD: suprapubic tenderness with voluntary guarding, no rebound, 
no masses or organomegaly
EXT: WWP, no c/c/e
 
Pertinent Results:
___ 01:45AM BLOOD 
WBC-9.1 RBC-3.78* Hgb-11.4* Hct-34.9* MCV-92 MCH-30.2 MCHC-32.7 
RDW-12.7 Plt ___
Neuts-54.7 ___ Monos-5.4 Eos-5.9* Baso-1.9
Glucose-81 UreaN-14 Creat-0.9 Na-139 K-4.4 Cl-105 HCO3-27 
AnGap-11
ALT-10 AST-19 AlkPhos-62 TotBili-0.2
Lipase-42
Albumin-4.0

CT ABDOMEN / PELVIS: 
Thickening of wall of the stomach, which may represent 
underdistension, however infectious/inflammation or infiltrative 
processes should be considered in the correct clinical setting. 

 
Brief Hospital Course:
ABDOMINAL PAIN, DYSURIA, URETHRAL PAIN: CT abd/pelvis with heavy 
fecal loading, I believe her abdominal pain and nausea in the 
setting of a history of IBS and dehydration is likely related to 
constipation.  She has small amt of watery stools which may be 
leaking around an impaction.  Will treat with colace, senna and 
miralax and a fleets enema today.  Narcotic pain medications are 
contraindicated in this case (pain from constipation).  I have 
discussed this extensively with the patient and she is demanding 
IV narcotics at least in the short term, I have discussed the 
reasons to not prescribe this and to work on the fecal loading / 
constipation issue first. U/a is negative, so unlikely related 
to any cystitis, will use pyridium for 3 days for symptoms to 
see if improve. Given h/o PUD will not use ibuprofen for pain. 
Tylenol prn..  F/u GC/Chlamydia.  Gastric thickening likely 
related to stomach underdistension but I have discussed this 
with the patient that she should see her PCP about this and will 
need an EGD for further workup or consultation with a GI 
specialist.  She understood this.  The patient left the hospital 
refusing to use bowel medications.  She stated that the only 
thing that worked for her was narcotic medications and if we 
were not going to prescribe these then she would go to ___ 
___.
 
Medications on Admission:
celexa 20mg po daily
protonix 40mg po bid
birth control pill
 
Discharge Medications:
 
1. citalopram 20 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily). 
 
2. pantoprazole 40 mg Tablet, Delayed Release (E.C.) Sig: One 
(1) Tablet, Delayed Release (E.C.) PO Q12H (every 12 hours).  
3. oral contraceptive  Sig: One (1) daily  once a day.  
4. docusate sodium 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO BID (2 
times a day) for 1 weeks.
Disp:*14 Capsule(s)* Refills:*0*
5. senna 8.6 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO BID (2 times a 
day) for 1 weeks.
Disp:*14 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
6. polyethylene glycol 3350 17 gram/dose Powder Sig: One (1) 
dose PO DAILY (Daily) for 1 weeks.
Disp:*7 doses* Refills:*0*
7. phenazopyridine 100 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO TID (3 
times a day) for 3 days.
Disp:*9 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Primary Diagnosis: 
Constipation

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted with abdominal pain and pain with urination 
after a recent urinary tract infection.

MEDICATION CHANGES: 
take PYRIDIUM for the next 3 days as needed for pain with 
urination
take COLACE, SENNA, and MIRALAX for constipation
 
Followup Instructions:
___

2.  Neurogenic claudication.
3. Radiculopathy.

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - requires assistance or aid (walker 
or cane).

 
Discharge Instructions:
-Activity:You should not lift anything greater than 10 lbs for 2 
weeks.You will be more comfortable if you do not sit or stand 
more than~45 minutes without getting up and walking around.

-Rehabilitation/ Physical ___ times a day you should go 
for a walk for ___ minutes as part of your recovery.You can 
walk as much as you can tolerate.Limit any kind of lifting.

-Diet: Eat a normal healthy diet.You may have some constipation 
after surgery.You have been given medication to help with this 
issue.

-Brace:You may have been given a brace.If you have been given a 
brace,this brace is to be worn when you are walking.You may take 
it off when sitting in a chair or while lying in bed.

-Wound Care: Keep the incision covered with a dry dressing on 
until follow up appointment. If the incision is draining cover 
it with a new sterile dressing.Once the incision is completely 
dry (usually ___ days after the operation) you may take a shower 
and place a new dry dressing on. Do not soak the incision in a 
bath or pool.If the incision starts draining at anytime after 
surgery, do not get the incision wet.Cover it with a sterile 
dressing.Call the office.

-Medications: You should resume taking your normal home 
medications. You have also been given Additional Medications to 
control your pain.Please allow 72 hours for refill of narcotic 
prescriptions,so please plan ahead.You can either have them 
mailed to your home or pick them up at the clinic located on 
___.We are not allowed to call in or fax narcotic 
prescriptions(oxycontin,oxycodone,percocet) to your pharmacy.In 
addition,we are only allowed to write for pain medications for 
90 days from the date of surgery.

-Follow up:Please Call the office and make an appointment for 2 
weeks after the day of your operation if this has not been done 
already.

-Please call the office if you have a fever>101.5 degrees 
Fahrenheit and/or drainage from your wound.
Physical Therapy:
1)Weight bearing as tolerated.2)Gait,balance training.3)No 
lifting >10 lbs.4)No significant bending/twisting. 
Treatments Frequency:
Keep the incision covered with a dry dressing on until follow up 
appointment. If the incision is draining cover it with a new 
sterile dressing.Once the incision is completely dry (usually 
___ days after the operation) you may take a shower and place a 
new dry dressing on. Do not soak the incision in a bath or 
pool.If the incision starts draining at anytime after surgery, 
do not get the incision wet.Cover it with a sterile 
dressing.Call the office.
 
Followup Instructions:
___

Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
___ line placement
 
History of Present Illness:
___ yo ___ at ___ wks via IVF dating with single IUP who 
presents with 4 weeks of severe emesis, nausea, and diarrhea 
which is at times bloody. She states that she's encountered this 
constellation of symptoms in each of her 3 pregnancies, but this 
is the worst and most severe episode in her history (per patient 
and husband). She states that she has lost 5 lbs, and cannot 
keep anything down without dry-heaving.
 
Past Medical History:
OBSTETRIC HISTORY
___: IVF 39 wks vag delivery - boy healthy
___: 36 wks vag delivery - boy, healthy
___: IVF 39 wks vag delivery
___: 2 first trim SAB's with D&C's

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY
___ - Ovarian hyperstim with hemorrhagic corpus luteum 
requiring
laparoscopy for hemoperitoneum

Unexplained tachycardia - on Atenolol

PAST SURGICAL HISTORY
see above
___ - laparoscopic cholecystectomy
prior knee surgery

GYNECOLOGIC HISTORY
Primary unexplained infertility
no STI's
no abnormal pap tests
2 D&C's in first trimester
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
non-contributory

(on admission)
96.5, 60, 97/63, 16, 100%

CTAB
RRR - no tachy
Abd: soft, NT, ND
Ext: warm, well perfused, no edema
skin: decreased skin turgor

___ WBC-4.7 RBC-2.86 Hgb-9.3 Hct-25.4 MCV-89 Plt-216
___ ___ PTT-35.5 ___ ___ ___ PTT-31.4 ___ ___ Glucose-80 UreaN-8 Creat-0.5 Na-136 K-3.9 Cl-102 
HCO3-25 AnGap-13
___ Calcium-9.1 Phos-3.9 Mg-1.8

___ Glu-95 BUN-5 Cre-0.5 Na-134 K-4.1 Cl-106 HCO3-22
___ ALT-7 AST-10 TBili-0.6 Lip-26 TSH-0.61
___ Albumin-3.2 Calcium-7.7 Phos-3.2 Mg-2.0 Iron-84
___ calTIBC-244 VitB12-305 ___ Ferritn-56 TRF-188

___ Glu-95 BUN-4 Creat-0.4 Na-133 K-3.4 Cl-105 HCO3-22
___ Calcium-7.5 Phos-2.8 Mg-1.8

FECAL CULTURE (Final ___: NO SALMONELLA OR SHIGELLA FOUND

CAMPYLOBACTER CULTURE (Final ___: NO CAMPYLOBACTER FOUND
OVA + PARASITES (Final ___: NO OVA AND PARASITES SEEN
FECAL CULTURE - (Final ___: NO YERSINIA FOUND
FECAL CULTURE - (Final ___: NO E.COLI 0157:H7 FOUND 
CLOSTRIDIUM DIFFICILE TOXIN A & B TEST (Final ___: 
 Feces negative for C.difficile toxin A & B by EIA. 
VIRAL CULTURE (Preliminary): No Virus isolated so far
 
Brief Hospital Course:
___ yo ___ IVF pregnancy admitted at 9w1d weeks with 4 weeks 
of severe emesis, nausea, and diarrhea. She was treated with 
IVFs, antiemetics, and electrolyte repletion. Her nausea was 
improved with Zofran. Given her previous history of hyperemesis 
requiring PICC lines and recurrent symptoms associated with a 5 
pound weight loss, the decision was made to proceed with PICC 
line placement. The PICC line was placed on ___ without 
difficulty. ___ services were arranged and she will continue IV 
fluids and antiemetics at home.
.
In regards to her diarrhea, this continued intermittently during 
this admission. Stool cultures were negative.
.
Ms ___ was noted to be severely anemic with a hematocrit of 
25. This was a normocytic anemia (MCV 89). Iron studies were 
normal and a blood smear showed some abnormal morphology. The 
etiology of her anemia is unclear, possibly related to 
nutritional deficiencies. She also had reported some bloody 
stools prior to admission, therefore, GI losses may also be a 
contributing factor. An outpatient hematology consult may be 
considered.
 
Medications on Admission:
Vaginal Progesterone 100mg q HS
Atenolol (off since pregnancy)
 
Discharge Medications:
1. progesterone 100 mg Suppository Sig: One (1) suppository 
Vaginal at bedtime.  
2. ondansetron HCl (PF) 4 mg/2 mL Solution Sig: Eight (8) mg 
Injection every four (4) hours.
Disp:*42 syringes* Refills:*6*
3. ___ NS & potassium chloride 20 mEq/L Parenteral Solution 
Sig: Two (2) liters Intravenous infuse overnight.
Disp:*14 liters* Refills:*6*
4. M.V.I. Adult ___ mg-mcg-mg-mg Solution Sig: One (1) 
dose Intravenous once a day: please give with IV fluids at 
night.
Disp:*30 solutions* Refills:*2*
5. Outpatient Lab Work
Please do complete Chem-10 twice weekly (M/Th) starting ___
Please fax results to Dr. ___: ___
Office Number: ___
 
Discharge Disposition:
Home With Service
 
Facility:
___
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Hyperemesis Gravidarum
Severe anemia
Diarrhea
 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.
 
Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted for hyperemesis and diarrhea. The diarrhea 
appears to be resolving. The studies we did are still pending, 
the results should be available over the weekend or early next 
week.
 
Followup Instructions:
___

text:
Name:  ___                 Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: PSYCHIATRY
 
Allergies: 
No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions
 
Attending: ___
 
Chief Complaint:
"Ever since ___ my mood has been off and I've been more 
anxious and stressed"
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
none
 
History of Present Illness:
Patient is a ___ y/o female student
at ___ with history of depression, anxiety and 
panic
attacks who was sent in from her school with passive SI and
worsening depression and anxiety.

She reports being a passenger in a minor car accident on ___ 
and
was without injuries but since then has felt sad and more 
anxious
with nearly one panic attack per day.  She reports being the
driver in a MVA in ___ and at that time developed panic 
attacks,
anxiety and depression.  At that time she started seeing a
psychiatrist and therapist and was started on Ativan and Zoloft
and had been doing well socially and academically but this 
latest
episode caused those symptoms to return.  She reports low mood,
poor sleep, concentration, memory and feelings of guilt.  She
describes near daily panic attacks that last ___ mins of
palpitations, sweating, nausea, and SOB.  Ativan only helps
minimally but usually goes away on its own or having someone 
talk
her down. Her school work is beginning to suffer as she cannot
concentrate in class or assignments and this is causing her
anxiety to worsen as she is afraid of losing her good academic
standing.  She does not report having fear of going outside.  
For
the past 3 days she has felt that "things would be better if I
were not alive" and has thought about whether she would survive 
a
fall from her ___ floor apartment.  

She does not report nightmares but has been avoiding cars, 
having
flashbacks to her prior accident and has been "extremely on
edge."  She does not report nightmares. 

She has no history of suicide attempts or self injurious
behavior. She denies symptoms of mania and psychosis.  
 
Past Medical History:
Past psychiatric history:
Diagnoses: Panic attacks, depression, anxiety
Hospitalizations: none
Current treaters:
Psychiatrist: Dr. ___ at ___ 
Counseling
Therapist: ___ at ___ Counseling
Medication trials: Currently on Zoloft and Ativan
SIB: hx of scratching herself with fingernails
Harm to others: denies
Access to weapons: denies
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
Mother with anxiety on unknown meds
Sister with OCD
___ uncle with schizophrenia
___ cousin with schizophrenia and SA
Maternal Grandmother with depression and psychiatric inpatient
admission late in life

 
Physical Exam:
General- NAD
Skin- no rashes or bruises
HEENT- PERRLA, MMM, normal oropharynx
Lungs- CTA bilaterally
CV- RRR, N S1 and S2, no m/r/g
Abdomen- Soft, NT, ND, +BS, no guarding or rebounding
Extremities- No edema, normal tone
Neuro- CN II-XII intact, normal gait, Romberg negative, FTF
intact, Heel to shin intact, ___ strength UE & ___ bilaterally,
normal sensation throughout

Neuropsychiatric Examination:
  *Appearance: Obese Caucasian female appearing state age,
wearing gown, has glasses, sitting on chair looking at cell 
phone
  Behavior: Cooperaative, appropriate, good eye contact
  *Mood and Affect: "Sad," Euthymic, reactive, full range
  *Thought process: Linear, no LOA
  *Thought Content: Passive SI, no HI, AH, VH.  Wanst to feel
normal and get back to baseline
  *Judgment and Insight: Good insight / good judgment
  Cognition:
    *Attention, *orientation, and executive function: ___, +MYOB
    *Memory: ___ registration, ___ after 5mins
    *Fund of knowledge: able to name first and current president
and play by ___
    Calculations: 7q=1.75
    Book/cover: Dont't judge what's on outisde, it's what is ont
he isnide that counts
    Apple/Orange: fruit
    *Speech: normal rate, tone and volume
    *Language: fluent, good vocabulary

 
Pertinent Results:
___ 04:45PM URINE  bnzodzpn-NEG barbitrt-NEG opiates-NEG 
cocaine-NEG amphetmn-NEG mthdone-NEG
___ 04:40PM   GLUCOSE-91 UREA N-13 CREAT-0.7 SODIUM-141 
POTASSIUM-4.1 CHLORIDE-101 TOTAL CO2-23 ANION GAP-21*
___ 04:40PM   WBC-15.1* RBC-5.15 HGB-14.9 HCT-43.8 MCV-85 
MCH-29.0 MCHC-34.1 RDW-13.4
___ 04:40PM   ASA-NEG ETHANOL-NEG ACETMNPHN-NEG 
bnzodzpn-NEG barbitrt-NEG tricyclic-NEG
___ 04:40PM   PLT COUNT-255
___ 04:40PM   NEUTS-75.7* LYMPHS-16.8* MONOS-4.0 EOS-2.9 
BASOS-0.___. Legal: ___
2. Medical: No acute or chronic issues

3. Psychiatric: 
#) ANXIETY
The patient has a reported longstanding history of anxiety 
dating back to early childhood. Her baseline generalized anxiety 
has predisposed her to current distress which is in excess of 
what would be expected following her acute stressors of being 
involved in a recent MVA and stress of work demands at school. 
Since the accident, the patient reports intrusive thoughts 
(without compulsions) revolving around the car accident that 
cause marked anxiety. The patient also reports a history of 
unprovoked panic attacks characterized by SOB, palpitations, 
sweating, lower extremity numbness, and depersonalization that 
have worsened in frequency since her car accident. Zoloft was 
restarted at 100mg rather than her previously prescribed dose of 
200mg to minimize activation side effects as the patient 
reported variable compliance with the medication. Propanolol for 
anxiety as needed was also used with no noted side effects. 
Ativan was discontinued as the patient reported no benefit.

Collateral Information: 
#) OUTPT TEAM - Patients outpatient Psychiatrist, Dr. 
___ therapist, ___, from ___ 
___ were contacted at time of admission in order 
to discuss circumstances of patients hospitalization and to 
obtain relevant history. They shared that the patient had been 
distraught and overwhelmed with school stress as well as coping 
with the retraumatization from the recent MVA. The patient's 
therapist mentioned that the patient has always had baseline 
anxiety but has managed to do very well in school. 

#) HOSPITAL RECORDS - No prior hospitalizations.

4. Social/Milieu: 
#) GROUPS - Patient attended many groups on the unit and was 
interactive with other patients.  

#) FAMILY - The patient's mother, ___, confirmed that the pt 
has a history of anxiety and tends to cope by getting angry with 
family members and then will feel better. ___ noticed that the 
pt is less angry when taking her Zoloft. ___ said that the pt 
has no history of suicide attempt and has never voiced SI to her 
parents. ___ did not believe there was an acute safety concern. 
She also felt that the recent car accident was a likely trigger 
to her current mood instability. 

5. Risk Assessment: 
The patient represents a potential chronic risk of impulsive and 
potentially dangerous behaviors given history of bullying, 
ongoing anxiety, and poor coping strategies. Protective factors 
include that he is currently in good behavioral control, 
medication compliant, future oriented and connected with outpt 
treatment. At this time, the acute risk has been diminished and 
the least restrictive setting for care is the outpatient 
setting.   

6. PROGNOSIS
Good - given lack of h/o self-harm, use of humor as a mature 
defense, motivation for positive change, and willingness to 
engage in care with many positive supports.

 
Medications on Admission:
The Preadmission Medication list is accurate and complete.
1. Lorazepam 0.5 mg PO Q4H:PRN anxiety 
2. Sertraline 200 mg PO DAILY 

 
Discharge Medications:
1. Sertraline 100 mg PO DAILY 
2. Propanolol 20mg PO BID:PRN anxiety
 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Adjustment disorder with anxiety

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
During your admission at ___, you were diagnosed with 
adjustment disorder with anxiety and treated included medication 
with sertraline and propanolol.
Please follow up with all outpatient appointments as listed.
Please continue all medications as directed.
Please avoid abusing alcohol and any drugs--whether prescription 
drugs or illegal drugs--as this can further worsen your medical 
and psychiatric illnesses.
Please contact your outpatient psychiatrist or other providers 
if you have any concerns.
Please call ___ or go to your nearest emergency room if you feel 
unsafe in any way and are unable to immediately reach your 
health care providers.
It was a pleasure to have worked with you and we wish you the 
best of health.
If you need to talk to a ___ Staff Member regarding issues of 
your hospitalization, please call ___

 
Followup Instructions:
___

post-tonsillectomy bleeding
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
none
 
History of Present Illness:
CC: post tonsillectomy bleeding

HPI: ___ female s/p tonsillectomy 5 days ago for chronic
tonsillitis, now with approximately 1 table spoon hemoptysis 
that
started one hour ago spontaneously.  No shortness of breath or
difficulty breathing.  No prior bleeding.  No report of easy
bruising or bleeding.
Of note, her younger brother had post tonsillectomy bleeding
requiring OR cautery at age ___.
 
Past Medical History:
PMH: anxiety
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
NC
 
Physical Exam:
AVSS
NAD, breathing comfortably
___
Face: non traumatic
B/l anterior NC wnl
OC/OP: no trismus.  Left tonsillar fossa healing appropriately
with no blood.  Right side with fresh clot, most of which was
suctioned, except difficulty tolerating clearing of clot in
inferior pole.  No signs of active bleeding or bright red blood.

 
Pertinent Results:
___ 01:25AM   ___ PTT-31.2 ___
___ 01:25AM   PLT COUNT-256
___ 01:25AM   WBC-8.7 RBC-4.59 HGB-13.6 HCT-39.0 MCV-85 
MCH-29.7 MCHC-35.0 RDW-12.4
 
Brief Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the Otolaryngology - Head and Neck 
Surgery service in stable condition on ___ ___ s/p 
tonsillectomy with self-limited bleeding from tonsillar bed. 

ENT: Tonsillar fossa had no active bleeding.
Neuro: Pain was controlled with po pain meds
Cardio: No issues. 
Pulm: No issues; O2 per nasal cannula was weaned.
GI: The patient tolerated advancement of diet to clears with 
>400cc po intake at time of discharge. 
GU: IV fluids were stopped when PO intake was greater than 
400mL.
Heme:  DVT prophylaxis with Heparin 5000 Units SC q 8 hours. 
ID: Antibiotics administered while in hospital.

At time of discharge the patients pain was well controlled, no 
chest pain or shortness or breath, no nausea/vomiting, 
tolerating clear liquid diet, good urine output, ambulating.  
The patient was afebrile, vital signs stable, no bleeding or 
clot in oral cavity.
 
Medications on Admission:
roxicet, amoxicillin, klonopin
 
Discharge Medications:
1. acetaminophen 650 mg/20.3 mL Solution Sig: 1000 (1000) mg PO 
Q6H (every 6 hours) as needed for pain for 1 weeks.  
2. hydromorphone 2 mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO Q3H (every 3 
hours) as needed for pain for 1 weeks.  

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Post-tonsillectomy bleed
 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.
 
Discharge Instructions:
Activity: No strenuous activity for 2 weeks. No heavy lifting 
greater than a carton of milk for 2 weeks.
Diet: Stay on liquid diet tonight. Tomorrow morning may advance 
to soft diet. Stay on soft diet for ___ weeks after discharge.
Meds: You may take 2 more doses of amoxicillin and then stop 
taking it. If you have a sore throat you may use 
over-the-counter chloraseptic spray no more than 4x/day as 
needed.
 
Followup Instructions:
___

Control of tonsil bleed 
Surgeon: ___
___

 
History of Present Illness:
The patient is a ___ female who
underwent a bilateral tonsillectomy on ___ for
chronic tonsillitis.  Upon reviewing her operative report,
there was no unexpected finding, nor was there any
significant bleeding.  The pathology report from the surgery
is not available for review at this time.  She then developed
bleeding predominantly from the left tonsil five days after
her surgery, initially noting a tablespoon of blood.  She was
seen initially in our emergency room and admitted with no
active bleeding.  She did go home the following day but then
returned this evening with further bleeding.  In the
emergency room, she had blood-tinged saliva but did not have
any measurable blood or active bleeding seen.

anxiety, chronic tonsillitis
 
Social History:

___

bleeding.

___ 05:00PM   PLT COUNT-___onsults: Pain service, Psychiatry

The patient was admitted to the Otolaryngology - Head and Neck 
Surgery service in stable condition on ___, s/p emergent 
examination under anesthesia and
control of left tonsillar postoperative bleeding.  Please see 
dictated op note for details.  Hospital course described below 
by system. 

ENT: Bilateral tonsillar fossa remained dry with no active 
bleeding or clot throughout the ___ hospital stay. 
Neck had no swelling.

Neuro: Pain was controlled with IV and then po pain meds. Pain 
service was consulted due to poorly controlled pain after 
multiple medications tried. Improved pain on PCA and then po 
dilaudid.
Psych: Patient with hx anxiety. Had panic attack in pre-op area. 
Seen by psychiatry who recommended continuing her home Klonopin 
and recommended she stop using marijuana.
Cardio: No issues. 
Pulm: No issues; O2 per nasal cannula was weaned.
GI: The patient tolerated advancement of diet to mechanical soft 
with >400cc po intake at time of discharge. Nausea controlled 
with prn zofran.
GU: IV fluids were stopped when PO intake was greater than 
400mL.
ID: Antibiotics administered perioperatively

At time of discharge the patients pain was well controlled, no 
chest pain or shortness or breath, no nausea/vomiting, 
tolerating full soft diet, good urine output, ambulating.  The 
patient was afebrile, vital signs stable, tonsillar fossa dry 
bilaterally.

Klonopin 2mg po daily prn anxiety

Disp:*15 Tablet, Rapid Dissolve(s)* Refills:*0*
6. Lidocaine Viscous 2 % Solution Sig: Twenty (20) mL Mucous 
membrane three times a day as needed for throat pain for 7 days.
Disp:*400 mL* Refills:*0*

Home

Post-tonsillectomy bleeding

___ 10:35PM   ___ PTT-26.8 ___

IMAGING  
___ CT abd/pelvis: 1. Non-displaced left sacral ala fracture 
and extending into the left ilium with pubic ramus fractures. 2. 
Non-displaced left L5 transverse process fracture. 3. No 
evidence of pelvic hematoma or active extravasation.  

 
Brief Hospital Course:
She was admitted to the Trauma Service. Orthopedics was 
consulted for her pelvic fractures; these were managed non 
operatively. She was evaluated by Physical therapy and may be 
weight bearing as tolerated. She was started on subcutaneous 
Heparin for DVT prophylaxis.  Her home medications were 
restarted and she is tolerating a regular diet. She is receiving 
Dilaudid and Tylenol prn for pain control which she reports as 
adequate. It is being recommended that she go to rehab following 
her acute hospital stay.
 
Medications on Admission:
insulin 
 
Discharge Medications:

hours as needed for pain.

times a day).

hours) as needed for pain.

Ophthalmic QHS (once a day (at bedtime)): Apply to both eyes.  
5. Heparin (Porcine) 5,000 unit/mL Solution Sig: One (1) ML 
Injection TID (3 times a day).  
6. Milk of Magnesia 800 mg/5 mL Suspension Sig: Thirty (30) ML's 
PO twice a day as needed for constipation.  
7. Senna 8.6 mg Tablet Sig: Two (2) Tablet PO BID (2 times a 
day) as needed for constipation.  
8. Insulin Glargine 100 unit/mL Solution Sig: ___ (25) 
Units Subcutaneous at bedtime.  
9. Humalog 100 unit/mL Solution Sig: One (1) Dose Subcutaneous 
four times a day as needed for per sliding scale: See Attached 
sliding scale.  

 
Discharge Disposition:
Extended Care
 
Facility:
___
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
s/p Fall
Left sacral ala fracture/left ileum fracture (non-displaced)
Left L5 transverse process fracture (non-displaced)
 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive
Activity Status: Ambulatory - requires assistance or aid (walker 
or cane)
 
Discharge Instructions:
You were hospitlized following a fall where you sustained 
fractures of your pelvis. Your injuries did not require surgical 
repair. You are being recommeded to go to a rehabilitation 
facility to improve your walking and strength. You may weight 
bear as tolerated on both lower extremeties.

History of Present Illness:
Mrs ___ is a pleasant ___ y/o F w/hx of GERD, breast cancer, 
duodenal adenoma dx'd with EGD/bx in ___. She presents today 
for repeat EGD/resection.  EGD was performed with resection of 
the polyp and was uncomplicated.  She is admitted for post 
procedure monitoring. 

On the floor, she has no complaints and states that she feels 
fine.  No n/v, No pain.  Had sips of water without difficulty 
however has been hesitant to have anything else to drink as she 
is concerned it may cause discomfort.

Review of systems:
(+) Per HPI
(-) Denies fever, chills, night sweats, recent weight loss or 
gain. Denies headache, sinus tenderness, rhinorrhea or 
congestion. Denies cough, shortness of breath. Denies chest pain 
or tightness, palpitations. Denies nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, 
constipation or abdominal pain. No recent change in bowel or 
bladder habits. No dysuria. Denies arthralgias or myalgias. 10 
pt ros otherwise negative.

OSTEOPOROSIS 
GASTROESOPHAGEAL REFLUX 
BREAST CANCER 
RHEUMATOID ARTHRITIS 
ASTHMA
PRE DIABETES
"LEAKY VALVE"

___

OSTEOPOROSIS

Sister HEART PROBLEM

Admission exam
Vitals: 97.7 PO94 / 58 L ___
Constitutional: Alert, oriented, no acute distress
EYES: Sclera anicteric,  EOMI, PERRL
ENMT: MMM, oropharynx clear, normal hearing, normal nares
Neck: Supple, JVP not elevated, no LAD
CV: Regular rate and rhythm, normal S1 + S2, no murmurs, rubs, 
gallops
Respiratory: Clear to auscultation bilaterally, no wheezes, 
rales, rhonchi
GI: Soft, non-tender, non-distended, bowel sounds present, no 
organomegaly, no rebound or guarding
GU: No foley
EXT: Warm, well perfused, no CCE
NEURO: aaox3 CNII-XII and strength grossly intact 
SKIN: no rashes or lesions

Discharge exam
Vitals: AF 94-100/58-62 ___ 96% on RA
GENERAL: Alert and in no apparent distress
EYES: Anicteric, pupils equally round, strabismus+
ENT: Ears and nose without visible erythema, masses, or trauma.  
Oropharynx without visible lesion, erythema or exudate; MMMs
CV: Heart regular, no murmur
RESP: Lungs clear to auscultation with good air movement 
bilaterally.  Breathing is non-labored
GI: Abdomen soft, non-distended, non-tender to palpation.  Bowel 
sounds present.  No HSM
MSK/EXTR: no joint erythema, wwp, no edema
SKIN: No rashes or ulcerations noted
NEURO: grossly intact
PSYCH: pleasant, appropriate affect
 
Pertinent Results:
Labs unremarkable

EGD

Normal mucosa in the esophagus
Normal mucosa in the stomach
Polyp in the second part of the duodenum (mucosal resection as 
described above)
Otherwise normal EGD to third part of the duodenum
 
Brief Hospital Course:
Pleasant ___ yo F with hx breast ca in remission, GERD, presents 
for monitoring following EGD for resection of duodenal adenoma. 
She tolerated diet advancement without any pain and had no signs 
of bleeding. She was discharged in the afternoon the day after 
the procedure with plans to follow-up with Dr. ___ 
for path and follow-up. She was otherwise continued on her home 
meds

 
Medications on Admission:
The Preadmission Medication list is accurate and complete.
1. Lansoprazole Oral Disintegrating Tab 30 mg PO DAILY 
2. Methotrexate 10 mg PO QFRI 
3. Fluticasone-Salmeterol Diskus (250/50)  1 INH IH BID 
4. Tiotropium Bromide 1 CAP IH DAILY 
5. FoLIC Acid 2 mg mg PO DAILY 
6. Multivitamins 1 TAB PO DAILY 
7. Denosumab (Prolia) 60 mg SC 2X/YR 

 
Discharge Medications:

7.  Tiotropium Bromide 1 CAP IH DAILY

Home

Duodenal polyp

Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

You were admitted to the hospital for observation after your 
polyp removal. There were no signs of bleeding or other 
complications from the procedure. Your pathology results will be 
sent to you and your referring doctor as soon as they are 
available. Please call Dr. ___ ___ in 10 
days if you have not received notification. You can schedule

reviewed with you.

History of Present Illness:
Ms ___ is a healthy ___ year old woman who presents from
home complaining of 4 days of epigastric pain and nausea with
bilious vomiting, subjective fevers and chills.  Thought pain 
was
indigestion and constipation, so tried laxatives and ibuprofen
without relief.  Had pain worse but similar one and half months
ago that lasted for 5 days, seen at OSH and treated as posible
gastritis, no ultrasound obtained at time.  Currently with

___

Eos-1.9 Baso-0.2
___ 12:02AM BLOOD ___ PTT-28.5 ___
___ 12:02AM BLOOD Glucose-89 UreaN-17 Creat-1.1 Na-138 
K-3.6 Cl-100 HCO3-29 AnGap-13
___ 07:00AM BLOOD Glucose-92 UreaN-8 Creat-0.9 Na-138 K-4.2 
Cl-102 HCO3-30 AnGap-10
___ 12:02AM BLOOD ALT-24 AST-21 AlkPhos-68 TotBili-0.9
___ 07:00AM BLOOD ALT-24 AST-21 AlkPhos-65 TotBili-0.7
___ 07:00AM BLOOD Calcium-8.8 Phos-3.2 Mg-2.1
 
Brief Hospital Course:
Patient seen in emergency department by surgical team.  Based on 
clinical history, physical exam and ultrasound findings it was 
determined that she had acute on chronic cholecystitis.  Her WBC 
was not elevated (7.4) and she remained afebrile.

Imaging:
___ RUQ U/S: multiple stones and sludge in the gallbladder, with 
a thick, edematous gallbladder wall and suggestion of small 
pericholecystic fluid. no bil dil.  cbd normal in caliber. PV 
patent. findings are concerning for cholecystitis.

The patient was admitted and treated with IV cipro and IV 
flagyl.  She was fluid resuscitated and initially made NPO.  Her 
pain quicly improved and her diet was slowly advanced.  By the 
time of discharge her pain was only induced with deep palpation 
and was very mild. She had no nausea or vomiting.  She was 
tolerating regular (low fat) diet.  She will be discharged home 
with 2 weeks of PO antibiotics and will follow up with Dr. 
___ in clinic for interval cholecystectomy.
 
Medications on Admission:
Ibuprofen 800 prn
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Cipro 500 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO twice a day for 2 
weeks.
Disp:*28 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
2. Flagyl 500 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO three times a day 
for 2 weeks.
Disp:*42 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
acute on chronic cholecystitis
 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.
 
Discharge Instructions:
Call if fever >101.  Call if recurrent symptoms.  Call with any 
questions or concerns.  

You were diagnosed with acute on chronic cholecystitis and were 
treated with IV antibiotics.  You will be discharged with a 2 
week course of antibiotics by mouth and should follow up in 
clinic at that time.
 
Followup Instructions:
___

text:
Name:  ___                Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: SURGERY
 
Allergies: 
Patient recorded as having No Known Allergies to Drugs
 
Attending: ___
 
Chief Complaint:
Chronic cholecystitis
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
___: Lap chole
 
History of Present Illness:
Ms ___ is a healthy ___ year old woman who presents from
home for cholecystectomy have having multiple episodes of 
epigastric pain and nausea with bilious vomiting, subjective 
fevers and chills.  Thought pain 
was indigestion and constipation, so tried laxatives and 
ibuprofen
without relief.  She turned out to have had multiple episodes vs 
chronic cholecystitis.
 
Past Medical History:
PMH: none
PSH: none

 
Social History:
___
Family History:
No cancer or stroke or heart disease. Brother with gallstones
 
Physical Exam:
97.9 117 135/90 16 100%RA 
pleasant woman in NAD, no jaundice
no scleral icterus, MMM
CTAB
tachycardic
soft, ND, NT, no ___
sign, no masses, no hepatomegaly
no c/c/e

 
Brief Hospital Course:
The patient was taken to the OR for a lap chole. Please see 
separately dictated operative note by Dr. ___ details of 
this procedure.  Postoperatively, pt was extubated and 
transferred to the PACU, where she remained afebrile and 
hemodynamically stable.  She was transferred to the floor later 
that day.
By the day of discharge, she was ambulating independently, 
voiding good amounts of urine, and tolerating a regular diet 
with no c/o nausea or vomiting. Her abdomen was soft and 
nondistended, with only appropriate incisional tenderness.  Her 
surgical wound was clean, dry, and intact with no signs of 
infection noted.  Her pain was well-controlled on PO pain 
medication, and she expressed her readiness to return home.

 
Medications on Admission:
None
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Oxycodone 5 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO Q4H (every 4 
hours) as needed for PAIN.  
 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Chronic cholecystitis
 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.
 
Discharge Instructions:
Please resume your pre-hospital medications.  You should 
follow-up with your primary care physician regarding new 
prescriptions and refills.
Please do not drive or drink alcohol while taking pain 
medication as this combination may make you drowsy.
In order to avoid constipation, be sure to take a stool softener 
(Docusate) and/or a laxative if you are taking narcotic pain 
medication. 
Please leave the Steri-strips in place on your incision (if you 
have any) and allow them to fall off on their own.  If they have 
not fallen off in ___ days, you may remove them yourself. 
Avoid heavy-lifting (no more than 15 lbs) for several weeks in 
order to prevent incisional hernia.
You may shower right away but please do not swim or soak in a 
tub for at least 2 weeks.  After you are done showering, just 
pat your incision dry.  If it is draining clear fluid, you can 
cover it with a dry dressing (such as gauze).
Call your surgeons office or go to the Emergency Room if you 
have fever (temperature greater than 100.5), chills, nausea, 
vomiting, abdominal pain, or if you notice signs of wound 
infection (redness, tenderness, or drainage from the incision).  
Please also call or go to the Emergency Room if you have any 
other concerns.

 
Followup Instructions:
___

K-4.0 Cl-102 HCO3-27 AnGap-14
___ 01:20PM BLOOD Glucose-137* UreaN-13 Creat-1.2 Na-139 
K-4.9 Cl-101 HCO3-27 AnGap-16
___ 01:20PM BLOOD ALT-12 AST-37 AlkPhos-85 TotBili-0.8

___:  cat scan of abdomen and pelvis:

Uncomplicated acute appendicitis. 
  

 
Brief Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the hospital with right lower 
quadrant pain.  Upon admission, he was made NPO, given 
intravenous fluids, and underwent imaging.  On cat scan of the 
abdomen he was reported to have a dilated appendix measuring up 
to 15 mm with a hyperemic wall.  There was periappendiceal fat 
stranding, but no evidence of perforation.  Because of this, he 
was taken to the operating room where he underwent a 
laparoscopic appendectomy.  The operative course was stable with 
minimal blood loss.  The patient was extubated after the 
procedure and monitored in the recovery room.

His post-operative course has been stable.  He was transitioned 
from intravenous analgesia to oral agents for pain management.  
His vital signs have been stable and he has been afebrile.  He 
has been tolerating a regular diet.  He was discharged home on 
POD #1 in stable condition.  A follow-up appointment was made 
with the acute care service.   
 
Medications on Admission:
none
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Acetaminophen 650 mg PO Q6H pain 
2. Docusate Sodium 100 mg PO BID 
3. OxycoDONE (Immediate Release)  ___ mg PO Q4H:PRN pain 
RX *oxycodone 5 mg ___ tablet(s) by mouth every four (4) hours 
Disp #*25 Tablet Refills:*0

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
acute appendicitis

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted to the hospital with rigith lower quadrant 
pain.  You underwent a cat scan of the abdomen and you were 
found to have appendicitis.  You were taken to the operating 
room to have your appendix removed.  You are now preparing for 
discharge home with the following instructions:

 You were admitted to the hospital with acute appendicitis. You 
were taken to the operating room and had your appendix removed 
laparoscopically.  You tolerated the procedure well and are now 
being discharged home with the following instructions:
Please follow up at the appointment in clinic listed below. We 
also generally recommend that patients follow up with their 
primary care provider after having surgery. We have scheduled an 
appointment for you listed below.
ACTIVITY:
 
Do not drive until you have stopped taking pain medicine and 
feel you could respond in an emergency.
You may climb stairs. 
You may go outside, but avoid traveling long distances until you 
see your surgeon at your next visit.
Don't lift more than ___ lbs for ___ weeks. (This is about the 
weight of a briefcase or a bag of groceries.) This applies to 
lifting children, but they may sit on your lap.
You may start some light exercise when you feel comfortable.
You will need to stay out of bathtubs or swimming pools for a 
time while your incision is healing. Ask your doctor when you 
can resume tub baths or swimming.
 
HOW YOU MAY FEEL: 
You may feel weak or "washed out" a couple weeks. You might want 
to nap often. Simple tasks may exhaust you.
You may have a sore throat because of a tube that was in your 
throat during surgery.
You could have a poor appetite for a couple days. Food may seem 
unappealing.
All of these feelings and reactions are normal and should go 
away in a short time.  If they do not, tell your surgeon.
 
YOUR INCISION:
Tomorrow you may shower and remove the gauzes over your 
incisions. Under these dressings you have small plastic bandages 
called steristrips. Do not remove steri-strips for 2 weeks. 
(These are the thin paper strips that might be on your 
incision.) But if they fall off before that that's okay.
Your incisions may be slightly red around the stitches. This is 
normal.
You may gently wash away dried material around your incision.
Avoid direct sun exposure to the incision area.
Do not use any ointments on the incision unless you were told 
otherwise.
You may see a small amount of clear or light red fluid staining 
your dressing or clothes. If the staining is severe, please call 
your surgeon.
You may shower. As noted above, ask your doctor when you may 
resume tub baths or swimming.
 
YOUR BOWELS:
Constipation is a common side effect of narcotic pain 
medicaitons. If needed, you may take a stool softener (such as 
Colace, one capsule) or gentle laxative (such as milk of 
magnesia, 1 tbs) twice a day. You can get both of these 
medicines without a prescription.
If you go 48 hours without a bowel movement, or have pain moving 
the bowels, call your surgeon. 
 
PAIN MANAGEMENT:
It is normal to feel some discomfort/pain following abdominal 
surgery. This pain is often described as "soreness". 
Your pain should get better day by day. If you find the pain is 
getting worse instead of better, please contact your surgeon.
You will receive a prescription for pain medicine to take by 
mouth. It is important to take this medicine as directed. Do not 
take it more frequently than prescribed. Do not take more 
medicine at one time than prescribed. Do not drink alcohol or 
drive while taking narcotic pain medication.
Your pain medicine will work better if you take it before your 
pain gets too severe.
Talk with your surgeon about how long you will need to take 
prescription pain medicine. Please don't take any other pain 
medicine, including non-prescription pain medicine, unless your 
surgeon has said its okay.
If you are experiencing no pain, it is okay to skip a dose of 
pain medicine.
Remember to use your "cough pillow" for splinting when you cough 
or when you are doing your deep breathing exercises.
If you experience any of the following, please contact your 
surgeon:
- sharp pain or any severe pain that lasts several hours
- pain that is getting worse over time
- pain accompanied by fever of more than 101
- a drastic change in nature or quality of your pain
 
MEDICATIONS:
Take all the medicines you were on before the operation just as 
you did before, unless you have been told differently.
If you have any questions about what medicine to take or not to 
take, please call your surgeon.
 
DANGER SIGNS:
Please call your surgeon if you develop:
- worsening abdominal pain
- sharp or severe pain that lasts several hours
- temperature of 101 degrees or higher
- severe diarrhea
- vomiting
- redness around the incision that is spreading
- increased swelling around the incision
- excessive bruising around the incision
- cloudy fluid coming from the wound
- bright red blood or foul smelling discharge coming from the 
wound
- an increase in drainage from the wound
 
 
Followup Instructions:
___

believes you are ready to be discharged home.

ultrasound. This is likely benign, but you will need a follow-up 
pelvic ultrasound in ___ weeks for further assessment.

concerns.

text:
Name:  ___                   Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: OBSTETRICS/GYNECOLOGY
 
Allergies: 
No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
induction of labor for chronic hypertension
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
low transverse cesarean section
 
History of Present Illness:
Pt presents today for induction of labor at 37w1d due to Chronic 
HTN and non- compliance with taking her medication. Also, being 
induced for chronic c/o DFM with continued non-reactive 
tracings. Pt has been followed weekly with BPP which have all 
been ___. Today pt reports no c/o uc's, no bleeding, no rom. Pt 
accompanied by her friend.
 
Past Medical History:
PMH: 
-Chronic HTN on nifedipine 30mg ER -Hypothyroidism on 250mg qd 
at hs
-2 intramural fibroids
-Obesity
-Hx depression suicide attempt at ___ -SC trait partner not 
screened
- ___ pap
PSH:
-LEEP ___
-TAB first trimester x 2
OB HX: G6P2 TAB 2,SAB1 EDC ___ 41w1d NSVD 7lbs14oz male ___
-___ 40w NSVD 8lbs10oz female ___
-TAB ___, TAB in ___, TAB ___
Labs: O+/RI/Hbsag nr/RPR nr/ HIV nr/ SC trait positive
NIPT low risk male
-Fetal survey low lying placenta that resolved
-Followed by ___ closely for chronic htn and c/o chronic DFM
-1 baby asa qd
- Nifedipine ER 30mg qd
-BPPs weeky as had persistent non-
reactive NSTs

 
Social History:
___
Family History:
non-contributory
 
Physical Exam:
VS: Afebrile, VSS 
Neuro/Psych: NAD, Oriented x3, Affect Normal 
Heart: RRR
Lungs: CTA b/l
Abdomen: soft, appropriately tender, fundus firm, incision c/d/i
Pelvis: minimal bleeding 
Extremities: warm and well perfused, no calf tenderness, no 
edema 
 
Brief Hospital Course:
On ___, Ms. ___ was admitted for induction of labor for 
chronic hypertension. She subsequently had persistent category 2 
fetal heart tracing as well as severe range blood pressures 
requiring an additional IV labetalol in addition to Nifedipine 
CR. She then underwent a low transverse cesarean section. 

She was started on magnesium sulfate immediately post partum for 
a planned total of 24 hours. However, at approximately 19 hours 
on magnesium, she became hypoxic to 85% on RA, improved to 93% 
on 4L NC. She had an EKG which showed sinus tachycardia, CXR 
which showed small pleural effusions, atelectasis, negative CTA, 
and a BNP within normal limits. On PPD#1 she was weaned to room 
air but still c/o intermittent SOB when supine. On PPD#2 she 
desaturated again to 86-91% while sleeping, which responded to 
1L NC at 95%. Later that day she was triggered for chest pain, 
BP 170/109, HR 140. She was given nifedipine 10mg which 
normalized her BP to the 120s. For her anti-hypertensive regimen 
she was started on Labetalol 200 TID. She had a repeat EKG which 
again demonstrated sinus tachycardia, CXR with persistent 
atelectasis. Repeat CBC, chem-10, BNP were stable; troponins 
were negative. PIH labs were also within normal limits. 
Cardiology was consulted who recommended continuation of 
labetalol and non-urgent echo. The echocardiogram showed mild 
symmetric LVH; normal global biventricular systolic function; 
Mild mitral regurgitation; Trivial posterior pericardial 
effusion versus fat pad. On PPD#3 she was noted to have a ___ 
HA, with dizziness upon standing, hypertensive to 160s/100s, and 
tachycardic to 111. Her HA improved with ibuprofen, Tylenol, 
oxycodone, reglan, and Ativan. Her BP and HR also improved with 
scheduled labetalol. Orthostatics obtained were negative. 

On PPD#1 she was also started on ampicillin, gentamicin, and 
clindamycin for presumed endometritis after becoming febrile. 
This was continued for 24 hours after her first afebrile 
temperature. She remained afebrile throughout the remainder of 
her postpartum course. 

For her history of hypothyroidism she was continued on levoxyl 
200mcg. She was also started on prophylactic Lovenox BID due to 
increased BMI. 

By postpartum day 4, she was tolerating a regular diet, 
ambulating independently, and pain was controlled with oral 
medications. She was afebrile with stable vital signs. She was 
then discharged home in stable condition with postpartum 
outpatient follow-up scheduled.

 
Medications on Admission:
Nifedipine CR 30mg daily
Pepcid 20mg po BID
Zofran 4mg ODT q6hours prn for nausea
PNV
 
 
Discharge Medications:
1.  Acetaminophen ___ mg PO Q4H:PRN Mild Pain  
2.  Ibuprofen 600 mg PO Q6H:PRN Moderate Pain 
RX *ibuprofen 600 mg 1 tablet(s) by mouth 3 times a day Disp 
#*60 Tablet Refills:*3 
3.  Labetalol 300 mg PO Q8H 
RX *labetalol 300 mg 1 tablet(s) by mouth 3 times a day Disp 
#*90 Tablet Refills:*2 
4.  Levothyroxine Sodium 200 mcg PO DAILY 
RX *levothyroxine [Levo-T] 200 mcg 1 tablet(s) by mouth daily 
Disp #*30 Tablet Refills:*11 
5.  OxyCODONE (Immediate Release) ___ mg PO Q4H:PRN Moderate to 
Severe Pain 
RX *oxycodone 5 mg 1 tablet(s) by mouth every 4 hours Disp #*20 
Tablet Refills:*0 
6.  Ranitidine 150 mg PO BID 
RX *ranitidine HCl [Acid Control (ranitidine)] 150 mg 1 
tablet(s) by mouth twice a day Disp #*60 Tablet Refills:*0 

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home With Service
 
Facility:
___
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
cesarean section
Chronic Hypertension
superimposed preeclampsia
Atalectasis
sinus tachycardia
post operative anemia

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
***
Per Cards:
- for mild mitral regurgitation, recommend f/u ECHO every ___ 
years
- LVH likely ___ hypertension, should maintain antihypertensive 
regimen
***
 
Followup Instructions:
___

Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ was admitted to the gynecology service for vaginal 
bleeding resulting in acute blood loss anemia in the setting of 
known fibroid uterus. Her HCT on arrival to the ED was 18.3. She 
received 1 unit of packed red blood cells and post-transfusion 
HCT was 20.2. She then received another 1 unit of packed red 
blood cells. Her post-transfusion HCT was 21.9. She was then 
admitted to the gynecology service for further management of her 
bleeding. She was started on Provera and pad counts were 
monitored. On HD#2, her AM HCT was 21. Patient remained 
clinically stable and no further blood transfusions were 
required. 

By hospital day #2, her vaginal bleeding had improved and her 
HCT remained stable.  She was then discharged home in stable 
condition with a 30-day course of Provera and outpatient 
follow-up scheduled.

 
Medications on Admission:
none
 
Discharge Medications:
1.  MedroxyPROGESTERone Acetate 10 mg PO BID 
RX *medroxyprogesterone 10 mg 1 tablet(s) by mouth twice a day 
Disp #*60 Tablet Refills:*0 

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
vaginal bleeding in setting of known fibroid uterus 

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___,

You were admitted to the gynecology service for vaginal bleeding 
in the setting of known uterine fibroids. Your bleeding has 
improved and the team believes you are ready to be discharged 
home. Please continue to take Provera for 30 days. Please call 
Dr. ___ office with any questions or concerns. 
Please follow the instructions below.

Call your doctor for:
* fever > 100.4F
* severe abdominal pain
* difficulty urinating
* vaginal bleeding requiring >1 pad/hr
* abnormal vaginal discharge
* redness or drainage from incision
* nausea/vomiting where you are unable to keep down fluids/food 
or your medication

 
Followup Instructions:
___

text:
Name:  ___                  Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: NEUROSURGERY
 
Allergies: 
latex
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
Neck pain
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
C3-C6 laminectomy with neuromonitoring on ___

 
History of Present Illness:
Ms. ___ is a ___ woman.  Patient has a C 
spine MRI that revealed 4 levels of cord compression, some of 
which are quite severe, especially C5-C6. Patient is able to 
ambulate independently but she does describe somemyelopathic 
features of trouble using her hands, more frequent urination, 
particularly at night and difficulty with stiffness with using 
her legs. Patient was admitted for an elective decompressive 
laminectomy over multiple levels, C3 through C6. 
 
Past Medical History:
Hypothyroid; s/p thyroidectomy in ___ arthritis; gout; LBP
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
NC
 
Physical Exam:
PHYSICAL EXAMINATION ON ADMISSION:
Alert and oriented x3. CN II-XII grossly intact.
Left: Delt 5-, Bi 5-. Tri 4+. Right: Delt 4, Bi 4+, Tri 4+. 
BLE: IP 5-, otherwise full.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION ON DISCHARGE:
a&ox3
Motor: ___ throughout with encouragement
Incision: sutures, c/d/i, blister of L shoulder

 
Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ was taken to the operating room on the day of 
admission and underwent a C3-C6 cervical laminectomy. She 
tolerated the procedure well and was extubated in the operating 
room. She was then transferred to the PACU for recovery. 

On ___, Ms. ___ was complaing of bilteral finger pain. 
Her strength remained close to full when encouraged.  Physical 
therapy was ordered due to patient concerns. 

On ___ Patient remained stable. Awaiting recommendations from 
___. 

On ___ Patient reamined stable. She is tolerating an advanced 
diet. Her pain is well controlled. ___ worked with the patient 
and recommended one more day of ___.

On ___, exam improved. She was evaluated by ___ and rehab was 
recommended. Magnesium citrate was ordered to help with a bowel 
movement.

On ___, the patient was discharged in stable and improved 
condition to her rehab facility.
 
Medications on Admission:
Levothyroid ___ mcg daily; Acetaminophen PRN; Multivitamin daily

 
Discharge Medications:
1. Acetaminophen 325-650 mg PO Q6H:PRN pain 
2. Diazepam 5 mg PO Q8H:PRN muscle spasm 
3. Docusate Sodium 100 mg PO BID 
4. Levothyroxine Sodium 112 mcg PO DAILY 
5. OxycoDONE (Immediate Release)  ___ mg PO Q4H:PRN pain 
6. Sarna Lotion 1 Appl TP TID:PRN itchy back 
7. Senna 1 TAB PO BID:PRN constipation 

 
Discharge Disposition:
Extended Care
 
Facility:
___
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Cervical Spinal Stenosis

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
POST-OP INSTRUCTIONS:
-Your large dressing may be removed the second day after 
surgery.
-You have sutures, keep your wound clean and dry until they are 
removed. 
-No tub baths or pool swimming for two weeks from your date of 
surgery.
-Do not smoke.
-No pulling up, lifting more than 10 lbs., or excessive bending 
or twisting.
-Limit your use of stairs to ___ times per day.
-Have a friend or family member check your incision daily for 
signs of infection.
-Take your pain medication as instructed; you may find it best 
if taken in the morning when you wake-up for morning stiffness, 
and before bed for sleeping discomfort. Pain medication should 
be used as needed when you have pain. You do not need to take it 
if you do not have pain.
-Do not take any anti-inflammatory medications such as Motrin, 
Advil, Aspirin, and Ibuprofen etc. for two weeks.
-Increase your intake of fluids and fiber, as pain medicine 
(narcotics) can cause constipation. We recommend taking an over 
the counter stool softener, such as Docusate (Colace) while 
taking narcotic pain medication.
-Clearance to drive and return to work will be addressed at your 
post-operative office visit.

CALL YOUR SURGEON IMMEDIATELY IF YOU EXPERIENCE ANY OF THE

Pain that is continually increasing or not relieved by pain 
medicine.

tenderness, and drainage.

Loss of control of bowel or bladder functioning

History of Present Illness:
Ms. ___ is a ___ woman. Patient has a C
spine MRI that revealed 4 levels of cord compression, some of
which are quite severe, especially C5-C6. Patient is able to
ambulate independently but she does describe somemyelopathic
features of trouble using her hands, more frequent urination,
particularly at night and difficulty with stiffness with using
her legs. Patient was admitted for an elective decompressive
laminectomy over multiple levels, C3 through C6.
Past Medical History:
Hypothyroid; s/p thyroidectomy in ___ arthritis; gout; LBP
Social History:
___
Family History:
NC
Physical Exam:
PHYSICAL EXAMINATION ON ADMISSION:
Alert and oriented x3. CN II-XII grossly intact.
Left: Delt 5-, Bi 5-. Tri 4+. Right: Delt 4, Bi 4+, Tri 4+.
BLE: IP 5-, otherwise full.
PHYSICAL EXAMINATION ON DISCHARGE:
a&ox3
Motor: ___ throughout with encouragement
Incision: sutures, c/d/i, blister of L shoulder
Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ was taken to the operating room on the day of
admission and underwent a C3-C6 cervical laminectomy. She
tolerated the procedure well and was extubated in the operating
room. She was then transferred to the PACU for recovery.
On ___, Ms. ___ was complaing of bilteral finger pain.
Her strength remained close to full when encouraged. Physical
therapy was ordered due to patient concerns.
On ___ Patient remained stable. Awaiting recommendations from
___.
On ___ Patient reamined stable. She is tolerating an advanced
diet. Her pain is well controlled. ___ worked with the patient
and recommended one more day of ___.
On ___, exam improved. She was evaluated by ___ and rehab was
recommended. Magnesium citrate was ordered to help with a bowel
movement.
On ___, the patient was discharged in stable and improved
condition to her rehab facility.
Medications on Admission:
Levothyroid ___ mcg daily; Acetaminophen PRN; Multivitamin daily
Discharge Medications:
1. Acetaminophen 325-650 mg PO Q6H:PRN pain
2. Diazepam 5 mg PO Q8H:PRN muscle spasm
3. Docusate Sodium 100 mg PO BID
4. Levothyroxine Sodium 112 mcg PO DAILY
5. OxycoDONE (Immediate Release) ___ mg PO Q4H:PRN pain
6. Sarna Lotion 1 Appl TP TID:PRN itchy back
7. Senna 1 TAB PO BID:PRN constipation
Discharge Disposition:
Extended Care
Facility:
___
Discharge Diagnosis:
Cervical Spinal Stenosis
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.
Discharge Instructions:
POST-OP INSTRUCTIONS:
-Your large dressing may be removed the second day after
surgery.
-You have sutures, keep your wound clean and dry until they are
removed.
-No tub baths or pool swimming for two weeks from your date of
surgery.
-Do not smoke.
-No pulling up, lifting more than 10 lbs., or excessive bending
or twisting.
-Limit your use of stairs to ___ times per day.
-Have a friend or family member check your incision daily for
signs of infection.
-Take your pain medication as instructed; you may find it best
if taken in the morning when you wake-up for morning stiffness,
and before bed for sleeping discomfort. Pain medication should
be used as needed when you have pain. You do not need to take it
if you do not have pain.
-Do not take any anti-inflammatory medications such as Motrin,
Advil, Aspirin, and Ibuprofen etc. for two weeks.
-Increase your intake of fluids and fiber, as pain medicine
(narcotics) can cause constipation. We recommend taking an over
the counter stool softener, such as Docusate (Colace) while
taking narcotic pain medication.
-Clearance to drive and return to work will be addressed at your
post-operative office visit.
CALL YOUR SURGEON IMMEDIATELY IF YOU EXPERIENCE ANY OF THE
FOLLOWING:
Pain that is continually increasing or not relieved by pain
medicine.
Any weakness, numbness, tingling in your extremities.
Any signs of infection at the wound site: redness, swelling,
tenderness, and drainage.
Fever greater than or equal to 101.5° F.
Loss of control of bowel or bladder functioning

Name:  ___                   Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: SURGERY
 
Allergies: 
No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
___ with abdominal pain and 20*17cm mass arising from left lobe 
of the liver
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
None. Will go home and follow up for planned resection of mass 
with Dr. ___. 
 
History of Present Illness:
___ year-old healthy male presenting with 12 hours of stabbing
abdominal pain around his umbilicus, not associated with any
other symptoms. He has never had a similar pain before. 

He was seen in an OSH, where Hct was 46 and US showed a large
liver mass. CT abd showed a 20*17 cm mass arising from the left
lobe of the liver with areas of necrosis vs fat. He was
transferred to ___ for further care. 

On admission to ___, the patient had persistent pain as
described and Hct was 42.
 
Past Medical History:
none
 
Social History:
Social: works in ___. Denies IVDU. Gets drunk 2 times 
per month. Smokes 1.5 ppw
 
Physical Exam:
Gen: Alert, oriented, in no acute distress
Abd: Firm over midline, palpable mass. Midline abd pain but not 
peritoneal. 
Neuro: Grossly intact
CV: RRR
Resp: Normal respiratory effort 
 
Pertinent Results:
___ 12:50PM   WBC-7.2 RBC-5.09 HGB-14.8 HCT-45.4 MCV-89 
MCH-29.1 MCHC-32.6 RDW-14.5 RDWSD-46.8*
 
Brief Hospital Course:
___ is a ___ who presented to the ED with 12 hours of 
stabbing abdominal pain around his umbilicus, not associated 
with any other symptoms. He has never had a similar pain before. 
A CT at an outside hospital revealed a 20*17 cm mass arising 
from the left lobe of the liver. On admission, the patient was 
hemodynamically stable with a HCT of 42. The patient had a 
sulfur colloid scan which was suggestive of possible hepatic 
adenoma vs. focal nodular hyperplasia. Tumor markers: CEA 3.5, 
APF 2.2, HepC -, ___ (all WNL). His case was discussed at 
tumor board and the decision was made to resect the mass. The 
patient was stable with no new complaints so the decision was 
made for the patient to go home and return for a planned hepatic 
mass resection with Dr. ___. 
 
Medications on Admission:
None
 
Discharge Medications:
1.  Acetaminophen 650 mg PO Q6H:PRN Pain - Mild  

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
20 x 17cm abdominal mass 

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Please call Dr. ___ office at ___ for fever > 
101, chills, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, constipation, increased 
abdominal pain, pain not controlled by your pain medication, 
swelling of the abdomen or ankles, yellowing of the skin or 
eyes, inability to tolerate food, fluids or medications, the 
drain sites have redness, drainage or bleeding, or any other 
concerning symptoms.

No driving if taking narcotic pain medication

Call with any questions
 
Followup Instructions:
___

text:
Name:  ___                   Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: SURGERY
 
Allergies: 
No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
Neoplasm of left lateral liver
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
___  Left lateral sectionectomy, intraoperative ultrasound, 
cholecystectomy, and incidental umbilical hernia repair.

 
History of Present Illness:
___ man who presented to the emergency department with 
acute onset of abdominal pain.
He noted increase in his abdominal girth over the past several 
months.  Imaging demonstrated a large mass off the left lateral 
section.  He was transferred to our institution for further 
evaluation.  CT was reviewed and suggested a
torsed left lateral section with a mass lesion containing fat.  
A sulfur colloid scan demonstrated no significant uptake in the 
majority of the left lateral section, consistent with adenoma or 
infarcted FNH.
 
Past Medical History:
right inguinal hernia repair as a child
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
Non-contributory to this admission
 
Physical Exam:
T 98.4F, HR 86, BP 165/84, RR 22, 100% O2sat 3L N.C.  
GENERAL: A+Ox3, anxiety
HEENT: normocephalic
HEART: RRR
LUNGS: nonlabored
BACK: epidural site c/d/i with sterile tegaderm dsg
ABD: midline incision covered by dry sterile dsg
MSK/EXT: moving bilateral extremities symmetrically
.
Weight at discharge: 94.7 kg
 
Pertinent Results:
Labs POD 0: ___
WBC-10.6* RBC-4.47* Hgb-12.7* Hct-39.3* MCV-88 MCH-28.4 
MCHC-32.3 RDW-14.5 RDWSD-47.1* Plt ___
___ 02:34PM BLOOD ___ PTT-32.9 ___
Glucose-106* UreaN-9 Creat-0.8 Na-144 K-4.7 Cl-108 HCO3-23 
AnGap-13
ALT-138* AST-204* AlkPhos-337* TotBili-0.5
Calcium-8.4 Phos-3.8 Mg-1.6
.
Labs at Discharge: ___
WBC-7.9 RBC-4.01* Hgb-11.4* Hct-35.5* MCV-89 MCH-28.4 MCHC-32.1 
RDW-13.8 RDWSD-44.9 Plt ___
Glucose-102* UreaN-3* Creat-0.7 Na-140 K-3.9 Cl-97 HCO3-28 
AnGap-15
ALT-49* AST-51* AlkPhos-207* TotBili-0.4
Calcium-8.7 Phos-5.7* Mg-1.5*
 
Brief Hospital Course:
___ y/o male with history of abdominal mass seen on CT, was 
having increased abdominal pain. He is now taken to the OR with 
Dr. ___ for resection.
.
At the time of the surgery, upon opening of the abdomen, the 
left lateral section and mass were delivered through the 
incision onto the abdominal wall. When the mass was examined, it 
was clearly torsed fully 360 degrees from its normal axis and it 
was manually untorsed.  The lateral section did appear somewhat 
ischemic but not frankly necrotic. A left lateral sectionectomy 
was performed. Given the presence of polyps and the patient's 
strong family history of gallbladder problems, largely
stones, the gallbladder was also removed to avoid further 
monitoring and possible future surgery. Additionally the small 
umbilical hernia was repaired as part of this surgery.
.
Post operatively the patient had an epidural. The epidural was 
initially split but he was still was not having good pain 
coverage at the site of the incision, and was taken back by APS 
for a regional block that seemed more effective with pain 
control.
.
Liver function tests did increase following the surgery, peak 
bilirubin occurred on POD 2 with result of 1.4. By day of 
discharge all LFTs were trending down (ALT 49 AST 51, Alk Phos 
207 and T Bili 0.4) He did not show any signs of encephalopathy 
and synthetic function was normal. 
.
Otherwise the patient did well after his surgery. He was 
ambulating, he voided without difficulty after the Foley 
catheter was removed. The incision was clean dry and intact. 
There was some erythema around the incision that looked like a 
tape reaction. He was afebrile and tolerating a regular diet 
prior to discharge.
.

 
Medications on Admission:
Naproxen prn
 
Discharge Medications:
1.  Acetaminophen 500 mg PO Q6H 
do not take more than ___ mg per day  
2.  Docusate Sodium 100 mg PO BID 
RX *docusate sodium 100 mg 1 capsule(s) by mouth twice a day 
Disp #*60 Capsule Refills:*0 
3.  HYDROmorphone (Dilaudid) ___ mg PO Q3H:PRN Pain - Moderate 
RX *hydromorphone [Dilaudid] 2 mg ___ tablet(s) by mouth every 
four (4) hours Disp #*15 Tablet Refills:*0 
4.  Senna 8.6 mg PO BID 
RX *sennosides [senna] 8.6 mg 1 by mouth twice a day Disp #*60 
Tablet Refills:*0 

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Neoplasm of left lateral section of liver (pathology pending)

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Please call Dr. ___ at ___ for fever of 101 or 
greater, chills, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, constipation, 
inability to tolerate food, fluids or medications, yellowing of 
skin or eyes, increased abdominal pain, incisional redness, 
drainage or bleeding, increased drainage from JP drain, 
dizziness or weakness, decreased urine output or dark, cloudy 
urine, swelling of abdomen or any other concerning symptoms

You may shower, do not apply powder/lotion or ointment to 
incision. 
Empty JP drain and record all output. Bring record of output to 
your follow up appointment with Dr. ___
 
___ Instructions:
___
