text:
Name:  ___                 Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: SURGERY
 
Allergies: 
No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
rib fracture 
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
N/A 
 
History of Present Illness:
___ PMH of DMI transferred after mechanical fall. Pt had 
mechanical fall while having a indoor picnic w/ her ___ year old 
granddaughter. She presented to OSH with left-sided chest pain, 
and reportedly had a small right pneumothorax on outside 
hospital imaging. She denies headstrike or loss of 
consciousness. She complains of point tenderness of ribs, denies 
SOB, N/V. 

She had CT Head, Cspine, Chest, Abd/Pel at the OSH all which 
demonstrated no further injuries. Her ROS was otherwise 
negative. 

 
Past Medical History:
DM 
Peripheral Vascular Disease 
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
Noncontributory
 
Physical Exam:
Discharge Physical Exam:
VS: 98.3, 132/69, 93, 18, 93 Ra 
Gen: A&O x3, sitting up in chair, NARD
CV: HRR
Pulm: TTP over right chest wall. bruising over right chest wall. 
LS: Fine crackles in middle and lower right lobes, crackles at 
base of left lobe. 
Abd: soft, NT/ND. 
Ext: No edema. 

 
Pertinent Results:
___ PORTABLE CHEST X-RAY: 
1. No definite pneumothorax is visualized.
2. Fractures of the bilateral eighth ribs, with patchy opacities 
at the
bilateral lung bases, right greater left, may represent 
contusions or
atelectasis in the setting of trauma, however infection cannot 
be excluded.
 
Brief Hospital Course:
The patient was found to have bilateral rib fractures: right 
___ ribs, left 8th rib. She was admitted to the Acute Care 
Surgery service for close monitoring of respiratory status and 
pain control. The patient was initially given supplemental 
oxygen, in setting of reported small pneumothorax on OSH 
imaging; this was weaned as tolerated. Her pain was controlled 
with oral agents and lidocaine patch. She ambulated with 
physical therapy who recommended discharge home. The patient was 
compliant with pulmonary toilet, utilizing incentive spirometer 
and ambulating early and often. On ___ she was appropriate 
for discharge home: she was breathing comfortably with 
appropriate oxygen saturation on room air and pain was 
well-controlled.  No other injuries were identified. She will 
follow-up with her primary care physician. 
 
Discharge Disposition:
Home With Service
 
Facility:
___
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Right ___ rib fractures, Left 8th rib fracture

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
                             ___ MD ___
 
Completed by: ___

text:
Name:  ___                   Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: SURGERY
 
Allergies: 
Patient recorded as having No Known Allergies to Drugs
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
GI Bleed
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
EGD (Upper Endoscopy)

 
History of Present Illness:
___ with no significant past medical history presenting with 
three months of guaiac positive stools, found to have a gastric 
ulcer on EGD prior to admission. Patient reports he first began 
being worked up for a GI bleed early this year after he was 
found to be guaiac positive on a routine physical exam. On ___ 
he underwent colonoscopy and on ___ he underwent EGD; 
colonoscopy was significant for several small polyps, EGD was 
unremarkable. He began Omeprazole daily on ___, which was 
increased to BID on ___. He then underwent a barium swallon 
on ___, which showed a large gastric ulcer. On ___ he 
underwent a repeat EGD which also showed the 1 cm deep ulcer in 
the cardia, with surrounding edema and active oozing of blood.  
The ulcer was biopsied and injected with epinephrine with 
partial hemostasis achieved. Given the active bleeding despite 
three weeks of PPI therapy he was referred to the ___ ER for 
further evaluation and consideration for surgical resection. 
Patient currently denies lightheadedness, dizziness, chest pain, 
shortness of breath, abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, fevers, 
or chills. His last bowel movement was last night and was normal 
in appearance.

ROS: Ten point review of systems performed and negative except 
as noted above.
 
Past Medical History:
H/O duodenal ulcer and H.pylori s/p treatment and eradication
Obesity
Hiatal hernia
Spinal Stenosis
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
Mother had a stroke in her ___; no FH of diabetes or cancer.
 
Physical Exam:
VS: T=96.7  BP=138/78  HR=58  RR=14  100% on RA
Gen: Awake, alert, comfortable appearing
HEENT: NCAT, EOMI, anicteric
CV: RR, no m/r/g
Pulm: CTA B
Abd: Soft, NTND
Ext: No edema
Psych: Good historian, good insight into own health, affect 
appropriate

Exam on discharge: Unchanged
 
Pertinent Results:
Admission Labs: ___ 10:15AM 
WBC-7.1 RBC-4.11* Hgb-10.7* Hct-33.3* MCV-81* Plt ___
Glucose-96 UreaN-14 Creat-0.9 Na-141 K-4.6 Cl-104 HCO3-29 
AnGap-13
ALT-28 AST-26 AlkPhos-62 TotBili-0.2

Discharge Labs: ___ 06:05AM 
WBC-4.4 RBC-3.57* Hgb-9.5* Hct-30.1* MCV-84 MCH-26.7* Plt ___
Glucose-94 UreaN-12 Creat-0.8 Na-141 K-4.0 Cl-105 HCO3-28 
AnGap-12

EGD: A 1.5cm cratered, oozing ulcer was found just below the 
cardia. Given its location, it was extremely difficult to 
perform any intervention. Both the standard endoscope and side 
viewing endoscope were used without any success.  

Abdominal/Pelvic CT: No significant abnormality is identified in 
the visualized portions of the lung bases. A large 13.5 cm x 8.9 
cm x 10.5 cm soft tissue mass with central necrosis is 
visualized in the mid-upper abdomen. The lesion is in continuity 
with the lesser curvature of the stomach and abuts the left 
hepatic lobe without a clear plane of separation. The lesion 
also abuts the anterosuperior aspect of the pancreatic head and 
body. The lesion encases the left gastric artery but does not 
involve the celiac artery or hepatic artery. The superior 
mesenteric artery, superior mesenteric vein and portal vein are 
separate from the lesion. A 1.8 cm x 1.5 cm area of low 
attenuation at the gastroesophageal junction (series 3, image 
14) most likely represents a small amount of fluid related to 
hiatus hernia. No significant abdominal lymphadenopathy is 
identified. No focal parenchymal abnormality is seen in the 
liver, spleen, or adrenal glands. A 1.5 cm x 1.6 cm exophytic 
cortical cyst is identified at the lower pole of the left 
kidney. No significant small or large bowel dilatation. A small 
linear area of hyperattenuation in the lumen of proximal small 
bowel (series 400b, image 31) most likely represents a tablet or 
foreign body material. No pelvic lymphadenopathy is identified. 
The urinary bladder is unremarkable in appearance. A few focal 
areas of calcification are seen in the central portion of the 
prostate gland. No suspicious lytic or sclerotic lesions are 
identified in the bony skeleton. 

 
Brief Hospital Course:
On the morning of admission to the hospital on ___ a repeat 
endoscopy was performed. He  was found to have a bleeding 
gastric ulcer in the cardia which was not reachable for 
intervention by the endoscopist. He was accordingly admitted to 
the hospital for further management. During this period of time 
he remained stable. A CT scan of the abdomen was then obtained. 
This study showed a very large mass measuring at least 15 cm in 
size and seemingly arising from the lesser curve of the stomach. 
It had quite a bit of internal necrosis. The diagnosis was that 
the patient had a large gastrointestinal stromal cell tumor that 
had eroded through the mucosa forming the ulcer. The  concern 
was for rupture given the large size and the extensive necrosis. 
The patient was taken to the operating room as aforementioned. 

Neuro: Morphine PCA was utilized immediately post-operative for 
pain control, this was transitioned to oral medications once the 
patient was tolerating a liquid diet.

Cardiovascular: The patient was admitted to the ICU post-op for 
close hemodynamic monitoring, vitals were monitored per unit 
routine. An arterial line was placed during at the time of 
operation for hemodynamic monitoring. It was discontinued on POD 
#1. After transfer to the floor, vital signs were monitored 
closely per unit routine. 

Resp: Continuous 02 saturations wre monitored while patient was 
in the ICU, supplemental oxygenwas provided to maintain 02 
saturations. Upon transfer to the floor 02 saturations were 
checked with vital signs per unit routine. Early ambulation was 
encouraged, incentive spirometry was utilized. 

GI: Post-operatively the patient was made NPO and an NGT was in 
placed to low continuous wall suction. It was removed on POD #3. 
 After NGT removal sips of clear liquids were started, this was 
advanced to clear liquids on POD #4, and regular diet on POD #5. 
IV protonix was started immediately post-operatively. This was 
transitioned to PO once the patient was tolerating a regular 
diet. 

Renal: Foley catheter was placed at the time of procedure. Urine 
output was closely monitored post-operatively. It was removed on 
POD #3, and the patient voided without difficulty. Electrolytes 
were monitored and repleted as necessary. Lactated ringers was 
started post-op, this was changed to D51/2NS, fluids were 
heplocked once the patient was tolerating clear liquid diet. 

Heme: Hct was checked post-operatively, there was no evidence of 
bleeding. 

 
Medications on Admission:
Omeprazole 20mg PO BID
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Pantoprazole 40 mg Tablet, Delayed Release (E.C.) Sig: One 
(1) Tablet, Delayed Release (E.C.) PO Q12H (every 12 hours).
Disp:*60 Tablet, Delayed Release (E.C.)(s)* Refills:*2*
2. Oxycodone 5 mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO Q4H (every 4 hours) 
as needed for pain.
Disp:*40 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
3. Colace 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO twice a day as 
needed for constipation.  

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Bleeding gastric ulcer
Gastric Mass, concerning for GIST; s/p partial gastrectomy

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted with a bleeding gastric ulcer and underwent a 
repeat endoscopy and an abdominal CT scan that showed a large 
mass. You underwent an excision of mass. Call Dr. ___ 
for ___ appointment in ___ weeks. You may resume you 
previous diet as tolerated.  It will take you several weeks to 
recover from the operation, try to remain active and walk 
several times per day. No heavy lifting or vigorous exercise. 
Resume all prior home medications unless otherwise instructed, 
take all new medications as prescribed. You may shower with your 
wound, allow water to run over the incision and pat dry, no tub 
baths/soaks/swimming. If you notice redness or drainage from the 
wound call the office for an appointment. If you experience any 
of the following symptoms go directly to the emergency 
department; chest pain, shortness of breath, severe pain not 
relieved by medication, intractable nausea/vomiting, or any 
other concerning symptoms. 
 
Followup Instructions:
___

text:
Name:  ___                  Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: SURGERY
 
Allergies: 
No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
Abdominal Pain
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
___:  Laparoscopic appendectomy 
___:  CT guided drainage of RLQ and pelvic collections with 
___ pigtails x2 

 
History of Present Illness:
___ otherwise healthy with abdominal pain. Started having 
periumbilical pain 2 days prior to presentation, initially 
attributed to food. Then pain migrated to pelvis bilaterally. 
Also had associated nausea, no emesis. Last BM in the morning 
day prior to presentation. No change in bowel habits. No
dysuria/hematuria. Reports anorexia, ate some toast and a banana 
day prior to presentation, otherwise not much PO intake. No 
fevers, chills, night sweats at home. Went to ___
where he was febrile to 101.0 and received invanz, then 
transferred to ___ due to ?lack of beds.
 
Past Medical History:
none
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
father diagnosed w/ colon cancer at age ___. no other colorectal 
cancer or IBD in family
 
Physical Exam:
Admission Physical exam: 
VS: 98.4, 79, 124/67, 12, 99% RA
Gen: NAD
CV: RRR
Pulm: CTA b/l
Abd: no scars. soft, nondistended. focally tender most in RLQ 
but
slightly tender also in LLQ. no rebound/guarding/rigidity
Ext: no edema

On discharge, the patient's vital sings were stable. His abdomen 
was mildly distended but soft and non- tender. The dressings at 
his drain sites and his surgical incisions were clean, dry, and 
intact. His exam was otherwise unchanged from admission. 
 
Brief Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted and underwent laparoscopic appendectomy 
on ___. In the operating room, he was identified to have 
perforated appendicitis. The case was uncomplicated. He 
initially did very well post-operatively. He was continued on 
antibiotics post-op given the finding of perforated 
appendicitis. He initially was tolerating a diet however he 
began to have increasing abdominal distention and 
abdominal/pelvic pain. On POD4 therefore, he underwent a CT scan 
which revealed RLQ and pelvic abscesses. On POD5 he had two 
drains placed by interventional radiology. He tolerated the 
procedures well. On the POD6, he began on a clear diet. He 
continued to improve and he was started on a regular diet and 
given PO antibiotics. On POD7, he was discharged home on oral 
antibiotics and pain medications. He has follow-up in one week 
in ___ clinic for drain removal.  
 
Medications on Admission:
None
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Acetaminophen 325-650 mg PO Q6H:PRN pain 
2. OxycoDONE (Immediate Release)  ___ mg PO Q4H:PRN pain 
Do not drive or consume alcohol while taking this medication  
RX *oxycodone 5 mg ___ tablet(s) by mouth every ___ hours Disp 
#*40 Tablet Refills:*0
3. Docusate Sodium 100 mg PO BID 
Take this medication while on narcotics meds 
RX *docusate sodium [Colace] 100 mg 1 capsule(s) by mouth twice 
a day Disp #*40 Capsule Refills:*0
4. Senna 8.6 mg PO BID:PRN Constipation  
Take this while on narcotic medication  
RX *sennosides [senna] 8.6 mg 1 by mouth twice a day Disp #*40 
Capsule Refills:*0
5. Ciprofloxacin HCl 500 mg PO Q12H 
RX *ciprofloxacin [Cipro] 500 mg 1 tablet(s) by mouth twice a 
day Disp #*23 Tablet Refills:*0
6. MetRONIDAZOLE (FLagyl) 500 mg PO Q8H 
RX *metronidazole [Flagyl] 500 mg 1 tablet(s) by mouth three 
times a day Disp #*34 Tablet Refills:*0

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home With Service
 
Facility:
___
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Perforated appendicitis 
Postoperative pelvic fluid collection

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted to the hospital with acute appendicitis. You 
were taken to the operating room and had your appendix removed 
laparoscopically.  Postoperatively, you developed a couple of 
abscesses that required drainage. You tolerated the procedure 
well and are now being discharged home with the drains.  Please 
note the following instructions:
You should follow up at the appointment in clinic listed below. 
We also generally recommend that patients follow up with their 
primary care provider after having surgery. We have scheduled an 
appointment for you listed below.
ACTIVITY:
 
Do not drive until you have stopped taking pain medicine and 
feel you could respond in an emergency.
You may climb stairs.
You may go outside, but avoid traveling long distances until you 
see your surgeon at your next visit.
Don't lift more than ___ lbs for ___ weeks. (This is about the 
weight of a briefcase or a bag of groceries.) This applies to 
lifting children, but they may sit on your lap.
You may start some light exercise when you feel comfortable.
You will need to stay out of bathtubs or swimming pools for a 
time while your incision is healing. Ask your doctor when you 
can resume tub baths or swimming.
 
HOW YOU MAY FEEL:
You may feel weak or "washed out" a couple weeks. You might want 
to nap often. Simple tasks may exhaust you.
You may have a sore throat because of a tube that was in your 
throat during surgery.
You could have a poor appetite for a couple days. Food may seem 
unappealing.
All of these feelings and reactions are normal and should go 
away in a short time.  If they do not, tell your surgeon.
 
YOUR INCISION:
Tomorrow you may shower and remove the gauzes over your 
incisions. Under these dressings you have small plastic bandages 
called steristrips. Do not remove steri-strips for 2 weeks. 
(These are the thin paper strips that might be on your 
incision.) But if they fall off before that that's okay.
Your incisions may be slightly red around the stitches. This is 
normal.
You may gently wash away dried material around your incision.
Avoid direct sun exposure to the incision area.
Do not use any ointments on the incision unless you were told 
otherwise.
You may see a small amount of clear or light red fluid staining 
your dressing or clothes. If the staining is severe, please call 
your surgeon.
You may shower. As noted above, ask your doctor when you may 
resume tub baths or swimming.
 
YOUR BOWELS:
Constipation is a common side effect of narcotic pain 
medicaitons. If needed, you may take a stool softener (such as 
Colace, one capsule) or gentle laxative (such as milk of 
magnesia, 1 tbs) twice a day. You can get both of these 
medicines without a prescription.
If you go 48 hours without a bowel movement, or have pain moving 
the bowels, call your surgeon.
 
PAIN MANAGEMENT:
It is normal to feel some discomfort/pain following abdominal 
surgery. This pain is often described as "soreness".
Your pain should get better day by day. If you find the pain is 
getting worse instead of better, please contact your surgeon.
You will receive a prescription for pain medicine to take by 
mouth. It is important to take this medicine as directed. Do not 
take it more frequently than prescribed. Do not take more 
medicine at one time than prescribed. Do not drink alcohol or 
drive while taking narcotic pain medication.
Your pain medicine will work better if you take it before your 
pain gets too severe.
Talk with your surgeon about how long you will need to take 
prescription pain medicine. Please don't take any other pain 
medicine, including non-prescription pain medicine, unless your 
surgeon has said its okay.
If you are experiencing no pain, it is okay to skip a dose of 
pain medicine.
Remember to use your "cough pillow" for splinting when you cough 
or when you are doing your deep breathing exercises.
If you experience any of the following, please contact your 
surgeon:
- sharp pain or any severe pain that lasts several hours
- pain that is getting worse over time
- pain accompanied by fever of more than 101
- a drastic change in nature or quality of your pain
 
MEDICATIONS:
Take all the medicines you were on before the operation just as 
you did before, unless you have been told differently.
If you have any questions about what medicine to take or not to 
take, please call your surgeon.
 
DANGER SIGNS:
Please call your surgeon if you develop:
- worsening abdominal pain
- sharp or severe pain that lasts several hours
- temperature of 101 degrees or higher
- severe diarrhea
- vomiting
- redness around the incision that is spreading
- increased swelling around the incision
- excessive bruising around the incision
- cloudy fluid coming from the wound
- bright red blood or foul smelling discharge coming from the 
wound
- an increase in drainage from the wound

General Drain Care:
*Please look at the site every day for signs of infection 
(increased redness or pain, swelling, odor, yellow or bloody 
discharge, warm to touch, fever).
*If the drain is connected to a collection container, please 
note color, consistency, and amount of fluid in the drain. Call 
the doctor, ___, or ___ nurse if the amount 
increases significantly or changes in character. Be sure to 
empty the drain frequently. Record the output, if instructed to 
do so.
*Wash the area gently with warm, soapy water.
*Keep the insertion site clean and dry otherwise.
*Avoid swimming, baths, hot tubs; do not submerge yourself in 
water.
*Make sure to keep the drain attached securely to your body to 
prevent pulling or dislocation.

 
Followup Instructions:
___

Brief Hospital Course:
He was admitted to ___ on ___ and underwent routine
preoperative testing and evaluation. He remained hemodynamically
stable and was taken to the operating room on ___. He
underwent CABG x 2 with Dr. ___. Please see operative note
for full details. He tolerated the procedure well and was
transferred to the CVICU in stable condition for recovery and
invasive monitoring. He received platelets for thrombocytopenia
with good effect.
He weaned from sedation, awoke neurologically intact and was
extubated on POD 1. Beta blocker was initiated and he was
diuresed toward his preoperative weight. He remained
hemodynamically stable and was transferred to the telemetry
floor for further recovery. He was evaluated by the physical
therapy service for assistance with strength and mobility. By
the time of discharge on POD 4 he was ambulating with
assistance, the wound was healing, and pain was controlled with
oral analgesics. He was discharged to Encompass at ___ in
good condition with appropriate follow up instructions.

Medically managed for several days due to her ___ use of 
Pradaxa and ASA. Once labs were stable, the patient was taken to 
the Operating Room for the above procedure. Refer to the

without complication and the patient was transferred to the PACU 
in a stable condition. TEDs/pnemoboots were used for 
postoperative DVT prophylaxis. Intravenous antibiotics were 
continued for 24hrs postop per standard protocol.Initial postop 
pain was controlled with a PCA. Diet was advanced as tolerated. 
The patient was transitioned to oral pain medication when 
tolerating PO diet. Foley was removed on POD#2. Physical therapy 
and Occupational Therapy was consulted for mobilization OOB to 
ambulate and ADL's. Hospital course was otherwise unremarkable. 
She was re-started on her ___ dose of Pradaxa prior to d/c. On 
the day of discharge the patient was afebrile with stable vital 
signs, comfortable on oral pain control and tolerating a regular 
diet.

Discharge Diagnosis:
cervical stenosis

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - requires assistance or aid (walker 
or cane).

 
Discharge Instructions:
You have undergone the following operation: Posterior Cervical 
Decompression 

Immediately after the operation:

                Activity: You should not lift anything greater 
than 10 lbs for 2 weeks. You will be more comfortable if you do 
not sit in a car or chair for more than ~45 minutes without 
getting up and walking around.

                Rehabilitation/ Physical Therapy:

___                ___ times a day you should go for a walk 
for ___ minutes as part of your recovery.  You can walk as 
much as you can tolerate.  

___                Isometric Extension Exercise in the 
collar: 2x/day x ___xercises as 
instructed.

                Cervical Collar / Neck Brace: You need to wear 
the brace at all times until your follow-up appointment which 
should be in 2 weeks.  You may remove the collar to take a 
shower.  Limit your motion of your neck while the collar is off. 
Place the collar back on your neck immediately after the shower.

                Wound Care: Remove the dressing in 2 days.  If 
the incision is draining cover it with a new sterile dressing.  
If it is dry then you can leave the incision open to the air.  
Once the incision is completely dry (usually ___ days after the 
operation) you may take a shower. Do not soak the incision in a 
bath or pool.  If the incision starts draining at anytime after 
surgery, do not get the incision wet. Call the office at that 
time. If you have an incision on your hip please follow the same 
instructions in terms of wound care.

                You should resume taking your normal ___ 
medications.

                You have also been given Additional Medications 
to control your pain. . Please allow 72 hours for refill of 
narcotic prescriptions, so please plan ahead.  You can either 
have them mailed to your ___ or pick them up at the clinic 
located on ___ 2.  We are not allowed to call in narcotic 
prescriptions (oxycontin, oxycodone, percocet) to the pharmacy.  
In addition, we are only allowed to write for pain medications 
for 90 days from the date of surgery.  

                Follow up:            

___                Please Call the office and make an 
appointment for 2 weeks after the day of your operation if this 
has not been done already.

___                At the 2-week visit we will check your 
incision, take baseline x rays and answer any questions.

___                We will then see you at 6 weeks from the 
day of the operation. At that time we will most likely obtain 
Flexion/Extension X-rays and often able to place you in a soft 
collar which you will wean out of over 1 week.  

Please call the office if you have a fever>101.5 degrees 
Fahrenheit, drainage from your wound, or have any questions.

Physical Therapy:
-You should not lift anything greater than 10 lbs for 2 weeks. 
You will be more comfortable if you do not sit in a car or chair 
for more than ~45 minutes without getting up and walking around.
-___ times a day you should go for a walk for ___ minutes as 
part of your recovery.  You can walk as much as you can 
tolerate.  
-Isometric Extension Exercise in the collar: 2x/day x ___xercises as instructed

Treatments Frequency:
Wound Care: Remove the dressing in 2 days.  If the incision is 
draining cover it with a new sterile dressing.  If it is dry 
then you can leave the incision open to the air.  Once the 
incision is completely dry (usually ___ days after the 
operation) you may take a shower. Do not soak the incision in a 
bath or pool.  If the incision starts draining at anytime after 
surgery, do not get the incision wet. Call the office at that 
time. If you have an incision on your hip please follow the same 
instructions in terms of wound care.

 
Followup Instructions:
___

ACUTE/ACTIVE PROBLEMS:
# Unintentional overdose of memantine, donepezil, and atenolol: 
patient had bradycardia to low ___.  She had some agitation 
which could signify some cholinergic toxicity.  Atenolol 
half-life was ___ hours in normal renal function.  Memantine and 
donepezil have longer half-lives of 60-70 hours.  All 
medications can influence heart
rate and cardiac conduction.  Patient was monitored on telemetry 
with no cardiac conduction abnormalities.  QTc was high normal.  
Atenolol was stopped due to risk of bradycardia if patient 
develops renal failure.  Donepezil and memantine will be 
restarted on discharge.  Care should be taken to prevent taking 
multiple doses of medications going forward.

# Hypertension: atenolol was stopped as noted above.  Amlodipine 
5 mg PO daily was started in its place with controlled blood 
pressure on discharge.

# Elevated lactic acid: likely from medication overdose, 
improved soon after admission.

# Alzheimer's dementia: ramelteon QHS given during admission.

TRANSITIONS OF CARE
-------------------
# Follow-up: patient's blood pressure should be monitored on new 
dose of amlodipine.  Medications may need to be further 
titrated.  Care should be taken to prevent patient taking 
multiple doses of medications going forward.

# Contacts/HCP/Surrogate and Communication: son, ___

Sinus bradycardia

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___,

It was a pleasure caring for you during your recent 
hospitalization.  You came to the hospital after taking too much 
of your medications.  Further testing showed that your heart 
rate was slowed by this, but did not continue to worsen over 
time.  By now, most of the medications should be out of your 
system.  You are now being discharged.

You will not continue on atenolol any longer.  Amlodipine is 
being given instead to control your blood pressure.

It is important that you continue to take your medications as 
prescribed and follow up with the appointments listed below.

Good luck!

unintential overdose of her memantine, donepezil, and atenolol.
ACUTE/ACTIVE PROBLEMS:
# Unintentional overdose of memantine, donepezil, and atenolol:
patient had bradycardia to low ___. She had some agitation
which could signify some cholinergic toxicity. Atenolol
half-life was ___ hours in normal renal function. Memantine and
donepezil have longer half-lives of 60-70 hours. All
medications can influence heart
rate and cardiac conduction. Patient was monitored on telemetry
with no cardiac conduction abnormalities. QTc was high normal.
Atenolol was stopped due to risk of bradycardia if patient
develops renal failure. Donepezil and memantine will be
restarted on discharge. Care should be taken to prevent taking
multiple doses of medications going forward.
# Hypertension: atenolol was stopped as noted above. Amlodipine
5 mg PO daily was started in its place with controlled blood
pressure on discharge.
# Elevated lactic acid: likely from medication overdose,
improved soon after admission.
# Alzheimer's dementia: ramelteon QHS given during admission.
TRANSITIONS OF CARE
-------------------
# Follow-up: patient's blood pressure should be monitored on new
dose of amlodipine. Medications may need to be further
titrated. Care should be taken to prevent patient taking
multiple doses of medications going forward.
# Contacts/HCP/Surrogate and Communication: son, ___
# Code Status/Advance Care Planning: confirmed full (please also
see current POE order)
Medications on Admission:
The Preadmission Medication list is accurate and complete.
1. Atorvastatin 10 mg PO QPM
2. Atenolol 50 mg PO DAILY
3. Donepezil 10 mg PO QHS
4. Namenda XR (MEMAntine) 28 mg oral DAILY
Discharge Medications:
1. amLODIPine 5 mg PO DAILY
2. Atorvastatin 10 mg PO QPM
3. Donepezil 10 mg PO QHS
4. Namenda XR (MEMAntine) 28 mg oral DAILY
Discharge Disposition:
Extended Care
Facility:
___
Discharge Diagnosis:
Medication overdose
Sinus bradycardia
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Confused - always.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.
Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___,
It was a pleasure caring for you during your recent
hospitalization. You came to the hospital after taking too much
of your medications. Further testing showed that your heart
rate was slowed by this, but did not continue to worsen over
time. By now, most of the medications should be out of your
system. You are now being discharged.
You will not continue on atenolol any longer. Amlodipine is
being given instead to control your blood pressure.
It is important that you continue to take your medications as
prescribed and follow up with the appointments listed below.
Good luck!
Followup Instructions:
___

the patient was admitted for neurologic observation, pain

times a day).
Disp:*60 Capsule(s)* Refills:*2*

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home With Service
 
Facility:
___
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
fracture of C2, type 2 odontoid fracture
 
Discharge Condition:
good
 
Discharge Instructions:
You have fractured the second cervical vertebra (C2) at the 
odontoid process (a part of the vertebra).  You must wear the 
neck collar at all times.  This is the best treatment for this 
fracture.  If you take off the collar, it is possible for the 
fracture to displace and possibly injury your spinal cord or 
nerves of the neck.  

Do not lift anything heavier than a gallon of milk.  Do not 
twist or bend your neck.  

If you have any feelings of numbness, tingling, or pain 
radiating down your arms or legs, you must call the office or go 
to the ER.  
Physical Therapy:
no lifting heavier than a gallon of milk.  no bending or 
twisting of the neck.  collar at all times.
Treatment Frequency:
none
 
Followup Instructions:
___

Ms. ___ is a ___ year old ___ at 35+2 who is admitted to 
the antepartum service for management of confirmed IUGR.  She 
was first admitted to labor and delivery for potential repeat 
c-section if her dating which placed her at term was correct.  
Notably when she arrived on L&D, she had a fetal deceleration 
when placed on the monitor.  It quickly returned to baseline and 
fetal monitoring remained otherwise reassuring.  Records from 
both ___ and ___ were obtained 
to confirm dating.  Her ___ established by 10 week ultrasound 
was ___.  While she still had IUGR, she was not yet at 
term and thus was admitted for further evaluation.

She had a variety of labs including TORCH titers, TSH, serum and 
urine tox screens which were negative.  She had a repeat BPP and 
Dopplers on ___ which were again reassuring.  She was seen by 
the NICU and SW in consultation.

Given reassuring fetal testing, she was discharged with close 
follow-up.

PNV

6 hours) as needed for Pain.  
3. Prenatal ___ mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO once a day.

Home

Intra-uterine growth restriction

several labs to try and identify why your baby is small and many 
are still pending.  It will be very important to keep your

___.

Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: ORTHOPAEDICS
 
Allergies: 
No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
Left ankle pain
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
Left Ankle Fracture Open Reduction Internal Fixation

 
History of Present Illness:
___ female patient, who works with us in the ___, in 
the radiology service.  She unfortunately sustained an ankle 
fracture on ___,
while she was repelling down a water fall.  This was actually 
more of a trimalleolar ankle fracture pattern that will 
certainly require a surgical fixation.  She was initially 
splinted, and we reexamine her out of splint today.  Her skin 
does not show any blistering and the fracture appears to be well 
reduced.  We resplinted her today, and we will book her for 
surgery for this ___ documenting the reason for surgery.  
She did have a hernia
repair in the past.
 
Past Medical History:
Hernia repair
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
Noncontributory
 
Physical Exam:
Discharge Physical Exam
Patient comfortable, in bed, nonlabored breathing room air. 
Left lower extremity
Splint and ACE wrap in place. It is clean, dry, intact
Foot is warm/well-perfused with good capillary refill
Sensation is grossly intact to light touch in sural, saphenous, 
deep and superficial peroneal distributions
Able to fire ___. Unable to fully assess TA/G/S due to 
splint.

 
Brief Hospital Course:
The patient presented as a same day admission for surgery. The 
patient was taken to the operating room on ___ for left 
ankle open reduction internal fixation, which the patient 
tolerated well. For full details of the procedure please see the 
separately dictated operative report. The patient was taken from 
the OR to the PACU in stable condition and after satisfactory 
recovery from anesthesia was transferred to the floor. The 
patient was initially given IV fluids and IV pain medications, 
and progressed to a regular diet and oral medications by POD#1. 
The patient was given ___ antibiotics and 
anticoagulation per routine. The patient's home medications were 
continued throughout this hospitalization. The patient worked 
with ___ who determined that discharge to home was appropriate. 
The ___ hospital course was otherwise unremarkable.

At the time of discharge the patient's pain was well controlled 
with oral medications, incisions were clean/dry/intact, and the 
patient was voiding/moving bowels spontaneously. The patient is 
touch down weight bearing in the left lower extremity, and will 
be discharged on lovenox for two weeks for DVT prophylaxis. The 
patient will follow up with Dr. ___ routine. A 
thorough discussion was had with the patient regarding the 
diagnosis and expected post-discharge course including reasons 
to call the office or return to the hospital, and all questions 
were answered. The patient was also given written instructions 
concerning precautionary instructions and the appropriate 
follow-up care. The patient expressed readiness for discharge.

 
Medications on Admission:
The Preadmission Medication list is accurate and complete.
1. Spironolactone 50 mg PO DAILY 
2. Citalopram 40 mg PO DAILY 
3. BuPROPion (Sustained Release) 150 mg PO QAM 

 
Discharge Medications:
1. BuPROPion (Sustained Release) 150 mg PO QAM 
2. Citalopram 40 mg PO DAILY 
3. Spironolactone 50 mg PO DAILY 
4. Enoxaparin Sodium 40 mg SC QPM 
Start: Today - ___, First Dose: Next Routine Administration 
Time 
RX *enoxaparin 40 mg/0.4 mL 40 mg SC QPM Disp #*14 Syringe 
Refills:*0
5. OxycoDONE (Immediate Release)  ___ mg PO Q4H:PRN pain 
RX *oxycodone 5 mg ___ capsule(s) by mouth q4hrs Disp #*130 
Capsule Refills:*0
6. Acetaminophen 1000 mg PO Q8H pain 
7. Docusate Sodium 100 mg PO BID constipation 
8. Milk of Magnesia 30 mL PO Q6H:PRN constipation 
9. Senna 8.6 mg PO BID:PRN constipation 

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Left Ankle Fracture

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - requires assistance or aid (walker 
or cane).

 
Discharge Instructions:
INSTRUCTIONS AFTER ORTHOPAEDIC SURGERY:

- You were in the hospital for orthopedic surgery. It is normal 
to feel tired or "washed out" after surgery, and this feeling 
should improve over the first few days to week. 
- Resume your regular activities as tolerated, but please follow 
your weight bearing precautions strictly at all times.

ACTIVITY AND WEIGHT BEARING:
- Touch down weight bearing in a splint 

MEDICATIONS:
- Please take all medications as prescribed by your physicians 
at discharge.
- Continue all home medications unless specifically instructed 
to stop by your surgeon.
- Do not drink alcohol, drive a motor vehicle, or operate 
machinery while taking narcotic pain relievers.
- Narcotic pain relievers can cause constipation, so you should 
drink eight 8oz glasses of water daily and take a stool softener 
(colace) to prevent this side effect.

ANTICOAGULATION:
- Please take Lovenox 40mg daily for 2 weeks

WOUND CARE:
- You may shower. No baths or swimming for at least 4 weeks.
- Any stitches or staples that need to be removed will be taken 
out at your 2-week follow up appointment.
- No dressing is needed if wound continues to be non-draining.
- Splint must be left on until follow up appointment unless 
otherwise instructed
- Do NOT get splint wet

DANGER SIGNS:
Please call your PCP or surgeon's office and/or return to the 
emergency department if you experience any of the following:
- Increasing pain that is not controlled with pain medications
- Increasing redness, swelling, drainage, or other concerning 
changes in your incision
- Persistent or increasing numbness, tingling, or loss of 
sensation
- Fever > 101.4
- Shaking chills
- Chest pain
- Shortness of breath
- Nausea or vomiting with an inability to keep food, liquid, 
medications down
- Any other medical concerns

FOLLOW UP:
Please follow up with your surgeon's team (Dr. ___, with 
___, NP in the Orthopaedic Trauma Clinic 14 days 
post-operation for evaluation. Call ___ to schedule 
appointment upon discharge.

Please follow up with your primary care doctor regarding this 
admission within ___ weeks and for and any new 
medications/refills.
Physical Therapy:
Touch down weight bearing, left lower extremity
Treatments Frequency:
- You may shower. No baths or swimming for at least 4 weeks.
- Any stitches or staples that need to be removed will be taken 
out at your 2-week follow up appointment.
- No dressing is needed if wound continues to be non-draining.
- Splint must be left on until follow up appointment unless 
otherwise instructed
- Do NOT get splint wet

 
Followup Instructions:
___

text:
Name:  ___                   Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: NEUROSURGERY
 
Allergies: 
gabapentin
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
low back pain
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
Removal of spinal cord stimulator ___

 
History of Present Illness:
___ y/o F with spinal cord stimulator placed in ___ of this 
year presents with continued low back pain. Patient presents for 
elective removal of spinal cord stimulator.
 
Past Medical History:
HTN
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
NC
 
Physical Exam:
On Discharge:
Lower extremity strength is graded as ___ bilaterally in the 
upper and lower extremities bilaterally. 
Dressing: clean, dry and intact without edema, erythema or 
discharge. 
 
Pertinent Results:
___ 06:20AM BLOOD WBC-5.7 RBC-4.08* Hgb-11.7* Hct-34.8* 
MCV-85 MCH-28.8 MCHC-33.8 RDW-12.6 Plt ___
___ 06:20AM BLOOD Plt ___
___ 06:20AM BLOOD ___ PTT-27.9 ___
___ 06:20AM BLOOD Glucose-93 UreaN-15 Creat-0.8 Na-142 
K-4.0 Cl-105 HCO3-28 AnGap-13
___ 06:20AM BLOOD Calcium-8.8 Phos-4.9* Mg-2.___ y/o F presents for elective removal of spinal cord 
stimulator. She was taken to the OR on ___ without any 
intraoperative complications. Patient was extubated and taken to 
the PACU. She was admitted to neurosurgery for overnight 
monitoring. There was sanguinous drainage from the incision 
site; the dressing was changed and there was no additional 
drainage overnight. She voided without difficulty and was 
ambulating in dependently. Her pain was controlled on oral 
oxycodone and acetaminophen. She was discharged to home on 
post-operative day one. 
 
Medications on Admission:
The Preadmission Medication list is accurate and complete.
1. Hydrochlorothiazide 25 mg PO DAILY 
2. BuPROPion 300 mg PO DAILY 
3. Oxycodone-Acetaminophen (5mg-325mg) ___ TAB PO Q6H:PRN pain 
4. Citalopram 40 mg PO DAILY 

 
Discharge Medications:
1. BuPROPion 150 mg PO BID 
2. Oxycodone-Acetaminophen (5mg-325mg) ___ TAB PO Q4H:PRN pain 
RX *oxycodone-acetaminophen [Percocet] 5 mg-325 mg ___ tablet(s) 
by mouth every ___ hours as needed Disp #*60 Tablet Refills:*0
3. Docusate Sodium 100 mg PO BID 
4. Citalopram 40 mg PO DAILY 
5. Hydrochlorothiazide 25 mg PO DAILY 

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
failed spinal cord stimulator

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Do not smoke.
Keep your wound(s) clean and dry / No tub baths or pool 
swimming for two weeks from your date of surgery.
No pulling up, lifting more than 10 lbs., or excessive bending 
or twisting.
Limit your use of stairs to ___ times per day.
Have a friend or family member check your incision daily for 
signs of infection.
Take your pain medication as instructed; you may find it best 
if taken in the morning when you wake-up for morning stiffness, 
and before bed for sleeping discomfort.
Increase your intake of fluids and fiber, as pain medicine 
(narcotics) can cause constipation. We recommend taking an over 
the counter stool softener, such as Docusate (Colace) while 
taking narcotic pain medication.
CALL YOUR SURGEON IMMEDIATELY IF YOU EXPERIENCE ANY OF THE 
FOLLOWING:

Pain that is continually increasing or not relieved by pain 
medicine.
Any weakness, numbness, tingling in your extremities.
Any signs of infection at the wound site: redness, swelling, 
tenderness, and drainage.
Fever greater than or equal to 10.5° F. 
Any change in your bowel or bladder habits (such as loss of 
bowl or urine control). 

 
Followup Instructions:
___

text:
Name:  ___                  Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: MEDICINE
 
Allergies: 
Sulfa (Sulfonamide Antibiotics)
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
Syncope
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
None

 
History of Present Illness:
___ is a ___ year old female with a history of
pulmonary MAC (followed at ___ in ___ currently
not on treatment), diarrhea-predominant IBS, and well controlled
hypertension who presents to the ___ with syncope. 

Patient is from ___, spends her winters in ___, and
was visiting ___ to be with her family for the holidays.  
They
were out to lunch today when she began to feel lightheaded while
she was still sitting down after enjoying her meal, which did
include 1 glass of alcohol. This feeling of lightheadedness
lasted for about 1 minute.  The next thing she remembers is
laying on the ground, she was told her family had gently lowered
her to the ground when she lost consciousness and there was no
traumatic injury. She states that upon return of her
consciousness, she did not feel confused or lethargic, though 
she
was very warm ("I remember being relieved when we finally got
outside to get into the ambulance"). 

Her total downtime is unclear. Apparently, there was a second
episode that occurred while she was still on the ground, which
was witnessed by EMS when waiting for an ambulance, and lasted
for about 10 seconds but the details are unclear and the patient
does not recall the event. No loss of bowel/bladder.

She denies any history of syncope, seizure, new medications 
(only
cardiac med is lisinopril 40mg). No history of angina symptoms.
She was on a recent flight from ___, but does not take
estrogens, does not smoke, no history of blood clots, no
signs/symptoms of DVT. 

On arrival to the floor, patient reports the above history and
feels like she is in her baseline state of health. 

In the ED, initial VS were:  97.7 50 93/57 16 100% RA 
Exam notable for:  unremarkable 
EKG:  sinus rhythm, no obvious arrhythmia pre-disposing 
waveforms
Labs showed:  mild hyponatremia, thrombocytopenia, trop < 0.01
Imaging showed: Irregular prominent/thickening at the right hila
with bronchial wall thickening and irregularity.  
Consults:  None. 
Patient received:  1L normal saline 

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS: 10 point ROS reviewed and negative except as
per HPI  

 
Past Medical History:
PAST MEDICAL AND SURGICAL HISTORY:  
-pulmonary MAC (followed at ___ in ___ 
currently
not on treatment)
-diarrhea-predominant IBS
-well controlled hypertension
-history of knee replacement  
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
-No history of sudden cardiac death 
-Brother with congenital heart disease s/p valve repair 
 
Physical Exam:
ADMISSION PHYSICAL
==================
VS: 97.5 144/74 59 18 92% RA 
GENERAL: NAD  
NECK: JVP not elevated   
HEART: RRR, S1/S2, no murmurs, gallops, or rubs  
LUNGS: diffuse rhonchi, breathing comfortably
ABDOMEN: nondistended, nontender in all quadrants
EXTREMITIES: warm, no pitting edema 
NEURO: A&Ox3, speech fluent, ___ strength in all groups 

DISCHARGE PHYSICAL
==================
Orthostatic Vitals: 
___ 0806 BP: 128/74 Lying HR: 51 
___ 0809 BP: 146/77 Sitting HR: 71 
___ 0812 BP: 130/73 Standing HR: 72 

___ 0749 Temp: 97.9 PO BP: 132/77 HR: 55 RR: 18 O2 sat: 94%
O2 delivery: Ra  
GENERAL: NAD  
NECK: JVP not elevated   
HEART: RRR, S1/S2, no murmurs, gallops, or rubs  
LUNGS: diffuse rhonchi, breathing comfortably
ABDOMEN: nondistended, nontender in all quadrants
EXTREMITIES: warm, no pitting edema 
NEURO: A&Ox3, speech fluent, ___ strength in all groups 

Repeat Orthostatics Negative
 
Pertinent Results:
ADMISSION LABS
==============
___ 04:42PM BLOOD WBC-4.0 RBC-3.85* Hgb-11.9 Hct-38.2 
MCV-99* MCH-30.9 MCHC-31.2* RDW-13.1 RDWSD-47.3* Plt ___
___ 04:42PM BLOOD Neuts-36.6 ___ Monos-12.4 Eos-3.0 
Baso-0.5 Im ___ AbsNeut-1.47* AbsLymp-1.90 AbsMono-0.50 
AbsEos-0.12 AbsBaso-0.02
___ 04:42PM BLOOD ___ PTT-23.6* ___
___ 04:42PM BLOOD Glucose-114* UreaN-15 Creat-0.8 Na-133* 
K-4.9 Cl-94* HCO3-23 AnGap-16
___ 04:42PM BLOOD cTropnT-<0.01
___ 04:42PM BLOOD TSH-4.0

MICRO
=====
None

IMAGING
=======
Irregular prominent/thickening at the right hila with bronchial 
wall 
thickening and irregularity, without priors for comparison.  
Correlate with any prior chest imaging for comparison.  
Correlate with any history of  right-sided chest procedure or 
known ongoing process.  5 mm left lung nodule  opacity. Chest CT 
would further assess the above findings if they have not already 
been  previously evaluated.  Underlying malignancy is not 
excluded. 

DISCHARGE LABS
==============
___ 06:24AM BLOOD WBC-4.2 RBC-3.55* Hgb-11.0* Hct-35.1 
MCV-99* MCH-31.0 MCHC-31.3* RDW-13.1 RDWSD-47.7* Plt ___
___ 06:24AM BLOOD Glucose-93 UreaN-13 Creat-0.5 Na-138 
K-4.3 Cl-103 HCO3-24 AnGap-___ female with a history of pulmonary MAC (followed at 
___ in ___ currently not on treatment), 
diarrhea-predominant IBS, and well controlled hypertension who 
presents to the ___ with dehdyration and syncope. 

# Syncope: She reported URI symptoms for 5 days prior to 
admission, with poor food and drink intake. On day of admission 
she went to dinner with her family, felt lightheaded and had a 
syncopeal episode while seated at the table. She denied chest 
pain, palpitations, shortness of breath, vertigo, bladder or 
bowel symptoms. She returned to her baseline upon waking after 
___. She has no hx of MI, CHF, or arrhythmia. She had no heart 
murmur on exam, EKG and troponin were within normal limits. She 
had positive orthostatic vitals and was given 2L of IVF with 
improvement. Etiology of syncope was felt to be dehydration 
possibly with postprandial syncope. She was discharged home in 
good condition. 

#Mild Thrombocytopenia (Stable) 
-Outpatient follow up. 

#Pulmonary MAC: Followed at ___, stable and not on 
therapy. 

#Diarrhea-predominant IBS: Continued Cholestyramine 8g daily 

Transitional Issues: 
[] recommend outpatient follow up for mild neutropenia and 
thrombocytopenia. Recheck CBC at next PCP ___. Could be 
suppression in setting of URI. 

Emergency Contact: ___ (daughter) ___

 
Medications on Admission:
The Preadmission Medication list is accurate and complete.
1. Lisinopril 40 mg PO DAILY 
2. Cholestyramine 8 gm PO QHS IBS-related diarrhea

Brief Hospital Course:

showed partial small bowel obstruction with the transition point 
at the stenotic-appearing ileoileal anastomosis in the lower mid 
abdomen without evidence of active inflammatory changes to 
suspect acute Crohn's flare. CBC with mild leukocytosis of 13, 
lactate 2.1.

exam benign. Will discharge with ACS and GI follow up.

text:
Name:  ___                 Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: UROLOGY
 
Allergies: 
Patient recorded as having No Known Allergies to Drugs
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
BPH
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
Greenlight Photovaporization of Prostate.

 
History of Present Illness:
___ with BPH here for PVP.
 
Brief Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to Dr. ___ service after 
greenlight vaporization of the prostate. No concerning 
intraoperative events occurred; please see dictated operative 
note for details. The patient received ___ antibiotic 
prophylaxis. Patient's postoperative course was uncomplicated. 
He received intravenous antibiotics and pyridium, maintained on 
bedrest and continous bladder irrigation overnight. On POD1, the 
CBI and foley catheter were discontinued, and he passed a 
voiding trial.  His urine was clear yellow without clots with 
post-void residual less than voided volumes. He remained 
afebrile throughout his hospital stay.  At discharge, patient's 
pain well controlled with oral pain medications, tolerating 
regular diet, ambulating without assistance, and voiding without 
difficulty. He is given pyridium and oral pain medications on 
discharge, without antibiotics. He is given explicit 
instructions to call Dr. ___ follow-up.
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Acetaminophen 500 mg Tablet Sig: Two (2) Tablet PO Q6H (every 
6 hours) as needed for fever or pain.  
2. Oxycodone 5 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO Q4H (every 4 
hours) as needed for pain.
Disp:*20 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
3. Omeprazole 20 mg Capsule, Delayed Release(E.C.) Sig: One (1) 
Capsule, Delayed Release(E.C.) PO DAILY (Daily).  
4. Phenazopyridine 100 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO TID (3 
times a day) as needed for bladder pain, burning urination for 3 
days.
Disp:*15 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
5. Ciprofloxacin 500 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO Q12H 
(every 12 hours).
Disp:*6 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
6. Docusate Sodium 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO BID (2 
times a day) for 15 days: Over the Counter.
Disp:*30 Capsule(s)* Refills:*0*

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
BPH, urinary retention

 
Discharge Condition:
Stable

 
Discharge Instructions:
- No vigorous physical activity for 2 weeks.
- Expect to see occasional blood in your urine and to experience 
urgency and frequecy over the next month.
- You may shower and bathe normally.
- Do not drive or drink alcohol if taking narcotic pain 
medication.
- Resume all of your home medications, but please avoid 
aspirin/advil for one week.
- Call Dr. ___ office (___) for follow-up AND if you 
have any questions.
- If you have fevers > 101.5 F, vomiting, severe abdominal pain, 
or inability to urinate, call your doctor or go to the nearest 
emergency room.
 
Followup Instructions:
___

text:
Name:  ___                  Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: UROLOGY
 
Allergies: 
Penicillins
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
Right kidney stones
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
Right percutaneous nephrolithotomy - ___ - Dr. ___

 
History of Present Illness:
She originally presented with at least four urinary tract 
infections in early ___, treated with Macrobid and these 
presented with malaise, decreased appetite, but no urinary 
symptoms.  Subsequent workup revealed large right kidney stone. 
Ureteroscopy and laser lithotripsy was performed in ___ by 
Dr. ___.  Subsequent scans have revealed residual calculi. 
 
Past Medical History:
1. Brain cyst ___ years, which is benign
2. Hypertension
3. T+A as a child
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
Negative for kidney, bladder cancer.  She has a brother and two 
sons with history of kidney stones.

 
Pertinent Results:
___ 06:30AM BLOOD WBC-10.5# RBC-3.53* Hgb-10.4* Hct-30.6* 
MCV-87 MCH-29.5 MCHC-34.0 RDW-13.4 Plt ___
___ 06:30AM BLOOD Glucose-133* UreaN-17 Creat-0.7 Na-141 
K-3.9 Cl-105 HCO3-26 AnGap-14
 
Brief Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to Dr. ___ service after 
percutaneous nephrolithotripsy. No concerning intraoperative 
events occurred; please see dictated operative note for details. 
The patient received ___ antibiotic prophylaxis. 
Patient's postoperative course was uncomplicated. On POD1, CT 
scan identified some residual nephrolithiasis that Dr. ___ 
plans on addressing using ureteroscopy.  Nephrostomy tubes were 
removed, then foley removed 1 hour after.  The patient passed a 
voiding trial.  Her urine was clear yellow without clots, and 
she remained afebrile throughout his hospital stay.  At 
discharge, patient's pain well controlled with oral pain 
medications, tolerating regular diet, ambulating without 
assistance, and voiding without difficulty. She was given oral 
pain medications on discharge, and asked to complete her 8 day 
course of macrobid.  She was given explicit instructions to call 
Dr. ___ follow-up.
 
Medications on Admission:
1. Macrobid ___ mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO twice a day 
for 7 days.
Disp:*14 Capsule(s)* Refills:*0*
2. Propranolol 80 mg Capsule,Sustained Action 24 hr Sig: One (1) 
Capsule,Sustained Action 24 hr PO DAILY (Daily).  
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Docusate Sodium 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO twice 
a day: take while taking narcotic pain medication to prevent 
constipation.
Disp:*60 Capsule(s)* Refills:*2*
2. Macrobid ___ mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO twice a day 
for 7 days.
Disp:*14 Capsule(s)* Refills:*0*
3. Propranolol 80 mg Capsule,Sustained Action 24 hr Sig: One (1) 
Capsule,Sustained Action 24 hr PO DAILY (Daily).  
4. Hydromorphone 2 mg Tablet Sig: 0.5-2 Tablets PO Q3H (every 3 
hours) as needed for pain.
Disp:*80 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Right kidney stones

 
Discharge Condition:
Stable

 
Discharge Instructions:
-Expect significant drainage (bloody drainage is expected) from 
your back.  Please change your dressings as often as needed to 
keep your skin as dry as possible.

-Please call if you experience fevers > 101.5

-Please try to urinate more often while there is still drainage 
from your back.  Wake up at least once at night to urinate.  

-Call Dr. ___ office to schedule a follow-up appointment 
AND if you have any urological questions, ___.
 
Followup Instructions:
___

___ F who had underwent R PCNL with Dr. ___ with some

stent removed on ___.  Shortly thereafter, she developed

pyelonephritis.  She was admitted from the ED.

___

___ 12:30PM BLOOD Glucose-119* UreaN-28* Creat-1.1 Na-141 
K-3.8 Cl-106 HCO3-22 AnGap-17
___ 12:30PM BLOOD Calcium-9.3 Phos-1.9* Mg-1.7
 
Brief Hospital Course:
Pt was admitted to Dr. ___ service and underwent a 
R ureteral stent placement on ___.  She was placed on 
gentamicin empirically for R obstructed pyelonephritis.  Blood 
cultures grew pan-sensitive E.Coli.  She remained on the floor 
for four days having intermittent but decreasing fevers.  She 
remained hemodynamically stable throughout her hospitalization.  
On day of discharge, she had been afebrile x 24 hours and her 
WBC count was normal.  ID was curbsided and recommended a 14-day 
course of PO antibiotics.  She was discharged with a 14-day 
course of ciprofloxacin, and was tolerating PO diet and 
ambulating without difficulty.  
 
Medications on Admission:
1. Propranolol 80 mg Capsule,Sustained Action 24 hr Sig: One (1) 
Capsule,Sustained Action 24 hr PO DAILY (Daily).  
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Propranolol 80 mg Capsule,Sustained Action 24 hr Sig: One (1) 
Capsule,Sustained Action 24 hr PO DAILY (Daily).  
2. Ciprofloxacin 500 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO twice a 
day for 14 days.
Disp:*28 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
3. Valacyclovir 1 g Tablet Sig: Two (2) Tablet PO twice a day 
for 1 days.
Disp:*4 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Right obstructed pyelonephritis

 
Discharge Condition:
Stable

 
Discharge Instructions:
-Please call if you experience fevers > 101.5 F or if you have 
persistent nausea/vomiting

-Take your antibiotics for 14 days. 
 
Followup Instructions:
___

The left atrium is normal in size. Left ventricular wall

free wall motion are normal. The aortic valve leaflets (3)

normal with trivial mitral regurgitation. Trivial mitral

atrial appendag is free of thrombus.The ascending aorta is 
borderline dilated,There is n thrombus.The decending thoracic 
aorta is normal in diameter  
 
Brief Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the hospital and brought to the 
operating room on ___ where the patient underwent CABGx4.  
Overall the patient tolerated the procedure well and 
post-operatively was transferred to the CVICU in stable 
condition for recovery and invasive monitoring. He required epi 
and neo of hemodynamic support. POD 1 found the patient 
extubated, alert and oriented and breathing comfortably.  The 
patient was neurologically intact and hemodynamically stable 
with continued pressor need. He developed rapid afib that was 
difficult to control and remained in the unit on diltiazem gtt 
and neo gtt. He was eventually transitioned to oral diltiazem 
weaned off neo and transferred to the stepdown unit on POD#4. 
His Hemodialysis was resumed. He had acute blood loss anemia and 
received intermittent transfusions. His  Coumadin  resumed for 
pre-op afib.  Beta blocker was initiated once off neo. Chest 
tubes and pacing wires were discontinued without complication.  
The patient was evaluated by the physical therapy service for 
assistance with strength and mobility.  By the time of discharge 
on POD #5 the patient was ambulating with a cane, the wound was 
healing and pain was controlled with oral analgesics.  The 
patient was discharged to home in good condition with 
appropriate follow up instructions.

and neo gtt. He was eventually transitioned to oral diltiazem
weaned off neo and transferred to the stepdown unit on POD#4.
His Hemodialysis was resumed. He had acute blood loss anemia and
received intermittent transfusions. His Coumadin resumed for
pre-op afib. Beta blocker was initiated once off neo. Chest
tubes and pacing wires were discontinued without complication.
The patient was evaluated by the physical therapy service for
assistance with strength and mobility. By the time of discharge
on POD #5 the patient was ambulating with a cane, the wound was
healing and pain was controlled with oral analgesics. The
patient was discharged to home in good condition with
appropriate follow up instructions.

anstamosis.  She presents now with crampy abdominal pain across

Crohn's disease

small bowel obstruction

Name:  ___              Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: CARDIOTHORACIC
 
Allergies: 
Penicillins / Bactrim
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
Right middle lobe nodule.

 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
___: Video-assisted thoracoscopic right middle lobectomy 
and mediastinal lymph node dissection.

 
History of Present Illness:
Ms. ___ is a ___ year old, former smoker, who in ___ 
had a small right lung nodule identified on a CXR  taken for an 
acute URI. She had a Chest CT which demonstrated a 8-mm 
ground-glass opacity in the anterior segment of the right upper 
lobe - a CT scan in ___ showed no change in the size of
the nodule and it was felt that this was possibly 
bronchoalveolar carcinoma with indolent growth. Several interval 
CT scans have been performed showing minimal interval growth of 
the RML ground-glass solid lesion, with increase in the soft 
tissue component, possibly BAC. In ___, she had another 
repeat CT
scan which showed no new nodules, the triangular mixed 
ground-glass and semi-solid nodule in the RML measured 16 x 11 
mm, compared to 15 x 10 mm in ___ and 11 x 9 mm in the 
original study in ___. She was admitted for Right VATS wedge 
resection with possible right middle lobectomy for the lesion. 
 
Past Medical History:
Osteoarthritis.
Anxiety/depression with posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD).
Detached retina in ___.
Atrial arrhythmia.
Cataract surgery in ___.
Carpal tunnel syndrome in ___.
Squamous cell carcinoma, right upper lobe.
Calcified granuloma in ___ treated with INH x 9 months.

 
Social History:
___
Family History:
non-contributory
 
Physical Exam:
VS: T: 99.2  HR: 76 SR  BP 116/74 Sats: 94% RA
General: ___ year-old female in no apparent distress
HEENT: normocephalic, mucus membranes moist
Neck: supple no lymphadenopathy
Card: RRR normal S1,S2, no murmur/gallop
Resp: decreased breath sounds right faint crackles at base, left 
clear
GI: benign
Extr: warm no edema
Incision: Right VATs clean, dry, intact
Neuro: non-focal
 
Pertinent Results:
___ WBC-11.0# RBC-4.21 Hgb-13.0 Hct-37.9 Plt ___
___ Glucose-135* UreaN-26* Creat-0.8 Na-140 K-3.6 Cl-106 
HCO3-23 
___ Calcium-9.6 Phos-4.3 Mg-1.9

CXR:
IMPRESSION:  
___
1. Slight improvement in postoperative atelectasis in right mid 
and lower 
lung regions. No new opacities to suggest a new site of 
infection. 
2. Unchanged right apical pneumothorax and loculated right 
pleural effusion.  
___: Similar size to the right pneumothorax after removal 
of chest 
tube. 
___: decrease in volume in the right lung consistent with 
recent operative procedure. Right chest tube is still present 
and there may be a tiny apical pneumothorax. The left base is 
clear, consistent with improving effusion and atelectasis. Some 
residual gas is seen in the subcutaneous tissues along the lower 
lateral chest wall on the right. 
___:
There is decrease in right lung volume which along with surgical 

sutures noted in that mid lung represents surgical changes. 
There is a chest tube present in the right lung. There is a 
small apical pneumothorax on the right. Bilateral small pleural 
effusions along with compressive atelectasis are present. 
Cardiomediastinal silhouette remains unchanged. 

 
Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ was admitted following Video-assisted 
thoracoscopic right middle
lobectomy and mediastinal lymph node dissection. She was 
extubated in the operating room, monitored in the PACU prior 
transfer to the floor.

Respiratory: incentive spirometer, ambulation she titrated off 
oxygen with supplemental with oxygen saturations 94% on room air

Chest tube: Right ___ drain to suction while in PACU, 
water-seal on floor with small amount of serosanguinous 
drainage.  The ___ was removed on ___ with residual small 
right apical pneumothorax.

Chest-film: serial chest films showed right lung volume loss 
consistent with surgery, resolving left effusion and 
atelectasis. 

Card: immediate postoperative she was in sinus rhythm.  On POD2 
she had a brief episode of atrial fibrillation which responded 
to beta-blockers.

GI: bowel regime and PPI 

Nutrition: tolerated a regular diet

Renal: normal renal function with good urine output

Pain; Dilaudid PCA transition to PO pain medication with good 
control

Neuro: non-focal

Disposition: ambulated in the halls continue to make steady 
progress and was discharged to home on ___ on 
beta-blockers.  She will follow-up with Dr. ___ as an 
outpatient.

 
Medications on Admission:
FLUTICASONE - 50 mcg Spray BID
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Fluticasone 50 mcg/Actuation Disk with Device Sig: One (1)  
Inhalation twice a day.  
2. Oxycodone 5 mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO every ___ hours as 
needed for pain for 2 weeks.
Disp:*45 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
3. Toprol XL 50 mg Tablet Sustained Release 24 hr Sig: One (1) 
Tablet Sustained Release 24 hr PO once a day.
Disp:*30 Tablet Sustained Release 24 hr(s)* Refills:*2*
4. Acetaminophen 325 mg Tablet Sig: Two (2) Tablet PO every six 
(6) hours as needed for pain.  

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Right middle lobe nodule.

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Call Dr. ___ ___ if you experience:
-Fever > 101 or chills
-Increased shortness of breath, cough or sputum productin
-Chest pain
-Incision develops drainage
-You may shower. No tub bathing or swimming until incision 
healed.
-Walk ___ times a day for ___ minutes to a goal of 30 minutes 
daily.

 
Followup Instructions:
___

Service: SURGERY
 
Allergies: 
No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
abdominal pain
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
none
 
History of Present Illness:
___ with a known left inguinal hernia that has been
increasingly painful and incarcerated for the past three days
during.  He reports vomiting three days ago but he thinks it was
due to food he had ate and not due to obstruction.  He denies
nausea, reports flatus and had a bowel movement yesterday which
was normal.  He denies fevers or chills or any other symptoms.

The hernia has been present for almost ___ years.  It was 
getting
larger over the last few months and he saw Dr. ___ in
clinic a few weeks ago with plans for repair in early ___.  He
denies a history of prior obstructive symptoms. 

 
Past Medical History:
asthma, GERD, PPD positive

 
Social History:
___
Family History:
non-contributory

 
Physical Exam:
98.9  73  112/57  16  99% RA
NAD, AAOx3
RRR, unlabored respirations
abdomen soft, NTND
incarcerated left inguinal hernia, palpable in inguinal canal,
moderately tender, no skin erythema
ext no edema

 
Pertinent Results:
___ 03:49PM   ___ COMMENTS-GREEN
___ 03:49PM   LACTATE-0.8
___ 03:40PM   GLUCOSE-80 UREA N-19 CREAT-1.0 SODIUM-141 
POTASSIUM-4.0 CHLORIDE-104 TOTAL CO2-26 ANION GAP-15
___ 03:40PM   estGFR-Using this
___ 03:40PM   PLT COUNT-178
___ 03:40PM   WBC-9.7 RBC-4.93 HGB-14.6 HCT-43.9 MCV-89 
MCH-29.6 MCHC-33.2 RDW-12.6
 
Brief Hospital Course:
The patient was seen in the ED and was thought to have an 
incarcerated inguinal hernia. The hernia was reduced manually, 
but the patient was admitted for observation. He did well 
overnight and his pain decreased. He is to call Dr. ___ 
___ and discuss moving the hernia repair to an earlier date.
 
Medications on Admission:
1. albuterol sulfate 90 mcg/actuation HFA Aerosol Inhaler Sig: 
___ Puffs Inhalation Q6H (every 6 hours) as needed for dyspnea.  

2. omeprazole 20 mg Capsule, Delayed Release(E.C.) Sig: One (1) 
Capsule, Delayed Release(E.C.) PO DAILY (Daily).  
3. fluticasone-salmeterol 500-50 mcg/dose Disk with Device Sig: 
One (1) Disk with Device Inhalation BID (2 times a day).  

 
Discharge Medications:
1. albuterol sulfate 90 mcg/actuation HFA Aerosol Inhaler Sig: 
___ Puffs Inhalation Q6H (every 6 hours) as needed for dyspnea.  

2. omeprazole 20 mg Capsule, Delayed Release(E.C.) Sig: One (1) 
Capsule, Delayed Release(E.C.) PO DAILY (Daily).  
3. fluticasone-salmeterol 500-50 mcg/dose Disk with Device Sig: 
One (1) Disk with Device Inhalation BID (2 times a day).  

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
left inguinal hernia
 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.
 
Discharge Instructions:
DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS:
You were admitted to the ___ surgery service for hernia pain.
General Discharge Instructions:
Please resume all regular home medications, unless specifically
advised not to take a particular medication.  Please take any 
new
medications as prescribed.
Please take the prescribed analgesic medications as needed.  You 
may
not drive or operate heavy machinery while taking narcotic 
analgesic
medications.  You may also take acetaminophen (Tylenol) as 
directed,
but do not exceed 4000 mg in one day.
Please get plenty of rest, continue to walk several times per 
day, and
drink adequate amounts of fluids.  Avoid strenuous physical 
activity
and refrain from heavy lifting greater than 10 lbs., until you
follow-up with your surgeon, who will instruct you further 
regarding
activity restrictions.  Please also follow-up with your primary 
care
physician.
Incision Care:
*Please call your surgeon or go to the emergency department if 
you
have increased pain, swelling, redness, or drainage from the 
incision
site.
*Avoid swimming and baths until cleared by your surgeon.
*You may shower and wash incisions with a mild soap and warm 
water.
Gently pat the area dry.
*If you have staples, they will be removed at your follow-up 
appointment.
*If you have steri-strips, they will fall off on their own.

Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. ___ is a ___ with hx lupus, etoh abuse, hep c s/p 
treatment who presents as a transfer after a fall while 
inebriated. He does not remember the fall. He was initially 
taken to ___ where he underwent pan scan 
and was
found to have right ___ through ___ displaced rib fractures.  He 
was transferred to ___ for further management and he was 
admitted to the Acute Care Surgery/Trauma service for further 
evaluation.

Given hx of alcohol abuse, the patient was started on CIWA. 
Social work was consulted to provide SBIRT.  Pain was managed 
with acetaminophen, ibuprofen and oxycodone.  The patient 
remained stable from a pulmonary standpoint; vital signs were 
routinely monitored. Good pulmonary toilet, early ambulation and 
incentive spirometry were encouraged throughout hospitalization. 
 Physical Therapy was consulted and felt patient was safe for 
discharge home.

At the time of discharge, the patient was doing well, afebrile 
and hemodynamically stable.  The patient was tolerating a diet, 
ambulating, voiding without assistance, and pain was well 
controlled.  The patient received discharge teaching and 
follow-up instructions with understanding verbalized and 
agreement with the discharge plan.

Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Right ___ lateral rib fractures

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted to the hospital after a fall and were found to 
have multiple right-sided rib fractures.  You received pain 
medication and your breathing was monitored.  You were evaluated 
by Physical Therapy who cleared you for discharge home. 

You are now ready to be discharged from the hospital.  Please 
follow the instructions below to ensure a safe recovery:

* Your injury caused right-sided rib fractures which can cause 
severe pain and subsequently cause you to take shallow breaths 
because of the pain.
 
* You should take your pain medication as directed to stay ahead 
of the pain otherwise you won't be able to take deep breaths. If 
the pain medication is too sedating take half the dose and 
notify your physician.
 
* Pneumonia is a complication of rib fractures.  In order to 
decrease your risk you must use your incentive spirometer 4 
times every hour while awake.  This will help expand the small 
airways in your lungs and assist in coughing up secretions that 
pool in the lungs.
 
* You will be more comfortable if you use a cough pillow to hold 
against your chest and guard your rib cage while coughing and 
deep breathing.
 
* Symptomatic relief with ice packs or heating pads for short 
periods may ease the pain.
 
* Narcotic pain medication can cause constipation therefore you 
should take a stool softener twice daily and increase your fluid 
and fiber intake if possible.
 
* Do NOT smoke
 
* If your doctor allows, non-steroidal ___ drugs 
are very effective in controlling pain ( ie, Ibuprofen, Motrin, 
Advil, Aleve, Naprosyn) but they have their own set of side 
effects so make sure your doctor approves.
 
* Return to the Emergency Room right away for any acute 
shortness of breath, increased pain or crackling sensation 
around your ribs (crepitus).

 
Followup Instructions:
___

You are now ready to be discharged from the hospital. Please
follow the instructions below to ensure a safe recovery:
* Your injury caused right-sided rib fractures which can cause
severe pain and subsequently cause you to take shallow breaths
because of the pain.
* You should take your pain medication as directed to stay ahead
of the pain otherwise you won't be able to take deep breaths. If
the pain medication is too sedating take half the dose and
notify your physician.
* Pneumonia is a complication of rib fractures. In order to
decrease your risk you must use your incentive spirometer 4
times every hour while awake. This will help expand the small
airways in your lungs and assist in coughing up secretions that
pool in the lungs.
* You will be more comfortable if you use a cough pillow to hold
against your chest and guard your rib cage while coughing and
deep breathing.
* Symptomatic relief with ice packs or heating pads for short
periods may ease the pain.
* Narcotic pain medication can cause constipation therefore you
should take a stool softener twice daily and increase your fluid
and fiber intake if possible.
* Do NOT smoke
* If your doctor allows, non-steroidal ___ drugs
are very effective in controlling pain ( ie, Ibuprofen, Motrin,
Advil, Aleve, Naprosyn) but they have their own set of side
effects so make sure your doctor approves.
* Return to the Emergency Room right away for any acute
shortness of breath, increased pain or crackling sensation
around your ribs (crepitus).
Followup Instructions:
___
