text:
Name:  ___                   Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: NEUROSURGERY
 
Allergies: 
gabapentin / amoxicillin / azithromycin / tramadol / tapentadol 
/ Lyrica
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
Radiuclopathy.
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
___ - Placement of spinal cord stimulator.

 
History of Present Illness:
___ with history of L5/S1 radiculopathy greater on L side and 
prior SCS here for elective placement of thoracic spinal cord 
stimulator. The risks and benefits of surgical intervention were 
discussed and the patient consented to the procedure. 
 
Past Medical History:
Radiuclopathy.
Hypertension. 
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
NC.
 
Physical Exam:
PHYSICAL EXAMINATION ON DISCHARGE:
Alert and oriented x3. Speech fluent and clear. Comprehension 
intact.
CN II-XII grossly intact.
Motor Examination: ___ strength in the upper and lower 
extremeties bilaterally. 
Incisions: clean, dry and intact. Closed with sutures. 

 
Brief Hospital Course:
The patient was taken to the operating room on the day of 
admission, ___ and underwent placement of a spinal cord 
stimulator. She tolerated the procedure well and was extubated 
in the operating room. She was then transferred to the PACU for 
close monitoring and later to the neuroscience floor.

On ___, the patient continued with pain and was encouraged to 
request pain medication when needed. She was not mobilizing 
well. It was determined she would remain an additional day.

On ___, the patient complained of back pain at the incision 
site. The Flexeril was discontinued and she was started on 
Valium for muscle spasm. She ambulated with the assistance of 
the nursing staff. 

On ___, the patient requested to remain in the hospital for an 
additional day.

On ___, the patient remained neurologically stable on 
examination. Her pain was better controlled on Valium for muscle 
spasm. She was ambulating independently, tolerating a diet and 
voiding without difficulty. She complained of constipation and 
received Magnesium Citrate. She was able to move her bowels. It 
was determined she would be discharged to home. 

 
Medications on Admission:
Flexeril 10mg
Vicodin PRN 

 
Discharge Medications:
1. Docusate Sodium 100 mg PO BID consitpation 
RX *docusate sodium 100 mg 1 tablet(s) by mouth BID. Disp #*30 
Tablet Refills:*0
2. HYDROmorphone (Dilaudid) ___ mg PO Q4H:PRN pain 
Hold for sedation or drowsiness. Do not drive while taking this 
medication.  
RX *hydromorphone [Dilaudid] 2 mg ___ tablet(s) by mouth every 4 
hours Disp #*60 Tablet Refills:*0
3. Diazepam 5 mg PO Q6H:PRN spasm 
Hold for sedation or drowsiness.  
RX *diazepam 5 mg 1 tablet by mouth every 6 hours Disp #*40 
Tablet Refills:*0
4. Acetaminophen 325-650 mg PO Q6H:PRN for fever or pain 
Do not exceed greater than 4g Acetaminophen in a 24-hour period. 
 
RX *acetaminophen 325 mg ___ tablet(s) by mouth every 6 hours 
Disp #*40 Tablet Refills:*0

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Radiculopathy.

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Surgery:
·        Your incision is closed with sutures. You will need 
suture removal. Please keep your incision dry until suture 
removal.
·        Do not apply any lotions or creams to the site. 
·        Please avoid swimming for two weeks after suture 
removal.
·        Call your surgeon if there are any signs of infection 
like redness, fever, or drainage. 

Activity:
·        We recommend that you avoid heavy lifting, running, 
climbing, or other strenuous exercise until your follow-up 
appointment.
·        You make take leisurely walks and slowly increase your 
activity at your own pace. ___ try to do too much all at once.
·        No driving while taking any narcotic or sedating 
medication. 
·        No contact sports until cleared by your neurosurgeon. 

Medications:
·        Please do NOT take any blood thinning medication 
(Aspirin, Ibuprofen, Plavix, Coumadin) until cleared by the 
neurosurgeon. 
·       You may use Acetaminophen (Tylenol) for minor discomfort 
if you are not otherwise restricted from taking this medication.
·        It is important to increase fluid intake while taking 
pain medications. We also recommend a stool softener like 
Colace. Pain medications can cause constipation. 
***      You are being discharged on Dilaudid for pain control. 
Do not take Vicodin while taking this medication. 

***      You are being discharged on Valium for treatment of 
muscle spasm. Do not take Flexeril while taking this medication.

 
Followup Instructions:
___

.

Brief Hospital Course:
*)Elevated Blood Pressure
Blood pressure was initially slightly elevated to the 130's/80's 
and given spontaneous rupture of membranes at term she was 
admitted to Labor and Delivery for augmentation of labor with 
pitocin. Her pre-eclampsia labs were all normal, and she had no 
symptoms of pre-eclampsia. Her blood pressure was not an active 
issue for the remainder of her hospital course.
.
*)Postpartum Hemorrhage
Labor progressed uneventfully and she had a spontaneous vaginal 
delivery, after which she had a postpartum hemorrhage with an 
estimated blood loss of 1000cc. She did have vital sign changes, 
with hypotension and tachycardia, with a hematocrit of 23.7. She 
was transfused 2 units of packed red blood cells, and her 
hematocrit demonstrated an overall appropriate increase to 27.8. 
Her vital signs were normal on discharge, and she was 
asymptomatic.     
 
Medications on Admission:
- pre-natal vitamins
- Zantac

hours) as needed.
Disp:50 Tablet(s) Refills:0

a day.
Disp:1 1 Refills:2

Home With Service

- postpartum after vaginal delivery
- postpartum hemorrhage

- stable

- discharge instruction sheet given

Name:  ___            Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: ORTHOPAEDICS
 
Allergies: 
seasonal
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
Right leg pain
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
Extensive curettage, recurrent giant cell tumor, right distal 
femur and open knee manipulation.

 
History of Present Illness:
___ is a ___ year old who was diagnosed with Giant Cell 
tumor of his right distal femur after a pathologic fracture.  
This was fixed with open reduction and internal fixation along 
with curettage at the time.  He did well initially but started 
to develop increasing pain.  This was followed and continued to 
worsen and x-ray was very suspicious for recurrent Giant Cell in 
the distal femur around the previous bone grafting.
 
Past Medical History:
Torticollis and club feet as newborn
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
Non-contributory
 
Physical Exam:
Well-developed, well-nourished. No acute distress
Chest clear to auscultation bilaterally
Heart rate and rhythm is regular
Abdomen is soft, nontender, nondistended
Extremities are well-perfused, and warm
Skin is intact
Right lower extremity with full distal strength and sensation.  
The incision over the distal lateral thigh is clean, dry, and 
intact with periincisional ecchymoses.
 
Pertinent Results:
___ 05:16AM BLOOD WBC-9.1 RBC-3.88* Hgb-11.9* Hct-34.0* 
MCV-88 MCH-30.8 MCHC-35.2* RDW-12.3 Plt ___
___ 05:16AM BLOOD Glucose-107* UreaN-14 Creat-0.9 Na-136 
K-4.1 Cl-98 HCO3-32 AnGap-10
 
Brief Hospital Course:
___ tolerated the procedure well.  He was placed in a 
continuous passive motion device starting at 0 - 40 degrees.  An 
epidural was inserted prior to the case for post-operative pain 
control and this was adjusted and ___ was able to tolerate 
the CPM without distress.  The CPM was increased by what 
___ could tolerate.  By POD#2 he was moving ___ degrees 
without much discomfort.  The dressings were chagned on POD#2 
and the wound was benign except for some ecchymosis.  The 
epidural was removed on POD#2 along with the foley catheter.  
His pain was well controlled and ___ was ready to go home.  
At the time of discharge he was afebrile, tolerating oral food 
and drink, pain controlled on oral pain medications, and voiding 
spontaneously.  He will be discharged with a CPM device and 
outpatient physical therapy.
 
Medications on Admission:
None
 
Discharge Medications:
1. CPM
2. acetaminophen 650 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO every six 
(6) hours as needed for pain.  
3. aspirin 325 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily).  
4. hydromorphone 2 mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO Q4H (every 4 
hours) as needed for pain.
5. docusate sodium 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO BID (2 
times a day).  

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
recurrent giant cell tumor right distal femur

 
Discharge Condition:
stable

 
Discharge Instructions:
Remove dressing tomorrow.  Apply dry dressing only if wound has 
drainage, otherwise leave open to air.  Maximum 25% of your 
weight on your right leg.

___

seasonal
Attending: ___.
Chief Complaint:
Right leg pain
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
Extensive curettage, recurrent giant cell tumor, right distal
femur and open knee manipulation.
History of Present Illness:
___ is a ___ year old who was diagnosed with Giant Cell
tumor of his right distal femur after a pathologic fracture.
This was fixed with open reduction and internal fixation along
with curettage at the time. He did well initially but started
to develop increasing pain. This was followed and continued to
worsen and x-ray was very suspicious for recurrent Giant Cell in
the distal femur around the previous bone grafting.
Past Medical History:
Torticollis and club feet as newborn
Social History:
___
Family History:
Non-contributory
Physical Exam:
Well-developed, well-nourished. No acute distress
Chest clear to auscultation bilaterally
Heart rate and rhythm is regular
Abdomen is soft, nontender, nondistended
Extremities are well-perfused, and warm
Skin is intact
Right lower extremity with full distal strength and sensation.
The incision over the distal lateral thigh is clean, dry, and
intact with periincisional ecchymoses.
Pertinent Results:
___ 05:16AM BLOOD WBC-9.1 RBC-3.88* Hgb-11.9* Hct-34.0*
MCV-88 MCH-30.8 MCHC-35.2* RDW-12.3 Plt ___
___ 05:16AM BLOOD Glucose-107* UreaN-14 Creat-0.9 Na-136
K-4.1 Cl-98 HCO3-32 AnGap-10
Brief Hospital Course:
___ tolerated the procedure well. He was placed in a
continuous passive motion device starting at 0 - 40 degrees. An
epidural was inserted prior to the case for post-operative pain
control and this was adjusted and ___ was able to tolerate
the CPM without distress. The CPM was increased by what
___ could tolerate. By POD#2 he was moving ___ degrees
without much discomfort. The dressings were chagned on POD#2
and the wound was benign except for some ecchymosis. The
epidural was removed on POD#2 along with the foley catheter.
His pain was well controlled and ___ was ready to go home.
At the time of discharge he was afebrile, tolerating oral food
and drink, pain controlled on oral pain medications, and voiding
spontaneously. He will be discharged with a CPM device and
outpatient physical therapy.
Medications on Admission:
None
Discharge Medications:
1. CPM
2. acetaminophen 650 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO every six
(6) hours as needed for pain.
3. aspirin 325 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily).
4. hydromorphone 2 mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO Q4H (every 4
hours) as needed for pain.
5. docusate sodium 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO BID (2
times a day).
Discharge Disposition:
Home
Discharge Diagnosis:
recurrent giant cell tumor right distal femur
Discharge Condition:
stable
Discharge Instructions:
Remove dressing tomorrow. Apply dry dressing only if wound has
drainage, otherwise leave open to air. Maximum 25% of your
weight on your right leg.
Followup Instructions:
___

Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ underwent a D&C for retained products of conception- 
please see operative note for intraop details. She was admitted 
overnight secondary to a high estimated blood loss of 1200 cc 
during the procedure. She received 1000mcg of cytotec intraop. 
Post-operatively her Hct was found to be 22.3 from 27.8 pre-op. 
On the evening of POD0 she complained of some dizziness. Given 
she was symptomatic, she was transfused 2 units of PRBC. Her Hct 
on POD1 increased appropriately to 26.3. Her bleeding decreased 
in amount and she had normal coags. She was discharged home on 
POD1 in stable condition.

retained products of conception
blood loss anemia

stable

than 1 pad/ hour

MCV-89 MCH-33.5* MCHC-37.8* RDW-12.2 Plt ___
 
Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. ___ was admitted to the service of Dr. ___ for a 
lumbar fusion L4-S1.  He was informed and consented and elected 
to proceed.  Please see Operative Note for procedure in detail.  

Post-operatively he was given antibiotics and pain medication.  
A hemovac drain was placed intra-operatively and this was 
removed POD 2.  Hematocrit was noticed to be low and he was 
transfused PRBCs.  he developed a post-op fever but defervesced 
with use of the incentive spirometer.  His bladder catheter was 
removed POD 3 and his diet was advanced without difficulty.  He 
was able to work with physical therapy for strength and balance. 
 He was discharged in good condition and will follow up in the 
Orthopaedic Spine clinic.

 
Medications on Admission:
Advil
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Docusate Sodium 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO BID (2 
times a day).
Disp:*60 Capsule(s)* Refills:*2*
2. Hydromorphone 2 mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO Q3H (every 3 
hours) as needed.
Disp:*100 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
3. Oxycodone 30 mg Tablet Sustained Release 12 hr Sig: One (1) 
Tablet Sustained Release 12 hr PO Q12H (every 12 hours).
Disp:*60 Tablet Sustained Release 12 hr(s)* Refills:*0*
4. Bisacodyl 5 mg Tablet, Delayed Release (E.C.) Sig: Two (2) 
Tablet, Delayed Release (E.C.) PO DAILY (Daily) as needed.
Disp:*60 Tablet, Delayed Release (E.C.)(s)* Refills:*0*
5. Cyclobenzaprine 10 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO TID (3 
times a day) as needed.
Disp:*60 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
6. Diazepam 5 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO Q6H (every 6 
hours) as needed.
Disp:*60 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Lumbar spondylosis and disc degeneration
Post-op blood loss anemia
Post-op fever
 
Discharge Condition:
Good
 
Discharge Instructions:
Please continue to take your pain medication with an over the 
counter laxative.  Call the clinic should you experience any 
redness, swelling or discharge at the incision site.  Call the 
clinic if you experience a temperature greater than 101 degrees. 
 
Do not smoke.  Do not lifting anything greater than a gallon of 
milk.
Call the clinic for any additional concerns.

Physical Therapy:
Activity:  Activity as tolerated
Lumbar corset for ambulation.

Treatment Frequency:
Please continue to change the dressing daily with dry, sterile 
gauze.
 
Followup Instructions:
___

Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ presented to ___ holding at ___ on ___ 
for hemorrhoidectomy. She tolerated the procedure well (Please 
see operative note for further details). After a brief stay in 
the PACU, she was discharged home, however, before leaving the 
hospital premises she noticed significant bleeding from her 
rectum. Her packing was replaced and the bleeding was found to 
have stopped. She was admitted for overnight observation. She 
had no bleeding overnight, and her hematocrit was found to be 
stable (32.7 post-operatively to 29.8 on POD1). 

On POD1, the patient was discharged to home. At discharge, she 
was tolerating a regular diet, passing flatus, voiding, and 
ambulating independently. She will follow-up in the clinic in 
___ weeks. This information was communicated to the patient 
directly prior to discharge.

[ ] Staple Line Bleed

4. OxycoDONE (Immediate Release)  ___ mg PO Q4H:PRN Pain

RX *ondansetron HCl 4 mg 1 tablet(s) by mouth Every 8 hours Disp 
#*20 Tablet Refills:*0
6. Synthroid ___ PO daily

Home

Hemorrhoids

Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Please resume all regular home medications, unless specifically 
advised not to take a particular medication.  Also, please take 
any new medications as prescribed.
 
Please get plenty of rest, continue to ambulate several times 
per day, and drink adequate amounts of fluids.  Avoid lifting

surgeon, who will instruct you further regarding activity 
restrictions.
 
Avoid driving or operating heavy machinery while taking pain 
medications.
 
Please follow-up with your surgeon as advised.

Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
Neurosyhillis
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
___ line placement
 
History of Present Illness:
This is a ___ year old man with recent diagnosis of HIV ___ 
(CD4 count 146), diagnosed with syphilis one week ago (based on 
blood work, per patient history) treated with PCN and then 
diagnosed with ?neurosyphillis based on LP yesterday done for 
visual complaints, presenting today for "admission to hospital" 
for PICC placement and PCN. No cough, no N/V. Does have runny 
nose. No HA or weakness in extremities. Visual changes for 1 
month (left eye not as sharp). Normal gait per patient. In 
___, he underwent ophtho. evaluation and was 
apparently diagnosed with optic neuritis and vitritis. LP 
performed ___ at ___ showed CSF glucose 34, protein 103, 
CSF WBC 3, RBC 76 (not clear which tube this was). Patient was 
sent from ___ for Penicillin 4 million units IV q4 hours x 14 
days.  
.  
In the ED, initial VS: 100.3, 108, 135/81, 18, 100% RA. Neuro 
exam normal except for tandem ataxia. Blood cultures sent. CBC 
WNL, lactate 1.4, lytes normal. Tylenol and Acyclovir 750 mg 
given due to blood cells on LP and concern for herpes 
encephalitis. Cultures were drawn given the ___ fever. 
Vital signs on transfer, 99.8, 100, 137/73, 20, 100%/RA.  
.  
ROS: Currently, patient says that he feels fine. He denies 
headache but does say that for about one month his vision in his 
left eye has not been as sharp as his right. He denies mental 
status change, confusion, weakness of balance difficulties. 
Cardiorespiratory review of systems is negative. Patient denies 
rash or joint pain. No abdominal pain, no diarrhea, and no 
nausea.

 
Past Medical History:
- HIV
- Recent diagnosis of syphilis as above
- ?depression  

 
Social History:
___
Family History:
___.
 
Physical Exam:
Vitals: T 99.0, BP 120/66, HR 82, RR 18, satting 99% RA.
General: A ___ ___ man in no distress.
HEENT: NC/AT, MMM, no conjunctival injection.
Chest: RRR, normal s1/s2, no m/r/g.
Lungs: Clear bilaterally anterior fields.
Abdomen: Soft, ___, normal bowel sounds.
Extremities: Warm, ___.
Neurological: Oriented x3, moving all extremities.

 
Pertinent Results:
1. Labs on admission:
___ 06:30PM BLOOD ___ 
___ Plt ___
___ 06:30PM BLOOD ___ 
___
___ 06:54PM BLOOD ___
.
2. Labs on discharge:
___ 06:35AM BLOOD ___ 
___ Plt ___
___ 06:35AM BLOOD ___ 
___
.
3. Microbiology:
Blood cultures (___): NGTD
.
4. Imaging/diagnostics:
- CXR (___): Left PICC extends to low SVC.
 
Brief Hospital Course:
___ year old man with recent dx of HIV ___ (CD4 count 146) 
admitted for ___ line placement to treat neurosyphilis.  
.  
# Neurosyphillis: In the context of recent left eye blurred 
vision, positive RPR titer ___, HIV positive with CD 4 
146, and abnormal lumbar puncture, diagnosis of neurosyphillis 
was made. Patient started on IV penicillin G. PICC line placed. 
He will continue Penicillin G Potassium 4 Million Units IV Q4H 
for 14 days after discharge.
. 
# HIV: Plan for initiation of HAART treatment per outpatient 
___ provider. COntinued on PCP prophylaxis with ___
.
# Other medical issues: Continued on Citalopram. 
.
Pending labs on discharge: 
(To be followed by PCP)
- Blood cultures (___): NGTD

 
Medications on Admission:
- Bactrim for PCP prophylaxis
- citalopram 20 mg daily

 
Discharge Medications:
1. penicillin G potassium 20 million unit Recon Soln Sig: Four 
(4) million units Injection Q4H (every 4 hours) for 14 days: Day 
1 = ___, Day 14 (last day) = ___.
Disp:*17 reconstituted solutions (20 million units each)* 
Refills:*0*
2. ___ mg Tablet Sig: One (1) 
Tablet PO DAILY (Daily).  
3. citalopram 20 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily). 
 
4. Saline Flush 0.9 % Syringe Sig: One (1) syringe Injection 
once a day for 14 days.
Disp:*20 syringes* Refills:*0*
5. Heparin Flush 10 unit/mL Kit Sig: One (1) kit Intravenous 
once a day for 14 days.
Disp:*14 kits* Refills:*0*

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home With Service
 
Facility:
___
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
PRIMARY DIAGNOSIS:
Neurosyphilis
Positive HIV
.
SECONDARY DIAGNOSES:
Depression

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Mr. ___, you were admitted to the ___ 
___ because you had positive blood test for syphilis. We gave 
you antibiotics to treat that. We put in a PICC line so you can 
go home and continue getting antibiotics. You will be following 
up with your primary care doctor.
.

- Penicillin G Potassium 4 Million Units IV Q4H 
CHANGED: none
REMOVED: none

text:
Name:  ___                Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: OTOLARYNGOLOGY
 
Allergies: 
Patient recorded as having No Known Allergies to Drugs
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
Oropharyngeal mass 
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
Transoral excision of oropharyngeal mass with z plasty 
reconstruction of palate
 
History of Present Illness:
Patient is a ___ woman who presents with a mass of her 
mouth.  She has had an ongoing lesion in her mouth in the area 
of the soft palate now
over the past year.  She notes it has now been slowly enlarging. 
 Patient with recent biopsy and diagnosis of adenocarcinoma of 
the soft palate. MRI on ___ demonstrated a 4 x 3 x 3.5 cm 
soft tissue mass involving the soft
palate predominantly on the right side.
 
Past Medical History:
Patient with no other significant history.  Patient does have a 
history of kidney stones and occasional alcohol use.  Previous 
surgeries include C sections in ___ and ___.  
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
Patient has no significant family history
 
Physical Exam:
On exam:
Vitals:  Temp-98.4 Blood Pressure 127/78, Resp rate 74, 100% on 
Room Air
Gen: NAD, pleasant, AOx3
Head/neck: EEOM, CN2-12 intact, large soft palate mass on the 
right displacing uvula.
Heart:  Regular rate and rhythm, no murmurs
Lungs: CTA Bilaterally, no wheezing
Abd: Soft, NT, ND, +BS
Extremities:  Bilateral pulses +, No weakness, no edema

 
Pertinent Results:
VIDEO OROPHARYNGEAL SWALLOW 
 
Brief Hospital Course:
Patient is a ___. female s/p resection of soft palate 
pleomorphic adenoma with palatal Z-plasty reconstruction.  
Patient tolerated the procedure well.  atient admitted to the 
PACU post op and was transferred to the floors. Patient received 
morphine IV for pain and was placed on continuous o2 monitoring. 
 Patient had a nasal trumpet in place.  Patient was kept NPo 
overnight and underwent a speach and swallow evaluation the next 
morning. Patient passed speecha and swallow evaluation and was 
permitted to take in clear liquids and was advanced to a soft 
diet. Patient given IV Unasyn and discharged on Augmentin 
liquid.  Patient also given liquid vicodin for pain and place on 
a medrol dose pack upon discharge.

 
Medications on Admission:
Ampicillin-Sulbactam 3 g IV Q6H  
Morphine Sulfate ___ mg IV Q2H:PRN pain 
hold for sedation, RR < 10  
Morphine Sulfate ___ mg IV PRN PAIN Q5MIN 
Maximum total dose not to exceed 0.3 mg/kg PACU ONLY  
Ondansetron 4 mg IV X1 PRN nausea/vomiting 

 

 
Discharge Medications:
1. Augmentin 400-57 mg/5 mL Suspension for Reconstitution Sig: 
Ten (10) mL PO twice a day for 7 days.
Disp:*140 ml* Refills:*1*
2. Roxicet ___ mg/5 mL Solution Sig: ___ mL PO every four (4) 
hours as needed for pain.
Disp:*300 ml* Refills:*0*
3. Medrol (Pak) 4 mg Tablets, Dose Pack Sig: One (1) Tablets, 
Dose Pack PO once a day for 6 days: Please use as directed.  
Start with 24mg on day 1, 20 mg on day two, 16 mg on day 3, 12 
mg on day 4, 8mg on day 5, and then 4 mg on day 6 then stop.
Disp:*21 Tablets, Dose Pack(s)* Refills:*0*

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Soft palate pleomorphic adenoma 

 
Discharge Condition:
Stable

 
Discharge Instructions:
Seek immediate medical attention for fever >101.5, chills, 
increased redness, swelling or discharge from incision, chest 
pain, shortness of breath, or anything else that is troubling 
you. OK to shower. No strenuous exercise or heavy lifting until 
follow up appointment, at least. Do not drive or drink alcohol 
while taking narcotic pain medications. Narcotic pain 
medications may cause constipation, if this occurs take an over 
the counter stool softener. Resume all home medications.  Please 
elevate your head when lying down and ingest food and liquids 
slowly as to prevent aspiration.  Rinse mouth with saline after 
meals. 
 
Followup Instructions:
___

text:
Name:  ___              Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: NEUROLOGY
 
Allergies: 
___
 
Attending: ___
 
Chief Complaint:
dizziness
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
None

 
History of Present Illness:
The patient is a ___ year old right handed woman with a history 
of RA, hyperlipidemia and diet controlled DM who presents with 
sudden onset of room spinning today around 7pm.

The patient reports feeling in her usual good state of health 
prior to this. She was lying down watching TV and when she stood 
up she had the sudden sensation that the room was spinning. She 
was unable to walk without falling and felt that she kept 
falling to the right. She had some mild nausea with this. The 
sensation was worse when moving her head to the right but 
generally
persisted until she was in the ED around 9:30 pm. She denies 
clumsiness, weakness, sensory changes, diplopia or 
lightheadedness. She has had a right/vertex headache off and on 
for the past few weeks that sometimes radiates to her right 
neck. It is throbbing in nature. It came on this evening after 
the vertigo started. She also has been bothered by her right ear 
for the past few weeks. She has a sensation of fullness and it 
feels itchy. No tinnitus or hearing loss.

On neuro ROS, the pt denies loss of vision, blurred vision, 
diplopia, dysarthria, dysphagia, lightheadedness, tinnitus or 
hearing difficulty. Denies difficulties producing or 
comprehending speech.  Denies focal weakness, numbness, 
parasthesiae. No bowel or bladder incontinence or retention.

text:
Name:  ___                     Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: ORTHOPAEDICS
 
Allergies: 
No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
Neck and arm pain
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
ACDF C4-7
 
History of Present Illness:
Mr. ___ has a long history of neck and arm pain.  He has 
attempted conservative therapy but has failed.  He now presents 
for surgical intervention.
 
Past Medical History:
Spinal stenosis
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
N/C
 
Physical Exam:
A&O X 3; NAD
RRR
CTA B
Abd soft NT/ND
BUE- good strength at deltoid, biceps, triceps, wrist 
flexion/extension, finger flexion/extension and intrinics; 
sensation intact C5-T1 dermatomes; - ___, reflexes 
symmetric at biceps, triceps and brachioradialis
BLE- good strength at hip flexion/extension, knee 
flexion/extension, ankle dorsiflexion and plantar flexion, 
___ sensation intact L1-S1 dermatomes; - clonus, reflexes 
symmetric at quads and Achilles

 
Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. ___ was admitted to the service of Dr. ___ for an 
anterior cervical fusion.  He was informed and consented and 
elected to proceed.  Please see Operative Note for procedure in 
detail.  
Post-operatively he was given antibiotics and pain medication.  
His bladder catheter was removed POD 1 and his diet was advanced 
without difficulty.  He was able to work with physical therapy 
for strength and balance.  He was discharged in good condition 
and will follow up in the Orthopaedic Spine clinic.

 
Medications on Admission:
escialopram
 
Discharge Medications:
1. oxycodone 5 mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO Q3H (every 3 hours) 
as needed for pain.
Disp:*100 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
2. diazepam 5 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO Q6H (every 6 
hours) as needed for spasm.
Disp:*90 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
3. docusate sodium 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO BID (2 
times a day).
Disp:*60 Capsule(s)* Refills:*2*
4. escitalopram 10 mg Tablet Sig: Two (2) Tablet PO DAILY 
(Daily).  

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Cervical stenosis and spondylosis
 
Discharge Condition:
Good
 
Discharge Instructions:
You have undergone the following operation: ANTERIOR cervical 
fusion C4-7 

 
Immediately after the operation:
 

 
-Activity: You should not lift anything greater than 10 lbs for 
2 weeks. You will be more comfortable if you do not sit or stand 
more than ~45 minutes without getting up and walking around.
 

 
-Rehabilitation/ Physical Therapy: 
 
o2-3 times a day you should go for a walk for ___ minutes as 
part of your recovery. You can walk as much as you can tolerate. 

 
oLimit any kind of lifting.
 

 
-Diet: Eat a normal healthy diet. You may have some constipation 
after surgery. You have been given medication to help with this 
issue.
 

 
-Brace: You have been given a collar. This is to be worn when 
you are walking. You may take it off when sitting in a chair or 
while lying in bed.
 

 
-Wound Care: Remove the dressing in 2 days. If the incision is 
draining cover it with a new sterile dressing. If it is dry then 
you can leave the incision open to the air. Once the incision is 
completely dry (usually ___ days after the operation) you may 
take a shower. Do not soak the incision in a bath or pool. If 
the incision starts draining at anytime after surgery, do not 
get the incision wet. Cover it with a sterile dressing. Call the 
office. 
 

 
-You should resume taking your normal home medications. No 
NSAIDs.
 

 
-You have also been given Additional Medications to control your 
pain. Please allow 72 hours for refill of narcotic 
prescriptions, so please plan ahead. You can either have them 
mailed to your home or pick them up at the clinic located on 
___. We are not allowed to call in or fax narcotic 
prescriptions (oxycontin, oxycodone, percocet) to your pharmacy. 
In addition, we are only allowed to write for pain medications 
for 90 days from the date of surgery.
 

 
Please call the office if you have a fever>101.5 degrees 
Fahrenheit and/or drainage from your wound.
 

 
Followup Instructions:
___

text:
Name:  ___              Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: NEUROSURGERY
 
Allergies: 
Macrobid
 
Attending: ___
 
Chief Complaint:
Back pain
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
L5-S1 microdiscectomy
 
History of Present Illness:
Mrs. ___ is a ___ female who
presents with a right S1 radiculopathy with corresponding 
imaging
findings.
She had this for about three to four months and exhausted
physical therapy, activity modification and injection.
We spent about 30 minutes discussing the surgery.  We discussed
complications, risks, and benefits including, but not limited to
coma, stroke and death, worsening of current condition, need for
further surgery, worsening or new back pain, paralysis, nerve
injury leading to weakness in her legs, bowel injury, vascular
injury, spinal fluid leak , meningitis and incontinence.
The patient also notes that the symptoms may not improve.  We
talked about postoperative recovery period and restrictions.
We discussed about indications, alternatives, complications,
risks and benefits and postoperative recovery period.  She would
like to go ahead and we will schedule her for a right L5-S1
microdiscectomy.

 
Past Medical History:
Infertility s/p Clomid treatment, gestational diabetes, 
hypothyroidism/hashimoto's disease

SURGICAL HISTORY:  C-section ___, hemorrhoid banding ___

 
Social History:
___
Family History:
Non-contributory
 
Physical Exam:
On discharge: A&Ox3, MAE ___. Incision w dermabond, cd&i. 

 
Brief Hospital Course:
On ___, patient presented to ___ for microdiskectomy L5-S1 for 
lumbar stenosis. Her intraoperative course was uneventful, 
please refer to the operative note for further details. She was 
extubated and transferred to ___ for close observation. 
On ___, the patient remained neurologically and hemodynamically 
intact. She expressed readiness to be discharged home. She was 
discharged home in stable conditions, all discharge instructions 
and follow up were given prior to discharge. 
 
Medications on Admission:
Levothyroxine 125 mcg daily
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Acetaminophen 325-650 mg PO Q6H:PRN for fever or pain 
Do not exceed more than 4grams in 24hrs.  
2. Bisacodyl 10 mg PO/PR DAILY:PRN constipation 
3. Diazepam 2 mg PO Q8H:PRN muscle spasm 
Do not drive while taking this medication  
RX *diazepam 2 mg 1 tab by mouth Q 8hrs Disp #*30 Tablet 
Refills:*0
4. Docusate Sodium 100 mg PO BID 
5. Levothyroxine Sodium 125 mcg PO DAILY 
6. OxycoDONE (Immediate Release)  ___ mg PO Q4H:PRN pain 
please do not drive or operate mechanical machinery while taking 
pain meds.  
RX *oxycodone 5 mg ___ tablet(s) by mouth Q 4hrs. Disp #*60 
Tablet Refills:*0

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Lumbar stenosis

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Surgery
Your incision is closed with dissolvable sutures underneath 
the skin and steri strips. You do not need suture removal. 
Do not apply any lotions or creams to the site. 
Please avoid swimming for two weeks after suture/staple 
removal.
Call your surgeon if there are any signs of infection like 
redness, fever, or drainage. 

Activity
We recommend that you avoid heavy lifting, running, climbing, 
or other strenuous exercise until your follow-up appointment.
You may take leisurely walks and slowly increase your activity 
at your own pace. ___ try to do too much all at once.
No driving while taking any narcotic or sedating medication. 
No contact sports until cleared by your neurosurgeon. 

Medications
Please do NOT take any blood thinning medication (Aspirin, 
Ibuprofen, Plavix, Coumadin) until cleared by the neurosurgeon. 
You may take Ibuprofen/ Motrin for pain.
You may use Acetaminophen (Tylenol) for minor discomfort if 
you are not otherwise restricted from taking this medication.
It is important to increase fluid intake while taking pain 
medications. We also recommend a stool softener like Colace. 
Pain medications can cause constipation. 

When to Call Your Doctor at ___ for:
Severe pain, swelling, redness or drainage from the incision 
site. 
Fever greater than 101.5 degrees Fahrenheit
New weakness or changes in sensation in your arms or legs.
 
Followup Instructions:
___

injury leading to weakness in her legs, bowel injury, vascular
injury, spinal fluid leak , meningitis and incontinence.
The patient also notes that the symptoms may not improve. We
talked about postoperative recovery period and restrictions.
We discussed about indications, alternatives, complications,
risks and benefits and postoperative recovery period. She would
like to go ahead and we will schedule her for a right L5-S1
microdiscectomy.
Past Medical History:
Infertility s/p Clomid treatment, gestational diabetes,
hypothyroidism/hashimoto's disease
SURGICAL HISTORY: C-section ___, hemorrhoid banding ___
Social History:
___
Family History:
Non-contributory
Physical Exam:
On discharge: A&Ox3, MAE ___. Incision w dermabond, cd&i.
Brief Hospital Course:
On ___, patient presented to ___ for microdiskectomy L5-S1 for
lumbar stenosis. Her intraoperative course was uneventful,
please refer to the operative note for further details. She was
extubated and transferred to ___ for close observation.
On ___, the patient remained neurologically and hemodynamically
intact. She expressed readiness to be discharged home. She was
discharged home in stable conditions, all discharge instructions
and follow up were given prior to discharge.
Medications on Admission:
Levothyroxine 125 mcg daily
Discharge Medications:
1. Acetaminophen 325-650 mg PO Q6H:PRN for fever or pain
Do not exceed more than 4grams in 24hrs.
2. Bisacodyl 10 mg PO/PR DAILY:PRN constipation
3. Diazepam 2 mg PO Q8H:PRN muscle spasm
Do not drive while taking this medication
RX *diazepam 2 mg 1 tab by mouth Q 8hrs Disp #*30 Tablet
Refills:*0
4. Docusate Sodium 100 mg PO BID
5. Levothyroxine Sodium 125 mcg PO DAILY
6. OxycoDONE (Immediate Release) ___ mg PO Q4H:PRN pain
please do not drive or operate mechanical machinery while taking
pain meds.
RX *oxycodone 5 mg ___ tablet(s) by mouth Q 4hrs. Disp #*60
Tablet Refills:*0
Discharge Disposition:
Home
Discharge Diagnosis:
Lumbar stenosis
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.
Discharge Instructions:
Surgery
Your incision is closed with dissolvable sutures underneath
the skin and steri strips. You do not need suture removal.
Do not apply any lotions or creams to the site.
Please avoid swimming for two weeks after suture/staple
removal.
Call your surgeon if there are any signs of infection like
redness, fever, or drainage.
Activity
We recommend that you avoid heavy lifting, running, climbing,
or other strenuous exercise until your follow-up appointment.
You may take leisurely walks and slowly increase your activity
at your own pace. ___ try to do too much all at once.
No driving while taking any narcotic or sedating medication.
No contact sports until cleared by your neurosurgeon.
Medications
Please do NOT take any blood thinning medication (Aspirin,
Ibuprofen, Plavix, Coumadin) until cleared by the neurosurgeon.
You may take Ibuprofen/ Motrin for pain.
You may use Acetaminophen (Tylenol) for minor discomfort if
you are not otherwise restricted from taking this medication.
It is important to increase fluid intake while taking pain
medications. We also recommend a stool softener like Colace.
Pain medications can cause constipation.
When to Call Your Doctor at ___ for:
Severe pain, swelling, redness or drainage from the incision
site.
Fever greater than 101.5 degrees Fahrenheit
New weakness or changes in sensation in your arms or legs.
Followup Instructions:
___

text:
Name:  ___                 Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: UROLOGY
 
Allergies: 
No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
Benign prostatic hypertrophy, elevated prostate-specific 
antigen, lower urinary tract symptoms.

 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
BIPOLAR TRANSURETHERAL RESECTION PROSTATE

 
History of Present Illness:
Mr. ___ is known to have BPH and lower urinary tract 
symptoms along with increased PSA.  He is now ___ years old.  He 
feels that his symptoms occasionally are worse.  He has had also 
two episodes of hematuria.  He has nocturia x 2.  Stream is not 
significantly changed, but he has some worsened urgency at 
times.
 
Past Medical History:
Otherwise, noncontributory.  Appetite is excellent, bowels are 
regular.

GERD
Two prior prostate procedures (___)
Allergic Rhinits/Seasonal Allergies
constipation
s/p RIGHT knee arthroscopy
s/p LEFT eye pterygium excision

 
Social History:
___
Family History:
non-contributory
 
Physical Exam:
WDWN male, nad, avss
Abdomen soft, nt/nd
foley catheter in place
extremities w/out edema, pitting, pain
 
 
Pertinent Results:
___ 06:35AM BLOOD WBC-7.8 RBC-4.43* Hgb-14.2 Hct-40.9 
MCV-93 MCH-32.0 MCHC-34.6 RDW-13.0 Plt ___
___ 06:35AM BLOOD Glucose-124* UreaN-9 Creat-0.9 Na-139 
K-4.4 Cl-102 HCO3-33* AnGap-8
 
Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. ___ was admitted to Urology service after bipolar 
transurethral resection of prostate. No concerning 
intraoperative events occurred; please see dictated operative 
note for details. He patient received ___ antibiotic 
prophylaxis. The patient's postoperative course was 
uncomplicated. He received intravenous antibiotics and 
continuous bladder irrigation overnight. On POD1 the CBI was 
discontinued and Foley catheter was left in place. He was given 
additional intravenous doses of antibiotics on POD1 prior to 
discharge. His urine was clear and without clots. He remained 
a-febrile throughout his hospital stay.  At discharge, the 
patient had pain well controlled with oral pain medications, 
was tolerating regular diet, ambulating without assistance, and 
versed on foley catheter care.  He was given pyridium and oral 
pain medications on discharge and a course of antibiotics along 
with explicit instructions to follow up in clinic.
 
Medications on Admission:
The Preadmission Medication list is accurate and complete.
1. Multivitamins W/minerals 1 TAB PO DAILY 
2. Loratadine 10 mg PO DAILY allergic rhinitis 
3. Aspirin EC 81 mg PO DAILY 

 
Discharge Medications:
1. Loratadine 10 mg PO DAILY allergic rhinitis 
2. Multivitamins W/minerals 1 TAB PO DAILY 
3. Acetaminophen 650 mg PO Q6H:PRN pain, fever>100 
4. Docusate Sodium 100 mg PO BID 
RX *docusate sodium [Colace] 100 mg ONE capsule(s) by mouth 
twice a day Disp #*60 Capsule Refills:*0
5. Oxycodone-Acetaminophen (5mg-325mg) 1 TAB PO Q4H:PRN 
breakthrough pain only(score>4) 
RX *oxycodone-acetaminophen [Percocet] 5 mg-325 mg ONE tablet(s) 
by mouth Q6hrs Disp #*10 Tablet Refills:*0
6. Aspirin EC 81 mg PO DAILY 
7. Phenazopyridine 100 mg PO TID Duration: 3 Days 
RX *phenazopyridine [Pyridium] 100 mg ONE tablet(s) by mouth 
Q8hrs Disp #*9 Tablet Refills:*0
8. Sulfameth/Trimethoprim DS 1 TAB PO BID Duration: 3 Days 
RX *sulfamethoxazole-trimethoprim [Bactrim DS] 800 mg-160 mg ONE 
tablet(s) by mouth twice a day Disp #*6 Tablet Refills:*0

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Benign prostatic hypertrophy with lower urinary tract symptoms

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
-Do not lift anything heavier than a phone book (10 pounds) or 
drive until you are seen by your Urologist in follow-up

-You may continue to periodically see small amounts of blood in 
your urine--this is normal and will gradually improve

-Resume all of your pre-admission medications

-Complete a course of antibiotics as prescribed.

-You may be discharged home with a medication called PYRIDIUM 
that will help with the "burning" pain you may experience when 
voiding. This medication may turn your urine bright orange.

-Colace has been prescribed to avoid post surgical constipation 
and constipation related to narcotic pain medication. 
Discontinue if loose stool or diarrhea develops. Colace is a 
stool softener, NOT a laxative

-Do not eat constipating foods for ___ weeks, drink plenty of 
fluids to keep hydrated

-No vigorous physical activity or sports for 4 weeks or until 
otherwise advised

-Tylenol should be your first line pain medication, a narcotic 
pain medication has been prescribed for breakthrough pain >4. 
Replace Tylenol with narcotic pain medication.

-Max daily Tylenol (acetaminophen) dose is 4 grams from ALL 
sources, note that narcotic pain medication also contains 
Tylenol

-Do not drive or drink alcohol while taking narcotics and do not 
operate dangerous machinery. Also, if the Foley catheter and Leg 
Bag are in place--Do NOT drive (you may be a passenger).

If you go home with a Foley catheter:

-Please also reference the nursing handout and instructions on 
routine care and hygiene

-Your Foley should be secured to the catheter secure on your 
thigh at ALL times until your follow up with the surgeon.

-Follow up for foley removal as directed and YOU MUST STOP THE 
DITROPAN (if you have been prescribed) at least 24hours before 
planned foley removal. DO NOT have anyone else other than your 
Surgeon or your surgeon's representative remove your Foley for 
any reason.

-Wear Large Foley bag for majority of time, leg bag is only for 
short-term when leaving house.

-Do not drive if you have a Foley in place

 
Followup Instructions:
___

text:
Name:  ___                 Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: SURGERY
 
Allergies: 
No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
Primary hyperparathyroidism
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
s/p left inferior parathyroidectomy

 
History of Present Illness:
The patient is a ___ who initially presented with kidney stones. 
 On further workup, she was noted to have primary 
hyperparathyroidism with localization to a left inferior 
parathyroid gland.
 
Past Medical History:
Primary hyperparathyroidism
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
non-contributory
 
Physical Exam:
On day of discharge:
Temp 98.1 HR 59  BP 96/60 RR 18 100%RA
Gen: alert and oriented x3, nad
Neck: c/d/i, no swelling or hematoma
___: RRR
Pulm: CTA b/l
Abd: s/nt/nd
 
Pertinent Results:
___ 01:13PM BLOOD PTH-164*
___ 03:30PM BLOOD PTH-5.2*
 
Brief Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the surgical service following left 
parathyroid resection.  PTH in the PACU decreased from 164 to 
5.2.  She was advanced to a regular diet, pain well controlled.  
On day of discharge she was tolerating a regular diet, pain 
controlled and neck incision without erythema, swelling or 
drainage.
 
Medications on Admission:
none
 
Discharge Medications:
1. oxycodone-acetaminophen ___ mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO 
Q6H (every 6 hours) as needed for pain.
Disp:*30 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
2. docusate sodium 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO BID (2 
times a day).  

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Parathyroid adenoma

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Please call your doctor or return to the ER for any of the 
following:
* You experience new chest pain, pressure, squeezing or 
tightness.
* New or worsening cough or wheezing.
* If you are vomiting and cannot keep in fluids or your 
medications.
* Your pain is not improving within ___ hours or not gone 
within 24 hours. Call or return immediately if your pain is 
getting worse or is changing location or moving to your chest or 

back.

*Avoid lifting objects > 5lbs until your follow-up appointment 
with the surgeon.

*Avoid driving or operating heavy machinery while taking pain 
medications.
* You have shaking chills, or a fever greater than 101.5 (F) 
degrees or 38(C) degrees.
* Any serious change in your symptoms, or any new symptoms that 
concern you. 
* Please resume all regular home medications and take any new 
meds 
as ordered. 
* Continue to ambulate several times per day.

Incision Care:
-Your steri-strips will fall off on their own. Please remove any 
remaining strips ___ days after surgery.
-You may shower, and wash surgical incisions.
-Avoid swimming and baths until your follow-up appointment.
-Please call the doctor if you have increased pain, swelling, 
redness, or drainage from the incision sites.

*Avoid driving while taking pain medication. 
*Continue taking stool softeners with pain medication to prevent 
constipation.
*You may feel tingling around your lips, arms & legs. Take TUMS 
(2 tabs four times for a few days until tingling goes away).
*If tingling becomes crampy-call the MD office or go to 
emergency room if unable to reach MD.
*You may return to work once you feel comfortable.
*Avoid physical/strenuous activity until you feel comfortable.
*You may shower. Avoid swimming or bath for ___ days.
 
Followup Instructions:
___

Discharge Disposition:
Home
Discharge Diagnosis:
Parathyroid adenoma
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.
Discharge Instructions:
Please call your doctor or return to the ER for any of the
following:
* You experience new chest pain, pressure, squeezing or
tightness.
* New or worsening cough or wheezing.
* If you are vomiting and cannot keep in fluids or your
medications.
* Your pain is not improving within ___ hours or not gone
within 24 hours. Call or return immediately if your pain is
getting worse or is changing location or moving to your chest or
back.
*Avoid lifting objects > 5lbs until your follow-up appointment
with the surgeon.
*Avoid driving or operating heavy machinery while taking pain
medications.
* You have shaking chills, or a fever greater than 101.5 (F)
degrees or 38(C) degrees.
* Any serious change in your symptoms, or any new symptoms that
concern you.
* Please resume all regular home medications and take any new
meds
as ordered.
* Continue to ambulate several times per day.
Incision Care:
-Your steri-strips will fall off on their own. Please remove any
remaining strips ___ days after surgery.
-You may shower, and wash surgical incisions.
-Avoid swimming and baths until your follow-up appointment.
-Please call the doctor if you have increased pain, swelling,
redness, or drainage from the incision sites.
*Avoid driving while taking pain medication.
*Continue taking stool softeners with pain medication to prevent
constipation.
*You may feel tingling around your lips, arms & legs. Take TUMS
(2 tabs four times for a few days until tingling goes away).
*If tingling becomes crampy-call the MD office or go to
emergency room if unable to reach MD.
*You may return to work once you feel comfortable.
*Avoid physical/strenuous activity until you feel comfortable.
*You may shower. Avoid swimming or bath for ___ days.
Followup Instructions:
___

___ yo G7P___ at ___ presented with rupture of membrane at 
17:30 of ___. She reported AFM, painful contractions, but no 
vaginal bleeding.

PNC:
  -Labs: O+/Ab-/RPRNR/RI/HBsAg-/HIV-/GBS unknown
  -GLT 80
  -US FFS NL; EFW ___ grams 75th%tile (done for cHTN)
  -Low risk Quad screen

SABx1

Gyn hx: hx of abnl pap, but normal pap on ___ right adnexal 
cyst 6.5 cm on ___ scan; denied hx of STIs, would like tubal 
ligation 5 to 6 wks postpartum.

PMH: cHTN, BP well controlled during this pregnancy 
(110-130/50-80), not on any medication; hx of depression, on 
Sertraline.

PSH: denied
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
None contributory.
 
Physical Exam:
BP 161/93
Gen: uncomfortable with contractions
Card: RRR
Lungs: CTAB
Abd: gravid, NT, soft; ___ of 7.5#
Ext: NT; NE
SVE: ___
FHT:145/mod var/+accel/-decel
Toco:Q2-3 mins
 
Pertinent Results:
___ 07:55PM BLOOD WBC-6.9 RBC-4.05* Hgb-11.8* Hct-34.6* Plt 
___
___ 07:14PM BLOOD WBC-8.4 RBC-3.85* Hgb-10.5* Hct-32.0* Plt 
___
___ 10:01PM BLOOD ___ PTT-23.7 ___ ___
___ 07:14PM BLOOD ___ PTT-23.9 ___ ___
___ 10:01PM BLOOD Creat-0.8
___ 07:14PM BLOOD Creat-0.7
___ 10:01PM BLOOD ALT-21
___ 07:14PM BLOOD ALT-17 AST-18
___ 10:01PM BLOOD UricAcd-5.8*
___ 07:14PM BLOOD UricAcd-6.1*

 
Brief Hospital Course:
Pt was admitted into labor and delivery for preterm labor. Pt 
was started on Penicillin for unknown GBS status. Her labor 
course was complicated by intrapartum fever. She was started on 
Ampicillin and Gentamicin, and it was continued postpartum and 
for 24 hours from the ___ documented afebrile time. Preeclampsia 
lab was checked on admission due to initial elevated BP. 
However, pt's BP decreased to 130s/80s after  her labor pain was 
controlled by anesthesia. The preeclampsia lab was negative 
except for uric acid of 5.8. Pt's delivery was uncomplicated. 
The NICU team was present at the delivery for prematurity and 
the infant was transferred to the NICU. Pt received routine 
postpartum care. Her course was complicated by increased BP on 
___. Repeat preeclampsia lab was obtained and they remained 
negative except for uric acid (increased from 5.8 to 6.1). Pt 
was started on Nifedipine 10 mg TID, however pt developed a 
headache. This was likely due to side effect of the Nifedipine. 
Pt was treated with Fioricet, and the headache resolved. As for 
control of BP, Nifedipine was stopped and Labetalol 400 mg BID 
was started. Pt's BP responded well to the Labetalol and 
remained within reasonable range. Pt was discharged on ___ 
in stable condition: afebrile, BP within reasonable range, able 
to eat regular food, under adequate pain control with oral 
medications, and ambulating and urinating without difficulty. 

 
Medications on Admission:
Sertraline, PNV, iron supplement
 
Discharge Medications:
1. docusate sodium 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO BID (2 
times a day) as needed for Constipation.
Disp:*60 Capsule(s)* Refills:*2*
2. oxycodone-acetaminophen ___ mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO 
Q4H (every 4 hours) as needed for Pain.
Disp:*30 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
3. ibuprofen 600 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO Q6H (every 6 
hours) as needed for Pain: Please take medication with food.
Disp:*60 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
4. labetalol 200 mg Tablet Sig: Two (2) Tablet PO BID (2 times a 
day).
Disp:*90 Tablet(s)* Refills:*1*

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Vaginal delivery of baby boy

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory 

 
Discharge Instructions:
Do not drive while taking Percocet.
Nothing in vagina (no tampons, no douching, no sex) for 6 weeks.
No tub baths or swimming until vaginal bleeding stops.
Do not lift anything heavier than 10 pounds for 6 weeks.
 

 
Followup Instructions:
___

text:
Name:  ___            Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: SURGERY
 
Allergies: 
No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
Right thyroid cyst, difficulty swallowing, sensation of 
pressure.
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
Right partial thyroidectomy.

 
History of Present Illness:
 The patient presented from an outside hospital
with a preliminary diagnosis of carcinoma based upon an exam
of a left thyroid mass.  There was, however, evidence to
suggest that it probably was not by ultrasound.

 
Past Medical History:
thyroid cysts, uterine fibroids
 
Social History:
Single, no children.
 
Physical Exam:
On Discharge:

AF, VSS
NCAT, EOMI, no scleral icterus
MMM, oropharynx clear, no voice changes
RRR
CATB, no stridor, no resp distress
ABD S/NT/ND
EXTREM warm, no peripheral edema
 
Pertinent Results:
none
 
Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ was admitted to the ___ service after 
partial left thyroidectomy for multinodular goiter. The complete 
operative report can be found in her ___ medical record. The 
procedure was uncomplicated and the patient tolerated it well. 
Immediately post-op, Ms. ___ was transferred to the PACU 
and subsequently to an overnight observation unit where she her 
diet was advanced from clear liquids to regular solids.  On 
post-op exam, the patient complained of minimal nausea, deep 
neck pain in the area of her incision, but her exam was 
otherwise normal.  In the morning of ___ the patient's pain 
was well controlled, she denied perioral or acral numbness or 
tingling. She was tolerating a regular diet and was 
OOB/ambulating and voiding independently. She was deemed 
appropriate for discharge.
 
Medications on Admission:
Flagyl vaginal gel
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Hydrocodone-Acetaminophen (5mg-500mg) ___ TAB PO Q4H:PRN pain 


 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Multinodular goiter.

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted to the inpatient general surgery unit after 
your total thyroidectomy. You have adequate pain control and 
have tolerated a regular diet and may return home to continue 
your recovery.

Upon discharge monitor for signs and symptoms of low calcium 
such as numbness or tingling around mouth/fingertips or muscle 
cramps in your legs. If you experience any of these signs or 
symptoms please call Dr. ___ for advice or if you 
have severe symptoms go to the emergency room. 

Please resume all regular home medications, unless specifically 
advised not to take a particular medication and take any new 
medications as prescribed. You will be given a prescription for 
narcotic pain medication, take as prescribed. It is recommended 
that you take a stool softner such as Colace while taking oral 
narcotic pain medication to prevent constipation. You may also 
take acetaminophen (Tylenol) as directed, but do not exceed 4000 
mg in one day. Please get plenty of rest, continue to walk 
several times per day, and drink adequate amounts of fluids. 

Please call your surgeon or go to the emergency department if 
you have increased pain, swelling, redness, or drainage from the 
incision site.You may shower and wash incisions with a mild soap 
and warm water.Avoid swimming and baths until cleared by your 
surgeon.Gently pat the area dry.You have a neck incision with 
steri-strips in place, do not remove, they will fall off on 
their own. 

 
Followup Instructions:
___

text:
Name:  ___                  Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: MEDICINE
 
Allergies: 
Fludrocortisone
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
Syncope
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
Upper Endoscopy
Barium study

 
History of Present Illness:
Ms. ___ is a ___ patient with GERD, IBS, positonal 
orthostatic tachycardiac syndrome (POTS), ADHD who had a 
withessed syncopal episode today during which she hit her head. 
She was in the student center at ___ where she is a student 
and was unconscious for <1 min. Denies post-syncopal HA or 
bleeding. For her POTS, at ___ needs good PO to avoid 
lightheadedness and has had dysphagia and poor PO intake for 5 
days. Has syncopized approx. once a week for a month and has 
felt "foggy" for 2 months. 2 weeks ago fainted in setting of 
"severe" abd pain which resolved spontaneously.  
.  
Pr Dr. ___ notes: She has had a number of GI symptoms 
including intermittent trouble swallowing, although she has 
never had to regurgitate food. She states that she has 
regurgitation of brash tasting fluid. It is worse when lying 
flat. She describes some substernal burning. She has been 
evaluated by 2 different gastroenterologists in the last ___ years 
and has undergone 2 endoscopies. Records are not available. She 
also has a history of erratic bowels. Her bowels wax and wane 
between formed stools and loose stools. She underwent a 
colonoscopy (unavailable) within the past year. She was not told 
that there were any abnormalities. She is troubled by 
intermittent vomiting. She has issues  
with her weight and it can vary by 10 pounds depending on her  
appetite.  
.  
In the ED, all labs were WNL. ECG showed NSR at 93 with nl axis 
and intervals. She developed a headache and was given Tylenol 
#3. GI was consulted by phone and recommended admission and EGD 
to assess dysphagia. No CT head performed.  

 
Past Medical History:
ADHD  
POTS (positonal orthostatic tachycardiac syndrome)  
IBS  
.  
Past surgical history is remarkable for a number of tubes being 
placed in her ears and she is also status post tonsillectomy.  

 
Social History:
___
Family History:
Nc
 
Physical Exam:
VS 98.4 101 16 130/80 98% RA  
GEN: WD female in bed in NAD  
HEENT: PERRL, EOMI  
NECK: supple. There is no thyromegaly.  
CHEST: clear. There is no CVA tenderness.  
ABD: Flat and benign with no mass or reproducible tenderness. 
There is no audible bruit.  
EXT: without edema.  
Psych: Listens to and questions appropriately  
 
Pertinent Results:
___: UPPER GI BARIUM STUDY: Barium passes freely through the 
esophagus. There are normal stripping waves. A 13-mm barium 
tablet passes freely through the esophagus without holdup. No 
hiatus hernia or gastroesophageal reflux is demonstrated. The 
stomach distends and empties normally, no abnormality is 
detected within the stomach. The duodenal bulb, loop, and 
visualized proximal small bowel are normal.

IMPRESSION: Normal upper GI barium study.
.
Upper Endoscopy: normal EGD to ___ part of duodenum. 
 
Brief Hospital Course:
___ female with GERD, IBS, positonal orthostatic 
tachycardiac syndrome (POTS), ADHD who had a withessed syncopal 
episode today during which she hit her head with ongoing 
dysphagia and poor PO intake x 5 days.  
.  
# Syncope: given her report of decreased PO intake, it was felt 
that the patient's syncopal episode was most likely a result of 
dehydration. She was rehydrated with IVFs. Her POTS was also a 
consideration. patient improved with IVFs and was able to 
ambulate. her TSH was within normal limits. 
.  
# Dysphagia: One of the patient's chief complaints was her 
dysphagia. She was being followed by Dr. ___ the ___ 
dept. ___ was consulted who recommended Upper endoscopy and 
barium swallow to evaluate for potential motility disorders and 
structural reasons for her dysphagia. Both of these studies were 
normal. Biopsies wer also taken during the EGD and will be 
follow up by GI.
.  
# POTS: This is ongoing. She tried Fludrocortisone but had 
swelling and did not tolerate it well. She may benefit from a 
trial of other medications this can be managed as an outpatient. 

.
She was discharged after discussions with Dr. ___ as well 
as the GI dept. She will follow up with Dr. ___ the GI 
service (phone numbers were provided). Upon discharge, the 
patient was eating solid food and tolerating liquids without 
difficulty. 
 
Medications on Admission:
Strattera 80mg daily  
Zyrtec 10mg daily  
Albuterol INH  
Aciphex ___ daily  
Ritalin 20mg daily
 
Discharge Medications:
Cont home medications
 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Dehydration

 
Discharge Condition:
AAO x 3
Eating solid food and drinking fluid

 
Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted because you passed out (syncopized). We think 
this was mainly from dehydration. Please ensure that you eat 
appropriately and drink enough fluids to stay well hydrated. We 
were concerned that your dysphagia was preventing you from 
taking adequate fluids. You underwent an endoscopy and a barium 
study to evaulate for potential reasons for you swallowing 
difficulty. These studies were normal. You will need to follow 
up with Dr. ___ further evaluation. Please also 
call your primary care doctor's office for a follow up 
appointment. 
 
Followup Instructions:
___

structural reasons for her dysphagia. Both of these studies were
normal. Biopsies wer also taken during the EGD and will be
follow up by GI.
.
# POTS: This is ongoing. She tried Fludrocortisone but had
swelling and did not tolerate it well. She may benefit from a
trial of other medications this can be managed as an outpatient.
.
She was discharged after discussions with Dr. ___ as well
as the GI dept. She will follow up with Dr. ___ the GI
service (phone numbers were provided). Upon discharge, the
patient was eating solid food and tolerating liquids without
difficulty.
Medications on Admission:
Strattera 80mg daily
Zyrtec 10mg daily
Albuterol INH
Aciphex ___ daily
Ritalin 20mg daily
Discharge Medications:
Cont home medications
Discharge Disposition:
Home
Discharge Diagnosis:
Dehydration
Discharge Condition:
AAO x 3
Eating solid food and drinking fluid
Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted because you passed out (syncopized). We think
this was mainly from dehydration. Please ensure that you eat
appropriately and drink enough fluids to stay well hydrated. We
were concerned that your dysphagia was preventing you from
taking adequate fluids. You underwent an endoscopy and a barium
study to evaulate for potential reasons for you swallowing
difficulty. These studies were normal. You will need to follow
up with Dr. ___ further evaluation. Please also
call your primary care doctor's office for a follow up
appointment.
Followup Instructions:
___

Service: MEDICINE

Fludrocortisone
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
Syncope
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
None
 
History of Present Illness:
Ms. ___ is a ___ patient with GERD, IBS, positonal 
orthostatic tachycardiac syndrome (POTS), ADHD who presents with 
syncopal episode. 
.
She had a fainting episode on ___, but did not seek medical 
care. She has a history of intermittent syncope as part of the 
POT syndrome. This was a winessed episode and she did not loose 
consciousness or did she fall. On ___ she complained of 
nausea, vommiting and headache, which she admitss to being 
chronic for her. On Wednsesday she had another episode of 
syncope, this time unwitnesses. At this time she also complained 
of multiple episodes of LOC. 
.
She states that these episodes are usual for her and that they 
are worse during the summer. In ___ she had a medication change, 
clonidine was substituted for proamatine.
.
Recently she had BRBPR and had a colonoscopy showing 
hemorrhoids. She's not aware of any other findings. She denies 
any recent fever, chills, sore throat, chest pain, palpitations, 
or dysuria.
 
Past Medical History:
ADHD  
POTS (positonal orthostatic tachycardiac syndrome)  
IBS  
GERD
Hiatal hernia
Pituitary adenoma
Small fiber neuropathy
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
NC
 
Physical Exam:
Physical Exam:
VS 98, 126/84, 88, 16, 100Ra
GEN: AO3 NAD  
HEENT: PERRL, EOMI, +red reflex, no papilledema   
CHEST: CTA B no c/w. 
CV RRR S1 S2 no gmr 
ABD: soft nt nd no hsm 
EXT: no eedema, +2 RP  
Neuro: CN ___ intact, intact sensory to touch, ___ distal ___ 
strength
 
Brief Hospital Course:
Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ is a ___ female with a history of postural 
orthostatic tachycardic syndrome (POTS), IBS, GERD, and ADHD who 
presented after unwitnessed episode of syncope. An EKG was 
obtained which showed an old Right Bundle Branch Block 
consistent with a previous EKG in ___, but no new 
changes.  CBC and electrolytes were within normal limits with 
the exception of an elevated BUN, consistent with prerenal 
azotemia secondary to dehydration.  Based on her history, exam, 
and laboratory findings, her episode of syncope was felt to be 
associated with her history of POTS, possibly triggered by 
hypovolemia.  She was observed overnight and was afebrile with 
stable vital signs throughout her stay.  She received IV 
maintenance fluids.  She was stable on discharge and is 
scheduled to follow-up with her neurologist, Dr. ___ at 
___. 
.
While the patient was hospitalized she provided a history of 
abuse while growing up. The paitent denied any elements of 
physical, emotional or verbal abuse in the current living 
environment. She thought that this was a safe environment. While 
in the hospital it was apparent that the patient was exhibiting 
behaviour patterns that wereincongruent with her age and that 
she had frequent shifts in her mood. The patient denied a 
suicidal ideation while in the hospital. A concern was also with 
regards to the possibility of an eating disorder, albeit no 
clinical or laboratory evidence was noted during this stay. It 
may be importnat to pursue outpatient psychiatric evaluation for 
these issues.
 
Medications on Admission:
Atomoxetine 120mg daily
Zyrtec 10mg daily
Singulair 10mg daily
Protonix 40mg daily
Midodrine 20mg in AM, 15 mg in afternoon, 15mg in evening
Topamax 50mg daily
 
Discharge Medications:
Same
 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Syncope
 
Discharge Condition:
Stable
 
Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted to ___ because you experienced an 
unwitnessed syncopal episode.  You received IV fluids and your 
temperature, heart rate, and blood pressure were normal during 
your stay.  Upon discharge, we encourage you to resume your 
normal activities and continue your home medication regimen.
 
Followup Instructions:
___

text:
Name:  ___               Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: OBSTETRICS/GYNECOLOGY
 
Allergies: 
Patient recorded as having No Known Allergies to Drugs
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
pelvic mass
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
exploratory laparotomy
right salpingo-oophorectomy
cystoscopy

 
History of Present Illness:
The patient is a ___ G2, P2 sent by Dr. ___ for 
a consultation regarding a pelvic mass.  She presented with 
lower abdominal discomfort in ___.  She had a CT of the 
abdomen and pelvis, which revealed a 10.8 cm
pelvic mass, which was largely cystic.  She had a followup 
pelvic ultrasound on ___, which revealed an 11 cm 
hypoechoic cyst with low-level echos and thick walls.  There was 
no free fluid.  A subsequent CA-125 was 84.  The patient was 
already seen and examined by Dr. ___, who recommended 
surgical management of the pelvic mass.  She felt that given the 
complex nature of the mass and the elevated CA-125, referral to 
gynecologic oncology was appropriate.  The patient has a history 
of undergoing TAHBSO in ___ for what she describes as a large 
but benign ovarian cyst.  Of note, she states that her pain has 
essentially resolved after lasting about two or three weeks.  
She
took some herbal medication and thinks that this may have 
resulted in resolution of the cyst.  Pt had an interval US which 
showed enlargement of the cyst so the decision was made to 
proceed with surgical excision of the mass to rule out 
malignancy.  
 
Past Medical History:
PAST MEDICAL HISTORY:  Significant for hypertension.

PAST SURGICAL HISTORY:  Appendectomy in ___ for ruptured
appendix, open cholecystectomy ___, TAHBSO ___.

OBSTETRICAL HISTORY:  Vaginal delivery x2.

GYNECOLOGICAL HISTORY:  Last Pap smear is unknown.  Last
mammogram was ___ and normal.
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
Negative for malignancies.
 
Physical Exam:
GENERAL APPEARANCE:  Well developed, well nourished.
HEENT:  Sclerae anicteric.
LYMPHATICS:  Lymph node survey was negative.
LUNGS:  Clear to auscultation.
HEART:  Regular without murmurs.
ABDOMEN:  Soft and nondistended and without palpable masses. 
There were multiple healed abdominal incisions with no evidence
of hernia.  There was no tenderness.
EXTREMITIES:  Without edema.
PELVIC:  The vulva and vagina were normal.  The cervix was
surgically absent.  Bimanual and rectovaginal examination
revealed a palpable mass at the vaginal apex, which was somewhat
mobile and smooth, measuring about 10 cm.  There was no
tenderness.  There was no associated cul-de-sac nodularity and
the rectal was intrinsically normal.
 
Brief Hospital Course:
___ was admitted after exploratory laparotomy, lysis of 
adhesions, right salpingo-oophorectomy, and cystoscopy done to 
remove a pelvic mass noted on CT and US.  Preliminary frozen 
pathology was benign intraop.  Please see operative report for 
details.  Pt received routine post-op care and was discharged 
home in good condition on POD#2.  
 
Medications on Admission:
metoprolol, flonase prn, asmanex prn, albuterol prn, nasonex prn 

 
Discharge Medications:
1. Ibuprofen 600 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO Q6H (every 6 
hours) as needed.
Disp:*60 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
2. Oxycodone-Acetaminophen ___ mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO 
Q4H (every 4 hours) as needed.
Disp:*60 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
3. Colace 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO twice a day as 
needed for constipation.
Disp:*60 Capsule(s)* Refills:*0*
4. Albuterol 90 mcg/Actuation Aerosol Sig: ___ Puffs Inhalation 
Q6H (every 6 hours) as needed.  
5. Fluticasone 50 mcg/Actuation Spray, Suspension Sig: One (1) 
Spray Nasal BID (2 times a day) as needed.  
6. Metoprolol Succinate 50 mg Tablet Sustained Release 24 hr 
Sig: One (1) Tablet Sustained Release 24 hr PO DAILY (Daily).  
 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
pelvic mass
 
Discharge Condition:
good
 
Discharge Instructions:
-Please call your physician if you experience fever > 100.4, 
chills, nausea and vomiting, worsening or severe abdominal pain, 

chest pain, trouble breathing, or vaginal bleeding.  Please call 

if you have redness and warmth around your incision, if you have 

any pus-like drainage from your incision, or if your incision 
reopens. 
- No heavy lifting or strenuous exercise for 6 weeks to allow 
your incision to heal completely. 
- Nothing per vagina (no tampons, intercourse, douching) for 4 
weeks. 
- No driving for two weeks; no driving while taking narcotic 
pain medications as they can make you drowsy. 
- Please keep your follow-up appointments as outlined below.  
 
Followup Instructions:
___

text:
Name:  ___            Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: SURGERY
 
Allergies: 
No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
R thyroid nodule
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
s/p R thyroidectomy (previous L thyroidectomy in ___

 
History of Present Illness:
___ had previously undergone left thyroid lobectomy several 
years ago for a benign goiter, and now presented with 
enlargement of the right lobe, which was
causing symptoms. She was admitted to ___ on ___ for right 
thyroid lobectomy (and consequently total thyroidectomy)

 
Past Medical History:
Uterine fibroids, 
MNG s/p L hemithyroidectomy,
hyperprolactinemia, 
obesity
PCOS
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
Father--DM2, HTN.  No obesity.

 
Physical Exam:
Vitals: T97.6, 121/81, 72, 18, 97% RA
NECK: wound with steri's with mild sang staining, intact.
Sensation intact. 
Pulm: non labored respirations
CV: reg rate 
Abd: soft, non tender. 
Ext: wwp
 
Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ was taken to the OR for R lobectomy which she 
tolerated without any complications. She was extubated in the 
OR, taken to the PACU without any issues. She was subsequently 
admitted overnight for brief observation. Her overnight stay was 
uneventful. She tolerated regular diet, ambulated without 
assistance, was discharged home on POD1 on levothyroxine 137mg 
qam and Calcium carbonate, with a follow-up in clinic in 4 
weeks.
 
Discharge Medications:
1.  Acetaminophen ___ mg PO Q6H:PRN Pain - Mild  
2.  Calcium Carbonate 1250 mg PO QID 
RX *calcium carbonate 500 mg calcium (1,250 mg) 1 tablet(s) by 
mouth 4 times daily Disp #*120 Tablet Refills:*0 
3.  levothyroxine 137 mcg 1 tablet(s) by mouth every morning 
Disp #*30 Tablet Refills:*0 

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
R Thyroid nodule now s/p R thyroid lobectomy

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

Vitals: T97.6, 121/81, 72, 18, 97% RA
NECK: wound with steri's with mild sang staining, intact.
Sensation intact. 
Pulm: non labored respirations
CV: reg rate 
Abd: soft, non tender. 
Ext: wwp

 
Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted to the inpatient general surgery unit after 
your total thyroidectomy. You have adequate pain control and 
have tolerated a regular diet and may return home to continue 
your recovery. You will be discharged home on thyroid  hormone 
replacement and calcium supplement, please take as prescribed. 
Monitor for signs and symptoms of low Calcium such as numbness 
or tingling around mouth/fingertips or muscle cramps in your 
legs. If you experience any of these signs or symptoms please 
call Dr. ___ for advice or if you have severe 
symptoms go to the emergency room. 

Please resume all regular home medications, unless specifically 
advised not to take a particular medication and take any new 
medications as prescribed. You may take acetaminophen (Tylenol) 
as directed, but do not exceed 4000 mg in one day. Please get 
plenty of rest, continue to walk several times per day, and 
drink adequate amounts of fluids. 

Please call your surgeon or go to the emergency department if 
you have increased pain, swelling, redness, or drainage from the 
incision site. You may shower and wash incisions with a mild 
soap and warm water. Avoid swimming and baths until cleared by 
your surgeon. Gently pat the area dry. You have a neck incision 
with steri-strips in place, do not remove, they will fall off on 
their own.
Thank you for allowing us to participate in your care.

 
Followup Instructions:
___
