Pre-operatively, he was consented. A CXR, EKG, UA, CBC,
Electrolytes, T/S - were obtained, all other preperations were
made.
He was prepped, and brought down to the operating room for
surgery. Intra-operatively, he was closely monitored and
remained hemodynamically stable. He tolerated the procedure well
without any difficulty or complication. For more complete
details, please see the operative note. Post-operatively, he was
extubated and transferred to the PACU for further stabilization
and monitoring. He was then transferred to the VICU for further
recovery. While in the VICU he received monitored care. When
stable, he was delined. His diet was advanced. A ___ consult was
obtained. When he was stabilized from the acute setting of post
operative care, he was transfered to floor status. On ___, the
patient spiked a mild fever and a fever workup was performed. No
source was conclusively identified before discharge but cultures
were sent and the patient was discharged on antibiotics.
Discharge Medications:
1. Aspirin 325 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily).
2. Hydromorphone 2 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO Q6H (every 6
hours) as needed for Pain.
Disp:*30 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
3. Zolpidem 5 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO HS (at bedtime)
as needed.
4. Docusate Sodium 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO BID (2
times a day).
5. Omeprazole 20 mg Capsule, Delayed Release(E.C.) Sig: Two (2)
Capsule, Delayed Release(E.C.) PO DAILY (Daily).
6. Metoprolol Succinate 50 mg Tablet Sustained Release 24 hr
Sig: One (1) Tablet Sustained Release 24 hr PO DAILY (Daily).
Disp:*30 Tablet Sustained Release 24 hr(s)* Refills:*2*
7. Simvastatin 10 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY
(Daily).
Disp:*30 Tablet(s)* Refills:*2*
8. Medication
Please continue all other medications as directed by your
primary care provider.
9. Levofloxacin 500 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO Q24H (every
24 hours) for 10 days.
Disp:*10 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
10. Acetaminophen 325 mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO Q6H (every 6
hours) as needed.
Discharge Disposition:
Home With Service
Facility:
___.
Discharge Diagnosis:
Infected ulcer and ischemia, left leg.
Discharge Condition:
Stable
Discharge Instructions:
Division of Vascular and Endovascular Surgery
Lower Extremity Bypass Surgery Discharge Instructions
What to expect when you go home:
1. It is normal to feel tired, this will last for ___ weeks
You should get up out of bed every day and gradually increase
your activity each day
Unless you were told not to bear any weight on operative foot:
you may walk and you may go up and down stairs
Increase your activities as you can tolerate- do not do too
much right away!
2. It is normal to have swelling of the leg you were operated
on:
Elevate your leg above the level of your heart (use ___
pillows or a recliner) every ___ hours throughout the day and at
night
Avoid prolonged periods of standing or sitting without your
legs elevated
3. It is normal to have a decreased appetite, your appetite will
return with time
You will probably lose your taste for food and lose some
weight
Eat small frequent meals
It is important to eat nutritious food options (high fiber,
lean meats, vegetables/fruits, low fat, low cholesterol) to
maintain your strength and assist in wound healing
To avoid constipation: eat a high fiber diet and use stool
softener while taking pain medication
What activities you can and cannot do:
No driving until post-op visit and you are no longer taking
pain medications
Unless you were told not to bear any weight on operative foot:
You should get up every day, get dressed and walk
You should gradually increase your activity
You may up and down stairs, go outside and/or ride in a car
Increase your activities as you can tolerate- do not do too
much right away!
No heavy lifting, pushing or pulling (greater than 5 pounds)
until your post op visit
You may shower (unless you have stitches or foot incisions) no
direct spray on incision, let the soapy water run over incision,
rinse and pat dry
Your incision may be left uncovered, unless you have small
amounts of drainage from the wound, then place a dry dressing
over the area that is draining, as needed
Take all the medications you were taking before surgery,
unless otherwise directed
Take one full strength (325mg) enteric coated aspirin daily,
unless otherwise directed
Call and schedule an appointment to be seen in 2 weeks for
staple/suture removal
What to report to office:
Redness that extends away from your incision
A sudden increase in pain that is not controlled with pain
medication
A sudden change in the ability to move or use your leg or the
ability to feel your leg
Temperature greater than 100.5F for 24 hours
Bleeding, new or increased drainage from incision or white,
yellow or green drainage from incisions
Followup Instructions:
___

text:
Name:  ___.              Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: UROLOGY
 
Allergies: 
Patient recorded as having No Known Allergies to Drugs
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
right ureteral stone
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
right ureteral stent placement
 
History of Present Illness:
HPI: ___ M with h/o Crohn's disease, rectal cancer, and
multiple abd surgeries including colectomy, ileo-anal pouch for
low grade dysplasia in ___, subsequent removal of pouch and end
ileostomy for pelvic abscesses, and total proctectomy ___
for rectal cancer who presents with RLQ abd pain which started
this AM.  Pt stated that he woke up to empty his ostomy 
appliance
and had sudden onset of RLQ pain which he described as pressure
pain.  Severity was ___ecided to presented to the ED. 
 Pt
denies any fever, chills, nausea/vomiting, sob, or dysuria.

 
Past Medical History:
Past Medical History;

Ulcerative colitis
Recurrent pouchitis, known anorectal anastomosis requiring 
hospitalization, last one ___

Past Surgical History:

___ s/p Ileoanal pouch and diverting ileostomy
___ s/p Ileostomy closure
 
Brief Hospital Course:
Patient was admitted to the hospital and pain controlled with iv 
medications. He was kept NPO after midnight and was taken to the 
operating room on HD 2 for right ureteral stent placement. He 
was transferred to the floor in stable condition and was 
voiding, ambulating, tolerating a regular diet, and pain 
controlled with po meds. He was discharged home with specific 
instructions to f/u with Dr. ___ probable eswl treatment on 
___.
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Acetaminophen 325 mg Tablet Sig: Two (2) Tablet PO Q6H (every 
6 hours) as needed for pain.  
2. Urocit-K 5 5 mEq Tablet Sustained Release Sig: One (1) Tablet 
Sustained Release PO three times a day for 1 weeks: WITH MEALS.
Disp:*21 Tablet Sustained Release(s)* Refills:*0*
3. Pyridium 100 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO three times a 
day as needed for pain for 3 days: Will turn urine orange.
Disp:*9 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
right ureteral stone
 
Discharge Condition:
stable
 
Discharge Instructions:
Despite the fact that no skin incisions were used, the area 
around the ureter and bladder is irritated. The stent is 
required in order keep the ureter open and urine flowing from 
the kidney to the bladder. Because one end of the ureter is in 
the bladder, it can cause irritation to the bladder. Therefore, 
it is normal to feel that you need the urge to urinate 
frequently when the stent is in place. Although the stent can be 
uncomfortable, it is important to have the stent to avoid 
damaging the kidney and ureter after your procedure. You may see 
some blood in your urine while the stent is in place and a few 
days afterward. Drink lots of fluid  this will help clear up 
your urine.

Diet
You may return to your normal diet immediately. Because of the 
raw surface of your bladder, alcohol, spicy foods, acidy foods 
and drinks with caffeine may cause irritation or frequency and 
should be used in moderation. To keep your urine flowing freely 
and to avoid constipation, drink plenty of fluids during the day 
(8 - 10 glasses). 

Activity
Your physical activity doesn't need to be restricted. However, 
if you are very active, you may see some blood in the urine. We 
would suggest to cut down your activity under these 
circumstances until the bleeding has stopped. 

Bowels
It is important to keep your bowels regular during the 
postoperative period. Straining with bowel movements can cause 
bleeding. A bowel movement every other day is reasonable. Use a 
mild laxative if needed, such as Milk of Magnesia ___ 
Tablespoons, or 2 Dulcolax tablets. Call if you continue to have 
problems. If you had been taking narcotics for pain, before, 
during or after your surgery, you may be constipated. Take a 
laxative if necessary.

Medication
You should resume your pre-surgery medications unless told not 
to. In addition you will often be given an antibiotic to prevent 
infection. These should be taken as prescribed until the bottles 
are finished unless you are having an unusual reaction to one of 
the drugs.

Problems You Should Report to Us 
a. Fevers over 100.5 Fahrenheit.
b. Heavy bleeding, or clots (See notes above about blood in 
urine).
c. Inability to urinate.
d. Drug reactions (Hives, rash, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea).
e. Severe burning or pain with urination that is not improving. 

Follow-up
You have and internal stent and it is important to have a 
follow-up appointment to remove your stent. You are scheduled to 
have lithotripsy on ___
 
Followup Instructions:
___

Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. ___   was admitted to the Orthopedic service on 
___ for right ankle fracture dislocation and left distal 
radius fracture after being evaluated and treated with closed 
reduction in the emergency room.  He underwent closed reduction 
of his distal radius fracture and a 2-stage treatment of his 
right ankle fracture-dislocation. In the first stage the 
fracture was operatively reduced and stabilized with external 
fixator. Following this, 2 days later he underwent open 
reduction and internal fixation of the right ankle. All 
procedures were without complications. Please see operative 
reports for full details. After each procedure, he was extubated 
without difficulty and transferred to the recovery room in 
stable condition.  In the early post-operative course Mr. ___ 
did well and was transferred to the floor in stable condition.

On hospital day 5 he was given intravenous fluid bolus for 
post-operative hypovolumenia manifested as orthostatic 
hypotenion with brief, self limitted pre-syncopal event.  

He had adequate pain management and worked with physical therapy 
while in the hospital. The remainder of his hospital course was 
uneventful and he is being discharged to home in stable 
condition.
 
Medications on Admission:
none
 
Discharge Medications:
1. acetaminophen 325 mg Tablet Sig: Two (2) Tablet PO Q6H (every 
6 hours).  
2. enoxaparin 40 mg/0.4 mL Syringe Sig: One (1)  Subcutaneous 
DAILY (Daily).
Disp:*14 * Refills:*0*
3. docusate sodium 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO BID (2 
times a day).
Disp:*30 Capsule(s)* Refills:*2*
4. oxycodone 5 mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO every ___ hours as 
needed for Pain: do not drive or drink alcohol while on this 
medication.
Disp:*100 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Open right bimalleolar ankle fracture with 8 cm medial 
laceration. 

Right distal radius fracture.

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - requires assistance or aid (walker 
or cane).

 
Discharge Instructions:
Wound Care: 
- Keep Incision clean and dry.
- You can get the wound wet or take a shower starting from 7 
days after surgery, but no baths or swimming for at least 4 
weeks. 
- Any stitches or staples that need to be removed will be taken 
out at your 2-week follow up appointment.
Activity: 
- Continue to be TOUCH DOWN weight bearing on your right leg and 
NON WEIGHTBEARING on your left arm
- You should not lift anything greater than 5 pounds. 
- Elevate right/left arm/leg to reduce swelling and pain.
- Do not remove splint/cast.  Keep splint/cast dry.
Other Instructions
- Resume your regular diet. 
- Avoid nicotine products to optimize healing. 
- Resume your home medications. Take all medications as 
instructed. 
- Continue taking the Lovenox to prevent blood clots.
- You have also been given Additional Medications to control 
your pain.  Please allow 72 hours for refill of narcotic 
prescriptions, so plan ahead.  You can either have them mailed 
to your home or pick them up at the clinic located on ___. 
 We are not allowed to call in narcotic (oxycontin, oxycodone, 
percocet) prescriptions to the pharmacy.   In addition, we are 
only allowed to write for pain medications for 90 days from the 
date of surgery.
- Narcotic pain medication may cause drowsiness.  Do not drink 
alcohol while taking narcotic medications.  Do not operate any 
motor vehicle or machinery while taking narcotic pain 
medications.  Taking more than recommended may cause serious 
breathing problems.
- If you have questions, concerns or experience any of the below 
danger signs then please call your doctor at ___ or go 
to your local emergency room.
 
Followup Instructions:
___

History of Present Illness:
___ year old male with no prior cardiac history who has a strong 
family history of premature CAD. He currently reports feeling 
fatigued for the past year and had a stress test done due to his 
family history of coronary artery disease. He has noticed some 
sporadic chest tightness and dyspnea that occurs unrelated to

was patent. The LAD had a 70% ostial stenosis and a 90% stenosis 
in the mid vessel involving the bifrication into a twin LAD.  
The LCx had a 70% mid vessel stenosis. The RCA had a 95% mid 
vessel stenosis. 2. Limited resting hemodynamics revealed normal 
left sided filling pressures with an LVEDP of 12 mmHg. There was 
normal systemic arterial systolic pressures with an SBP of 106 
mmHg. 3. There was no evidence of aortic valve gradient on left 
heart pullback. 
.
___ Echo: PRE-BYPASS: No spontaneous echo contrast or 
thrombus is seen in the body of the left atrium or left atrial 
appendage. A small patent foramen ovale is present. Left 
ventricular wall thicknesses are normal. The left ventricular 
cavity size is normal. Overall left ventricular systolic 
function is low normal (LVEF 50-55%). There is mild hypokinesis 
of the apical and mid portions of the septal wall with normal RV 
free wall contractility. The diameters of aorta at the sinus, 
ascending and arch levels are normal. The aortic valve leaflets 
(3) appear structurally normal with good leaflet excursion and 
no aortic stenosis or aortic regurgitation. The mitral valve 
appears structurally normal with trivial mitral regurgitation. 
There is no pericardial effusion. Dr. ___ was notified in

which revealed severe coronary artery disease. Following cardiac 
cath he was admitted for surgical work-up. On ___ he was 
brought to the operating room where he underwent a coronary 
artery bypass graft x 4,with a left internal mammary artery 
graft to the left
anterior descending and reversed saphenous vein grafts to the 
marginal branch, diagonal branch, and right coronary artery with 
___. Please see operative report for further surgical 
details. Following surgery he was transferred to the CVICU for 
invasive monitoring in stable condition. Within 24 hours he was 
weaned from sedation, awoke neurologically intact and extubated. 
On post-op day one he was started on beta-blockers and diuretics 
and diuresed back to his pre-op weight. Later on this day he was 
transferred to the step-down floor for further care. Chest tubes 
and epicardial pacing wires were removed per protocol. He 
continued to make good progress while working with physical 
therapy for strength and mobility. On post-op day three he 
required a blood transfusion due to low HCT and blood pressure. 
He continued to progress and was cleared for discharge to home 
on POD#4. All follow up appointments were advised.

family history of premature CAD. He currently reports feeling
fatigued for the past year and had a stress test done due to his
family history of coronary artery disease. He has noticed some
sporadic chest tightness and dyspnea that occurs unrelated to
activity. He was referred for cardiac catheterization to further
evaluate. He was found to have three vessel diseae and is now
being admitted to cardiac surgery for revascularization.
Past Medical History:
Esophageal reflux
Hyperlipidemia
Hearing loss
Erectile dysfunction
Peptic ulcer age ___ in setting of steroids
Social History:
___
Family History:
Premature coronary artery disease-father has 5 stents- first
placed when he was in his early ___. Uncle died of "sudden
death" r/t an MI at age ___ 2 months ago. Another uncle had CABG
ins his ___.
Physical Exam:
Pulse:63 Resp:18 O2 sat:97/RA
B/P Right:127/83 Left:119/74
Height:6'1" Weight:217 lbs
General:
Skin: Dry [x] intact [x]
HEENT: PERRLA [x] EOMI [x]
Neck: Supple [x] Full ROM [x]
Chest: Lungs clear bilaterally [x]
Heart: RRR [x] Irregular [] Murmur [] grade ______
Abdomen: Soft [x] non-distended [x] non-tender [x] bowel sounds
+ [x]
Extremities: Warm [x], well-perfused [x] Edema none
Varicosities: None [x]
Neuro: Grossly intact [x]
Pulses:
Femoral Right:2+ Left:2+
DP Right:2+ Left:2+
___ Right:2+ Left:2+
Radial Right:2+ Left:2+
Carotid Bruit Right:- Left:-
Pertinent Results:
___ Cardiac cath: 1. Selective coronary angiography in this
right dominant system demonstrated three vessel CAD. The LMCa
was patent. The LAD had a 70% ostial stenosis and a 90% stenosis
in the mid vessel involving the bifrication into a twin LAD.
The LCx had a 70% mid vessel stenosis. The RCA had a 95% mid
vessel stenosis. 2. Limited resting hemodynamics revealed normal
left sided filling pressures with an LVEDP of 12 mmHg. There was
normal systemic arterial systolic pressures with an SBP of 106
mmHg. 3. There was no evidence of aortic valve gradient on left
heart pullback.
.
___ Echo: PRE-BYPASS: No spontaneous echo contrast or
thrombus is seen in the body of the left atrium or left atrial
appendage. A small patent foramen ovale is present. Left
ventricular wall thicknesses are normal. The left ventricular
cavity size is normal. Overall left ventricular systolic
function is low normal (LVEF 50-55%). There is mild hypokinesis
of the apical and mid portions of the septal wall with normal RV
free wall contractility. The diameters of aorta at the sinus,
ascending and arch levels are normal. The aortic valve leaflets
(3) appear structurally normal with good leaflet excursion and
no aortic stenosis or aortic regurgitation. The mitral valve
appears structurally normal with trivial mitral regurgitation.
There is no pericardial effusion. Dr. ___ was notified in
person of the results in the operating room.
POSTBYPASS: Patient is A paced and receiving an infusion of
phenylephrine. LVEF = 50%. Aorta is intact post decannulation.
RV function is unchanged.
Brief Hospital Course:
As mentioned in the HPI, Mr. ___ underwent a cardiac cath
which revealed severe coronary artery disease. Following cardiac
cath he was admitted for surgical work-up. On ___ he was
brought to the operating room where he underwent a coronary
artery bypass graft x 4,with a left internal mammary artery
graft to the left
anterior descending and reversed saphenous vein grafts to the
marginal branch, diagonal branch, and right coronary artery with
___. Please see operative report for further surgical
details. Following surgery he was transferred to the CVICU for
invasive monitoring in stable condition. Within 24 hours he was
weaned from sedation, awoke neurologically intact and extubated.
On post-op day one he was started on beta-blockers and diuretics
and diuresed back to his pre-op weight. Later on this day he was
transferred to the step-down floor for further care. Chest tubes
and epicardial pacing wires were removed per protocol. He
continued to make good progress while working with physical
therapy for strength and mobility. On post-op day three he
required a blood transfusion due to low HCT and blood pressure.
He continued to progress and was cleared for discharge to home
on POD#4. All follow up appointments were advised.

VIAGRA (last dose ___ WED ___ Dosage uncertain
SIMVASTATIN 40 mg Daily
ASPIRIN 81 mg Daily

(3 times a day).
Disp:*90 Tablet(s)* Refills:*2*

Disp:*30 Tablet(s)* Refills:*2*

Disp:*7 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*

back and leg pain

History of Present Illness:
see H+P

Brief Hospital Course:
Patient was admitted to the ___ Spine Surgery Service and 
taken to the Operating Room for the above procedure.  Refer to 
the dictated operative note for further details.  The surgery 
was complicated by a small dural tear, and patient was kept HOB 
flat x48 hrs without any headache or other symptoms.  
TEDs/pnemoboots were used for postoperative DVT prophylaxis.  
Intravenous antibiotics were continued for 24hrs postop per 
standard protocol. Initial postop pain was controlled with a IV 
meds.  Diet was advanced as tolerated.  The patient was 
transitioned to oral pain medication when tolerating PO diet.  
Foley was removed on POD#2.  Physical therapy was consulted for 
mobilization OOB to ambulate.  Hospital course was otherwise 
unremarkable.  On the day of discharge the patient was afebrile 
with stable vital signs, comfortable on oral pain control and 
tolerating a regular diet. 
 
Discharge Medications:
1. docusate sodium 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO BID (2 
times a day).  
2. senna 8.6 mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO BID (2 times a day).  

3. hydrochlorothiazide 12.5 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO 
DAILY (Daily).  
4. clonazepam 0.5 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO BID (2 times 
a day).  
5. lisinopril 20 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily). 
 
6. gabapentin 300 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO TID (3 
times a day).  
7. simvastatin 40 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY 
(Daily).  
8. multivitamin     Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily). 
 
9. calcium carbonate 200 mg (500 mg) Tablet, Chewable Sig: One 
(1) Tablet, Chewable PO BID (2 times a day).  
10. cholecalciferol (vitamin D3) 400 unit Tablet Sig: One (1) 
Tablet PO DAILY (Daily).  
11. acetaminophen 500 mg Tablet Sig: Two (2) Tablet PO Q6H 
(every 6 hours) as needed for pain.  
12. alum-mag hydroxide-simeth 200-200-20 mg/5 mL Suspension Sig: 
___ MLs PO QID (4 times a day) as needed for dyspepsia.  
13. MS ___ 15 mg Tablet Sustained Release Sig: One (1) Tablet 
Sustained Release PO twice a day for 10 days.
Disp:*20 Tablet Sustained Release(s)* Refills:*0*
14. morphine 15 mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO every four (4) 
hours as needed for pain.
Disp:*60 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
15. Ativan 0.5 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO every six (6) 
hours as needed for anxiety.
Disp:*12 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home With Service
 
Facility:
___
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Lumbar stenosis, instability

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Requires assistance (walker/cane)

 
Discharge Instructions:
You have undergone the following operation: Lumbar Decompression 
With Fusion

Immediately after the operation:

-Activity: You should not lift anything greater than 10 lbs for 
2 weeks. You will be more comfortable if you do not sit or stand 
more than ~45 minutes without getting up and walking around.

-Rehabilitation/ Physical Therapy: 
o2-3 times a day you should go for a walk for ___ minutes as 
part of your recovery.  You can walk as much as you can 
tolerate. 
oLimit any kind of lifting.

-Diet: Eat a normal healthy diet. You may have some 
constipation after surgery.  You have been given medication to 
help with this issue.

-Wound Care: Remove the dressing in 2 days.  If the incision is 
draining cover it with a new sterile dressing.  If it is dry 
then you can leave the incision open to the air.  Once the 
incision is completely dry (usually ___ days after the 
operation) you may take a shower. Do not soak the incision in a 
bath or pool.  If the incision starts draining at anytime after 
surgery, do not get the incision wet. Cover it with a sterile 
dressing.  Call the office. 

-You should resume taking your normal home medications.

-You have also been given Additional Medications to control 
your pain.  Please allow 72 hours for refill of narcotic 
prescriptions, so please plan ahead.  You can either have them 
mailed to your home or pick them up at the clinic located on 
___ 2.  We are not allowed to call in or fax narcotic 
prescriptions (oxycontin, oxycodone, percocet) to your pharmacy. 
 In addition, we are only allowed to write for pain medications 
for 90 days from the date of surgery.

Physical Therapy:
Activity:  Out of bed as tolerated, physical therapy without 
restrictions, no brace needed

Treatments Frequency:
 Site: Lumbar 
 Type:  Surgical
 Dressing:  Gauze - dry

Physical Therapy, mobilization

 
Followup Instructions:
___

text:
Name:  ___                      Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: NEUROSURGERY
 
Allergies: 
No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
aneurysm
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
___ Left ICA Aneurysm Pipeline 

 
History of Present Illness:
___ female who has had some recent problems with memory 
issues, which
resulted in an MRI scan.  This had shown a fairly large aneurysm
of the left supraclinoid carotid artery. Patient presents today 
for elective intervention of aneurysm. 

 
Past Medical History:
Bilateral subdural hygromas
memory loss
severe mitral valve regurgitation
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
nc
 
Physical Exam:
ON DISCHARGE:
Alert and oriented to person, place and time. Face symmetrical, 
tongue midline.  PERRL, EOMI.
R groin has small hematoma. Large R hematoma in thigh stable.
Pedal pulses bilaterally were checked with Doppler and were 
present.
 
Pertinent Results:
___ CTA PELVIS W/ & WO CONTRAST ***** 
 
Brief Hospital Course:
# LEFT ICA ANEURSYM/Groin pseudoaneurysm: Patient presents to 
___ for left ICA aneurysm pipeline embolization; case 
uneventful, patient extubated in the angio-suite and transferred 
to the PACU for continued care and observation. While in the 
PACU, patient had low blood pressure; fluid boluses given and 
hematocrit checked which was 29. CTA Pelvis completed to rule 
out RP bleed. The scan was negative for a bleed, but did show a 
pseudoaneurysm. Vascular was consulted and saw the patient on 
___. They recommended an ultrasound of the left wrist and right 
groin which were negative for abnormalities.  After she became 
symptomatic with a declining hematocrit, she was administered 
one unit of blood on ___. Her hematocrit stabilized and she was 
discharged to home on ___. 

 
Medications on Admission:
Aspirin 325mg
Plavix 75mg
 
Discharge Medications:
1.  Acetaminophen 325-650 mg PO Q6H:PRN fever or pain  
2.  Aspirin 325 mg PO DAILY 
RX *aspirin 325 mg 1 tablet(s) by mouth daily Disp #*90 Tablet 
Refills:*1 
3.  Bisacodyl 10 mg PO/PR DAILY:PRN constipation  
4.  Clopidogrel 75 mg PO DAILY 
RX *clopidogrel 75 mg 1 tablet(s) by mouth daily Disp #*90 
Tablet Refills:*0 
5.  Docusate Sodium 100 mg PO BID  
6.  Senna 17.2 mg PO QHS  

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Left ICA Aneurysm 
Hematoma
Pseudoaneurysm

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Activity
You may gradually return to your normal activities, but we 
recommend you take it easy for the next ___ hours to avoid 
bleeding from your groin.
Heavy lifting, running, climbing, or other strenuous exercise 
should be avoided for ten (10) days. This is to prevent bleeding 
from your groin.
You make take leisurely walks and slowly increase your 
activity at your own pace. ___ try to do too much all at once.
Do not go swimming or submerge yourself in water for five (5) 
days after your procedure.
You make take a shower.
Medications
Resume your normal medications and begin new medications as 
directed.
You may be instructed by your doctor to take one ___ a day 
and/or Plavix. If so, do not take any other products that have 
aspirin in them. If you are unsure of what products contain 
Aspirin, as your pharmacist or call our office.
You may use Acetaminophen (Tylenol) for minor discomfort if 
you are not otherwise restricted from taking this medication.
If you take Metformin (Glucophage) you may start it again 
three (3) days after your procedure.
Care of the Puncture Site
You will have a small bandage over the site.
Remove the bandage in 24 hours by soaking it with water and 
gently peeling it off.
Keep the site clean with soap and water and dry it carefully.
You may use a band-aid if you wish.

What You ___ Experience:
Mild tenderness and bruising at the puncture site (groin).
Soreness in your arms from the intravenous lines.
Mild to moderate headaches that last several days to a few 
weeks.
Fatigue is very normal
Constipation is common. Be sure to drink plenty of fluids and 
eat a high-fiber diet. If you are taking narcotics (prescription 
pain medications), try an over-the-counter stool softener.
When to Call Your Doctor at ___ for:
Severe pain, swelling, redness or drainage from the puncture 
site. 
Fever greater than 101.5 degrees Fahrenheit
Constipation
Blood in your stool or urine
Nausea and/or vomiting
Extreme sleepiness and not being able to stay awake
Severe headaches not relieved by pain relievers
Seizures
Any new problems with your vision or ability to speak
Weakness or changes in sensation in your face, arms, or leg

 
Followup Instructions:
___

right groin pseudoaneurysm
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
___: ___ thrombin injection of right groin pseudoaneurysm 

 
History of Present Illness:
___ with left ICA aneurysm status 10 days post pipeline 
embolization complicated by pseudoaneurysm of right common 
femoral artery. She is admitted in preparation for thrombin 
injection by ___ tomorrow.
 
Past Medical History:
Bilateral subdural hygromas
memory loss
severe mitral valve regurgitation
osteopenia

 
Social History:
___
Family History:
N/A
 
Physical Exam:
GEN: AOx3, NAD
CV: RRR
PULM: breathing comfortably on room air 
GI: soft, NT, ND 
EXT: pitting edema of the right lower extremity to the forefoot, 
with extensive ecchymosis of the circumferential right lower 
extremity, extending to the right foot; pedal pulses faintly 
palpable but limited ___ edema 

 
Pertinent Results:
___: PSEUDOANEURYSM EMBOLIZATION
FINDINGS: 
1. Large 4 x 3 x 2 cm pseudoaneurysm originating off of the 
right proximal 
superficial femoral artery. 
2. Successful thrombosis of the pseudoaneurysm. 
3. Postprocedure ultrasound demonstrated a patent superficial 
femoral artery. 
IMPRESSION:  
Technically successful thrombin injection resulting in 
thrombosis of the right groin pseudoaneurysm. 

___: U/S RIGHT FEMORAL RIGHT IMPRESSION:    
4.8 cm thrombosed pseudoaneurysm within the right groin.  Normal 
appearance of the common femoral artery and vein on color and 
spectral Doppler imaging. 

 
Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ was admitted from the vascular surgery clinic to the 
inpatient service on ___ in preparation for interventional 
radiology procedure. On ___ she underwent thrombin 
injection of the right common femoral artery pseudoaneurysm. She 
tolerated the procedure well, please see the operative report 
for more details. Following the procedure she remained in the 
hospital for monitoring of her pulse exam and hemodynamic 
status. There was no evidence of hematoma and she remained 
hemodynamically stable. On ___ she underwent repeat 
ultrasound for evaluation, which showed a thrombosed 
pseudoaneurysm slightly larger in size. In discussions with the 
diagnostic and interventional radiologists this was determined 
to be expected with treatment of a pseudoaneurysm. She was 
deemed appropriate for discharge home. She will follow up in the 
___ clinic in one week's time and will undergo a 
surveillance ultrasound of the right groin at this time. 
 
Medications on Admission:
The Preadmission Medication list is accurate and complete.
1. Acetaminophen 325-650 mg PO Q6H:PRN fever or pain 
2. Aspirin 325 mg PO DAILY 
3. Clopidogrel 75 mg PO DAILY 
4. Bisacodyl 10 mg PO/PR DAILY:PRN constipation 
5. Docusate Sodium 100 mg PO BID 
6. Senna 17.2 mg PO QHS 

 
Discharge Medications:
1.  Acetaminophen 650 mg PO Q8H:PRN Pain - Mild  
2.  Aspirin 325 mg PO DAILY  
3.  Bisacodyl 10 mg PO DAILY:PRN constipation  
4.  Clopidogrel 75 mg PO DAILY  
5.  Docusate Sodium 100 mg PO BID  
6.  Senna 17.2 mg PO QHS Duration: 1 Dose  

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Large right groin hematoma with  1.1 cm pseudoaneurysm arising 
just below the common femoral artery bifurcation. 

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ was admitted to the postpartum floor after 
presenting with elevated blood pressures thought to be due to 
not taking her medications as directed at home. She was also 
found to have a Pfannensteil incision cellulitis on 
presentation. 
.
For her blood pressures, she was maintained on the nifedipine CR 
30mg PO daily that she was originally discharged on. Her 
pre-eclampsia labs were within normal limits, though she had a 
mild transaminitis which was likely due to the fact that she had 
been taking acetaminophen 500mg Q2 hours since her prior 
discharge. Her blood pressures remained in the normal range 
throughout her admission. She was discharged on the same regimen 
of nifedipine CR 30mg PO daily. 
.
For her wound cellulitis, she was started on Keflex. She 
remained afebrile throughout her admission.

___ 03:59AM URINE  bnzodzpn-POS barbitrt-NEG opiates-NEG

Brief Hospital Course:
Patient was admitted to labor and delivery after being cleared 
by the Emergency Department.  She was considered stable and kept 
on continuous monitoring.  The fetal heart tracing was suddenly 
lost and so transabdominal bedside ultrasound was done.  FHT was 
low and irregular.  She was taken for stat cesarean delivery.  
Please see operative note for full details.  NICU staff was 
present for delivery but there was fetal demise.  Apgars were 
0/0/0.

cesaerean delivery
fetal demise

Routine postpartum instructions were reviewed.
The patient was counselled about the nature of classical uterine 
incision and the need for repeat cesarean deliveries in future 
pregnancies.  It was also recommended that she not get pregnant 
for one year to allow for optimal healing of the uterine 
incision.  A prescription for birth control pills was given to 
patient and she was instructed to start them on the first ___ 
after discharge.

text:
Name:  ___               Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: MEDICINE
 
Allergies: 
Penicillins / Sulfa (Sulfonamides) / Morphine Sulfate
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
Ulcerative Colitis flare
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
Sigmoidoscopy

 
History of Present Illness:
Patient is a ___ y/o F with history of Ulcerative colitis 
presenting with abdominal pain and increased diarrhea x1 week. 

The patient reports that for the past month she has been 
increasing her dose of Asacol, and is now on 800mg twice daily. 
Over the weekend, she began feeling a little pain in her 
abdomen. On ___ morning she woke up at 830 AM with severe, 
sharp abdominal pain. This lasted until about 1pm. She went to 
___ urgent care, they took some blood tests and concluded she 
did not have any inflammation, and she was discharged. She woke 
up the next day with pain again, and went back to urgent care. 
They did a KUB and discharged her. She spoke to her primary on 
___ who prescribed her Rowasa enema, which imrpoved her symptoms 
for that day. ___, whoever, the pain returned. She had been 
having ___ water bowel movements with blood and mucous mon-tue. 
After the rowasa, she had only 2 BMS that day, ___ she was 
back up to about ___ BMS. On ___ night, the pain became 
very sharp, and she called the GI fellow on call here, who 
recommended she come in.

The patient reports ___ water bowel movements daily x5 days. Her 
abdominal pain is sharp, diffuse and intermittent, she reports 
it lasts about 10 minutes for every 30 minutes. SHe also 
complains for fecal urgency, and the feeling of constantly 
having to have a BM. She reports having diarrhea everytime she 
eats or drinks anythign all week. The blood in her stook has 
been mininal, mostly just specs. She denies fevers, chills. 
abdominal pain as above. Nausea, no vomitting. 

In the ER, the patients intial vitals were T 98.5, BP 108/80, RR 
18, 100% on RA. She recieved zofran 4mg IVx1, Morphine 4mg IVx1. 


 
Past Medical History:
Ulcerative Colitis dx ___
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
father recently diagnosed with IBS

 
Physical Exam:
Vitals: T: 97.6 BP: 107/62 P: 96 RR: 20 O2Sat: 100% RA
Gen: no acute distress
HEENT: Clear OP, MMM
NECK: Supple, No LAD, No JVD
CV: RR, NL rate. NL S1, S2. No murmurs, rubs or gallops
LUNGS: CTA, BS ___, No W/R/C
ABD: Soft, NT, ND. NL BS. Patient had just recieved morphine, so 
pain was minimal
EXT: No edema. 2+ DP pulses ___
SKIN: No lesions
NEURO: A&Ox3. Appropriate. CN ___ grossly intact. Preserved 
sensation throughout. ___ strength throughout. ___ reflexes, 
equal ___. Normal coordination. Gait assessment deferred
PSYCH: Listens and responds to questions appropriately, pleasant

 
Pertinent Results:
___ CT abd/pelvis: IMPRESSION: 
1. Bowel wall thickening involving the rectum and entire colon 
with 
associated mild mesenteric stranding and bowel wall edema and 
prominent 
mesenteric lymph nodes most compatible with proctocolitis. 
Mucosal enahncement suugesting disease activity. Associated 
bowel wall thickening of the terminal ileum and dilation 
suggesting that there also may be a chronic component, and a 
component of ileitis. Overall findings are nonspecific and could 
be related to known ulcerative colitis flare, though infectious 
processes cannot be excluded. 

___ Sigmoidoscopy
Impression: Abnormal mucosa in the colon (biopsy, biopsy)
Otherwise normal sigmoidoscopy to 60 cm 

___ 03:10AM BLOOD ESR-23*
___ 03:10AM BLOOD CRP-61.9*
___ 03:10AM BLOOD WBC-10.5# RBC-4.59# Hgb-14.2# Hct-40.2 
MCV-88 MCH-31.0 MCHC-35.4* RDW-12.7 Plt ___
___ 08:10AM BLOOD WBC-7.1 RBC-3.51* Hgb-11.1* Hct-32.0* 
MCV-91 MCH-31.7 MCHC-34.8 RDW-12.7 Plt ___

___ Stool culture negative for ova/parasite, cdiff, 
salmonella, shigella, campylobacter
 
Brief Hospital Course:
Pt is a ___ y/o F with history of ulcerative colitis presenting 
with abdominal pain and diarrhea diagnosed with ulcerative 
colitis flare.

hospital course by problem

Ulcerative Colitis Flare: Patient admitted with the above 
symptoms. Intially these were thought to be an adverse reaction 
to starting asacol versus ulcerative colitis flare. The patient 
had stool culture which were negative for infection. She had a 
sigmoidsocopy that showed diffuse inflammation throughout the 
colon, consistent with flare of Ulcerative colitis. Her ESR (23) 
and CRP (62) were elevated; biopsies were taken to rule-out CMV. 
She was intially treated with morpine and zofran for abd pain 
and nausea. She developed a rash to morphine and was switched to 
dilauded. GI consult team followed her while she was admitted. 
Once stool cultures were negative, the patient was started on IV 
methylprednisolone 20mg TID for 2days. She was able to tolerated 
a liquid, and then a regular, diet. She no longer required 
narcotics or antinausea medications. The frequency of her bowel 
movements decreased to ___ and were no longer bloody. She 
was transitioned to 40mg PO prednisone the night before she was 
dicharged. She tolerated this well with no increase in 
abdmominal pain. She was discharged in time for her GI follow-up 
appoint with with Dr. ___. Her plan on discharge was to wean 
prednisone by 5mg a week, starting with 40mg. She was also 
discharged on Calcium and vitamin D and pantoprazole to take 
while on prednisone. Asacol was held and Azathioprine was 
continued throughout the hospitalization, and on discharge. 

Bandemia/Leukocytosis: UA  negative, stool cultures negative. 
Likely due to colonic inflammation. Resolved with fluids. 

Discharge Day Exam: NCAT, anicteric; heart regular rate and 
rhythm, no m/r/g; lungs CTA B; abdomen soft, NTND; no ___ edema.

Greater than 30 minutes was spent on discharge planning.

 
Medications on Admission:
Rowasa x2 days
Azathioprine 100mg daily
Probiotics
Asacol, stopped 2 days ago 800mg twice daily
MV
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Azathioprine 50 mg Tablet Sig: Two (2) Tablet PO DAILY 
(Daily).  
2. Omeprazole 20 mg Capsule, Delayed Release(E.C.) Sig: One (1) 
Capsule, Delayed Release(E.C.) PO DAILY (Daily).
Disp:*30 Capsule, Delayed Release(E.C.)(s)* Refills:*1*
3. Calcium Carbonate 500 mg (1,250 mg) Tablet Sig: One (1) 
Tablet PO BID (2 times a day).
Disp:*60 Tablet(s)* Refills:*1*
4. Cholecalciferol (Vitamin D3) 400 unit Tablet Sig: Two (2) 
Tablet PO DAILY (Daily).
Disp:*60 Tablet(s)* Refills:*2*
5. Prednisone 20 mg Tablet Sig: as directed Tablet PO once a 
day: as directed.
Disp:*45 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
6. Prednisone 20 mg Tablet Sig: as directed Tablet PO DAILY 
(Daily).
Disp:*90 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Ulcerative Colitis flare

 
Discharge Condition:
stable, tolerating regular diet

 
Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted to the hospital with abdominal pain and 
diarrhea from an Ulcerative colitis flare. You had stool culture 
that were negative. You had a sigmodoscopy which showed evidence 
of inflammation in your colon, consistent with a flare. You were 
treated with IV steroids for 2 days, and then transitioned to 
oral steroids. You tolerated this well and your symptoms 
improved. You were able to tolerate a full diet for the past 
day. 

Please take all medications as prescribed. The following changes 
were made to your medication regimen:
1. You have been started on tapering dose of PREDNISONE (a 
steroid) to be taken every evening. You will reduce your dose by 
5mg every WEEK. the doses are as follows:
- Please take 40mg everyday for 1 week (this is two 20mg pills)
- then take 35mg everyday for 1 week (this is one 20mg pill and 
three 5mg pills)
- then take 30mg everyday for 1 week (this is one 20mg pill and 
two 5mg pills)
- then take 25mg everyday for 1 week (one 20mg pill and one 5mg 
pill)
- then take 20mg every for 1 week (one 20mg pill)
- 15mg for the next week (three 5mg pills)
- 10mg for the next week
- and finally 5mg for the lats week

2. You should take Calcium and vitamin D every while you are on 
prednisone
3. Omeprazole 20mg every while on steroids
 
Followup Instructions:
___

text:
Name:  ___                    Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: ORTHOPAEDICS
 
Allergies: 
No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
Right distal third tib-fib fracture
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
No surgical intervention was performed.

 
History of Present Illness:
___ male w/ hx cardiac stent ___ years ago presents with the
above fracture s/p MCC earlier today. Patient notes he was going
unknown speed when he lost control around a turn. Was wearing a
helmet. No LOC. Has painin RLE. Some tingling but can sense
touch. Was placed in air splint. Has some TTP at right rib cage,
otherwise no complaints. oF note has medial tibial cellulitis
being treated for past few days with amoxicillin.  
 
Past Medical History:
Cardiac stent about ___ years ago. 
 
Social History:
Denies tobacco. Drinks about 2 drinks 4 times a week
 
Physical Exam:
General: Well-appearing male in no acute distress.

Right upper extremity:
- Skin intact
- No deformity, edema, ecchymosis, erythema, induration
- Soft, non-tender arm and forearm
- Full, painless ROM at shoulder, elbow, wrist, and digits
- Fires EPL/FPL/DIO
- SILT axillary/radial/median/ulnar nerve distributions
- 2+ radial pulse, WWP

Left upper extremity:
- Skin intact
- cystic like mass on distal forearm, unchanged in size per pt 
- No deformity, edema, ecchymosis, erythema, induration
- Soft, non-tender arm and forearm
- Full, painless ROM at shoulder, elbow, wrist, and digits
- Fires EPL/FPL/DIO
- SILT axillary/radial/median/ulnar nerve distributions
- 2+ radial pulse, WWP

Right lower extremity:
- Skin intact
- Swelling at anterior thigh though compartments are 
compressible
- Has area of cellulitis at medial leg with eschar at mid
anteromedial tibia 
- Some bruising at distal third in area of fracture. 
- Soft, non-tender thigh
- Fires weak ___
- SILT though somewhat decreased in S/S/SP/DP/T distributions
- 2+ DP pulse, WWP

Left lower extremity:
- Skin intact
- No deformity, edema, ecchymosis, erythema, induration
- Soft, non-tender thigh and leg
- Full, painless ROM at hip, knee, and ankle
- Fires ___
- SILT S/S/SP/DP/T distributions
- 2+ DP pulses, WWP
 
Brief Hospital Course:
The patient presented to the emergency department and was 
evaluated by the orthopedic surgery team. The patient was found 
to have a distal tib-fib fracture and was admitted to the 
orthopedic surgery service. The patient was treated 
nonoperatively in a short leg cast. The patient worked with 
physical therapy who determined that discharge to home with 
follow-up in ___ near his home was appropriate. The patient 
was given anticoagulation per routine, and the patient's home 
medications were continued throughout this hospitalization. The 
___ hospital course was otherwise unremarkable.

At the time of discharge the patient's pain was well controlled 
with oral medications, and the patient was voiding/moving bowels 
spontaneously. The patient is NWB in the right lower extremity, 
and will be discharged on Lovenox for DVT prophylaxis. The 
patient will follow up with ___ Orthopedics and his PCP for 
ongoing care.  He has stated that he does not anticipate any 
issues with seen both ___ orthopedics and his PCP next week. He 
was told that should he encounter any issues whatsoever in 
arranging follow-up appointments in ___  that he should feel 
free to call us.  He was told directly that this injury may very 
well require surgery and that close follow-up is necessary. He 
also understands that should his cellulitis worsen he should 
seek immediate medical attention. The patient was also given 
written instructions concerning precautionary instructions and 
the appropriate follow-up care. The patient expressed readiness 
for discharge.
 
Medications on Admission:
Aspirin 81 mg PO DAILY  
 
Discharge Medications:
1.  Acetaminophen 650 mg PO Q6H  
2.  Cephalexin 500 mg PO Q6H Cellulitis 
RX *cephalexin 500 mg 1 capsule(s) by mouth q6 hours Disp #*56 
Capsule Refills:*0 
3.  Docusate Sodium 100 mg PO BID  
4.  Enoxaparin Sodium 40 mg SC Q24H 
RX *enoxaparin 40 mg/0.4 mL 40 mg Subcutaneously Nightly Disp 
#*30 Syringe Refills:*0 
5.  OxyCODONE (Immediate Release) ___ mg PO Q3H:PRN Pain - 
Moderate 
  Reason for PRN duplicate override: Alternating agents for 
similar severity
RX *oxycodone 10 mg 1 tablet(s) by mouth q4 PRN Disp #*70 Tablet 
Refills:*0 
6.  Senna 8.6 mg PO BID:PRN Constipation - First Line  
7.  Tizanidine 2 mg PO TID:PRN Spasms 
RX *tizanidine 2 mg 1 tablet(s) by mouth q8 PRN Disp #*30 Tablet 
Refills:*0 
8.  Aspirin 81 mg PO DAILY  

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Right distal third tib-fib fracture with intra-articular 
involvement

 
Discharge Condition:
AVSS
NAD, A&Ox3
RLE: Examined before cast was placed.  There is residual 
erythema from the patient's cellulitis that is mildly improved 
since admission.  Ecchymosis is noted over the distal tibia.  
Fires FHL, ___, TA, GCS. SILT ___ n distributions. 2+ 
DP pulse, wwp distally. After the cast was placed: SILT exposed 
toes, fires exposed toes, WWP exposed toes.

 
Discharge Instructions:
INSTRUCTIONS AFTER ORTHOPAEDIC SURGERY:

- You were in the hospital for orthopedic surgery. It is normal 
to feel tired or "washed out" after surgery, and this feeling 
should improve over the first few days to week. 
- Resume your regular activities as tolerated, but please follow 
your weight bearing precautions strictly at all times.

ACTIVITY AND WEIGHT BEARING:
-Nonweightbearing in the  right lower extremity

MEDICATIONS:
  1)  Take Tylenol ___ every 6 hours around the clock. This is 
an over the counter medication.
  2)  Add  oxycodone as needed for increased pain. Aim to wean 
off this medication in 1 week or sooner.  This is an example on 
how to wean down:
Take 1 tablet every 3 hours as needed x 1 day,
then 1 tablet every 4 hours as needed x 1 day,
then 1 tablet every 6 hours as needed x 1 day,
then 1 tablet every 8 hours as needed x 2 days, 
then 1 tablet every 12 hours as needed x 1 day,
then 1 tablet every before bedtime as needed x 1 day.  
Then continue with Tylenol for pain.
  3)  Do not stop the Tylenol until you are off of the narcotic 
medication.
  4)  Per state regulations, we are limited in the amount of 
narcotics we can prescribe. If you require more, you must 
contact the office to set up an appointment because we cannot 
refill this type of pain medication over the phone. 
  5)  Narcotic pain relievers can cause constipation, so you 
should drink eight 8oz glasses of water daily and continue 
following the bowel regimen as stated on your medication 
prescription list. These meds (senna, colace, miralax) are over 
the counter and may be obtained at any pharmacy.
  6)  Do not drink alcohol, drive a motor vehicle, or operate 
machinery while taking narcotic pain relievers.
  7)  Please take all medications as prescribed by your 
physicians at discharge.
  8)  Continue all home medications unless specifically 
instructed to stop by your surgeon.

- Please take Lovenox daily for 4 weeks

how to wean down:
Take 1 tablet every 3 hours as needed x 1 day,
then 1 tablet every 4 hours as needed x 1 day,
then 1 tablet every 6 hours as needed x 1 day,
then 1 tablet every 8 hours as needed x 2 days,
then 1 tablet every 12 hours as needed x 1 day,
then 1 tablet every before bedtime as needed x 1 day.
Then continue with Tylenol for pain.

medication.

contact the office to set up an appointment because we cannot

Brief Hospital Course:
___ G4P1 with spontaneous di-di twins admitted at 25+6 weeks 
with PPROM.
.
Mrs ___ was grossly ruptured with clear fluid on arrival 
to labor and delivery. She otherwise had no signs or symptoms of 
chorioamnionitis. Fetal testing was reassuring and her twins 
were breech/vertex and EFW's were 50% and 75% for A and B 
respectively. She had no contractions on toco. She was started 
on Amp/Erythro for latency and given a course of betamethasone 
for fetal lung maturity. The NICU was consulted. After prolonged 
monitoring on labor and delivery, she was transferred to the 
antepartum floor. ___ (Dr ___ was consulted and ultrasound 
showed breech/breech twins with minimal fluid arount Twin A, BPP 
___ and nl fluid around Twin B, BPP ___. His recommendations 
included close fetal surveillance with daily NSTs and twice 
weekly BPPs, betamethasone, and latency antibiotics. Later that 
evening she was transferred to labor and delivery for prolonged 
monitoring after she reported cramping and leaking pink-tinged 
fluid. She also had variables in both fetal heart tracings. Upon 
arrival, a prolapsed umbilical cord was noted and stat classical 
cesarean section was performed. Twin A, baby girl delivered from 
breech with apgars of 6 and 7. Twin B, baby boy, transverse lie, 
apgars with 6 and 7. NICU staff was present for delivery and 
transferred the infant immediately for prematurity. Prior to 
delivery, she had received her second dose of betamethasone, 
however was not yet BMZ complete.
.
Mrs ___ had no postoperative complications and she was 
discharged home on POD#5.

prenatal vitamins

Brief Hospital Course:
The patient was brought to the operating room on ___ for a 
right total knee arthroplasty.  See operative note for details.  
He tolerated the procedure well.  He was extubated and brought 
to the recovery room in stable condition.  From there, he was 
transferred to the floor for further care.  On the floor he did 
well.  He was evaluated by physical therapy and progressed well. 
 On POD#3 he had dyspnea on exursion and desaturations to the 
80's when off of oxygen.  A CTA was done that showed a RLL PE.  
Medicine was consulted and he was placed on coumadin with a 
therapuetic lovenox bridge.  His hospital course was otherwise 
without incident.  His pain was well controlled.  His labs and 
vital signs remained stable.  He is being discharged today in 
stable condition.
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Oxycodone 5 mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO Q4-6H () as needed 
for pain.

(1) Tablet, Delayed Release (E.C.) PO Q24H (every 24 hours).  
3. Hexavitamin     Tablet Sig: One (1) Cap PO DAILY (Daily).  
4. Senna 8.6 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO BID (2 times a 
day) as needed for constipation.  
5. Magnesium Hydroxide 400 mg/5 mL Suspension Sig: Thirty (30) 
ML PO BID (2 times a day) as needed.  
6. Docusate Sodium 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO BID (2 
times a day).  
7. Nifedipine 60 mg Tablet Sustained Release Sig: Two (2) Tablet 
Sustained Release PO QD ().  
8. Hydrochlorothiazide 12.5 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO 
DAILY (Daily).  
9. Atenolol 50 mg Tablet Sig: Two (2) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily).  
10. Atorvastatin 10 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY 
(Daily).  
11. Acetaminophen 325 mg Tablet Sig: Two (2) Tablet PO Q4H 
(every 4 hours).  
12. Enoxaparin 80 mg/0.8 mL Syringe Sig: One (1)  Subcutaneous 
Q12H (every 12 hours): please continue through ___ and/or INR 
> 2, and overlap one day, whichever if longer.  
13. Warfarin 5 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily) 
for 3 months: please continue lovenox through ___ and/or INR > 
2, and overlap one day, whichever if longer.  Goal INR ___.

Extended Care

___

Right knee ostoearthritis
Pulmonary Embolism

Stable

increases with any activity and even standing. She describes the
pain as ___. She denies bowel, bladder or sexual issues.

MVA ___
hypothyroidism

appendectomy ___

Physical Exam:
On Arrival:
Neuro:

L     5>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>

vibration bilaterally.

On discharge:

affect.

Incision clean, dry, and intact; steri-strips in place.

Motor:
      D    B     T    WE   WF    IP    Q  H     AT    ___    G
R     5>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>
L     5>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>

Sensation: Intact to light touch bilaterally.

 
Brief Hospital Course:
The patient presented as a same day admission for surgery. The 
patient was taken to the operating room on ___ for T10-L2 
posterior spinal fusion, which the patient tolerated well. For 
full details of the procedure please see the separately dictated 
operative report. The patient was taken from the OR to the PACU 
in stable condition and after satisfactory recovery from 
anesthesia was transferred to the floor. The patient was 
initially given IV fluids and IV pain medications, and 
progressed to a regular diet and oral medications by POD#2. Pain 
control was initially an issue but by POD3 she was more 
comfortable. The patient was given ___ antibiotics 
and anticoagulation per routine. The patient's home medications 
were continued throughout this hospitalization. The patient 
worked with ___ who determined that discharge to home was 
appropriate. The ___ hospital course was otherwise 
unremarkable.

At the time of discharge the patient's pain was well controlled 
with oral medications, incisions were clean/dry/intact, and the 
patient was voiding/moving bowels spontaneously. The patient 
will follow up with Dr. ___ routine. A thorough 
discussion was had with the patient regarding the diagnosis and 
expected post-discharge course including reasons to call the 
office or return to the hospital, and all questions were 
answered. The patient was also given written instructions 
concerning precautionary instructions and the appropriate 
follow-up care. The patient expressed readiness for discharge.

 
Medications on Admission:
Levothyroxine 112mg qAM
 
Discharge Medications:
1.  Acetaminophen 1000 mg PO Q6H  
2.  Bisacodyl 10 mg PO/PR DAILY  
3.  Cepacol (Sore Throat Lozenge) 1 LOZ PO Q4H:PRN sore throat  
4.  Diazepam 5 mg PO BID:PRN pain 
RX *diazepam 5 mg 1 tablet by mouth BID PRN Disp #*15 Tablet 
Refills:*0 
5.  Docusate Sodium 100 mg PO BID  
6.  OxyCODONE (Immediate Release) ___ mg PO Q4H:PRN Pain - 
Moderate 
RX *oxycodone 5 mg ___ tablet(s) by mouth q4h prn Disp #*50 
Tablet Refills:*0 
7.  Senna 8.6 mg PO BID  
8.  Levothyroxine Sodium 112 mcg PO DAILY  

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
T11-12 kyphosis

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Spinal Fusion

Surgery
Your dressing may come off on the second day after surgery. 
Please keep the incision dry for 72 hours post-op 
Your incision is closed with absorbable sutures which will not 
require removal. Do not remove your Steri-strips; let them fall 
off.
Do not apply any lotions or creams to the site. 
Please avoid swimming for two weeks
Call your surgeon if there are any signs of infection like 
redness, fever, or drainage. 

Activity
You must wear your brace at all times when out of bed. You may 
apply your brace sitting at the edge of the bed. You do not need 
to sleep with it on. 
We recommend that you avoid heavy lifting, running, climbing, 
or other strenuous exercise until your follow-up appointment.
You make take leisurely walks and slowly increase your 
activity at your own pace. ___ try to do too much all at once.
No driving while taking any narcotic or sedating medication. 
No contact sports until cleared by your neurosurgeon. 
Do NOT smoke. Smoking can affect your healing and fusion.

Medications 
Do not take any anti-inflammatory medications such as Motrin, 
Advil, Aspirin, and Ibuprofen etc until cleared by your 
neurosurgeon.
You may use Acetaminophen (Tylenol) for minor discomfort if 
you are not otherwise restricted from taking this medication.
It is important to increase fluid intake while taking pain 
medications. We also recommend a stool softener like Colace. 
Pain medications can cause constipation. 

When to Call Your Doctor at ___ for:
Severe pain, swelling, redness or drainage from the incision 
site. 
Fever greater than 101.5 degrees Fahrenheit
New weakness or changes in sensation in your arms or legs.

 
Followup Instructions:
___

text:
Name:  ___                     Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: ORTHOPAEDICS
 
Allergies: 
Patient recorded as having No Known Allergies to Drugs
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
Left hand stiffness with extensor tendon scar tissue with radial 
digital nerve palsy.

 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
1. Left hand tenolysis extensor digitorum communis tendon
    x4, extensor indicis proprius tendon as well as the
    extensor pollicis longus tendon and extensor carpi
    radialis longus and extensor carpi radialis brevis
    tendons.
2. Manipulation under anesthesia left index and long
    finger, distal interphalangeal joints and proximal
    interphalangeal joints.
3. Capsulectomy metacarpophalangeal joints to the second,
    third and fourth digits.
4. Radiodigital nerve neurolysis.

 
History of Present Illness:
This is a ___ gentleman who had a skate injury from 
hockey to the dorsum of his left hand that lacerated all of his 
extensor tendons and the patient underwent repairs to those 
extensor tendons on ___ and developed significant amount of 
scar tissue and is here today for surgical correction of this 
problem.

 
Past Medical History:
None
.
PAST SURGICAL HISTORY
right ACL reconstruction ___ years ago.

 
Social History:
___
Family History:
non-contributory
 
Physical Exam:
Pre-procedure PE from Anesthesia Record ___:
Pulse-->63/min resps-->16/min b/p-->152/96 O2sat-->98%
Airway: as documented in detail in Anesthesia Record
Dental: Good
Head/neck range of motion: Free range of motion
Heart: S1S2 regular
Lungs: Clear to auscultation
 
Brief Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the plastic surgery service on 
___ and had surgical repail of left hand stiffness with 
extensor tendon scar tissue with radial digital nerve palsy.  
The patient tolerated the procedure well. 
.
Neuro: Post-operatively, the patient received Dilaudid IV with 
good effect and adequate pain control. When tolerating oral 
intake, the patient was transitioned to oxycodone. The patient 
felt that oxycodone 5 mg might make him a bit sleepy although it 
provided good pain control so Dr. ___ discharging him 
with prescriptions for both oxycodone and for Vicodin 
(7.5/500mg) that patient could have two different options for 
pain control depending on his needs.
.
CV: The patient was stable from a cardiovascular standpoint; 
vital signs were routinely monitored.
.
Pulmonary: The patient was stable from a pulmonary standpoint; 
vital signs were routinely monitored.
.
GI/GU: Post-operatively, the patient was given IV fluids until 
tolerating oral intake. His diet was advanced when appropriate, 
which was tolerated well. Intake and output were closely 
monitored. 
.
ID: Post-operatively, the patient was started on IV cefazolin, 
then switched to PO cephalexin on POD#1. The patient's 
temperature was closely watched for signs of infection. 
.
Prophylaxis: The patient was encouraged to get up and ambulate 
as early as possible. 
.
At the time of discharge on POD#1, the patient was doing well, 
afebrile with stable vital signs, tolerating a regular diet, 
ambulating, voiding without assistance, and pain was well 
controlled. He was discharged home with sutures on anterior 
surface of left hand as well as a ___ drain in the area of 
the anterior wrist.  

 
Medications on Admission:
oxycodone
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Oxycodone 5 mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO every six (6) hours 
as needed for pain.
Disp:*25 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
2. Hydrocodone-Acetaminophen 7.5-500 mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets 
PO every six (6) hours: Max ___. Each tab has 500mg Tylenol 
(max 4000mg ___.
Disp:*50 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
3. Keflex ___ mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO every six (6) 
hours for 7 days.
Disp:*28 Capsule(s)* Refills:*0*

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Hypertrophic scar s/p trauma left hand

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Followup Instructions:
___

text:
Name:  ___                   Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: NEUROSURGERY
 
Allergies: 
Percocet / Vicodin / Ciprofloxacin
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
Fall
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
None
 
History of Present Illness:
Patient is an ___ y/o female who was transferred from ___.  Per report she fell this morning at 7 am at home.  
Her
PCA took her to ___ in the afternoon when her
headaches worsened. CT of the head revealed a left SDH with 1cm
of midline shift. Upon arrival to ___ patient was awake and
neurologically intact. In the ED she became acutely lethargic 
and
was intubated and transferred to ___.  Here her CT was 
repeated
and showed expansion of her subdural hematoma.  Upon 
examination,
patient showed very minimal response to stimuli.

 
Past Medical History:
Back pain, mental illness, depression, hypertension,
hypercholesteremia
PSH: Appendectomy, Back Surgery, Cholecystectomy, hysterectomy

 
Social History:
___
Family History:
Unknown
 
Physical Exam:
PHYSICAL EXAM:
O: T:  BP: 189/84        HR:    R 14 CMV      O2Sats
Gen: Intubated

HEENT: Left ecchymotic with a subgaleal hematoma over left eye
      
Neck: Trauma Collar
Lungs: CTA bilaterally.
Cardiac: RRR. 
Abd: Soft
Extrem: Warm and well-perfused.
Neuro:
Mental status: Unresponsive

Cranial Nerves:
I: Not tested
II: Pupils equally round 4mm non reactive, weak corneal on the
left, weak cough, No gag

Motor: No Response to noxious stimuli

Toes MUTE

 
Pertinent Results:
CT head w/o contrast: ___
IMPRESSION:  Increase in size of left intracranial subdural 
hematoma with 
increase in midline shift and effacement of the suprasellar 
cistern concerning for downward transtentorial herniation. 

 
Brief Hospital Course:
Mrs. ___ was transferred from ___ with a 1 cm acute SDH 
after falling. Her SDH  expanded on arrival to ___, with a 1.5 
cm midline shift and impending downward transtentorial 
herniation. Her GCS was 3 on arrival. The patient was 
transferred to the ICU with a poor exam. No surgical 
intervention indicated as patient's exam and prognosis are poor. 

On ___, the patient was posturing to noxious stimulus, no 
corneals and decreased cough. Dr. ___ spoke to her family 
and updated them regarding patient's prognosis. Social work was 
consulted to guide the family regarding patient's wishes and 
discussing CMO/code status. 

On ___ the family was at the patients bedside and the decision 
was made to make the patient care and comfort measures only.  
The patient was extubated. and transferred to the floor.

The patient and family had been seen by Palliative Care.  The 
patient was placed on a low-dose morphine drip with PRN morphine 
boluses for tachypnea, dyspnea and overall facilitation of 
comfort.  On ___, the bedside RN contacted the Neurosurgery 
team to inform that the patient died.  She was pronounced at 
___.  Her daughter, ___, was informed.  The daughter did not 
request an autopsy.  All admitting and "report of death" 
paperwork was completed.
 
Medications on Admission:
unknown
 
Discharge Medications:
none
 
Discharge Disposition:
Expired
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
subdural hematoma

 
Discharge Condition:
deceased

 
Discharge Instructions:
none
 
Followup Instructions:
___

red, and thus CBI continued.  After CBI was clamped, and urine 
was clear pink, it was determined that the patient could safely 
undergo a trial of void.  However, the patient was quite anxious 
about pink color of urine and that he would not be able to void 
once the catheter was removed. He requested to stay overnight.  
On POD #2, CBI was clamped, and later evaluation revealed clear 
yellow urine.  Trial of void was performed, and he was able to 
urinate immediately, with a PVR of approximately 30 cc.  He was 
able to void yellow urine again within 3 hours of his voiding 
trial.  He had no complaints of pain, was tolerating a diet 
without n/v, ambulating without difficulty.  It was determined 
that he could safely be discharged home on POD #2.   
 
Medications on Admission:
omeprazole magnesium [Prilosec OTC] 20 mg Tablet daily
 
alfuzosin [Uroxatral] 10 mg Tablet Sustained Release 24 hr daily
 
atorvastatin [Lipitor] 10 mg Tablet daily 
 
flaxseed * patient unable to identify actual drug name *  daily, 
___ uncertain

wheat germ oil * patient unable to identify actual drug name * 
daily, ___ uncertain
 
Cod Liver Oil Oral Capsule 1 cap every day
 
Multivitamins Oral 1 tab-cap every day

 
Discharge Medications:
1. Acetaminophen ___ mg PO Q6H:PRN pain, temp 
RX *acetaminophen 500 mg ___ tablet(s) by mouth every six (6) 
hours Disp #*60 Tablet Refills:*0
2. Docusate Sodium 100 mg PO BID constipation 
RX *docusate sodium 100 mg 1 capsule(s) by mouth twice a day 
Disp #*60 Capsule Refills:*0
3. OxycoDONE (Immediate Release)  5 mg PO Q4H:PRN nausea 
RX *oxycodone 5 mg 1 tablet(s) by mouth every four (4) hours 
Disp #*30 Tablet Refills:*0
4. Phenazopyridine 100 mg PO TID Duration: 3 Days 
RX *phenazopyridine 200 mg 1 tablet(s) by mouth three times a 
day Disp #*12 Tablet Refills:*0

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
BPH
 
Discharge Condition:
Stable
AOx3
functionally independent
 
Discharge Instructions:
-Do not lift anything heavier than a phone book (10 pounds) or 
drive until you are seen by your Urologist in follow-up

-You may continue to periodically see small amounts of blood in 
your urine--this is normal and will gradually improve

 -Resume all of your pre-admission medications, except HOLD 
aspirin until you see your urologist in followup AND your foley 
has been removed (if not already done)

-You will be discharged home with a medication called PYRIDIUM 
that will help with the "burning" pain you may experience when 
voiding. This medication may turn your urine
bright orange.

      -Colace has been prescribed to avoid post surgical 
constipation and constipation related to narcotic pain 
medication. Discontinue if loose stool or diarrhea develops. 
Colace is a stool softener, NOT a laxative

-Do not eat constipating foods for ___ weeks, drink plenty of 
fluids to keep hydrated

-No vigorous physical activity or sports for 4 weeks or until 
otherwise advised

-Tylenol should be your first line pain medication, a narcotic 
pain medication has been prescribed for breakthrough pain >4. 
Replace Tylenol with narcotic pain medication.

-Max daily Tylenol (acetaminophen) dose is 4 grams from ALL 
sources, note that narcotic pain medication also contains 
Tylenol

-Do not drive or drink alcohol while taking narcotics and do not 
operate dangerous machinery. Also, if the Foley catheter and Leg 
Bag are in place--Do NOT drive (you may be a passenger).

text:
Name:  ___            Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: UROLOGY
 
Allergies: 
No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
Hematuria, inability to void
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
None this admission

 
History of Present Illness:
Mr. ___ is a ___ yo M with BPH who had recently
undergone a TURP by Dr. ___ on ___.  He was discharged 
on
POD#2 after succesfully passing a trial of void. He was able to
urinate without difficulty until the evening of ___, when he
strained to have a bowel movement, noticed blood at his 
uretheral
meatus, and subsequently was unable to void.  He presented to 
the
ER, where a foley was placed and his bladder was irrigated
revealing clots.  Several days later, he presented to clinic on
___ because he wanted his catheter removed.  He did not have 
any
urinary difficulties until today, when he noticed some 
hematuria,
and again was unable to void.  He presented to ___,
with clot retention today.  Another foley was placed, bladder
irrigated, and patient wished to be admitted at ___.  He 
denies
any fever, chills, nausea, abdominal pain, lightheadedness,
dizziness.

 
Past Medical History:
BPH
Prostatitis

ALL:  NKDA

 
Social History:
___
Family History:
Unremarkable
 
Physical Exam:
Afebrile, VSS
NAD, pleasant, conversant
Unlabored breathing
Abdomen ND, soft, NTTP
Foley ___ in place draining clear pink urine
Extremities WWP
No gross focal abnormalities
 
Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. ___ was admitted for continuous irrigation of his 
bladder, which he was able to tolerate.  During his admission, 
he did not complain of any pain, except for sporadic bladder 
spasms.  He remained afebrile, with stable vital signs.  He was 
able to tolerate a regular diet, ambulate independently, and 
produce adequate amounts of clear urine.  On HD #2, his 
hematuria was significantly improved, CBI was discontinued.  He 
was sent home with his foley catheter and instruction to follow 
up in clinic the following week for voiding trial.  
 
Medications on Admission:
omeprazole magnesium [Prilosec OTC] 20 mg Tablet daily
 
alfuzosin [Uroxatral] 10 mg Tablet Sustained Release 24 hr daily
 
atorvastatin [Lipitor] 10 mg Tablet daily 
 
flaxseed * patient unable to identify actual drug name *  daily, 

___ uncertain

wheat germ oil * patient unable to identify actual drug name * 
daily, ___ uncertain
 
Cod Liver Oil Oral Capsule 1 cap every day
 
Multivitamins Oral 1 tab-cap every day

Acetaminophen ___ mg PO Q6H:PRN pain, temp 

OxycoDONE (Immediate Release)  5 mg PO Q4H:PRN pain 

 
Discharge Medications:
1. Atorvastatin 10 mg PO DAILY 
2. Docusate Sodium 100 mg PO BID 
3. Finasteride 5 mg PO DAILY 
RX *finasteride 5 mg 1 tablet(s) by mouth daily Disp #*30 Tablet 
Refills:*0
4. Omeprazole 20 mg PO DAILY 

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Clot retention 

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
-Do not lift anything heavier than a phone book (10 pounds) or 
drive until you are seen by your Urologist in follow-up

-You may continue to periodically see small amounts of blood in 
your urine--this is normal and will gradually improve

 -Resume all of your pre-admission medications, except HOLD

-Colace has been prescribed to avoid post surgical 
constipation and constipation related to narcotic pain 
medication. Discontinue if loose stool or diarrhea develops. 
Colace is a stool softener, NOT a laxative

-Do not eat constipating foods for ___ weeks, drink plenty of 
fluids to keep hydrated

-No vigorous physical activity or sports for 4 weeks or until 
otherwise advised

-Tylenol should be your first line pain medication, a narcotic

Replace Tylenol with narcotic pain medication.

-Max daily Tylenol (acetaminophen) dose is 4 grams from ALL

Tylenol

-Do not drive or drink alcohol while taking narcotics and do not

text:
Name:  ___                     Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: ORTHOPAEDICS
 
Allergies: 
No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
___ yo RHD male with initial injury to dorsum of left hand
with extensor tendon laceration in ___. Underwent the
following on ___
1. Extensor tendon second, third and fourth digit tenolysis.
2. Arthroscopically assisted procedure to the left hand.
Here with two day hx of increased erythema, edema, and
fluctuance.  Wound spontaneously drained.  Denies fevers, 
chills,
or other sign of systemic infection. Pain is minimal.

 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
Bedside incision, drainage, and debridement of dorsal left hand 
abscess
 
History of Present Illness:
___ yo RHD male with initial injury to dorsum of left hand
with extensor tendon laceration in ___. Underwent the
following on ___
1. Extensor tendon second, third and fourth digit tenolysis.
2. Arthroscopically assisted procedure to the left hand.
Here with two day hx of increased erythema, edema, and
fluctuance.  Wound spontaneously drained.  Denies fevers, 
chills,
or other sign of systemic infection. Pain is minimal.

 
Past Medical History:
Hypertension
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
non-contributory
 
Physical Exam:
Open draining wound, dorsum left hand.  Erythema,
induration, and fluctuance.  Pulses / sensation intact in R/M/U
distribution.  FROM in extension / flexion.

 
Pertinent Results:
___ 11:00PM   WBC-11.6* RBC-4.75 HGB-15.3 HCT-42.3 MCV-89 
MCH-32.2* MCHC-36.2* RDW-12.9
___ 11:00PM   NEUTS-68.4 ___ MONOS-4.1 EOS-2.1 
BASOS-0.___ -Admitted for IV unasyn and pain control
___ - resolving cellulitis, AF, VSS, kept for 1 more day of 
IV therapy.  Preliminary wound cultures pending.
___ - Preliminary cultures coag negative staph.  AF, VSS, 
wound with semi-purulent drainage.  Stable for discharge.
 
Medications on Admission:
Lisinopril
 
Discharge Medications:
1. lisinopril 5 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily) 
as needed for htn.  
2. Bactrim DS 800-160 mg Tablet Sig: Two (2) Tablet PO twice a 
day as needed for infection for 3 days: Then 1 tablet BID x 11 
Days. Dispense #34.
Disp:*34 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
3. Vicodin ___ mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO every ___ hours 
as needed for pain.
Disp:*30 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
4. iodoform ___ X ___  -yard Bandage Sig: One (1) inch Topical 
twice a day as needed for wound care: Pack wound as directed.
Disp:*3 bottles* Refills:*3*
5. Gauze Pad 4 X 4   Bandage Sig: One (1) pad Topical twice a 
day as needed for wound care: wound care as directed.
Disp:*2 boxes* Refills:*5*
6. Kerlix ___ X ___  -yard Bandage Sig: One (1) roll Topical 
twice a day as needed for wound care: wound care as directed.  
Provide equivalent dressing supply as needed.
Disp:*25 rolls* Refills:*5*

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
1) Left dorsal hand abscess and cellulitis
2) Coagulase negative Staph on Preliminary cultures

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
1) Betadine / warm tap water soaks for 15 minutes / twice a day. 
Then may shower, pack wound lightly with ___ iodoform gauze 
(enough to raise wound edges circumferentially).  Cover with dry 
gauze and kerlix roll.
2) Take Bactrim DS, 2 tabs PO BID x 3 days, then 1 tab PO BID x 
11 days
3) Keep LUE elevated as much as possible
4) Do not drive while taking pain meds
5) Do not submerge wound in pool, hot tub, lake, ocean, etc...

 
Followup Instructions:

drainage from lumbar incision

I&D of lumbar wound (___)

 
History of Present Illness:
___ y.o. male s/p L4 hemilaminectomy with L3 laminotomy right
sided (___) that was c/b CSF leak and lumbar wound with
readmission and treatment with vancomycin and ertapenem who now
presents with drainage from his wound.

Patient was readmitted to the hospital on ___ and then
discharged on ___.  During that time he underwent I&D of
lumbar wound as well as dural repair.  He reports that this
morning, he noted yellow drainage from his wound.  He was seen 
as
recently as yesterday by Dr. ___ his wound was clean,
dry, and intact at that time.

He otherwise denies fevers, chills, abdominal pain, chest pain,
shortness of breath.  He denies weakness/numbness.
