see admit H&P
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
see admit H&P
 
Physical Exam:
see admit H&P
 
Brief Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted for wound monitoring and for MRI. His 
antibiotics were continued.  He was taken to the operating room 
on ___ for I&D of his lumbar spine operative site.  
Cultures were followed postoperatively, and the infectious 
disease service was consulted for antibiotic recommendations.  
Meropenem was changed to cefepime due to allergic response to 
meropenem.  The pt tolerated infusion of cefepime prior to 
discharge home.  The patient was discharged home with services, 
tolerating regular diet and with pain well controlled on oral 
medications.  Antibiotics will be planned for 3 week course 
(last day of treatment on ___ per ID service 
recommendations.
 
Medications on Admission:
1. Docusate 100mg PO BID prn constipation
2. Acetaminophen 325-650mg PO q 6 hours prn fever/pain
3. ertapenem 1gm IV daily x 3 weeks
4. Vancomycin 1250mg IV q 8 hours 
5. oxycodone ___ q ___ hours prn pain
 
Discharge Medications:
1. docusate sodium 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO BID (2 
times a day) as needed for constipation.  
2. acetaminophen 325 mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO Q6H (every 6 
hours) as needed for pain/fever.  
3. vancomycin 500 mg Recon Soln Sig: 1500 (1500) mg Intravenous 
Q 8H (Every 8 Hours).  
4. oxycodone 5 mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO Q4H (every 4 hours) 
as needed for pain: do not drink alcohol, drive, or operate 
machinery while taking this medication.  
5. docusate sodium 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO BID (2 
times a day) as needed for constipation.  
6. acetaminophen 325 mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO Q6H (every 6 
hours) as needed for pain/fever.  
7. oxycodone 5 mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO Q4H (every 4 hours) 
as needed for pain: do not drink alcohol, drive, or operate 
machinery while taking this medication.
Disp:*100 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
8. vancomycin 500 mg Recon Soln Sig: 1500 (1500) mg Intravenous 
every twelve (12) hours for 18 days: last day of treatment on 
___.
Disp:*QS QS* Refills:*0*
9. cefepime 2 gram Recon Soln Sig: Two (2) grams Intravenous Q8H 
(every 8 hours) for 18 days: last day of treatment on ___ 
___.
Disp:*QS QS* Refills:*0*

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home With Service
 
Facility:
___
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
lumbar wound drainage

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
-Activity: You should not lift anything greater than 10 lbs for 
2 weeks. You will be more comfortable if you do not or sit or 
stand more than ~45 minutes without moving around.
-Rehabilitation/ Physical Therapy: 
o2-3 times a day you should go for a walk for ___ minutes as 
part of your recovery.  You can walk as much as you can 
tolerate. 
oLimit any kind of lifting.
-Diet: Eat a normal healthy diet. You may have some 
constipation after surgery. .
-Wound Care: If the incision is draining cover it with a new 
sterile dressing.  If it is dry then you can leave the incision 
open to the air.  Once the incision is completely dry (usually 
___ days after the operation) you may take a shower. Do not soak 
the incision in a bath or pool.  If the incision starts draining 
at anytime after surgery, do not get the incision wet. Cover it 
with a sterile dressing.  Call the office. 
-You should take your Normal Medications.
-You have also been given Additional Medications to control 
your pain. 
 
Followup Instructions:
___

Total laparoscopic hysterectomy, bilateral salpingo-oophrectomy, 
cystoscopy

 
History of Present Illness:
___ G0 presenting for consultation regarding recent diagnosis 
of endometrial cancer. Patient presented to Dr. ___ 
with irregular vaginal bleeding and had a PUS that showed an 
abnormal endometrial stripe. She subsequently underwent a Hsc, 
D&C on ___ that showed grade 1 endometrioid endometrial 
adenocarcinoma.  PUS on ___ showed a 8.4x4.3x6.0cm mildly 
enlarged uterus, normal ovaries. She currently has daily 
spotting, no heavy bleeding. 10 point ROS positive for 
occasional pelvic pain and lower back pain, otherwise negative.

 
Past Medical History:
Obstetrical History: G0 
.

- Unsure LMP, almost daily bleeding for the past several months
- Menses previously regular every month. Denies history of
menorrhagia or dysmenorrhea
- Denies history of abnormal Pap tests. Last Pap test ___
negative
- Denies history of pelvic infections of sexually transmitted
infections
- Denies history of HRT
.

by Dr ___ at ___ and therapist

.

appendectomy  
.

-Last Colonoscopy: no

.
All: NKDA

___

First cousin with breast cancer. No fam hx of GYN/colon cancer 

 
Physical Exam:

Afebrile, vitals stable
No acute distress
CV: regular rate and rhythm
Pulm: clear to auscultation bilaterally
Abd: soft, appropriately tender, nondistended, incision 
clean/dry/intact, no rebound/guarding
___: nontender, nonedematous

 
Pertinent Results:
___ 07:55AM BLOOD WBC-7.6 RBC-3.79* Hgb-10.9* Hct-31.4* 
MCV-83 MCH-28.8 MCHC-34.8 RDW-12.9 Plt ___
___ 07:55AM BLOOD Neuts-71.7* ___ Monos-8.2 Eos-0.3 
Baso-0.1
___ 07:55AM BLOOD Glucose-93 UreaN-13 Creat-0.8 Na-139

Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ was admitted to the gynecologic oncology service 
after undergoing a total laparoscopic hysterectomy, bilateral 
salpingo-oophorectomy, and cystoscopy. Please see the operative 
report for full details.  
.
Her post-operative course is detailed as follows. Immediately 
postoperatively, her pain was controlled with one dose of IV 
dilaudid and PO ibuprofen and percoset. Her diet was advanced 
without difficulty. On post-operative day 1, her urine output 
was adequate so her Foley catheter was removed and she voided 
spontaneously. 
.
She was maintained on her home psychiatric medications and was 
seen by Social Work during her hospitalization. 
.
By post-operative day 2, she was tolerating a regular diet, 
voiding spontaneously, ambulating independently, and pain was 
controlled with oral medications. She was then discharged home 
in stable condition with outpatient follow-up scheduled.

 
Medications on Admission:
topical betamethasone, bupropion SR 150 2 tabs daily, fluoxetine 
20mg dialy, Lamictal 100mg 2 tabs in AM, 1 tab in afternoon at 
14:00; Synthroid ___, olanzapine 2.5mg daily prn anxiety, 
trazodone 150mg QHS

 
Discharge Medications:

2. BuPROPion (Sustained Release) 150 mg PO DAILY 
3. Fluoxetine 20 mg PO DAILY 
4. Ibuprofen 600 mg PO Q6H pain

5. LaMOTrigine 200 mg PO QAM

8. OLANZapine 2.5 mg PO DAILY:PRN anxiety 
9. Oxycodone-Acetaminophen (5mg-325mg) ___ TAB PO Q4H:PRN pain 
Do not drive or drink alcohol while using this medication.

Disp #*50 Capsule Refills:*2

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
endometrial cancer
*final pathology still pending*

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___,

You were admitted to the gynecologic oncology service after 
undergoing the procedures listed below. You have recovered well 
after your operation, and the team feels that you are safe to be 
discharged home. Please follow these instructions: 
. 
Laparoscopic instructions:  
* Take your medications as prescribed.  
* Do not drive while taking narcotics.  
* Do not combine narcotic and sedative medications or alcohol.  
* Do not take more than 4000mg acetaminophen (APAP) in 24 hrs.  
* No strenuous activity until your post-op appointment.  
* Nothing in the vagina (no tampons, no douching, no sex) for 
___ weeks.
* No heavy lifting of objects >10 lbs for 4 weeks.  
* You may eat a regular diet.
* It is safe to walk up stairs.  
.
Incision care:  
* You may shower and allow soapy water to run over incision; no 
scrubbing of incision. No bath tubs for 6 weeks.  
* If you have steri-strips, leave them on. If they are still on 
after ___ days from surgery, you may remove them.    
.
To reach medical records to get the records from this 
hospitalization sent to your doctor at home, call ___.  

.
Call your doctor at ___ for:  
* fever > 100.4  
* severe abdominal pain  
* difficulty urinating  
* vaginal bleeding requiring >1 pad/hr  
* abnormal vaginal discharge  
* redness or drainage from incision  
* nausea/vomiting where you are unable to keep down fluids/food 
or your medication  
* chest pain or difficulty breathing 
* onset of any concerning symptoms 
 
Followup Instructions:
___

Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ was admitted to the gynecologic oncology service
after undergoing a total laparoscopic hysterectomy, bilateral
salpingo-oophorectomy, and cystoscopy. Please see the operative
report for full details.
.
Her post-operative course is detailed as follows. Immediately
postoperatively, her pain was controlled with one dose of IV
dilaudid and PO ibuprofen and percoset. Her diet was advanced
without difficulty. On post-operative day 1, her urine output
was adequate so her Foley catheter was removed and she voided
spontaneously.
.
She was maintained on her home psychiatric medications and was
seen by Social Work during her hospitalization.
.
By post-operative day 2, she was tolerating a regular diet,
voiding spontaneously, ambulating independently, and pain was
controlled with oral medications. She was then discharged home
in stable condition with outpatient follow-up scheduled.

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___,
You were admitted to the gynecologic oncology service after
undergoing the procedures listed below. You have recovered well
after your operation, and the team feels that you are safe to be
discharged home. Please follow these instructions:
.
Laparoscopic instructions:
* Take your medications as prescribed.
* Do not drive while taking narcotics.
* Do not combine narcotic and sedative medications or alcohol.
* Do not take more than 4000mg acetaminophen (APAP) in 24 hrs.
* No strenuous activity until your post-op appointment.
* Nothing in the vagina (no tampons, no douching, no sex) for
___ weeks.
* No heavy lifting of objects >10 lbs for 4 weeks.
* You may eat a regular diet.
* It is safe to walk up stairs.
.
Incision care:
* You may shower and allow soapy water to run over incision; no
scrubbing of incision. No bath tubs for 6 weeks.
* If you have steri-strips, leave them on. If they are still on
after ___ days from surgery, you may remove them.
.
To reach medical records to get the records from this
hospitalization sent to your doctor at home, call ___.
.
Call your doctor at ___ for:
* fever > 100.4
* severe abdominal pain
* difficulty urinating
* vaginal bleeding requiring >1 pad/hr
* abnormal vaginal discharge
* redness or drainage from incision
* nausea/vomiting where you are unable to keep down fluids/food
or your medication
* chest pain or difficulty breathing
* onset of any concerning symptoms

___

Name:  ___              Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: UROLOGY
 
Allergies: 
Patient recorded as having No Known Allergies to Drugs
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
Left renal mass
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
Robot-assisted laparoscopic left partial nephrectomy by Dr. 
___ laparoscopic left salpingo-oophorectomy by Dr. 
___ 

 
___ of Present Illness:
___ is a healthy ___ woman who had a bladder 
infection
two months ago presented with dysuria, urgency, and frequency. 
No nausea, vomiting, fever, or chills.  She was thought to
potentially have pyelonephritis and underwent a CT scan at that
time.  This was performed at ___.  It showed a 3-cm lesion in 
the left kidney, but it was solid and quite suspicious.  She 
underwent a followup MRI on
___, again revealing a 3-cm lesion partially exophytic,
well defined, majority of which is endophytic inside the kidney,
and suspicious for either chromophobe renal cell or oncocytoma. 
She appears to have a single renal artery and renal vein with no
obvious adenopathy.

She does complain of lower right back pain for years.  No gross
hematuria and no left flank pain.

 
Past Medical History:
Past Medical History:  Chest pain, focal three months ago;
intermittent shortness of breath; and dizziness.

Surgeries:  Bladder suspension in ___ at ___.

 
Social History:
___
Family History:
Family history is negative for bladder or kidney cancer.

 
Pertinent Results:
___ 05:35AM BLOOD WBC-5.7 RBC-3.94* Hgb-10.3* Hct-31.3* 
MCV-80* MCH-26.2* MCHC-33.0 RDW-13.3 Plt ___
___ 05:35AM BLOOD Plt ___
___ 05:35AM BLOOD Glucose-104* UreaN-7 Creat-0.8 Na-138 
K-3.3 Cl-104 HCO3-28 AnGap-9
___ 05:35AM BLOOD Calcium-7.9* Mg-1.9
 
Brief Hospital Course:
Patient was admitted to Urology after undergoing robot-assisted 
laparoscopic left partial nephrectomy and laparoscopic left 
salpingo-oophorectomy. No concerning intraoperative events 
occurred; please see dictated operative notes for details. The 
patient received perioperative antibiotic prophylaxis. The 
patient was transferred to the floor from the PACU in stable 
condition.  In the PACU, she was noted to have left eye redness 
and pain, and an ophthalmology consult was requested.  She was 
felt to have a left corneal abraison likely secondary to 
exposure during surgery versus scratching her eye post-op as she 
was waking up from her anesthesia.  She was given antibiotic 
ointment and artificial tears per Ophtho recommendations.  On 
POD0, pain was well controlled on PCA, hydrated for urine output 
>30cc/hour, and provided with pneumoboots and incentive 
spirometry for prophylaxis. On POD1, the patient ambulated, 
restarted on home medications, basic metabolic panel and 
complete blood count were checked, pain control was transitioned 
from PCA to oral analgesics, diet was advanced to a clears/toast 
and crackers diet. On POD2, JP and urethral catheter (foley) 
were removed without difficulty and diet was advanced as 
tolerated. The remainder of the hospital course was relatively 
unremarkable. The patient was discharged in stable condition, 
eating well, ambulating independently, voiding without 
difficulty, and with pain control on oral analgesics. On exam, 
incisions were clean, dry, and intact, with no evidence of 
hematoma, collection or infection. The patient was given 
explicit instructions to follow-up in clinic with Dr. ___ in 
___ weeks.

 
Medications on Admission:
None
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Acetaminophen 325 mg Tablet Sig: Two (2) Tablet PO Q4H (every 
4 hours) as needed for fever.  
2. Tylenol-Codeine #3 300-30 mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO every 
___ hours as needed for pain. Disp:*40 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
3. Docusate Sodium 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO BID (2 
times a day).
Disp:*60 Capsule(s)* Refills:*2*
4. Timolol Maleate 0.5 % Drops Sig: One (1) Drop Ophthalmic BID 
(2 times a day).
Disp:*1 bottle* Refills:*2*
5. Polyvinyl Alcohol 1.4 % Drops Sig: ___ Drops Ophthalmic Q6H 
(every 6 hours) as needed for Eye irritation.
Disp:*1 bottle* Refills:*0*

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Left Renal Mass

 
Discharge Condition:
Stable

 
Discharge Instructions:
-You may shower but do not bathe, swim or immerse your 
incisions.
 
-Do not eat constipating foods for ___ weeks, drink plenty of 
fluids.
 
-Do not lift anything heavier than a phone book (10 pounds) or 
drive until you are seen by your Urologist in follow-up.
 
-Tylenol should be your first line pain medication, a narcotic 
pain medication has been prescribed for breakthough pain >4.  
Replace Tylenol with narcotic pain medication.  Max daily 
Tylenol dose is 4gm, note that narcotic pain medication also 
contains Tylenol (acetaminophen)
 
-Do not drive or drink alcohol while taking narcotics
 
-Colace has been prescribed to avoid post surgical constipation 
and constipation related to narcotic pain medication, 
discontinue if loose stool or diarrhea develops.
 
-Resume all of your home medications, except hold NSAID 
(aspirin,  and ibuprofen containing products such as advil & 
motrin,) until you see your urologist in follow-up
 
-Call your Urologist's office today to schedule/confirm your  
follow-up appointment in 3 weeks AND if you have any questions.
 
-If you have fevers > 101.5 F, vomiting, or increased redness, 
swelling, or discharge from your incision, call your doctor or 
go to the nearest ER
 
-Call Dr. ___ to set up follow-up appointment and if 
you have any urological questions. ___

 
Followup Instructions:
___

Ms. ___ is a ___ female who was discovered to 
have an incidental left renal mass.  She saw Dr. ___ 
underwent ___ laparoscopic left partial nephrectomy 
on ___.  Her postoperative course
was uncomplicated and she was discharged as scheduled on 
___.  She was doing otherwise well until yesterday at 
approximately 3 p.m. when she experienced a sudden onset of left 
flank pain.  The pain was across her entire left side of her 
back and did come around to her left lower quadrant as well.  
She also felt some left-sided pain upon inhalation.  Other 
complaints included some dizziness as well as a headache.  She 
had no fevers or chills and no nausea or vomiting.  She has been 
otherwise eating well.  In terms of her urine, she had been 
urinating normally, however, had noticed some tea-colored urine 
for the last week or so.  No shortness of breath or chest pain.
 
Past Medical History:
PAST MEDICAL HISTORY:  Focal chest pain three months ago,
intermittent shortness of breath, and dizziness.

PAST SURGICAL HISTORY:  Bladder suspension in ___ at ___, ___ laparoscopic left partial
nephrectomy on ___.

___

K-4.3 Cl-103 HCO3-30 AnGap-10

Patient was admitted to the Urology service for observation 
after she was seen in the Emergency room.  A CT A/P as well as a 
CTA chest were performed with contrast, all of which were 
negative for significant pathology.  There was no evidence of 
intraperitoneal bleed.  Her urine was barely pink tinged.  She 
remained in a degree of pain in the AM of HD 2, but her 
condition was unchanged.  Her hct was stable.  She was 
discharged on HD 2 ambulating, tolerating regular diet, and with 
pain controlled on PO pain meds.  She will be contacted by Dr. 
___ for ___.

(2 times a day).

Home

left flank pain

Ms. ___ is a ___ female who was discovered to
have an incidental left renal mass. She saw Dr. ___
underwent ___ laparoscopic left partial nephrectomy
on ___. Her postoperative course
was uncomplicated and she was discharged as scheduled on
___. She was doing otherwise well until yesterday at
approximately 3 p.m. when she experienced a sudden onset of left
flank pain. The pain was across her entire left side of her
back and did come around to her left lower quadrant as well.
She also felt some left-sided pain upon inhalation. Other
complaints included some dizziness as well as a headache. She
had no fevers or chills and no nausea or vomiting. She has been
otherwise eating well. In terms of her urine, she had been
urinating normally, however, had noticed some tea-colored urine
for the last week or so. No shortness of breath or chest pain.

intermittent shortness of breath, and dizziness.

nephrectomy on ___.

Patient was admitted to the Urology service for observation
after she was seen in the Emergency room. A CT A/P as well as a
CTA chest were performed with contrast, all of which were
negative for significant pathology. There was no evidence of
intraperitoneal bleed. Her urine was barely pink tinged. She
remained in a degree of pain in the AM of HD 2, but her
condition was unchanged. Her hct was stable. She was
discharged on HD 2 ambulating, tolerating regular diet, and with
pain controlled on PO pain meds. She will be contacted by Dr.

Name:  ___                      Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: SURGERY
 
Allergies: 
Patient recorded as having No Known Allergies to Drugs
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
Hurthle cell lesion left thyroid lobe.

 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
___ Left thyroid lobectomy

 
History of Present Illness:
___ with Hurthe cell lesion of the left thyroid lobe.  He 
presents today for elective left hemithyroidectomy.
 
Past Medical History:
PMH: hypertension, GERD, chronic cough though to be secondary to 
post-nasal drip, and mild creatinine elevation
PSH: hernia repair and knee surgery
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
N/A
 
Physical Exam:
On Discharge:
Afebrile, Vital signs stable
No distress, alert and oriented
Slight hoarsness to voice
Neck soft, no hematoma
Incision clean and dry, no erythema
RRR
Lungs clear
 
Pertinent Results:
None
 
Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. ___ was admitted on ___ after undergoing a successful 
left thyroid lobectomy.  His diet was advanced to regular and he 
had good pain control with oral medications.  He does have a 
slighly hoarse voice but has no breathing difficulty.  His neck 
is soft with no signs of edema.  He is discharged home in good 
condition.
 
Medications on Admission:
Fluticasone 50 mcg 1 pff daily, Metoprolol 25mg daily, 
Omeprazole 20mg daily, simvastatin 20mg daily
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Fluticasone 50 mcg/Actuation Spray, Suspension Sig: Two (2) 
Spray Nasal DAILY (Daily).  
2. Metoprolol Tartrate 25 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY 
(Daily).  
3. Simvastatin 10 mg Tablet Sig: Two (2) Tablet PO DAILY 
(Daily).  
4. Omeprazole 20 mg Capsule, Delayed Release(E.C.) Sig: One (1) 
Capsule, Delayed Release(E.C.) PO DAILY (Daily).  
5. Amlodipine 5 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily).  

6. Hydrocodone-Acetaminophen ___ mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO 
every six (6) hours as needed for pain.
Disp:*20 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Hurthle cell lesion left thyroid lobe.

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Call if you experience:
- fever > 101
- chills
- shortness of breath, difficulty breathing
- swelling of the neck
- inability to eat or drink
- worsening hoarseness of you voice
- increasing redness around your incision or drainage from your 
incision
- any other concerns you may have
.
Medications:
- continue all of your medications
- you will be given a prescription for narcotic pain medication, 
do not drive while on this medication
.
Incision:
- leave the white strips across your incision, they will fall 
off on their own in a few days
 
Followup Instructions:
___

text:
Name:  ___                      Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: SURGERY
 
Allergies: 
Patient recorded as having No Known Allergies to Drugs
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
Hurthle cell carcinoma left thyroid lobe.

 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
Completion Thyroidectomy

 
History of Present Illness:
This patient had previously undergone left thyroid lobectomy at 
his request to treat a Hurthle cell lesion which unfortunately 
came back carcinoma.Consequently
he was brought back for removal of the right lobe.

 
Past Medical History:
PMH: hypertension, GERD, chronic cough though to be secondary to 
post-nasal drip, and mild creatinine elevation
PSH: hernia repair and knee surgery
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
N/A
 
Physical Exam:
General: Well appearing, no distress, tolerating a regulra diet
Neuro: Alert and oriented X 3
Resp: No distress
Cardiac:RRR
Abd: non-tender
Extremities: no numbness or tingling
Anterior Neck Incision: Incision closed with steri-strips, well 
approximated, no significant drainage 
 
Pertinent Results:
___ 07:05AM BLOOD Calcium-9.4
 
Brief Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the inpatient ward after having a  
Completion Thyroidectomy. The patient remained on the inpatient 
ward overnight without any acute event. On the morning of 
post-operative day one, a serum calcium was drawn and was 9.4. 
The anterior neck incision was well approximated and closed with 
steri-strips. The patient was discharged home with proper 
follow-up and pain management instructions.
 
Medications on Admission:
Amlodipine 5mg qd
Lopressor 25mg qd 
Prilosec 20mg qd
Simvastatin 20mg qd 
Multivitamin
 
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Liothyronine 25 mcg Tablet Sig: 0.5 Tablet PO BID (2 times a 
day).
Disp:*30 Tablet(s)* Refills:*2*
2. Amlodipine 5 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily).  

3. Metoprolol Succinate 25 mg Tablet Sustained Release 24 hr 
Sig: One (1) Tablet Sustained Release 24 hr PO DAILY (Daily).  
4. Omeprazole 20 mg Capsule, Delayed Release(E.C.) Sig: One (1) 
Capsule, Delayed Release(E.C.) PO DAILY (Daily).  
5. Simvastatin 10 mg Tablet Sig: Two (2) Tablet PO DAILY 
(Daily).  
6. Hydrocodone-Acetaminophen ___ mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO 
every eight (8) hours as needed for pain.
Disp:*30 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Hurthle Cell Carcinoma Left Thyroid Lobe

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted to the hospital after a Comlpetion 
Thyroidectomy for treatent of  Hurthle cell carcinoma in your 
left thyroid lobe. The removed tissue was sent to pathology for 
further study and you will be given these results at your 
follow-up appointment. This procedure went well, you have 
tolerated a regular diet, and you pain is controled with 
medications by mouth. You are ready to return home. You will be 
sent home on a medication called Liothyronine Sodium for 
replacement of your thyroid hormone. If your voice becomes 
hoarse or you have difficulty speaking please call the office or 
if it is severe please come to the emergency room. Please rest 
and do not do any heavy lifting for ___ weeks. 

The parathyroid glands are located near the thyroid gland in the 
neck. The parathyroid glands are resposible for regulating the 
calcium levels in the body. Sometimes during surgery on the 
thyroid gland the parathyroid can become injured or stunned. 
This can cause a low calcium level in the blood. The calcium 
level in your blood was checked this morning and was normal 
however it is important that you watch for signs ans symptoms of 
low calcium levels. These include: numbness and tingling in your 
extremities or around your mouth, confusion, siezures, or muscle 
spasms. Please watch for these signs and if they occur call the 
office, if severe go to the ___ room. 

You have an incision on the front of your nect. This is closed 
with suture and steristrips. The incision can be left uncovered 
however if you prefer you can place a small sterile gauze 
dressing over the area. Please watch for signs and symptoms of 
infection including: increased redness, drainage of white or 
green discharge from the wound, fever, or increased pain at the 
incision line. If the incision opens or bleeds please call the 
office. You may shower, let the warm water run over the area, 
pat the incision line dry but do not rub. 

Please follow-up with Dr. ___ as instructed. 

 
Followup Instructions:
___

his request to treat a Hurthle cell lesion which unfortunately

The patient was admitted to the inpatient ward after having a
Completion Thyroidectomy. The patient remained on the inpatient
ward overnight without any acute event. On the morning of
post-operative day one, a serum calcium was drawn and was 9.4.
The anterior neck incision was well approximated and closed with
steri-strips. The patient was discharged home with proper
follow-up and pain management instructions.

Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.
Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted to the hospital after a Comlpetion
Thyroidectomy for treatent of Hurthle cell carcinoma in your
left thyroid lobe. The removed tissue was sent to pathology for
further study and you will be given these results at your
follow-up appointment. This procedure went well, you have
tolerated a regular diet, and you pain is controled with
medications by mouth. You are ready to return home. You will be
sent home on a medication called Liothyronine Sodium for
replacement of your thyroid hormone. If your voice becomes
hoarse or you have difficulty speaking please call the office or
if it is severe please come to the emergency room. Please rest
and do not do any heavy lifting for ___ weeks.
The parathyroid glands are located near the thyroid gland in the
neck. The parathyroid glands are resposible for regulating the
calcium levels in the body. Sometimes during surgery on the
thyroid gland the parathyroid can become injured or stunned.
This can cause a low calcium level in the blood. The calcium
level in your blood was checked this morning and was normal
however it is important that you watch for signs ans symptoms of
low calcium levels. These include: numbness and tingling in your
extremities or around your mouth, confusion, siezures, or muscle
spasms. Please watch for these signs and if they occur call the
office, if severe go to the ___ room.
You have an incision on the front of your nect. This is closed
with suture and steristrips. The incision can be left uncovered
however if you prefer you can place a small sterile gauze
dressing over the area. Please watch for signs and symptoms of
infection including: increased redness, drainage of white or
green discharge from the wound, fever, or increased pain at the
incision line. If the incision opens or bleeds please call the
office. You may shower, let the warm water run over the area,
pat the incision line dry but do not rub.
Please follow-up with Dr. ___ as instructed.
Followup Instructions:
___

Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ was admitted to the Orthopedic service on ___ for 
bilateral tibia plateau, bilateral proximal humerus and a left 
scaphoid fracture after being evaluated and treated with closed 
reduction in the emergency room.  She underwent open reduction 
internal fixation of the left tibial plateau fracture and 
external fixation of the right tibial plateau fracture without 
complication on ___. Please see operative report for full 
details. She was extubated without difficulty and transferred to 
the recovery room in stable condition. She returned to the OR on 
___ for removal of the external fixator and open reduction 
internal fixation of the right tibial plateau fracture. Please 
see operative report for full details. She was extubated without 
difficulty and transferred to the recovery room in stable 
condition. In the early post-operative course Ms. ___ did well 
and was transferred to the floor in stable condition.

On hospital day 2 she was transfused 3 units of packed red blood 
cells over the next 2 days for post-operative anemia. On 
hospital day 4 she complained of shortness of breath and chest 
tightness. An EKG was ordered but was unremarkable. given the 
extent of her multiple injuries and surgeries, a CT angiogram 
was ordered, which revealed a filling defect in a segmental 
branch of the pulmonary artery feeding the lingula. She was not 
switched to therapeutic anticoagulation but remained on a 
prophylactic dose, because it was felt that this finding did not 
correlate with her physical exam.  

She had adequate pain management and worked with physical 
therapy while in the hospital.  The remainder of her hospital 
course was uneventful and Ms. ___ is being discharged to rehab 
in stable condition. She will follow up in clinic in 2 weeks for 
staple removal, wound check and repeat films of both knees and 
shoulders. 

 
Medications on Admission:
Lisinopril

 
Discharge Medications:
1. enoxaparin 40 mg/0.4 mL Syringe Sig: One (1)  Subcutaneous 
QPM (once a day (in the evening)) for 4 weeks.  
2. bisacodyl 5 mg Tablet, Delayed Release (E.C.) Sig: Two (2) 
Tablet, Delayed Release (E.C.) PO DAILY (Daily) as needed for 
constipation.  
3. docusate sodium 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO BID (2 
times a day).  
4. Senna Laxative 8.6 mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO BID (2 times 
a day).  
5. magnesium hydroxide 400 mg/5 mL Suspension Sig: Thirty (30) 
ML PO Q6H (every 6 hours) as needed for conspitation.  
6. ondansetron HCl (PF) 4 mg/2 mL Solution Sig: One (1)  
Injection Q8H (every 8 hours) as needed for nausea.  
7. oxycodone 5 mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO Q3H (every 3 hours) 
as needed for pain for 3 weeks.  
8. fentanyl 25 mcg/hr Patch 72 hr Sig: One (1) Patch 72 hr 
Transdermal Q72H (every 72 hours) for 3 weeks.  
9. pantoprazole 40 mg Tablet, Delayed Release (E.C.) Sig: One 
(1) Tablet, Delayed Release (E.C.) PO Q24H (every 24 hours).  
10. acetaminophen 325 mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO Q6H (every 6 
hours) as needed for pain.  
11. lorazepam 1 mg Tablet Sig: 0.5-2 Tablets PO Q4H (every 4 
hours) as needed for anxiety.  

 
Discharge Disposition:
Extended Care
 
Facility:
___
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Bilateral tibial plateau fractures, Bilateral proximal humerus 
fractures, and Left scaphoid fracture.

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Out of Bed with assistance to chair or 
wheelchair.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Wound Care:
- Keep Incision clean and dry.
- You can get the wound wet or take a shower starting from 7 
days after surgery, but no baths or swimming for at least 4 
weeks.
- Dry sterile dresssing may be changed daily.  No dressing is 
needed if wound continues to be non-draining.
- Any stitches or staples that need to be removed will be taken 
out at your 2-week follow up appointment.
Activity:
- Continue to be non-weight bearing on both of your arms and 
legs.
- You should not lift anything greater than 5 pounds.
- Elevate your arms and legs to reduce swelling and pain.
- Do not remove your braces; keep them dry.
Other Instructions
- Resume your regular diet.
- Avoid nicotine products to optimize healing.
- Resume your home medications. Take all medications as 
instructed.
- Continue taking the Lovenox to prevent blood clots.
- You have also been given Additional Medications to control 
your pain.  Please allow 72 hours for refill of narcotic 
prescriptions, so plan ahead.  You can either have them mailed

Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ was admitted to the Orthopedic service on ___ for
bilateral tibia plateau, bilateral proximal humerus and a left
scaphoid fracture after being evaluated and treated with closed
reduction in the emergency room. She underwent open reduction
internal fixation of the left tibial plateau fracture and
external fixation of the right tibial plateau fracture without
complication on ___. Please see operative report for full
details. She was extubated without difficulty and transferred to
the recovery room in stable condition. She returned to the OR on
___ for removal of the external fixator and open reduction
internal fixation of the right tibial plateau fracture. Please
see operative report for full details. She was extubated without
difficulty and transferred to the recovery room in stable
condition. In the early post-operative course Ms. ___ did well
and was transferred to the floor in stable condition.
On hospital day 2 she was transfused 3 units of packed red blood
cells over the next 2 days for post-operative anemia. On
hospital day 4 she complained of shortness of breath and chest
tightness. An EKG was ordered but was unremarkable. given the
extent of her multiple injuries and surgeries, a CT angiogram
was ordered, which revealed a filling defect in a segmental
branch of the pulmonary artery feeding the lingula. She was not
switched to therapeutic anticoagulation but remained on a
prophylactic dose, because it was felt that this finding did not
correlate with her physical exam.
She had adequate pain management and worked with physical
therapy while in the hospital. The remainder of her hospital
course was uneventful and Ms. ___ is being discharged to rehab
in stable condition. She will follow up in clinic in 2 weeks for
staple removal, wound check and repeat films of both knees and
shoulders.

Lisinopril

QPM (once a day (in the evening)) for 4 weeks.

Tablet, Delayed Release (E.C.) PO DAILY (Daily) as needed for
constipation.
3. docusate sodium 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO BID (2
times a day).
4. Senna Laxative 8.6 mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO BID (2 times
a day).
5. magnesium hydroxide 400 mg/5 mL Suspension Sig: Thirty (30)
ML PO Q6H (every 6 hours) as needed for conspitation.
6. ondansetron HCl (PF) 4 mg/2 mL Solution Sig: One (1)
Injection Q8H (every 8 hours) as needed for nausea.
7. oxycodone 5 mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO Q3H (every 3 hours)
as needed for pain for 3 weeks.
8. fentanyl 25 mcg/hr Patch 72 hr Sig: One (1) Patch 72 hr
Transdermal Q72H (every 72 hours) for 3 weeks.
9. pantoprazole 40 mg Tablet, Delayed Release (E.C.) Sig: One
(1) Tablet, Delayed Release (E.C.) PO Q24H (every 24 hours).
10. acetaminophen 325 mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO Q6H (every 6
hours) as needed for pain.
11. lorazepam 1 mg Tablet Sig: 0.5-2 Tablets PO Q4H (every 4
hours) as needed for anxiety.
Discharge Disposition:
Extended Care
Facility:
___
Discharge Diagnosis:
Bilateral tibial plateau fractures, Bilateral proximal humerus
fractures, and Left scaphoid fracture.
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Out of Bed with assistance to chair or
wheelchair.
Discharge Instructions:
Wound Care:
- Keep Incision clean and dry.
- You can get the wound wet or take a shower starting from 7
days after surgery, but no baths or swimming for at least 4
weeks.
- Dry sterile dresssing may be changed daily. No dressing is
needed if wound continues to be non-draining.
- Any stitches or staples that need to be removed will be taken
out at your 2-week follow up appointment.
Activity:
- Continue to be non-weight bearing on both of your arms and
legs.
- You should not lift anything greater than 5 pounds.
- Elevate your arms and legs to reduce swelling and pain.
- Do not remove your braces; keep them dry.
Other Instructions
- Resume your regular diet.
- Avoid nicotine products to optimize healing.
- Resume your home medications. Take all medications as
instructed.
- Continue taking the Lovenox to prevent blood clots.
- You have also been given Additional Medications to control
your pain. Please allow 72 hours for refill of narcotic
prescriptions, so plan ahead. You can either have them mailed
to your home or pick them up at the clinic located on ___. We are not allowed to call in narcotic (oxycontin, oxycodone,
percocet) prescriptions to the pharmacy. In addition, we are
only allowed to write for pain medications for 90 days from the
date of surgery.
- Narcotic pain medication may cause drowsiness. Do not drink
alcohol while taking narcotic medications. Do not operate any
motor vehicle or machinery while taking narcotic pain
medications. Taking more than recommended may cause serious
breathing problems.
- If you have questions, concerns or experience any of the below
danger signs then please call your doctor at ___ or go

___ L4-5 Decompression (___)

 
History of Present Illness:
___ w/ refractory lumbar stenosis

Denies
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
NC
 
Physical Exam:
AVSS

Well appearing, NAD, comfortable

BUE: SILT C5-T1 dermatomal distributions

BUE: ___ Del/Tri/Bic/WE/WF/FF/IO

BUE: tone normal, negative ___, 2+ symmetric DTR 
bic/bra/tri

All fingers WWP, brisk capillary refill, 2+ distal pulses

BLE: SILT L1-S1 dermatomal distributions

BLE: ___ ___

BLE: tone normal, no clonus, toes downgoing, 2+ DTR knee/ankle

All toes WWP, brisk capillary refill, 2+ distal pulses

 
Pertinent Results:
 
Brief Hospital Course:
Patient was admitted to the ___ Spine Surgery Service and 
taken to the Operating Room for the above procedure.  Refer to 
the dictated operative note for further details.  The surgery 
was without complication and the patient was transferred to the 
PACU in a stable condition.  TEDs/Pneumoboots were used for 
postoperative DVT prophylaxis.  Intravenous antibiotics were 
continued for 24hrs postop per standard protocol. Initial postop 
pain was controlled with a PCA.  Diet was advanced as tolerated. 
 The patient was transitioned to oral pain medication when 
tolerating PO diet.  Foley was removed postoperatively.  
Physical therapy was consulted for mobilization OOB to ambulate. 
 Hospital course was otherwise unremarkable.  On the day of 
discharge the patient was afebrile with stable vital signs, 
comfortable on oral pain control and tolerating a regular diet. 

 
Medications on Admission:
None
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Diazepam ___ mg PO Q8H:PRN spasm 
2. Docusate Sodium 100 mg PO BID 
3. OxycoDONE (Immediate Release)  ___ mg PO Q4H:PRN Pain 
Hold for sedation, RR<12 or altered mental status 

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Lumbar spinal stenosis

 
Discharge Condition:
Alert and Oriented
Ambulating

 
Discharge Instructions:
You have undergone the following operation: Lumbar Decompression 
Without Fusion

 

Immediately after the operation:

     Activity: You should not lift anything greater than 10 lbs 
for 2 weeks. You will be more comfortable if you do not sit or 
stand more than ~45 minutes without moving around.

 

     Rehabilitation/ Physical Therapy: 

___           ___ times a day you should go for a walk for 
___ minutes as part of your recovery.  You can walk as much as 
you can tolerate. 

___           Limit any kind of lifting.

 

     Diet: Eat a normal healthy diet. You may have some 
constipation after surgery.  You have been given medication to 
help with this issue.

 

     Brace: You may have been given a brace. This brace is to 
be worn when you are walking. You may take it off when sitting 
in a chair or lying in bed.

 

     Wound Care: Remove the dressing in 2 days.  If the 
incision is draining cover it with a new sterile dressing.  If 
it is dry then you can leave the incision open to the air.  Once 
the incision is completely dry (usually ___ days after the 
operation) you may take a shower. Do not soak the incision in a 
bath or pool.  If the incision starts draining at anytime after 
surgery, do not get the incision wet. Cover it with a sterile 
dressing and call the office. 

 

     You should resume taking your normal home medications.

 

     You have also been given Additional Medications to control 
your pain. Please allow 72 hours for refill of narcotic 
prescriptions, so please plan ahead.  You can either have them 
mailed to your home or pick them up at the clinic located on 
___.  We are not allowed to call in or fax narcotic 
prescriptions (oxycontin, oxycodone, percocet) to your pharmacy. 
 In addition, we are only allowed to write for pain medications 
for 90 days from the date of surgery.

 

     Follow up: 

___           Please Call the office and make an appointment 
for 2 weeks after the day of your operation if this has not been 
done already.

___           At the 2-week visit we will check your 
incision, take baseline X-rays and answer any questions. We may 
at that time start physical therapy.

___           We will then see you at 6 weeks from the day 
of the operation and at that time release you to full activity.

 

 

Please call the office if you have a fever>101.5 degrees 
Fahrenheit and/or drainage from your wound.

 
Followup Instructions:
___

that worsened over the past year. Fibroids diagnosed via u/s in

daily. Fibroids cause pelvic pain/cramping each month with

LBP
R knee pain

Lungs: Clear to auscultation bilaterally, no wheezes, rales, 
ronchi  
CV: Regular rate and rhythm, normal S1 + S2, no murmurs, rubs, 
gallops

present, no rebound tenderness or guarding, no organomegaly

___ 08:00AM   PLT COUNT-317
___ 08:00AM   ___ssessment and Plan: This is a ___ year old female with history 
of lower back pain who is status post uterine fibroid 
emobolization by interventional radiology.

1. Status Post embolization: When the patient arrived on the 
floor after her procedure her vitals were stable and she 
remained pain free on a dilaudid PCA. Through the course of 
admission, she was able to tolerate a regular diet, transition 
from intravenous pain medication to oral pain medication and was 
able to walk out of bed with minor assistance. She currently 
complains of lower abdominal pain which is expected after this 
procedure and she is being appropriately treated per 
interventional radiology protocol. She was given a prescription 
for Percocet ___ taken by mouth every ___ hours for pain, 
Ibuprofen 800 mg taken by mouth three times a day for ten days, 
and colace 100-200 mg taken by mouth twice a day as needed for 
constipation. She is to follow up with interventional radiology 
if any further problems arise.  

2. Lower Back Pain: This pain remained stable during the course 
of the admission. She was continued on her home medication of 
Gabapentin 600 mg daily and Nortriptyline 30 mg by mouth taken 
at night daily. She is to see her primary care physician for 
further assessment.

Gabapentin 600 daily 
Nortriptyline 10 tid

times a day) as needed for constipation.  
4. Ibuprofen 400 mg Tablet Sig: Two (2) Tablet PO three times a 
day for 10 days.  
5. Percocet ___ mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO every ___ 
hours as needed for pain for 25 doses.

Extended Care

___

Status post uterine fibroid embolectomy

Lower Back Pain

Stable

Ibuprofen 800 mg taken by mouth three times a day for 10 days

text:
Name:  ___               Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: OBSTETRICS/GYNECOLOGY
 
Allergies: 
vancomycin
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
breast erythema
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
none
 
History of Present Illness:
___ s/p SVD on ___ with recurrent mastitis of both
breasts represent to triage with worsening symptoms after being
started on clindamycin yesterday. Per prior notes, pt initially
diagnosed with L breast mastitis on ___ and received 10 
days
of dicloxacillin with full resolution of infection. On ___,
she developed mastitis of the right breast and was admitted for
24 hours of IV ancef and then transitioned to PO keflex for 10
days. On ___, she had recurrent left breast mastitis and
completed an additional 10 days of keflex.

Most recently, she began having symptoms again on the right
breast and was started on keflex on ___. She continued to be
febrile at home to a Tmax of 101.6 after starting antibiotics 
and
thus was started on clindamycin for improved MRSA coverage. 
Since
then, she has had a Tmax of 100.0 however has noted worsening
erythema and pain. She reports fevers/chills, denies n/v. She
currently is pumping 3x per day as she is weaning her infant off
of the breast.

 
Past Medical History:
OBHx:  SVD x 1 (___)

GynHx: denies h/o abnormal paps, STIs

PMH: denies

PSH: denies

 
Social History:
___
Family History:
noncontributory
 
Physical Exam:
Presenting Exam:
98.1  HR 88 BP 112/65  RR 18 
Breast: Left Breast NT with no erythema and no lesions.  Right
breast with significant tenderness and mass noted as well warmth
and erythema in wedge fashion at 1 oclock. This extends to chest
wall and outline done.
Abd: Soft NT ND No masses

Discharge Exam:
Vital signs stable
Breast: Left breast without erythema or tenderness; Right breast 
with improved erythema and softening
Abdomen: soft, nontender
 
Pertinent Results:
___ 05:58PM   PLT COUNT-268
___ 05:58PM   WBC-13.1* RBC-4.04* HGB-12.4 HCT-35.7* MCV-88 
MCH-30.7 MCHC-34.8 RDW-13.7

Final Report 
EXAMINATION:  RIGHT BREAST ULTRASOUND 
  
INDICATION:  ___ female who is postpartum and 
breastfeeding, presents 
with right-sided mastitis. Evaluate for drainable fluid 
collection. 
  
COMPARISON:  Left breast ultrasound dated ___. 
  
TECHNIQUE:  Targeted right breast ultrasound was performed.  
Selected images 
were obtained. 
  
FINDINGS:  
  
Targeted ultrasound was performed of the regions of skin 
erythema in the right 
breast, which include the upper inner quadrant, lower inner 
quadrant, and 
lower outer quadrant, 1-7 cm from the nipple. Within the regions 
of skin 
erythema there is evidence of skin thickening, without any 
drainable fluid 
collection identified. 
  
There are no suspicious solid or cystic lesions identified. 
  
IMPRESSION:  
  
No drainable fluid collection identified in the right breast. 
  
RECOMMENDATION:  Clinical followup until symptom resolution is 
recommended. 
  
NOTIFICATION:  Findings reviewed with the patient at the 
completion of the 
study. Additionally, these findings were discussed with Dr. 
___ by Dr. 
___ telephone at 16:39 on ___, 5 min after 
discovery. 
  
BI-RADS:  2 Benign. 
  

 
Brief Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the hospital on ___ for inpatient 
management of mastitis in the setting of recurrent infection 
with failed outpatient treatment.  A breast ultrasound 
demonstrated no evidence of an abscess or drainable collection.  
The patient had a leukocytosis with a white count of 13.1.  She 
was started on IV vancomycin but developed a maculopapular rash, 
so the decision was made to transition to IV clindamycin.  The 
infectious disease team was consulted, and they recommended 
continuation of IV clindamycin, in addition to nasal staph swab 
and breastmilk culture.  She was then discharged home in stable 
condition on ___ on oral clindamycin and planned follow up.
 
Medications on Admission:
PNV, colace, iron, ibuprofen prn

 
Discharge Medications:
1. Clindamycin 450 mg PO Q6H Duration: 7 Days 
RX *clindamycin HCl 150 mg 3 capsule(s) by mouth every 6 hours 
Disp #*84 Capsule Refills:*0
2. Xulane (norelgestrom-ethinyl estradiol) 150-35 mcg/24 hr 
transdermal once weekly 
RX *norelgestrom-ethinyl estradiol [Xulane] 150 mcg-35 mcg/24 
hour apply one patch once weekly Disp #*3 Patch Refills:*11

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
right mastitis

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
-take clindamycin 150mg 3 tabs every 6 hours for additional 7 
days
-may restart birth control patch (xulane) as used in past
 
Followup Instructions:
___

text:
Name:  ___                 Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: OTOLARYNGOLOGY
 
Allergies: 
Penicillins / Clindamycin
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
Worsening throat pain
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
Incision and Drainage of right peritonsillar area

 
History of Present Illness:
The patient is a ___ with a history of peritonsillar cellulitis 
in ___, who was seen in the ___ ED on ___ with negative 
needle aspiration. 
CT scan was performed, which was negative for abscess.  She was
monitored overnight in ED observation unit and treated with 
Levo/Flag IV, secondary to PCN and Clindamycin allergy.  She 
felt significantly improved the
next morning and was discharged home on PO antibiotics.  She 
returned today to Dr. ___ with worsening 
right-sided odynophagia.  Aspiration was attempted in the 
office, which returned negative for purulence. She had trismus, 
and intolerance to solid and liquids. No difficulty breathing.  
Not tolerating solids or liquids.  Mono was negative 2 days ago. 
 

 
Past Medical History:
LBP
R knee pain 
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
Non- contributory
 
Physical Exam:
On admission: 
AVSS
Gen: NAD, mild discomfort, voice strong, no stridor, no stertor
Ears: auricles, canal and ___ WNL AU.
NC/NP: anterior rhinoscopy: mild turbinate enlargement, septum
midline, no purulent exudate. NP without lesions, eustachian
tubes patent bilaterally
OC/OP: No trismus, asymmetric R>>L 3+ tonsil on R with erythema,
no exudate. peritonsillar area soft, without erythema. uvula
midline.
Neck: supple, full range of motion, tender to palpation on right
with shotty lymphadenopathy.  No other LAD or masses
appreciated.

 
Brief Hospital Course:
The patient is a ___ year old female with right peritonsillar 
cellulitis, s/p negative aspiration.  She presented to clinic on 
day of admission with worsening ondynophagia after initial 
improvement on IV antibiotics.  In the clinic, needle aspiration 
was negative, and a small incision was made in the right 
pre-tonsillar space to exclude abscess. No immediate drainage 
was observed.  She was admitted to ENT service, Dr. ___ 
___ observation.  She was continued on IV levaquin and flagyl 
and placed on IVF.  On hospital day 2, she reported drainage of 
fluid in her mouth with improvement in her throat symptoms.  Her 
diet was advanced to softs, which she tolerated without issue.  
The remainder of her hospital course was unremarkable; 
specifically, she remained afebrile, breathing comfortably on 
room air, with oral cavity/oropharynx without trismus.  

On hospital day 2, given her improvement, both team and patient 
agree that she is ready for discharge to home.  She is being 
discharged afebrile, with stable vital signs, breathing 
comfortable on room air, pain well controlled on elixer roxicet, 
tolerating a soft diet without nausea or vomiting, voiding 
without issue.  She is being discharged on PO levaquin and 
flagyl for a 10 day course. She is planned to follow-up with Dr. 
___ in 7 days.

 
Medications on Admission:
1. metronidazole 500 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO Q8H (every 
8 hours) for 10 days.  
2. oxycodone-acetaminophen ___ mg/5 mL Solution Sig: ___ MLs 
PO Q4H (every 4 hours) as needed for pain.  
3. levofloxacin 500 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO once a day 
for 10 days.  

 
Discharge Medications:
1. metronidazole 500 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO Q8H (every 
8 hours) for 10 days.  
2. oxycodone-acetaminophen ___ mg/5 mL Solution Sig: ___ MLs 
PO Q4H (every 4 hours) as needed for pain.  
3. levofloxacin 500 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO once a day 
for 10 days.  

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Right peritonsillar cellulitis

 
Discharge Condition:
Stable, afebrile, tolerating POs.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Seek immediate medical attention for fever, worsening pain, 
difficulty breathing, difficulty opening your mouth, or problems 
swallowing.
 
Followup Instructions:
___

text:
Name:  ___                  Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: SURGERY
 
Allergies: 
Sulfa (Sulfonamide Antibiotics) / Ceclor / Claritin
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
bicycle collision
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
none

 
History of Present Illness:
A ___ y/o healthy M presented to the ED via EMS with left hip
pain s/p a bicycle accident. Per EMS, the patient was found
down and bystanders report that the patient was biking down
the road at an unknown speed when a parked car opened their
door and the patient hit the door. EMS reported that the
patient dented the door, was flung over the door, and landed
about 10 feet in front of the car. Bystanders reported that
the patient was not wearing a helmet, hit his head, and had
a brief LOC. EMS reported that on scene, the patient was
alert and oriented x1 with no memory of the event. EMS
reported that the patient had stable vital signs through
transport and has seemed to start remembering more of the
event and becoming less confused. Here, the patient endorsed
L hip pain. The patient reported that he thinks his last
tetanus shot was in ___, but he is not sure. A full
history and review of systems was unable to be completed due
to the patient's AMS.
 
Past Medical History:
none
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
noncontributory
 
Physical Exam:
Admission Physical Exam:
Temp: 97.8 HR: 72 BP: 153/70 Resp: 14 O(2)Sat: 97 Normal
Constitutional: NAD
HEENT: Pupils equal, round and reactive to light
C-collar in place
Chest: Airway intact, bilateral breath sounds, chest wall
nontender with no crepitus
Cardiovascular: 2+ radial pulses bilaterally, DP pulses
intact bilaterally
Abdominal: Soft, Nontender
Extr/Back: Moves all extremities, no pain with ROM of
bilateral ___, no midline spine tenderness
Skin: Abrasion over the web space between the R pinky and
ring finger, abrasion over the R dorsal great toe, abrasion
over the forehead and nasal, R anterior shin abrasion
Neuro: Speech fluent, confused MAEW
Psych: Normal mood

Discharge Physical Exam:
VS: 97.5, 126/78, 63, 16, 97 RA
Gen: A&O x3, ambulating in room in NAD
CV: HRR
Pulm: LS ctab
Chest: Mildly TTP over left chest wall
Abd: soft, mildly TTP in LUQ/flank area w/ deep palp
Ext: No edema  
 
Pertinent Results:
___ 07:55AM BLOOD WBC-6.1 RBC-4.51* Hgb-13.7 Hct-41.7 
MCV-93 MCH-30.4 MCHC-32.9 RDW-12.4 RDWSD-42.2 Plt ___
___ 03:56PM BLOOD WBC-7.4 RBC-4.36* Hgb-13.3* Hct-39.8* 
MCV-91 MCH-30.5 MCHC-33.4 RDW-12.3 RDWSD-40.7 Plt ___
___ 06:30AM BLOOD Glucose-95 UreaN-14 Creat-0.8 Na-142 
K-4.0 Cl-103 HCO3-22 AnGap-17
___ 06:30AM BLOOD Calcium-9.6 Phos-3.4 Mg-1.9
___ 08:57PM BLOOD ASA-NEG Ethanol-NEG Acetmnp-NEG 
Tricycl-NEG

Radiology: 
___ Right hand- Normal 
___ CT chest 1. Multiple nondisplaced posterior rib fractures
are noted in the left second, third, fifth, and sixth ribs.  No
pneumothorax. 
2. Ill-defined hypodensity the superior aspect of the spleen
measures up to 2.6 cm and has an appearance of a splenic 
infarct,
although in the setting of trauma a splenic laceration cannot be
entirely excluded.  No perisplenic nor intra-abdominal fluid. 
  
___ CT C spine no cervical spine fracture or malalignment. 
Acute nondisplaced left posterior second rib fracture. 
  
___ CT head No acute intracranial abnormality.

 
Brief Hospital Course:
___ year old male admitted to the Trauma service after a bicycle 
crash. Injuries identified were posterior left sided ___, 
___ and 6th rib fractures and a possible splenic laceration seen 
on CT. The patient was hemodynamically stable and breathing 
comfortably on room air. He was admitted for pain control, 
pulmonary toilet, and monitoring of blood work to ensure he was 
not bleeding. 

Pain was well controlled. Hematocrit remained stable. Diet was 
progressively advanced as tolerated to a regular diet with good 
tolerability. The patient voided without problem. During this 
hospitalization, the patient worked with ___ and OT, ambulated 
early and frequently, was adherent with respiratory toilet and 
incentive spirometry, and actively participated in the plan of 
care. The patient received subcutaneous heparin and venodyne 
boots were used during this stay.

At the time of discharge on HD2, the patient was doing well, 
afebrile with stable vital signs. The patient was tolerating a

Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted to ___ after a bicycle crash. You were found 
to have left sided rib fractures and a splenic infarct (versus 
laceration). You blood levels were monitored and there was no 
signs of bleeding. Your pain was controlled and ___ has cleared 
you for discharge home to continue your  recovery. 

Liver/ Spleen lacerations:

*AVOID contact sports and/or any activity that may cause injury 
to your abdominal area for the next ___ weeks.
 
*If you suddenly become dizzy, lightheaded, feeling as if you 
are going to pass out go to the nearest Emergency Room as this 
could be a sign that you are having internal bleeding from your 
liver or spleen injury.

* Your injury caused multiple left rib fractures which can cause 
severe pain and subsequently cause you to take shallow breaths 
because of the pain.
 
* You should take your pain medication as directed to stay ahead 
of the pain otherwise you won't be able to take deep breaths. If 
the pain medication is too sedating take half the dose and 
notify your physician.
 
* Pneumonia is a complication of rib fractures.  In order to 
decrease your risk you must use your incentive spirometer 4 
times every hour while awake.  This will help expand the small 
airways in your lungs and assist in coughing up secretions that 
pool in the lungs.
 
* You will be more comfortable if you use a cough pillow to hold 
against your chest and guard your rib cage while coughing and 
deep breathing.
 
* Symptomatic relief with ice packs or heating pads for short 
periods may ease the pain.
 
* Narcotic pain medication can cause constipation therefore you 
should take a stool softener twice daily and increase your fluid 
and fiber intake if possible.
 
* Do NOT smoke
 
* If your doctor allows, non-steroidal ___ drugs 
are very effective in controlling pain ( ie, Ibuprofen, Motrin, 
Advil, Aleve, Naprosyn) but they have their own set of side 
effects so make sure your doctor approves.
 
* Return to the Emergency Room right away for any acute 
shortness of breath, increased pain or crackling sensation 
around your ribs (crepitus).

___

Pathology
Procedure date    ___ 
DIAGNOSIS: 
1.  Left lobe, liver lesion (A):
Malignant endocrine (carcinoid) tumor
2.  Small intestine, right colon, and mesenteric mass (F-AH):
A.  Malignant endocrine (carcinoid) tumor, 0.6 cm, (slides M and 
N) with associated mesenteric metastasis, 4.5 cm in greatest 
dimension.
B.  The tumor is positive for chromogranin and synaptophysin; 
extensive lymphatic vascular invasion is noted.
C.  Proximal and distal resection margins free of neoplasm.
D.  Vermiform appendix, within normal limits.
E.  Seven (7) regional lymph nodes, all with no evidence of 
malignancy.
3.  Wedge excision, left lobe liver (B-D):
Malignant endocrine (carcinoid) tumor, present at the green 
inked (inferior) margin.
4.  Additional inferior lateral margins, left lobe, liver (E):
Hepatic parenchyma with cautery artifact and no malignancy 
identified.

 
Brief Hospital Course:
___: Patient was admitted to the surgical service after 
resection of Small bowel, R colon and L metastectomy.  Pt 
remained NPO, IVF, with morphine PCA for pain control, NGT. 
___: NGT removed due to decreased output. Pt changed from NPO 
to Sips. Foley removed. Urinated spontaneously. Morphine PCA for 
pain control. Pain well controlled. 
___: Pt continued on Sips.Diet advanced to clears. 
Continued to tolerate fluid without symptoms of N/V. Medications 
switched to oral, including pain medication.
___: Advanced to regular diet - tol without difficulty. Vitals 
stable. Incision CDI. Ambulating.
Disharged home with planned follow-up with Dr. ___ in ___ 
weeks. 
 
Medications on Admission:
Toprol XL 50', Quinapril 40', HCTZ 25'
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Oxycodone-Acetaminophen ___ mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO 
Q4H (every 4 hours) as needed for pain for 2 weeks: take with 
food
take with colace.
Disp:*30 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
2. Metoprolol Tartrate 50 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO once 
a day.
Disp:*30 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
3. Colace 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO twice a day for 
2 weeks: take with percocet.
Disp:*28 Capsule(s)* Refills:*0*

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Primary: Small Bowel mesenteric carcinoid Left lobe Liver 
metastasis 
Secondary: HTN

 
Discharge Condition:
VS Stable, Tolerating regular diet, Ambulating, Pain well 
controlled with Po pain meds

 
Discharge Instructions:
Please call your doctor or return to the ER for any of the 
following:
* You experience new chest pain, pressure, squeezing or 
tightness.
* New or worsening cough or wheezing.
* If you are vomiting and cannot keep in fluids or your 
medications.
* You are getting dehydrated due to continued vomiting, 
diarrhea or other reasons. 

* Signs of dehydration include dry mouth, rapid heartbeat or 
feeling dizzy or faint when standing.
* You see blood or dark/black material when you vomit or have a 
bowel movement.
* Your pain is not improving within ___ hours or not gone 
within 24 hours. Call or return immediately if your pain is 
getting worse or is changing location or moving to your chest or 

back.

*Avoid lifting objects > 5lbs until your follow-up appointment 
with the surgeon.

*Avoid driving or operating heavy machinery while taking pain 
medications.
* You have shaking chills, or a fever greater than 101.5 (F) 
degrees or 38(C) degrees.
* Any serious change in your symptoms, or any new symptoms that 
concern you. 
* Please resume all regular home medications and take any new 
meds 
as ordered. 
* Continue to ambulate several times per day.
Incision Care: 
-Your steri-strips will fall off on their own. Please remove any 
remaining strips ___ days after surgery.
-You may shower, and wash surgical incisions.
-Avoid swimming and baths until your follow-up appointment.
-Please call the doctor if you have increased pain, swelling, 
redness, or drainage from the incision sites.

in her life, always associated with pain.

___
Family History:
Noncontributory

The patient was admitted to the Plastic Surgery Service for 
excision of deep margin of her BCC. The patient was taken to the 
OR and underwent an uncomplicated surgery.  The patient 
tolerated the procedure without complications and was 
transferred to the PACU in stable condition.  Please see 
operative report for details. Post operatively pain was with PO 
pain meds once tolerating POs.  The patient tolerated diet 
advancement without difficulty. 

The patient received ___ antibiotics.  On discharge, 
the incision was clean, dry, and intact without evidence of 
erythema or drainage, with a wound vac in place.  The patient 
was discharged in stable condition with written instructions 
concerning precautionary instructions and the appropriate 
follow-up care.  

All questions were answered prior to discharge and the patient 
expressed readiness for discharge.

text:
Name:  ___                   Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: PLASTIC
 
Allergies: 
Amoxicillin
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
Basal Cell Carcinoma of the scalp

 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
1. Adjacent tissue transfer and local tissue rearrangement of 
the scalp measuring less than 10 sq cm.
2. Full-thickness skin grafting of the scalp measuring 64 sq cm.

 
History of Present Illness:
___ with one year history of scalp crusting treated with 
betamethasone lotion, recently discovered to be BCC. Patient had 
prior surgery for treatment of an open Mohs defect of the scalp 
related to resection of basal cell carcinoma.  Thepatient now 
presents for the next stage of her reconstruction effort. 
 
Past Medical History:
1.  History of gastroesophageal reflux disease in ___ diagnosed
by Dr. ___ in ___.
2.  Rhinitis with allergic testing, negative on skin testing by
Dr. ___, alleviated by fluticasone prescribed by 
Dr. ___ much better off of dairy products.
3.  Recurrent vasovagal syncope.  She has had six episodes total
in her life, always associated with pain.

 
Social History:
___
Family History:
Noncontributory
 
Physical Exam:
Pre-procedure physical exam as documented in anesthesia record 
___:
Pulse: 85/min
Resp: 20/min
BP: 141/77
O2sat: 96%
Temp: 98.5F
.
General: anxious
Mental/psych: A/Ox3
Airway: as Documented in detail in anesthesia record
Dental: good
Head/neck range of motion: free range of motion
Lungs: clear to auscultation

 
Brief Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the plastic surgery service on 
___ and had a full thickness skin graft from her right 
groin donor site to her scalp defect.  The patient tolerated the 
procedure well. 
.
Neuro: Post-operatively, the patient received IV pain meds with 
good effect and adequate pain control. When tolerating oral 
intake, the patient was transitioned to oral pain medications. 
Patient was given Ativan prn for anxiety.  She reported good 
relief with ativan.
.
CV: The patient was stable from a cardiovascular standpoint; 
vital signs were routinely monitored.
.
Pulmonary: The patient was stable from a pulmonary standpoint; 
vital signs were routinely monitored.
.
GI/GU: Post-operatively, the patient was given IV fluids until 
tolerating oral intake. Her diet was advanced when appropriate, 
which was tolerated well. She was also started on a bowel 
regimen to encourage bowel movement. Intake and output were 
closely monitored. 
.
ID: Post-operatively, the patient was started on IV cefazolin, 
then switched to PO cefadroxil for discharge home. The patient's 
temperature was closely watched for signs of infection. 
.
At the time of discharge on POD#1, the patient was doing well, 
afebrile with stable vital signs, tolerating a regular diet, 
ambulating, voiding without assistance, and pain was well 
controlled.  She was discharged with right groin donor site 
incision clean/dry/intact without evidence of hematoma.  Her 
scalp graft site had a bolster dressing in place with kerlix 
head wrap in place.
 
Medications on Admission:
oxycodone, dilaudid, tylenol
 
Discharge Medications:
1. acetaminophen 325 mg Tablet Sig: Two (2) Tablet PO Q6H (every 
6 hours) as needed for fever, pain.  
2. lorazepam 1 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO Q8H (every 8 
hours) as needed for anxiety.
Disp:*50 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
3. Colace 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO twice a day: 
over the counter stool softener.  
4. oxycodone 5 mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO every ___ hours.
Disp:*70 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
5. senna 8.6 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO BID (2 times a 
day) as needed for constipation: over the counter vegetable 
laxative.  
6. cefadroxil 500 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO every 
twelve (12) hours for 7 days.
Disp:*14 Capsule(s)* Refills:*0*

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Basal Cell Carcinoma of the scalp

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
-There is a 'bolster' dressing on your scalp flap/graft site and 
it needs to stay in place until you see Dr. ___ follow up 
visit on ___.
-Your scalp bolster should always be covered with clean, dry, 
dressing like the gauze kerlix dressing you have in place now.  
If this dressing comes loose or becomes soiled, change the 
gauze/kerlix dressing as needed.
-You may shower 48 hours after surgery but do not let water run 
on your head/scalp area.  You may shower from the neck down only 
and you may let the water run over your right groin donor site 
incision.
.
Diet/Activity: 
1. You may resume your regular diet. 
2. DO NOT bend over, avoid heavy lifting and do not engage in 
strenuous activity until instructed by Dr. ___. 
. 
Medications: 
1. Resume your regular medications unless instructed otherwise 
and take any new meds as ordered. 
2. You may take your prescribed pain medication for moderate to 
severe pain.  
3. Take prescription pain medications for pain not relieved by 
tylenol. 
4. Take your antibiotic as prescribed. 
5. Take Colace, 100 mg by mouth 2 times per day, while taking 
the prescription pain medication. You may use a different 
over-the-counter stool softener if you wish. 
6. Do not drive or operate heavy machinery while taking any 
narcotic pain medication. You may have constipation when taking 
narcotic pain medications (oxycodone, percocet, vicodin, 
hydrocodone, dilaudid, etc.); you should continue drinking 
fluids, you may take stool softeners, and should eat foods that 
are high in fiber. 
7. do not take any medicines such as Motrin, Aspirin, Advil or 
Ibuprofen etc
. 
Call the office IMMEDIATELY if you have any of the following: 
1. Signs of infection: fever with chills, increased redness, 
swelling, warmth or tenderness at the surgical site, or unusual 
drainage from the incision(s). 
2. A large amount of bleeding from the incision(s) or drain(s). 
3. Fever greater than 101.5 oF 
4. Severe pain NOT relieved by your medication. 
. 
Return to the ER if: 
* If you are vomiting and cannot keep in fluids or your 
medications. 
* If you have shaking chills, fever greater than 101.5 (F) 
degrees or 38 (C) degrees, increased redness, swelling or 
discharge from incision, chest pain, shortness of breath, or 
anything else that is troubling you. 
* Any serious change in your symptoms, or any new symptoms that 
concern you. 

 
Followup Instructions:
___
