6 hours) as needed for fever, pain.
2. lorazepam 1 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO Q8H (every 8
hours) as needed for anxiety.
Disp:*50 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
3. Colace 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO twice a day:
over the counter stool softener.
4. oxycodone 5 mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO every ___ hours.
Disp:*70 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
5. senna 8.6 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO BID (2 times a
day) as needed for constipation: over the counter vegetable
laxative.
6. cefadroxil 500 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO every
twelve (12) hours for 7 days.
Disp:*14 Capsule(s)* Refills:*0*
Discharge Disposition:
Home
Discharge Diagnosis:
Basal Cell Carcinoma of the scalp
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.
Discharge Instructions:
-There is a 'bolster' dressing on your scalp flap/graft site and
it needs to stay in place until you see Dr. ___ follow up
visit on ___.
-Your scalp bolster should always be covered with clean, dry,
dressing like the gauze kerlix dressing you have in place now.
If this dressing comes loose or becomes soiled, change the
gauze/kerlix dressing as needed.
-You may shower 48 hours after surgery but do not let water run
on your head/scalp area. You may shower from the neck down only
and you may let the water run over your right groin donor site
incision.
.
Diet/Activity:
1. You may resume your regular diet.
2. DO NOT bend over, avoid heavy lifting and do not engage in
strenuous activity until instructed by Dr. ___.
.
Medications:
1. Resume your regular medications unless instructed otherwise
and take any new meds as ordered.
2. You may take your prescribed pain medication for moderate to
severe pain.
3. Take prescription pain medications for pain not relieved by
tylenol.
4. Take your antibiotic as prescribed.
5. Take Colace, 100 mg by mouth 2 times per day, while taking
the prescription pain medication. You may use a different
over-the-counter stool softener if you wish.
6. Do not drive or operate heavy machinery while taking any
narcotic pain medication. You may have constipation when taking
narcotic pain medications (oxycodone, percocet, vicodin,
hydrocodone, dilaudid, etc.); you should continue drinking
fluids, you may take stool softeners, and should eat foods that
are high in fiber.
7. do not take any medicines such as Motrin, Aspirin, Advil or
Ibuprofen etc
.
Call the office IMMEDIATELY if you have any of the following:
1. Signs of infection: fever with chills, increased redness,
swelling, warmth or tenderness at the surgical site, or unusual
drainage from the incision(s).
2. A large amount of bleeding from the incision(s) or drain(s).
3. Fever greater than 101.5 oF
4. Severe pain NOT relieved by your medication.
.
Return to the ER if:
* If you are vomiting and cannot keep in fluids or your
medications.
* If you have shaking chills, fever greater than 101.5 (F)
degrees or 38 (C) degrees, increased redness, swelling or
discharge from incision, chest pain, shortness of breath, or
anything else that is troubling you.
* Any serious change in your symptoms, or any new symptoms that
concern you.
Followup Instructions:
___

text:
Name:  ___.               Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: MEDICINE
 
Allergies: 
Patient recorded as having No Known Allergies to Drugs
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
Rectal Bleeding
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
Sigmoidoscopy with biopsy

 
History of Present Illness:
___ with PMH of ulcerative colitis presenting with six weeks of 
bloody diarrhea consistent with prior UC flares. Patient reports 
her last flare of UC was in ___. She subsequently 
became pregnant, and had no GI upset throughout her pregnancy. 
Six weeks post-partum she began to develop bloody, loose stools 
w/tenesmus. She was breastfeeding at the time and hoping to 
avoid starting medication, so did not seek medical attention for 
three weeks. At that time, three weeks prior to presentation, 
she was started on Prednisone 10mg TID, and she stopped 
breastfeeding. She had no change in her stools while on 
Prednisone, averaging 6 bloody bowel movements a day, 
particularly worse at night. Bowel movements are painful, and 
she also has intermittent bilateral lower quadrant pain 
throughout the day with no clear precipitant. Two days prior to 
presentation she was told to increase her Prednisone to 40mg PO 
Daily. Again, she had no clinical improvement, and she presented 
to the emergency room for further evaluation. She denies recent 
travel or sick contacts. No fevers, chills, nausea, vomiting, 
chest pain or shortness of breath. 

While in the emergency room she was found to be afebrile with 
normal vital signs. Her electrolytes and CBC were normal, a UA 
and hCG were negative, and she was admitted to the medical 
service.

ROS: Full ten-point review of systems performed and negative 
except as noted above.

 
Past Medical History:
Ulcerative Colitis
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
No FH of IBD or diabetes. Mother had melanoma but is doing well. 

 
Physical Exam:
VS: T=97.9  BP=121/73  HR=78  RR=16  O2 Sat=100% on Ra
Gen: Awake, alert, NAD
HEENT: NCAT, EOMI, anicteric
CV: RR, no m/r/g
Pulm: CTA B
Abd: Soft, NTND
Ext: No edema or calf tenderness
Psych: Affect appropriate, good insight into own health

Exam on Discharge:
Awake, alert, pleasant. Abdominal exam benign, vital signs 
stable. Cardiac and pulmonary exams wnl.
 
Pertinent Results:
___

141  105  17        AGap=15 
-------------  109 
4.4  25  0.6  

     12
8.0>----<  374 
     38

Ca: 9.8 Mg: 1.9 P: 4.4
ALT: 26 AP: 83 Tbili: 0.3 Alb: 4.2 AST: 15  
___:  Lip: 44     
HCG: Negative
ESR: 4    CRP:0.7

___
WBC-9.3 RBC-4.58 Hgb-13.0 Hct-40.6 MCV-89 Plt ___. Ulcerative colitis flare: Vital signs and hematocrit stable; 
no recent acute change in diarrhea. No fever or WBC to suggest 
systemic infection, although localized infection cannot be ruled 
out, especially given patient's recent relative immunocompromise 
while pregnant. Stool cultures and two C.Diff specimens 
negative; CMV pending. Pathology on biopsy results also pending. 
Patient was treated initially with IV steroids, and transitioned 
to Prelone 15mg/mL, 8mL's BID on the morning of discharge. Her 
last dose of IV steroids was given on the morning of ___.

The evening prior to discharge she had no blood bowel movements, 
a significant improvement from her prior average of 6 bowel 
movements per night. She did have one bloody BM on the morning 
of discharge. She was instructed to continue Prelone 8mL BID and 
begin Mesalamine and Hydrocortisone enemas at home. She will 
follow-up with ___ in one to two weeks. While on Prelone 
she was instructed to avoid NSAIDs and take daily Calcium and 
Vitamin D.

 
Medications on Admission:
Prednisone - 10 mg Tablet - one tablet three times a day
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Colazal 750 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO TID (3 times a 
day).
Disp:*90 Capsule(s)* Refills:*2*
2. Hydrocortisone 100 mg/60 mL Enema Sig: One (1)  Rectal once a 
day.
Disp:*1 month's supply* Refills:*2*
3. Mesalamine 4 gram/60 mL Enema Sig: One (1)  Rectal once a 
day.
Disp:*1 month's supply* Refills:*2*
4. Prelone 15 mg/5 mL Solution Sig: Eight (8) mL PO twice a day.
Disp:*1 month's supply* Refills:*2*

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Ulcerative Colitis

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent

 
Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted with a flare of your ulcerative colitis, which 
improved with IV steroids. A stool test for CMV and the 
pathology results of your biopsy are still pending and should be 
followed up by your outpatient providers.

Your Prednisone was increased to 30mg twice a day, and it is 
recommended that you start 5-ASA enemeas and Hydrocortisone 
enemas at home. Please take calcium and vitamin D while you are 
on Prednisone, and avoid non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs 
like Ibuprofen or Aspirin.
 
Followup Instructions:
___

___ 9:16 pm URINE **FINAL REPORT ___
URINE CULTURE (Final ___: MIXED BACTERIAL FLORA ( >= 3 
COLONY TYPES), CONSISTENT WITH SKIN AND/OR GENITAL 
CONTAMINATION. 

Pelvic US ___: A small amount of cysts intra-abdominal 
intrapelvic ascites is present, slightly increased in comparison 
with the reference study from ___. Again seen are 
markedly enlarged ovaries bilaterally, containing multiple 
follicles and cysts with internal echogenic components, possibly 
reflecting post-harvesting hemorrhage. The right ovary measures 
8.1 x 6.3 x 7.3 cm and the left ovary measures 6.3 x 5.3 x 6.0 
cm.  Arterial and venous waveforms are demonstrated within both 
ovaries. The endometrial stripe measures 1.3 cm in thickness.  
The uterus appears normal.
IMPRESSION:
1. Small amount of ascites has slightly increased since ___.
2. Bilateral enlarged ovaries containing multiple follicles and 
complex cysts, compatible with known ovarian stimulation related 
to IVF.
3. Venous and arterial waveforms are demonstrated within both 
ovaries.
 
Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ was admitted to the gynecology service after 
being transferred from ___ for abdominal pain 
and bloating s/p embryo transfer on ___, concerning for 
ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome.

She was made NPO and given IV tylenol and IV dilaudid as needed 
for pain. Serial abdominal exams were reassuring. She underwent 
pelvic ultrasound revealing a small amount of ascites slightly 
increased from the prior study at the OSH, bilateral enlarged 
ovaries containing multiple follicles and complex cysts,
compatible with known ovarian stimulation related to IVF, and 
venous and arterial waveforms are demonstrated within both 
ovaries. The small amount of ascites was unable to be drained. 
Her electrolytes, CBC and liver function tests were 
unremarkable, except for a slightly elevated hematocrit at 44 
and sodium of 132 at which time she was placed on D5NS for IV 
fluids.

Given these reassuring findings, on the afternoon of hospital 
day #1, her diet was advanced and she tolerated a regular diet. 
Her pain was well-controlled with oral tylenol and oxycodone. 
She was then discharged in stable condition with out-patient 
follow-up scheduled.
 
Medications on Admission:
PNV, 2mg estrace BID, crinone 8% BID
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Acetaminophen ___ mg PO Q6H:PRN pain 
RX *acetaminophen 325 mg ___ tablet(s) by mouth every six (6) 
hours Disp #*30 Tablet Refills:*0
2. OxycoDONE (Immediate Release)  ___ mg PO Q4H:PRN pain 
RX *oxycodone 5 mg ___ tablet(s) by mouth every four (4) hours 
Disp #*15 Tablet Refills:*0
 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
abdominal pain & bloating
 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.
 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear ___,
You were admitted to the gynecology service after presenting 
with abdominal pain and bloating after embryo transfer, given 
concern for ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome. You lab work was 
normal. Your ultrasound showed large ovaries with follicles 
consistent with recent IVF but no obvious source of your pain. 
You have tolerated a regular diet and are now safe to go home. 
Please follow the instructions below.

General instructions:  
* Take your medications as prescribed.  
* Do not drive while taking narcotics. 
* Take a stool softener such as colace while taking narcotics to 
prevent constipation. 
* Do not combine narcotic and sedative medications or alcohol.  
* Do not take more than 4000mg acetaminophen (APAP) in 24 hrs.   

* You may eat a regular diet.  
 
Call your doctor for:  
* fever > 100.4  
* severe abdominal pain  
* difficulty urinating  
* vaginal bleeding requiring >1 pad/hr  
* abnormal vaginal discharge  
* redness or drainage from incision  
* nausea/vomiting where you are unable to keep down fluids/food 
or your medication  

To reach medical records to get the records from this 
hospitalization sent to your doctor at home, call ___.
 
Followup Instructions:
___

Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.
Discharge Instructions:
Dear ___,
You were admitted to the gynecology service after presenting
with abdominal pain and bloating after embryo transfer, given
concern for ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome. You lab work was
normal. Your ultrasound showed large ovaries with follicles
consistent with recent IVF but no obvious source of your pain.
You have tolerated a regular diet and are now safe to go home.
Please follow the instructions below.
General instructions:
* Take your medications as prescribed.
* Do not drive while taking narcotics.
* Take a stool softener such as colace while taking narcotics to
prevent constipation.
* Do not combine narcotic and sedative medications or alcohol.
* Do not take more than 4000mg acetaminophen (APAP) in 24 hrs.
* You may eat a regular diet.
Call your doctor for:
* fever > 100.4
* severe abdominal pain
* difficulty urinating
* vaginal bleeding requiring >1 pad/hr
* abnormal vaginal discharge
* redness or drainage from incision
* nausea/vomiting where you are unable to keep down fluids/food
or your medication
To reach medical records to get the records from this
hospitalization sent to your doctor at home, call ___.
Followup Instructions:
___

text:
Name:  ___                      Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: MEDICINE
 
Allergies: 
No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
Post operative monitoring/Hypoxia  
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
CT guided biopsy of L lung mass

 
History of Present Illness:
___ F h/o PMHx metastatic stage IV inflammatory breast CA who is 
undergoing palliative radiation therapy, who presented to ___ 
today for an elective left apical lung mass biopsy. At the time 
of the procedure, she developed an expected amount of 
postprocedure intraparenchymal hemorrhage, however, following 
the procedure, she desaturated to 89% and had to be placed on a 
nonrebreather. Her sats came up and she was weaned to room air 
in the RCU. However, she continued to desaturate with movement, 
to the high ___. Given this and patient preference, she will be 
admitted to the hospitalist service overnight for observation.  
 The patient also developed a small pneumothorax following the 
procedure, which was aspirated successfully. There was trace 
pneumothorax on her 4 hour postprocedure followup chest xray, 
which radiology did not feel played a significant role in her 
desaturation.  
 Upon arrival to the floor, patient reports feeling well. She 
reports her procedure was in the morning, has had no chest pain, 
shortness of breath, did not feel the hypoxia. She has no leg 
swelling, no other symptoms.  

 
Past Medical History:
-Metastatic R breast poorly differentiated carcinoma, ER 
negative, PR negative, and HER-2/neu negative. Per rad/onc note: 
"originally treated with TC and this was followed by Taxol; the 
last chemotherapy was in ___. Most recently, this 
patient felt some masses in the right breast that are slightly 
painful at times. They are not invading the skin and she had a 
CT of the chest, abdomen and pelvis, which was done on ___.  
 -This revealed a new right breast mass with minimal thickening 
consistent with a history of recurrent inflammatory breast 
cancer."  
 -Stroke  
 -Atrial fibrillation  
 -Hysterectomy  
 -Hypercholesterolemia,  
 -Gout  
 -Chronic kidney disease stage III  
 -Coronary artery disease  
 -Rhinitis.  
 -S/p hysterectomy  
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
Father- with heart disease, MI. Prevalent heart disease and DM 
in family.
 
Physical Exam:
ADMISSION PHYSICAL EXAM:
========================
VITAL SIGNS: 98.5 BP 129-140/68-77 HR 87 RR16 96% 2L NC  
GENERAL: well appearing, elderly woman, in NAD, Nasal cannula on 
 
HEENT: PERRL, EOMI, moist mucous membranes, clear OP, tongue 
midline  
NECK: no cervical lymphadenopathy, JVD not elevated  
BREAST: right breast lateral with small palpable mobile mass, 
left breast ithout masses  
CARDIAC: irregular rhythm, regular rate, without murmur  
LUNGS: Decreased BS over LUL, otherwise clear, trace crackles at 
right base, symmetric air movement  
ABDOMEN: soft non tender, non distended  
EXTREMITIES: no peripheral edema, warm and well perfused  
NEUROLOGIC: alert and oriented x3 

DISCHARGE PHYSICAL EXAM:
========================
VS: T 98.1, BP 125/74, HR 82, RR 18, O2 94% RA
GEN: Well appearing elderly woman, NAD
LUNGS: Breathing unlabored on room air, decreased BS LUL. No 
wheezes, rales, or rhonchi
CV: Irregular rhythm, regular rate, no m/r/g
EXT: No ___ edema

K-3.2* Cl-104 HCO3-25 AnGap-18
___ 06:09AM BLOOD CK-MB-3 cTropnT-<0.___ year-old woman with metastatic stage IV inflammatory breast 
CA undergoing palliative radiation therapy, who underwent 
elective ___ lung biopsy of L apical mass, subsequently developed 
hypoxia to ___ post procedurally and was admitted overnight for 
monitoring. Post procedural CXRs demonstrated tiny pneumothorax 
that radiology did not feel explained hypoxia. This improved on 
subsequent CXRs. Weaned to room air on arrival to the floor and 
remained stable with no dyspnea. Ambulatory sat *88-90. Hypoxia 
likely in setting of post-procedural atelectasis or aspiration. 
Discharged home to follow-up with outpatient providers.

Hyperglycemia 
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
None

 
History of Present Illness:
Ms. ___ is a ___ year old woman with IDDM type 2, HTN, DLP 
who recently lost her insurance and has ran out of her 
medications. Today she presents with "weakness" and 
hyperglycemia. Ms. ___ reports receiving her care at ___ 
until ___ when she lost her insurance. Her insulin regimen 
consisted of lantus (unknown dose) and humalog sliding scale. 
She has not taken lantus in over six months, and since then has 
stretched her humalog. Her last insulin was back in ___. 
She also reports taking a medication for hypertension and 
dyslipidemia, but has also ran out of these medications. Over 
the past two months she reports feelin "ill," with poor 
concentration, polyuria (urinating ___ times overnight), 
polydypsia, reduced appetite and poor po intake. Since 
___, she started to feel very weak. She also expresses 
feeling lightheaded and dizzy in the morning upon rising, 
nauseous, but without any syncopal episodes or falls. She denies 
vertigo, headaches, shortness of breath, dysuria, chest pain. 
She endorses a chronic cough secondary to cigarrette smoking. Of 
note, she reports some hair loss, cold intolerance, and a ~20lb 
weight loss over the past year. She denies any fevers, chills, 
nightsweats.  
.  
In the ED, initial vs were: VS 97.8 75 91/71 16 100. On exam, 
patient had negative romberg sign. Her labs were notable for 
glucose 420s, normal bicarb, urine ketones negative. She was 
given 2 L NS by mouth and 6U of lantus and her ___ came back as 
360s. A CXR was unremarkable. Patient was admitted for further 
control of her hyperglycemia and dehydration.  
.  
On the floor, she continues to feel "weak" and tired. Currently, 
she denies any N/V, F/C, abdominal pain.

no rebound tenderness or guarding. Firm nodular area in lower

___ 01:15PM URINE  COLOR-Yellow APPEAR-Clear SP ___ year old woman with IDDM type 2, HTN, DLP who recently lost 
her insurance and has ran out of her medications, who presents 
with hyperglycemia.  
.  
Patient presented with symptoms of uncontrolled Diabetes as she 
was unable to access insulin for over a month.  On presentation 
she had trace ketones in her urine, but normal Na/K/bicarb and 
Cr at baseline and serum osm was not elevated to suggest DKA or 
HSS.  She was treated with ivfs initially, and restarted on an 
ISS and lantus 12u bedtime.  SW work was consulted. Ultimately, 
it was discerned that patient must make backpayments to 
___ to reestablish Medicaid.  She was given two 
weeks worth of Free Care medications from ___ and 
discharged with plans for her to apply for free care at ___.  
Her PCP's office was notified of plan and outpatient appointment 
established for her.  Her home medications as confirmed by PCP's 
office were restarted on discharge.

text:
Name:  ___           Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: MEDICINE
 
Allergies: 
Percocet
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
diarrhea
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
none
 
History of Present Illness:
___ h/o recurrent Cdiff colitis since ___ (developed after 
taking cipro while travelling in ___ in ___ when 
she experienced travellers diarrhea) who was transferred from 
___ ED to ___ ED for ongoing diarrhea and abdominal cramping. 
 She was admitted to ___ ___ to ___ for diarrhea and cdiff 
recurrence with treatment including PO vanco and rifaxamin after 
GI and ID consultation.  She had normal screening colonoscopy 
before her illness in early ___.  She has not had bloody 
stools.  Her current bowel patterns include frequent soft stools 
that ocurr multiple times a day and are not liquidy.  She does 
not have blood or much mucous with stools.  She has lower 
abdominal cramping and no tenesmus.  She developed dry heaves 
over the past week and has had poor appetite and oral intake 
with approx 5 lb weight loss.  She is fatigued and experiences 
chills.  13pt ROS otherwise negative including no new oral 
ulcers, no cough, resp symptoms, rash, easy bruising.

I reviewed all pertinent ___ notes, which should be 
referred to for further details of recent illness.
 
Past Medical History:
head injury
hyperlipidemia
migraines
seronegative rehumatoid arthritis
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
per ___ consult: no known IBD
 
Physical Exam:
97.8 130/60 55 16
thin, calm female lying in bed, appears tired
clear breath sounds, regular s1 and s2
no oral ulcers
LLQ abd tenderness without guarding or rebound, no organomegaly
external rectal exam unremarkable, digital rectal exam deferred
no rash on trunk or extremities
 
Pertinent Results:
___ 12:40AM BLOOD WBC-6.7 RBC-4.25 Hgb-11.9* Hct-37.6 
MCV-89 MCH-28.0 MCHC-31.6 RDW-13.0 Plt ___
___ 12:40AM BLOOD Glucose-85 UreaN-8 Creat-0.5 Na-141 K-3.3 
Cl-109* HCO3-23 AnGap-12
___ 12:40AM BLOOD ALT-21 AST-20 AlkPhos-42 TotBili-0.2
___ 12:40AM BLOOD Albumin-3.8 Calcium-8.4 Phos-2.6* Mg-1.7

___ CT report ___
  ___
      
     CT SCAN ABDOMEN AND PELVIS WITH CONTRAST:
      
     CLINICAL HISTORY:   Left lower quadrant pain and diarrhea.  

      
     Contrast utilized Omnipaque-300 150 cc.
      
     DOSE DLP:  334 mCy per cm.
      
     FINDINGS:
      
     The lung bases are normal.  
      
     The liver enhances normally.  The liver, spleen, pancreas,
     gallbladder, adrenal glands and kidneys are normal.  The 
aorta and IVC
     are normal.  Copious fecal material seen in the colon.  The 
appendix
     is normal with a diameter of 5 mm.  The distal sigmoid 
colon appears
     to have a thickened somewhat nodular and enhancing wall 
consistent
     with an inflammatory process.  I do not see diverticula to 
suggest
     diverticulitis but other inflammatory process should be 
considered. 
     Follow-up is suggested as proliferative process cannot be 
excluded.  
      
     CONCLUSION:
      
     THICKENING OF THE SIGMOID COLON.  THERE ARE NO DIVERTICULA. 
 THIS
     COULD BE AN INFLAMMATORY PROCESS BUT NEOPLASM CANNOT BE 
ENTIRE
     EXCLUDED.  FOLLOW-UP STRONGLY RECOMMENDED.
      

Endoscopy ___:
 Normal mucosa in the whole esophagus
Normal mucosa in the whole stomach
Normal mucosa in the duodenal bulb (biopsy)
Normal mucosa in the second part of the duodenum (biopsy)
Otherwise normal EGD to third part of the duodenum

Colonoscopy ___:
 Normal mucosa in the whole colon (biopsy)
The terminal ileum was intubated and appeared normal.
Otherwise normal colonoscopy to terminal ileum

Biopsies:  Pending

 
Brief Hospital Course:
___ with RA, recurrent Cdiff colitis admitted with frequent 
stools (not liquid) and dry heaves and LLQ tenderness, with 
negative evaluation for new infection or IBD.

#Diarrhea
#Recurrent cdiff

While admitted she did not have diarrhea.  She underwent CT 
abdomen that showed significant improvement in sigmoid bowel 
thickening seen on prior CT at ___ last month.  She 
experienced epigastric pain.  GI consulted and performed 
endoscopy and colonoscopy that were normal.  Because her 
diarrhea improved and they felt she had adequate response to 
treatment for what was considered first recurrence of cdiff, her 
vanco and rifaxamin were stopped.  Eventually able to send stool 
for micro studies, with negative giardia.  

She had no significant diarrhea while hospitalized, but some 
nausea and decreased appetite.  After normal EGD and 
colonoscopy, symptoms were most likely related to a post 
infectious irritable bowel disease, and she was started on 
symptomatic treatment. 

She did continue to have nausea, and decreased appetite, and may 
benefit from nutrition evaluation after discharge. 

## Atypical chest pain
Developed atypical chest pain on ___.  She was monitored on 
telemetry, had negative enzymes and unchanged EKG.  Attributed 
to anxiety

Chronic issues:

## Rheumatoid arthritis
She was continued on outpatient regimen.

 
Medications on Admission:
The Preadmission Medication list is accurate and complete.
1. Vancomycin Oral Liquid ___ mg PO Q6H 
2. Rifaximin 550 mg PO BID 
3. PredniSONE 2.5 mg PO DAILY 
4. Hydroxychloroquine Sulfate 200 mg PO BID 
5. Ondansetron 4 mg PO Q8H:PRN naus 
6. Meclizine 12.5 mg PO Q8H:PRN naus 
7. Nadolol 40 mg PO DAILY 
8. Fluoxetine 20 mg PO DAILY 
9. TraZODone 150 mg PO HS:PRN insomn 

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Irritable bowel disease
Migraine
Dehydration
Anxiety
Chest pain

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
you were admitted with diarrhea, but did not have diarrhea while 
admitted.  ct scan showed no inflammation.  Your endoscopy and 
colonoscopy did not show any evidence of obvious inflammation.  
The biopsies are still pending.  

It did not apppear that you had ongoing Clostridium dificile 
colitis, and treatment was stopped.

Overall we thought your symptoms were related to a post 
infectious IBD, and they will improve over time.

your antibiotics for cdiff were stopped
 
Followup Instructions:
___

Name:  ___                   Unit No:   ___

Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: SURGERY
 
Allergies: 
No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
jaundice, fevers
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
ERCP and stent placement
 
History of Present Illness:
Pt is a ___ F w/ h/o obstructive jaundice planning for 
hepaticojejunostomy, presents to the ED w/ fevers. The patient 
was previously seen in the ___ clinic for obstructive jaundice, 
and had undergone ERCP/EUS w/ negative brushings as well as CBD 
stent placement. Upon presentation to the hospital, the patient 
states the she had new fevers to 101 over the preceding 24 hrs, 
as well as abdominal pain.
 
Past Medical History:
PMH: HL, GERD, gastric ulcer
PSH: D&C, tooth extractions

 
Social History:
___
Family History:
Mother with gallbladder disease and who died from
intestinal perforation, brother with lung cancer, CAD

 
Physical Exam:
At time of discharge,
afebrile, VSS
NAD, jaundice/scleral icterus
RRR
CTAB
Abd soft, NT, ND
Ext warm no edema
 
Pertinent Results:
RUQ Ultrasound:
FINDINGS:  There is massive intrahepatic biliary duct 
dilatation.  The common bile duct measures 1.5 cm in diameter.  
The gallbladder is distended and has a thickened wall.  There is 
hyperechoic nonshadowing material in the gallbladder which 
changed in configuration over the course of the exam, likely 
sludge.  There is a slightly hyperechoic ill defined mass in the 
area of the pancreatic head and may represent known tumor. 
Pancreatic duct is not dilated.  The right kidney measures 11.6 
cm and is unremarkable.  
  
IMPRESSION:  Massive intrahepatic biliary duct dilatation and 
common bile duct dilatation.  The gallbladder is distended with 
a thickened wall and there is a small amount of sludge.  There 
is no sonographic ___ sign.  Clinically correlate for 
possibility of acute cholecystitis. 

___ 08:12PM BLOOD WBC-16.2* RBC-3.20* Hgb-10.7* Hct-32.1* 
MCV-100* MCH-33.5* MCHC-33.4 RDW-16.0* Plt ___
___ 07:10AM BLOOD WBC-12.6* RBC-3.09* Hgb-10.3* Hct-31.5* 
MCV-102* MCH-33.4* MCHC-32.8 RDW-16.1* Plt ___
___ 11:32PM BLOOD ___ PTT-26.3 ___
___ 07:10AM BLOOD ___
___ 08:12PM BLOOD ALT-178* AST-132* AlkPhos-450* Amylase-32 
TotBili-25.1* DirBili-19.2* IndBili-5.9
___ 07:10AM BLOOD ALT-145* AST-103* AlkPhos-383* Amylase-20 
TotBili-21.9*
___ 07:10AM BLOOD Calcium-8.1* Phos-2.0* Mg-2.___ presented with obstructive jaundice secondary to pancreatic 
head lesion, presenting with new onset fevers and abdominal 
pain. A RUQ ultrasound was performed, showing ductal dilation 
suggestive of obstruction, as well as gallbladder distention and 
wall thickening suggestive of infection. Patient was admitted to 
the service and started on IV hydration and broad spectrum 
antibiotics, with resolution of fever and abdominal pain. 
Subsequently, an ERCP was performed and her previous stent was 
not observed and had likely migrated out. A new stent was placed 
successfully with return of bile. She recovered from this 
procedure well and was tolerating a regular diet. At time of 
discharge she was eating well, passing flatus, voiding, and 
ambulating appropriately. She will be discharged home and will 
follow-up for her regularly scheduled surgery next week. During 
this hospitalization she had labs, UA, CXR, and EKG for 
pre-operative testing.
 
Medications on Admission:
Alendronate 70qweek, Hydroxyzine 25 prn, Omeprazole 20', 
rosuvastatin 20', CaCO3/Vit D, Omega fatty acids. 

 
Discharge Medications:
1. Amoxicillin-Clavulanic Acid ___ mg PO Q12H 
RX *amoxicillin-pot clavulanate 875 mg-125 mg 1 Tablet(s) by 
mouth twice daily Disp #*28 Tablet Refills:*0
2. HydrOXYzine 25 mg PO Q6H:PRN itching 
RX *hydroxyzine HCl 25 mg ___ tabs by mouth every 6 hours Disp 
#*30 Tablet Refills:*1
3. Omeprazole 20 mg PO DAILY 
4. Alendronate 70qweek, CaCO3/Vit D, Omega fatty acids.
 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
obstructive jaundice secondary to pancreatic head lesion

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
You were evaluated for fevers. You had an ERCP and your prior 
stent had been dislodged. A new stent was placed successfully 
and you are now ready to return home. Please resume all regular 
home medications, unless specifically advised not to take a 
particular medication.  Also, please take any new medications as 
prescribed.

You will continue a course of augmentin while at home. This 
should be taken until your scheduled surgery next week.

Please get plenty of rest, continue to ambulate several times 
per day, and drink adequate amounts of fluids.  Avoid lifting 
weights greater than ___ lbs until you follow-up with your 
surgeon, who will instruct you further regarding activity 
restrictions.

Avoid driving or operating heavy machinery while taking pain 
medications.

Please follow-up with your surgeon and Primary Care Provider 
(PCP) as advised.

 
Followup Instructions:
___

Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ is a ___ year old G1 at ___ who was admitted on 
___ with preterm contractions and threatened preterm labor.

Over 2 hours, a sterile vaginal exam was unchanged at 
long/closed/post ___ ___. Tocolysis was deferred. A WBC and 
differential was within normal limits. A UA was negative with 
few bacteria. Genital cultures were obtained as well. 

On hospital day 2, patient felt much better. She denied any more 
symptoms of preterm labor. She was made beta complete. She was 
then discharged to home with close follow up. 

 
Medications on Admission:
PNV, iron, Colace 
 
Discharge Medications:
PNV, iron, Colace 
 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
preterm contractions

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear. Ms. ___,

 You were admitted to the hospital with contractions concerning 
for preterm labor. You were monitored without any evidence of 
further vaginal bleeding. You received betamethasone for fetal 
lung maturity and you were counseled by the NICU team. All of 
your fetal testing have been reassuring.  We think it is now 
safe for you to go home. 

Please follow the instructions below:  
 - Attend all appointments with your obstetrician and all fetal 
scans  
 - Monitor for the following danger signs:  
 - headache that is not responsive to medication  
 - abdominal pain  
 - increased swelling in your legs  
 - vision changes  
 - Worsening, painful or regular contractions  
 - Vaginal bleeding  
 - Leakage of water or concern that your water broke  
 - Nausea/vomiting  
 - Fever, chills  
 - Decreased fetal movement  
 - Other concerns  
 
Followup Instructions:
___

text:
Name:  ___                 Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: MEDICINE
 
Allergies: 
Patient recorded as having No Known Allergies to Drugs
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
facial swelling, hoarseness
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
Fiberscopic Airway Examination

 
History of Present Illness:
This is a ___ male with no previous history of urticaria 
and angioedema who, for the past three weeks, describes waxing 
and waning, swelling, and some hive-like lesions.  They can, for 
most days, be on the body lasting a few
hours at a time with areas of some redness and slight swelling 
and itchiness that go away spontaneously in a few hours.  There 
were a couple of days where there was some lip swelling, but 
never severe until this morning when he awoke up with quite 
prominent lip and face swelling as well as sensation of
hoarseness of his voice.  He presented to the ED and was given 
Solu-Medrol 125mg, diphenhydramine, and Pepcid.  He was admitted 
to the ICU for careful observation.  ENT consultation in the ED 
included fiberoptic endoscopic examination showing no vocal cord 
swelling, and his airway was cleared.

 
Past Medical History:
1. ADHD.
2. Hyperlipidemia
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
Son with asthma
 
Physical Exam:
VITAL SIGNS:  Blood pressure 134/76, pulse 97, respiratory rate
18.  Sat is 99% on room air.
GENERAL APPEARANCE: Comfortable, NAD
HEENT: NC/AT, MMM, no tongue swelling or oral lesions
LIPS: Lower greater than upper mild degree of lip swelling.  
NECK:  Perhaps slight residual swelling noted, but no 
appreciable
angioedema.
SKIN:  No hives actively noted
HEART: RRR, S1/S2 present, -mrg
LUNGS: clear to auscultation bilaterally, no wheezes or crackles
ABD: +BS, soft, NT, ND
EXT: 2+ peripheral pulses, no swelling or edema

 
Pertinent Results:
___ 09:30AM   GLUCOSE-114* UREA N-20 CREAT-1.0 SODIUM-139 
POTASSIUM-4.4 CHLORIDE-104 TOTAL CO2-27 ANION GAP-12
___ 09:30AM   WBC-7.5 RBC-5.18 HGB-15.0 HCT-43.5 MCV-84 
MCH-28.9 MCHC-34.5 RDW-13.3
___ 09:30AM   NEUTS-71.4* ___ MONOS-5.5 EOS-2.1 
BASOS-0.7
___ 09:30AM   PLT COUNT-324
 
Brief Hospital Course:
This is a ___ yo male with 3 weeks of recurrent angioedema and 
urticaria with no clear etiology. On admission to the MICU 
urticaria was inapparrent and facial angioedema nearly resolved. 
ENT fiberoptic exam did not demonstrate any airway edema.
Allergy was consulted and felt this could be a new onset of 
chronic idiopathic urticaria and angioedema. Given patient's 
symptoms were improved, he was discharged home with Prednisone 
40 mg per day for five days, Fexofenadine 60 b.i.d.,Famotidine 
20 mg daily, Diphenhydramine ___ mg q.6h. p.r.n. for mild 
swelling and EpiPen p.r.n. for severe swelling. He is scheduled 
to follow up in allergy clinic on ___.

 
Medications on Admission:
AMPHETAMINE-DEXTROAMPHETAMINE [ADDERALL XR] - 15 mg Capsule,
Sust. Release 24 hr - 1 Capsule(s) by mouth ___ daily
SIMVASTATIN [ZOCOR] - 20 mg Tablet - 1 (One) Tablet(s) by mouth
once a day
TRAZODONE - 50 mg Tablet - ___ Tablet(s) by mouth bedtime
 
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Prednisone 20 mg Tablet Sig: Two (2) Tablet PO once a day for 
5 days.
Disp:*10 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
2. Allegra 60 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO twice a day.
Disp:*60 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
3. Pepcid 20 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO once a day.
Disp:*30 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
4. Benadryl 25 mg Capsule Sig: ___ Capsules PO every ___ hours 
as needed for allergy symptoms.
Disp:*30 Capsule(s)* Refills:*0*
5. EpiPen 0.3 mg/0.3 mL Pen Injector Sig: One (1)  Intramuscular 
PRN 
6. Adderall XR 15mg ___ daily
7. Simvastatin 20mg daily
8. Trazadone 50mg qHS

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Primary: Angioedema
Secondary: Hyperlipidemia, Insomnia, Attention Deficit Disorder

 
Discharge Condition:
stable

 
Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted to the ICU to monitor your facial swelling. 
You were seen by ENT who examined your airway and did not see 
any swelling. You were also seen by an allergy specialist who 
recommends that you follow up in outpatient allergy clinic. It 
is unclear what exactly is causing your facial swelling and the 
rash you describe. It is possible this represents a condition 
called angioedema.

NEW Medications:
Prednisone 40mg daily (start ___: This is a steroid you should 
take for 5 days.
Benadryl 25mg-50mg ___: as needed for rash and facial 
swelling
Allegra 60 mg twice a day: this is a medication to prevent 
allergic symptoms
Pepcid 20mg daily: this is another medication to prevent allegic 
symptoms
Epinephrine Pen: USE ONLY IN EMERGENCY--i.e. if you feel as 
though you are having airway swelling or difficulty breathing

You are scheduled to follow up in allergy clinic.

You should contact your PCP or come to the ED if you experience 
difficulty breathing or feeling as though there is swelling in 
your airway or if you notice continued hoarseness in your voice.

 
Followup Instructions:
___

Service: UROLOGY
 
Allergies: 
No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions

Chief Complaint:
Urinary retention
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
TURP

 
History of Present Illness:
This patient is a ___ white male who has a
history of multiple episodes of urinary retention and currently
presents with a Foley catheter from his last episode of 
retention
___. On flomax and finasteride. Prostate ultrasound 
showing 150 gram prostate. Now presents for TURP.

 
Past Medical History:
PMHx: BPH, retention, HLD
PSHx: ESWL, cataract surgery, knee surgeries

 
Social History:
___
Family History:
NC
 
Physical Exam:
NAD
AVSS
WWP
Unlabored breathing
Abdomen soft, NT, ND
GU: Foley clear yellow with light pink tinge
Ext WWP, good distal pulses, no edema
 
Pertinent Results:
___ 11:53AM   GLUCOSE-126* UREA N-14 CREAT-0.9 SODIUM-141 
POTASSIUM-4.3 CHLORIDE-108 TOTAL CO2-31 ANION GAP-6*
___ 11:53AM   estGFR-Using this
___ 11:53AM   CALCIUM-8.4 MAGNESIUM-1.9
___ 11:53AM   WBC-14.2* RBC-4.18* HGB-13.0*# HCT-36.7*# 
MCV-88 MCH-31.0 MCHC-35.3* RDW-12.7
___ 11:53AM   PLT COUNT-269
 
Brief Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to Dr. ___ service after 
bipolar transurethral resection of prostate. No concerning 
intraoperative events occurred; please see dictated operative 
note for details. He patient received ___ antibiotic 
prophylaxis and was started on ciprofloxacin. The patient's 
postoperative course was uncomplicated. His Foley was placed on 
traction for 2 hours after the procedure and continuous bladder 
irrigation overnight. On POD1 the CBI was discontinued but his 
urine became slightly bloody. He was thus kept on continuous 
bladder irrigation until POD2, at which point it was clamped. 
His urine was clear and and without clots. He remained a-febrile 
throughout his hospital stay.  At discharge, the patient had 
pain well controlled with oral pain medications, was tolerating 
regular diet, ambulating without assistance. He was discharged 
with a Foley catheter and one week of antibiotics.  He was 
instructed to follow up in clinic in one week for void trial
 
Medications on Admission:
See LMR
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Acetaminophen 650 mg PO Q4H:PRN pain, fever>100 
2. Bacitracin Ointment 1 Appl TP TID 
3. Ciprofloxacin HCl 500 mg PO Q12H 
4. Docusate Sodium 100 mg PO BID 
5. Finasteride 5 mg PO DAILY 
6. OxycoDONE (Immediate Release)  5 mg PO Q4H:PRN pain 
7. Simvastatin 20 mg PO DAILY 
8. Tamsulosin 0.4 mg PO HS 

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
BPH, Urinary retention

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
-Do not lift anything heavier than a phone book (10 pounds) or 
drive until you are seen by your Urologist in follow-up

-You may continue to periodically see small amounts of blood in 
your urine--this is normal and will gradually improve

-Resume all of your pre-admission medications, except HOLD 
aspirin until you see your urologist in followup AND your foley 
has been removed (if not already done)

-Continue taking PROSCAR (Finasteride) AND/OR your other 
prostate shrinking medications until you are otherwise advised 
.

-You MAY be discharged home with a medication called PYRIDIUM 
that will help with the "burning" pain you may experience when 
voiding. This medication may turn your urine bright orange.

-Colace has been prescribed to avoid post surgical constipation 
and constipation related to narcotic pain medication. 
Discontinue if loose stool or diarrhea develops. Colace is a 
stool softener, NOT a laxative, and available over the counter.  
The generic name is DOCUSATE SODIUM.  It is recommended that you 
use this medication.

-Do not eat constipating foods for ___ weeks, drink plenty of 
fluids to keep hydrated

-No vigorous physical activity or sports for 4 weeks and while 
Foley catheter is in place. 

-Tylenol should be your first line pain medication, a narcotic 
pain medication has been prescribed for breakthrough pain >4. 
Replace Tylenol with narcotic pain medication.

-Max daily Tylenol (acetaminophen) dose is 4 grams from ALL 
sources, note that narcotic pain medication also contains 
Tylenol

-Do not drive or drink alcohol while taking narcotics and do not 
operate dangerous machinery. Also, if the Foley catheter and Leg 
Bag are in place--Do NOT drive (you may be a passenger).

-Please refer to the provided nursing instructions and handout 
on Foley catheter care, waste elimination and leg bag usage.

-Your Foley should be secured to the catheter secure on your 
thigh at ALL times until your follow up with the surgeon.

-Follow up in 1 week for wound check and Foley removal. DO NOT 
have anyone else other than your Surgeon remove your Foley for 
any reason.

-Wear Large Foley bag for majority of time, leg bag is only for 
short-term when leaving house.

-Please continue to take ciprofloxacin until you see Dr. ___ 
___ Foley removal.
 
Followup Instructions:
___

text:
Name:  ___                      Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: UROLOGY
 
Allergies: 
No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
Right flank pain
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
cystoscopy, right ureteroscopy, laser lithotripsy, biopsy, stent 
placement

 
History of Present Illness:
(From admission:) 
___ who presents with right flank pain.  Patient states
that he woke today with pain in his right lower abdomen.  Felt
similar to past stone episodes.  He is followed by Dr. ___ for 2 known right kidney stones; currently followed with
serial imaging.  No nausea or vomiting; no fever.  No UTI
symptoms.  Of note, had one episode of diarrhea this morning.
 
Past Medical History:
High cholesterol, depression. previous rotator cuff repair ___
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
NC
 
Physical Exam:
NAD
Equal chest rise b/l
Abd soft NTND
Min R CVA tenderness
Ext WWP
 
Pertinent Results:
___ 06:41AM BLOOD WBC-9.6 RBC-4.17* Hgb-12.6* Hct-38.7* 
MCV-93 MCH-30.2 MCHC-32.6 RDW-13.6 RDWSD-46.3 Plt ___
___ 06:41AM BLOOD Glucose-232* UreaN-18 Creat-2.0* Na-137 
K-3.9 Cl-102 HCO3-25 AnGap-14
 
Brief Hospital Course:
Given that CT showed 4mm R UVJ stone with new elevation in Cr 
from 1.3 from 1.7, patient was admitted to the urology service 
for further observation.  Overnight, he was placed on aggressive 
IVF hydration and pain controlled.  He was also given a single 
dose of ceftriaxone.  On the morning of HD 2, he continued to 
require IV narcotics for pain control and also experienced an 
elevation in his Cr to 2.0.  As such, the decision was made to 
proceed to the OR for operative intervention.

He underwent cystoscopy, right ureteroscopy, laser lithotriospy, 
biopsy, and stent placement. Abnormal tissue was encountered in 
the mid-ureter which was likely reactive. A biopsy and cytology 
was obtained. 

He tolerated the procedure well; see the dictated operative note 
for full details. He recovered in the PACU.  His diet was 
advanced as tolerated there, where he remained afebrile with 
excellent pain control.  

Given that the patient's pain was controlled with oral pain 
medications, tolerating regular diet, ambulating without 
assistance, and voiding without difficulty, he was discharged 
home after the procedure.  

Patient was explicitly advised to follow up as directed as the 
indwelling ureteral stent must be removed and or exchanged.

 
Medications on Admission:
The Preadmission Medication list is accurate and complete.
1. Celecoxib 200 mg ORAL BID:PRN pain 
2. Simvastatin 20 mg PO QPM 
3. Pantoprazole 40 mg PO Q24H 
4. Multivitamins 1 TAB PO DAILY 
5. sildenafil 100 mg oral DAILY:PRN 
6. Aspirin 81 mg PO DAILY 

 
Discharge Medications:
1. Pantoprazole 40 mg PO Q24H 
2. Simvastatin 20 mg PO QPM 
3. Acetaminophen 650 mg PO Q6H 
4. HYDROmorphone (Dilaudid) ___ mg PO Q4H:PRN Pain 
RX *hydromorphone 2 mg 1 tablet(s) by mouth every four (4) hours 
Disp #*25 Tablet Refills:*0
5. Tamsulosin 0.4 mg PO QHS 
RX *tamsulosin 0.4 mg 1 capsule(s) by mouth at bedtime Disp #*14 
Capsule Refills:*0
6. Aspirin 81 mg PO DAILY 
7. Celecoxib 200 mg ORAL BID:PRN pain 
8. Multivitamins 1 TAB PO DAILY 
9. Sildenafil 100 mg ORAL DAILY:PRN sexual activity 
10. Docusate Sodium 100 mg PO BID:PRN constipation 
RX *docusate sodium 100 mg 1 capsule(s) by mouth twice a day 
Disp #*28 Capsule Refills:*0
11. Phenazopyridine 100 mg PO TID dysuria Duration: 3 Days 
RX *phenazopyridine 100 mg 1 tablet(s) by mouth three times a 
day Disp #*10 Tablet Refills:*0

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Urolithiasis

 
Discharge Condition:
Stable and ready for discharge

 
Discharge Instructions:
-You can expect to see occasional blood in your urine and to 
possibly experience some urgency and frequency over the next 
month;  this may be related to the passage of stone fragments or 
the indwelling ureteral stent (if there is one).

-The kidney stone may or may not have been removed AND/or there 
may fragments/others still in the process of passing.

-You may experience some pain associated with spasm of your 
ureter.; This is normal. Take the narcotic pain medication as 
prescribed if additional pain relief is needed.

-Ureteral stents MUST be removed or exchanged and therefore it 
is IMPERATIVE that you follow-up as directed. 

-Do not lift anything heavier than a phone book (10 pounds) 

-You may continue to periodically see small amounts of blood in 
your urine--this is normal and will gradually improve

-Resume your pre-admission/home medications EXCEPT as noted. You 
should ALWAYS call to inform, review and discuss any medication 
changes and your post-operative course with your primary care 
doctor.  HOLD ASPIRIN and aspirin containing products for one 
week unless otherwise advised.

-IBUPROFEN (the ingredient of Advil, Motrin, etc.) may be taken 
even though you may also be taking Tylenol/Acetaminophen. You 
may alternate these medications for pain control. For pain 
control, try TYLENOL FIRST, then ibuprofen, and then take the 
narcotic pain medication as prescribed if additional pain relief 
is needed.

-Ibuprofen should always be taken with food. Please discontinue 
taking and notify your doctor should you develop blood in your 
stool (dark, tarry stools)

-You MAY be discharged home with a medication called PYRIDIUM 
that will help with the "burning" pain you may experience when 
voiding. This medication may turn your urine bright orange.

-Colace has been prescribed to avoid post surgical constipation 
and constipation related to narcotic pain medication. 
Discontinue if loose stool or diarrhea develops. Colace is a 
stool softener, NOT a laxative, and available over the counter. 
The generic name is DOCUSATE SODIUM. It is recommended that you 
use this medication.

-Do not eat constipating foods for ___ weeks, drink plenty of 
fluids to keep hydrated

-No vigorous physical activity or sports for 4 weeks and while 
Foley catheter is in place.

IF YOU ARE DISCHARGED HOME WITH A FOLEY CATHETER:
-Please refer to the provided nursing instructions and handout 
on Foley catheter care, waste elimination and leg bag usage.

-Your Foley should be secured to the catheter secure on your 
thigh at ALL times until your follow up with the surgeon.

-Follow up in 1 week for Foley removal. DO NOT have anyone else 
other than your Surgeon remove your Foley for any reason.

-Wear Large Foley bag for majority of time, leg bag is only for 
short-term when leaving house.

FOLLOW-UP INSTRUCTIONS:
___

stool (dark, tarry stools)
-You MAY be discharged home with a medication called PYRIDIUM
that will help with the "burning" pain you may experience when
voiding. This medication may turn your urine bright orange.
-Colace has been prescribed to avoid post surgical constipation
and constipation related to narcotic pain medication.
Discontinue if loose stool or diarrhea develops. Colace is a
stool softener, NOT a laxative, and available over the counter.
The generic name is DOCUSATE SODIUM. It is recommended that you
use this medication.
-Do not eat constipating foods for ___ weeks, drink plenty of
fluids to keep hydrated
-No vigorous physical activity or sports for 4 weeks and while
Foley catheter is in place.
IF YOU ARE DISCHARGED HOME WITH A FOLEY CATHETER:
-Please refer to the provided nursing instructions and handout
on Foley catheter care, waste elimination and leg bag usage.
-Your Foley should be secured to the catheter secure on your
thigh at ALL times until your follow up with the surgeon.
-Follow up in 1 week for Foley removal. DO NOT have anyone else
other than your Surgeon remove your Foley for any reason.
-Wear Large Foley bag for majority of time, leg bag is only for
short-term when leaving house.
FOLLOW-UP INSTRUCTIONS:
___

dinner.  He had crampy epigastric and RUQ pain which awoke him 
at
3 AM last night and gradually worsened to ___ RUQ pain.  He
reports associated nausea without emesis.  He also has had
associated gastric reflux.  He denies fevers, chills, diarrhea,
or constipation.  Of note, he had similar symptoms in ___ of 
this
year and was seen at an OSH in ___.  A RUQ U/S peroformed
demonstrated gall stones.  He was offered surgery at that time,
but his pain resolved and he declined the surgery as he was

 
Past Medical History:
PMH: symptomatic cholelithiasis, HTN, HLD

PSH: open appendectomy

 
Social History:
___
Family History:
Brother with DM-2. Both parents alive in their ___, his
father has HTN.  His children are healthy.

 
Physical Exam:
VS: 96.2 84 138/77 20 99% 
Gen: NAD, AOx3
Neck: supple, trachea midline, no LAD
HEENT: MMM, Anicteric, EOM-I
___: reg
Pulm: no resp distress
Abd: S/ND/TTP RUQ, -___, no rebound or guarding
___: no LLE

 
Pertinent Results:
___ 06:05AM   WBC-4.6 RBC-4.47* HGB-14.2 HCT-40.0 MCV-90 
MCH-31.7 MCHC-35.4* RDW-13.1
___ 06:05AM   NEUTS-53.7 ___ MONOS-7.5 EOS-1.5 
BASOS-1.6
___ 06:05AM   PLT COUNT-243
___ 06:05AM   ALT(SGPT)-32 AST(SGOT)-27 ALK PHOS-59 TOT 
BILI-0.4
___ 06:05AM   LIPASE-70*

___ Liver US :
1. Distended gallbladder wall, containing multiple mobile 
stones, with a 
large CBD. There is no wall thickening, pericholecystic fluid, 
and no 
sonographic ___ sign is elicited. A distal obstructing 
stone within the CBD is a possibility. The findings are less 
compatible with cholecystitis, but a HIDA scan can be performed 
to assess for emptying. 
2. Echogenic and coarsened liver, most compatible with fatty 
infiltration. A more advanced process such as fibrosis/cirrhosis 
cannot be excluded with this technique. 

 
Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. ___ was evaluated by the Acute Care service in the 
Emergency Room and based on his past history and recurrent pain 
he was taken to the Operating Room on ___ and underwent a 
laparoscopic cholecystectomy.  He tolerated the procedure well 
and returned to the PACU in stable condition.  He maintained 
stable hemodynamics and his pain was well controlled.

Following transfer to the Surgical floor he continued to make 
good progress.  He was started on a liquid diet which was 
gradually advanced to regular and he tolerated it well. He was 
up and walking independently and had adequate pain relief.  His 
port sites were dry
After an uncomplicated recovery he was discharged to home on 
___ and will follow up in the ___ in ___ weeks.
 
Medications on Admission:
Simvastatin 20', Sertraline 50', Amlodipine 5'
   

 
Discharge Medications:
1. oxycodone 5 mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO Q4H (every 4 hours) 
as needed for pain.
Disp:*40 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
2. simvastatin 10 mg Tablet Sig: Two (2) Tablet PO DAILY 
(Daily).  
3. sertraline 50 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily). 
 
4. acetaminophen 325 mg Tablet Sig: Two (2) Tablet PO Q6H (every 
6 hours) as needed for pain or fever.  
5. omeprazole 20 mg Capsule, Delayed Release(E.C.) Sig: One (1) 
Capsule, Delayed Release(E.C.) PO DAILY (Daily).  
6. amlodipine 5 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO once a day.  

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Acute cholecystitis

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
You are being discharged on medications to treat the pain from 
your operation. These medications will make you drowsy and 
impair your ability to drive a motor vehicle or operate 
machinery safely. You MUST  refrain from such activities while 
taking these medications.

 

 

Please call your doctor or return to the emergency room if you 
have any of the following:
 

 * You experience new chest pain, pressure, squeezing or 
 tightness.
 
* New or worsening cough or wheezing.
 
* If you are vomiting and cannot keep in fluids or your 
 medications.
 
* You are getting dehydrated due to continued vomiting, 
 diarrhea or other reasons. Signs of dehydration include dry 
 mouth, rapid heartbeat or feeling dizzy or faint when standing.
 
* You see blood or dark/black material when you vomit or have a 
 bowel movement.
 

* You have shaking chills, or a fever greater than 101.5 (F) 
 degrees or 38(C) degrees.
 
* Any serious change in your symptoms, or any new symptoms that 
 concern you. 
 
* Please resume all regular home medications and take any new 
meds 
 as ordered.  

Activity:
No heavy lifting of items ___ pounds for 6 weeks. You may 
resume moderate
exercise at your discretion, no abdominal exercises.

Wound Care:
You may remove the dressings tomorrow.

You may shower, no tub baths or swimming. 

If there is clear drainage from your incisions, cover with 
clean, dry gauze. 
Your steri-strips will fall off on their own. Please remove any 
remaining strips ___ days after surgery.
Please call the doctor if you have increased pain, swelling, 
redness, or drainage from the incision sites.

 
Followup Instructions:
___

text:
Name:  ___          ___ No:  ___

Admission Date: ___        Discharge Date: ___

Date of Birth:  ___        Sex:  F

Service:  ORT


REASON FOR ADMISSION:  Right foot ankle instability.

POSTOPERATIVE DISCHARGE:  Right foot ankle instability.

OPERATION PERFORMED:  ___, was a right foot
___ repair with arthroscopy of the right ankle.

BRIEF HOSPITAL COURSE:  ___ is a pleasant female
who had the abovementioned procedure for instability of her
ankle.  The patient had the operation on ___ and was
discharged on ___.  The patient did well while in the
hospital.  She had a splint which was modified because she
said it was a little uncomfortable.  By the time it was
modified and she left, she said that the ankle was
comfortable.  Her pain was controlled with oral pain
medications and she was restarted on all of her home
medications.  The patient will be discharged to a rehab
facility where she will receive physical therapy.

She will remain in her splint until followup in two weeks.
The patient can remain partial weightbearing on the right leg
with crutches in her splint with a cast boot.

The patient will followup two weeks out from her operation at
which time the splint will be removed. She will be placed
back in a cast after the sutures have been removed.  The
patient will be in a cast two weeks after which point she
will return to our clinic and then she will be placed in a
walking boot.  There were no complications while in the
hospital and is routine discharge.

on ___.  His staples will be removed in the office in 2 
weeks.

After an uncomplicated recovery he was discharged to home on 
___.
 
Medications on Admission:
none
 
Discharge Medications:
1. hydromorphone 2 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO every ___ 
hours as needed for pain.
Disp:*20 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
2. Colace 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO twice a day.  
3. Tylenol ___ mg Tablet Sig: Two (2) Tablet PO every six (6) 
hours as needed for pain.  
4. Milk of Magnesia 400 mg/5 mL Suspension Sig: Thirty (30) ml 
PO at bedtime as needed for constipation.  

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Acute cholecystitis

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Please call your doctor or nurse practitioner or return to the 
Emergency Department for any of the following:

*You experience new chest pain, pressure, squeezing or 
tightness.

*New or worsening cough, shortness of breath, or wheeze.

*If you are vomiting and cannot keep down fluids or your 
medications.

*You are getting dehydrated due to continued vomiting, diarrhea, 
or other reasons. Signs of dehydration include dry mouth, rapid 
heartbeat, or feeling dizzy or faint when standing.

*You see blood or dark/black material when you vomit or have a 
bowel movement.

*You experience burning when you urinate, have blood in your 
urine, or experience a discharge.

*Your pain in not improving within ___ hours or is not gone 
within 24 hours. Call or return immediately if your pain is 
getting worse or changes location or moving to your chest or 
back.

*You have shaking chills, or fever greater than 101.5 degrees 
Fahrenheit or 38 degrees Celsius.

*Any change in your symptoms, or any new symptoms that concern 
you.

Please resume all regular home medications , unless specifically 
advised not to take a particular medication. Also, please take 
any new medications as prescribed.

Please get plenty of rest, continue to ambulate several times 
per day, and drink adequate amounts of fluids. Avoid lifting 
weights greater than ___ lbs until you follow-up with your 
surgeon.

Avoid driving or operating heavy machinery while taking pain 
medications.

Incision Care:

*Please call your doctor or nurse practitioner if you have 
increased pain, swelling, redness, or drainage from the incision 
site.

*Avoid swimming and baths until your follow-up appointment.

*You may shower, and wash surgical incisions with a mild soap 
and warm water. Gently pat the area dry.

*Your staples will be removed at your follow-up appointment.

 
Followup Instructions:
___

There are comminuted fractures of the left clavicle and scapula. 
The multiple posterior and lateral rib fractures involving the 
third through eighth ribs are not well seen. Patchy opacities at 
the left lung base, and apex are consistent with aspiration or 
contusion as seen on CT. The right lung is relatively clear. 
There is a small amount of left pleural fluid seen at the left 
lung apex. No pneumothorax. 

___ CHEST (PA & LAT)
Interval development of left lower lobe collapse. No evidence of 

pneumothorax.

POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS:  Lower lobe atelectasis.  Rule out a
post obstructive pneumonia.

Allowing for positional differences, no substantial change.

___ : Pt was admitted to the trauma surgery service s/p MCC.  
Pt was kept NPO, IVF.  Aggressive pain control. Pt's coumadin 
was held.  Ortho consult for scapula---> Sling to Left Arm,NTD.  
C spine was cleared both radiographically and clinically.  

___:  chest x ray--> new LLL collapse a repeat CXR again 
confirmed this .  Pt was sent to Interventional pulmonology for 
flexible Bronchoscopy.  ___ was started on augmentin.  
INr was found to be supratherapuetic at 7.5.  Pt was put on fall 
precautions.

___: Aggressive pulmonary toilet. 

___: Pt was discharged home F/u INR was 4.5. Pt was given 
strict instructions to go to ___ clinic in a.m. for follow 
up of INR and to avoid any activities that might involve risk of 
bleeding.

Coumadin 
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Docusate Sodium 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO BID (2 
times a day).  
2. Magnesium Hydroxide 400 mg/5 mL Suspension Sig: Thirty (30) 
ML PO Q6H (every 6 hours) as needed for constipation.  
3. Bisacodyl 5 mg Tablet, Delayed Release (E.C.) Sig: Two (2) 
Tablet, Delayed Release (E.C.) PO DAILY (Daily) as needed for 
constipation.  
4. Augmentin 875-125 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO three 
times a day for 10 days.
Disp:*30 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
5. Oxycodone-Acetaminophen ___ mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet 
PO Q4-6H () as needed for pain: do not exceed 8 tablets in 24 
hours.  do not take tylenol while on this medication.
Disp:*50 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
6. Coumadin 1 mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablet PO once a day for 2 
days: please take 0.5 mg of coumadin until repeat INR.  Then 
Take as directed by your primary provider.
Disp:*5 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
s/p Motorcycle crash
Left hemopneumothorax
Left lower lobe pneumonia
Left rib fracture
Left clavicle fracture
Left comminuted scapula fracture

 
Discharge Condition:
Hemodynamically stable, tolerating a regular diet, pain 
adequately controlled.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Return to the Emergency room room if you develop any fevers, 
chills, headache, dizzines, chest pain, productive cough, 
shortness of breath, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea and/or any other 
symptoms that are concerning to you.

You must follow up your INR ___.  Take 0.5 mg of 
coumadin until that time then as directed by your primary 
provider.

Avoid sport, or any high risk behavior given you elevated INR 
and your current  bleeding risk.

Continue to wear the sling for comfort.

DO NOT bear any weight on your left arm.

Continue with Augmentin until the course is completed.

HOSPITAL COURSE AND ILLNESS:  This lady underwent a
ligamentous reconstruction of her left ankle on ___.
She was immobilized postoperatively in a splint, and was on
bed rest and crutches.  She was admitted to the hospital for
patient management and pain management.

Her hospital course was uneventful.  She underwent
progressive improvement in her pain levels.  She was seen by
the rehabilitation service and was taught 3 point partial
weightbearing, crutch gait, and transfers.

Her condition improved to the point where she was judged to
be ambulatory and able to care for herself.  She lives in a
group home.  Her condition at discharge was improved.

DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS:  Her discharge instructions were to
be on a 3-point partial weightbearing crutch gait, and to
return to see Dr. ___ in his office in 10 days.

FINAL DIAGNOSIS:  Chronic lateral ligamentous instability of
the left ankle.



                        ___, MD

Name:  ___                    Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: NEUROSURGERY
 
Allergies: 
Pollen Extracts
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
Cerebellar Brain Mass/Vertigo
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
___: Suboccipital craniotomy for mass resection

 
History of Present Illness:
___ female who was recently seen in outpatient clinic, 
having been referred for a newly diagnosed intracranial lesion. 
The patient was
worked up at an outside facility and presented with films 
indicating an approximately 2 x 2.5 cm contrast enhancing 
lesion, most consistent with a tentorial notch meningioma. Since 
the patient is significantly symptomatic from this lesion, the 
patient is also in need of a histopathological diagnosis to 
further decide on treatment and management
 
Past Medical History:
s/p hysterectomy
Cerebal Palsy
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
Non-contributory
 
Physical Exam:
On Admission:
Patient is alert, oriented to person; place; date. Mildly 
depressed affect, but pleasant. Full motor strength throughout 
upper and lower extremities. 

On Discharge:

Afebrile. Alert and oriented x3. Following all commands. PERRLA 
3.0mm to 2.5mm. speech is clear. CN II-XII intact. EOM's full 
with conjugate gaze. No diplopia or nystagmus. No pronator 
drift. Surgical suture line is clean, dry and intact. There is 
no edema, erythema or eccymosis. There is no drainage present. 
The patient has been out of bed and ambulating. She has been 
cleared by ___ for d/c to home. 

 
Pertinent Results:
Labs on Admission;
___ 08:31PM BLOOD WBC-14.5*# RBC-4.42 Hgb-12.5 Hct-35.5* 
MCV-80* MCH-28.3 MCHC-35.2* RDW-14.0 Plt ___
___ 08:31PM BLOOD ___ PTT-19.7* ___
___ 08:31PM BLOOD Glucose-209* UreaN-12 Creat-1.0 Na-143 
K-3.6 Cl-107 HCO3-16* AnGap-24*
___ 08:31PM BLOOD Calcium-9.1 Phos-4.1 Mg-1.7

Imaging:
MRI Head w/Contrast ___: FINDINGS: Patient is status post left 
suboccipital craniotomy, with expected 
post-operative changes. There are a few, approximately 4- mm 
sized punctate foci of T1- hyperintensity (4:12, 4:11, 4:10) in 
the surgical resection bed, which have corresponding 
susceptibility artifact on gradient- recalled echo sequence, and 
likely represent small residual foci of post- operative 
hemorrhage. On T1W post- gadolinium sequences, there is more 
planar or sheet like enhancement along the ___ aspect of 
the tentorium which likely relates to operative manipulation. On 
T1W MP-RAGE and SE post- gadolinium sequences, there are several 
small enhancing vessels seen along the posterior aspect of the 
surgical resection bed, seen on the pre-operative study, which 
likely represent normal vessels at the margin of the surgical 
resection bed. Allowing for the above, no definitive evidence 
for residual tumor is seen. The ventricles and sulci are normal 
in size and in contour. There is no shift of normally-midline 
structures. No new enhancing mass is identified. No foci 
concerning for infarction seen on diffusion- weighted imaging. 

___ 05:45AM BLOOD WBC-11.2* RBC-4.52 Hgb-12.8 Hct-35.7* 
MCV-79* MCH-28.3 MCHC-35.9* RDW-13.7 Plt ___
___ 05:45AM BLOOD Plt ___
___ 05:45AM BLOOD Plt ___
 
Brief Hospital Course:
Patient was electively admitted on ___ for suboccipital 
craniotomy for cerebellar mass resection. Intraoperatively, she 
diureised nearly seven liters of urine, which was treated with 
albumin and crystalloid IV fluids. Due to the excessive urine 
output, and elecated lactate in this setting, she was kept 
intubated overnight in the ICU for concerns of potential airway 
compromise. 

On POD#1, DVT prophylaxsis was started, and MRI of the head was 
performed to evaluate for residual tumor burden.  Post operative 
MR imaging was obtained routinely. She has been followed by 
Neuro-oncology, social service, ___ and OT while inpt. She has 
progressed as expected in the immediate post op course with no 
perioperative complications. She is tolerating all p.o. food and 
fluid well. She will follow up as outlined in the Neurosurgery 
and Brain tumor clinics.

Antivert

Discharge Condition:
Neurologically Stable

 
Discharge Instructions:
General Instructions/Information

Have a friend/family member check your incision daily for 
signs of infection.
Take your pain medicine as prescribed.
Exercise should be limited to walking; no lifting, straining, 
or excessive bending.
You may wash your hair only after sutures have been removed. 
You may shower before this time using a shower cap to cover 
your head.
Increase your intake of fluids and fiber, as narcotic pain 
medicine can cause constipation. We generally recommend taking 
an over the counter stool softener, such as Docusate (Colace) 
while taking narcotic pain medication.
Unless directed by your doctor, do not take any 
anti-inflammatory medicines such as Motrin, Aspirin, Advil, and 
Ibuprofen etc.  
You are being sent home on steroid medication, make sure you 
are taking a medication to protect your stomach (Prilosec, 
Protonix, or Pepcid), as these medications can cause stomach 
irritation.  Make sure to take your steroid medication with 
meals, or a glass of milk. 
Clearance to drive and return to work will be addressed at 
your post-operative office visit.
Make sure to continue to use your incentive spirometer while 
at home.
CALL YOUR SURGEON IMMEDIATELY IF YOU EXPERIENCE ANY OF THE 
FOLLOWING

New onset of tremors or seizures.
Any confusion or change in mental status. 
Any numbness, tingling, weakness in your extremities.
Pain or headache that is continually increasing, or not 
relieved by pain medication.
Any signs of infection at the wound site: increasing redness, 
increased swelling, increased tenderness, or drainage.
Fever greater than or equal to 101° F.

 
Followup Instructions:
___

count (15.5), and urinalysis suspicious for infection. She was 
treated with IV Ceftriaxone until she was afebrile for over 24 
hours. Urine culture grew pansensitive Proteus. She was 
transitioned to po antibiotics (Keflex) and will complete a 14 
day course. She will then continue Keflex for suppression for 
the remainder of the pregnancy.

MFM was consulted and an ultrasound was performed. Ultrasound 
revealed a breech fetus, BPP ___, normal AFI, and EFW 
2148g(63%). Additionally, an intra-abdominal umbilical cord 
varix measuring 1.5 x 1.5cm. She was counseled regarding the 
potential risks involved with this finding and recommendations 
included twice weekly testing with assessment of the varix, 
growth scans, and delivery no later than 39 weeks.
.
Ms ___ was discharged home in stable condition and will have 
close outpatient followup.

possibilities include an abscess and a superinfected branchial 
cleft cyst. 2. Extension of hypodense material from the 
collection to the retropharyngeal and prevertebral spaces at 
C3-C6, concerning for phlegmon or early abscess formation. C5-6 
endplate irregularities are most likely degenerative, but 
infection cannot be excluded. Cervical spine MRI is suggested 
for further evaluation. 

MRI Spine ___: Extensive soft tissue edema and residual right 
parapharyngeal fluid collection as described above. Extremely 
limited study due to motion and lack of IV contrast. Please 
refer to concurrent CT neck for details.  

CT Neck ___: 1. Interval drainage of a large rim-enhancing 
right neck fluid collection with multiple small residual 
collections in the operative bed, colectively measuring upto 3.6 
cm. 

 
Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. ___ was transferred from an OSH for a large right neck 
abscess and odynophagia. The patient was taken to the OR for 
operative drainage. Please see dedicated operative report for 
full details. The patient was kept intubated and taken to the 
ICU for overnight observation. On POD 1, the patient was 
extubated and his diet was advanced. He stayed one more day in 
the ICU while awaiting a bed and was then transferred to the 
floor. He had been started on vanc/unasyn in the ED here at 
___ and cultures were obtained, which grew out beta lactamase 
negative Haemophilus influenzae. Due to continuing concern about 
his neck, an MRI was attempted on ___, but the patient could 
not tolerate the procedure. A follow up CT was then obtained and 
further drainage was deemed unnecessary based on those results. 
An ID consult was obtained and the antibiotics were changed to 
cefepime and flagyl. They also suggested an HIV test, which was 
negative. The patient responded well on this regimen. During his 
hospital stay, he had good pain control on oral meds, had normal 
hemodynamics and oxygen saturations, was ambulatory, and 
tolerated an oral diet. On ___, the patient expressed 
a desire to go home. ID recommendations included a week of IV 
antibiotics. Thus, the patient decided to sign himself out of 
the hospital against medical advice. He will be completing a 
course of oral antibiotics, will have ___ services for dressing 
changes, and will follow up with Dr. ___. The patient was 
counseled as to the risks of his going home, and he decided to 
leave against medical advice to go home. 
 
Medications on Admission:
Methadone 100mg QD, oxycodone 15mg q6 prn pain  

 
Discharge Medications:
1. Methadone 40 mg Tablet, Soluble Sig: 2.5 Tablet, Solubles PO 
DAILY (Daily) as needed for home maintenence dose.  
2. Nicotine 14 mg/24 hr Patch 24 hr Sig: One (1) Patch 24 hr 
Transdermal DAILY (Daily).
Disp:*30 Patch 24 hr(s)* Refills:*2*
3. Oxycodone 5 mg/5 mL Solution Sig: Five (5) mL PO Q6H (every 6 
hours) as needed for pain.
Disp:*300 mL* Refills:*0*
4. Augmentin 875-125 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO twice a 
day for 21 days.
Disp:*42 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home With Service
 
Facility:
___
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
right neck abscess
 
Discharge Condition:
Stable

 
Discharge Instructions:
___ will come to change your packing and dressing once a day.  
Call your doctor's office or go to the ED if you start to have 
fevers/chills, increasing difficulty breathing, new redness or 
swelling at the surgical site, or if you have any other 
concerns.  
 
Followup Instructions:
___

Brief Hospital Course:
Mrs. ___ is a ___, gravida 1, para zero, at 40 weeks 
and 2 days gestation.  She presented to Labor and Delivery for 
induction of labor in the setting of several mildly elevated 
blood pressures.  She progressed to 7
cm of cervical dilation, but had a slow, protracted course and 
failed to make further progress.  Arrest of dilation was 
diagnosed and the decision was made to proceed with cesarean 
section.  All consents were signed. Procedure was complicated by 
intraoperative hemorrhage secondary to uterine atony. For full 
detail see operative note. Patient was trasfused 1 unit PRBC. At 
the end of the procedure patient was hemodynamically stable with 
good urine output. 

Post operatively, patient recovered well and was discharged in 
stable condition on POD 4.

Levothyroxine Sodium 50 mcg PO 5X/WEEK (___)

identified on his scans was consistent with a basaloid lesion
of probable salivary gland origin. Now presenting for 
parotidectomy and neck dissection
 
Past Medical History:
1.  Squamous cell carcinoma as noted above.

3.  Lumbar spinal stenosis, for which the patient has had

release surgery.

5.  Hypercholesterolemia.
6.  Hypertension.

NC

Patient admitted on ___ and underwent parotidectomy and 
bilateral neck dissection under Dr. ___. He tolerated 
the procedure, please see op report. He was extubated in OR then 
transferred to PACU in stable condition.  He was then 
transferred to the floor for remainder of hospital course.  Pain 
was adequately controlled with medication. He tolerated room air 
without desats on ambulation. Tolerating PO with bowel 
movements. Wound site was healing and stable; drains were 
removed upon meeting the criteria.  Pt had stable vital signs, 
afebrile, tolerating PO, and ambulating at the time of 
discharge. He will follow up with Dr. ___ in ___ 
days.

Disp:*30 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
3. Metoprolol Tartrate 25 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO BID 
(2 times a day).

(Daily).

(1) Cap PO DAILY (Daily).

times a day).
Disp:*60 Capsule(s)* Refills:*2*
7. Senna 8.6 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO BID (2 times a 
day).
Disp:*60 Tablet(s)* Refills:*2*

Home

Parotid mass

Stable
