text:
Name:  ___                  Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: NEUROSURGERY
 
Allergies: 
Patient recorded as having No Known Allergies to Drugs
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
pain with walking
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
Lumbar laminectomy
 
History of Present Illness:
___ gentleman who has had difficulty walking and pain in 
his hamstrings that dates back about ___ years and has been 
getting progressively worse.  He is unable to walk more than a 
few blocks.  He describes pain that shoots and stabs into his 
hamstrings that is limiting his further activity.  Symptoms are
exacerbated by standing and somewhat better with sitting.  He 
denies difficulty with bowel or bladder function.  He has tried 
conservative therapy including physical therapy, with no help.
 
Past Medical History:
1.  Squamous cell carcinoma as noted above.
2.  History of skin basal cell and squamous cell carcinomas.
3.  Lumbar spinal stenosis, for which the patient has had
continued pseudoclaudication symptoms and had elected for a
release surgery.
4.  Mitral regurgitation.
5.  Hypercholesterolemia.
6.  Hypertension.

 
Social History:
___
Family History:
NC
 
Physical Exam:
On examination, his motor strength is ___ in hip flexion,
extension, quadriceps, hamstrings, dorsiflexion, and plantar
flexion bilaterally.  His sensory examination is intact with
respect to the modality of light touch.  His reflexes were
hypoactive, but symmetric.  The straight leg raise was negative
bilaterally as was the ___ maneuver.  His back was flat 
and
nontender.  His distal pulses were palpable bilaterally.
 
Pertinent Results:
Flexion and extension x-rays obtained in the ___ today
demonstrate normal alignment.  There is no abnormal movement 
when
flexion and extension views are compared.  An MRI of the
lumbosacral spine obtained on ___ demonstrates again
normal alignment.  There is mild-to-moderate stenosis at L2-L3. 
At L3-L4 and at L4-L5, there is significant stenosis.  At L3-L4,
there is foraminal stenosis on the right side.

 
Brief Hospital Course:
Pt was admitted electively to hospital, went to OR where under 
general anesthesia underwent lumbar decompression.  he tolerated 
the procedure well, was extubated, transferred to PACU and then 
floor. Diet and actvity were advanced.  Pain medication was 
transitioned to PO.  He was ambulating in halls.  Incision was 
clean dry and intact. he had left shoulder pain on first post op 
morning - he had EKG within nl limits and no chest pain.  He had 
history of old trauma and was likely agravated with OR 
positioning.  Xray was done which showed degenerative changes 
but no fracture or dislocation and patient was instructed to 
follow up with orthopedist locally. His foley was removed on 
POD#1 but he was unable to void.  He was given a re-trial of 
void and had persistent post void residuals on bladder scan.  A 
foley was re-placed and he was discharged to home with a leg 
bag.  He will follow up with urology in two weeks. 
 
Medications on Admission:
asa 
mvi
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Docusate Sodium 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO BID (2 
times a day): take while on pain med.
Disp:*60 Capsule(s)* Refills:*0*
2. Aspirin 81 mg Tablet, Chewable Sig: One (1) Tablet, Chewable 
PO DAILY (Daily).  
3. Multivitamin     Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily). 
 
4. Oxycodone 5 mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO Q3H (every 3 hours) 
as needed for pain.
Disp:*60 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Lumbar stenosis
left shoulder pain
urinary retention

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
 
Discharge Instructions:
        Do not smoke
        Keep wound clean / No tub baths or pools until seen in 
follow up/ remove dressing ___/ begin daily showers ___
        You have steri-strips in place  keep dry x 72 hours.  
Do not pull them off. They will fall off on their own or be 
taken off in the office
        No pulling up, lifting> 10 lbs., excessive bending or 
twisting for two weeks.
        Limit your use of stairs to ___ times per day
        Have a family member check your incision daily for 
signs of infection
        Take pain medication as instructed; you may find it 
best if taken in the a.m. when you wake if you experience muscle 
stiffness and before bed for sleeping discomfort
        Increase your intake of fluids and fiber as pain 
medicine (narcotics) can cause constipation
 
Followup Instructions:
___

text:
Name:  ___                       Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: NEUROSURGERY
 
Allergies: 
No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
Pituitary tumor
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
___ - Endoscopic transhenoidal hypophysectomy

 
History of Present Illness:
___ is a ___ year old male with history of cerebral palsy 
with cognitive impairment, and epilepsy who was found to have an 
incidental 2.4cm pituitary tumor after a trauma. He presents for 
elective surgical intervention.

 
Past Medical History:
Hypertension, cerebral palsy, epilepsy
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
Non-contributory
 
Physical Exam:
Upon Discharge:
===============
General:
VS: ___ ___ Temp: 98.8 PO BP: 128/83 HR: 80 RR: 20 O2 sat:
97% O2 delivery: RA 

Bowel Regimen: [x]Yes [ ]No

Exam: Cognitive delay 
Opens eyes: [x]spontaneous [ ]to voice [ ]to noxious
Orientation: [x]Person [x]Place [ ]Time
Follows commands: [ ]Simple [x]Complex [ ]None

Pupils:  Anisocoria L>R, reactive to light
EOM: [x]Full [ ]Restricted

Face Symmetric: [x]Yes [ ]No
Tongue Midline: [x]Yes [ ]No

Speech Fluent: [ ]Yes [x]No - Slight dysarthria (baseline)
Comprehension intact [x]Yes [ ]No

Motor:
Right upper extremity contracted at baseline and ___ strength.
Left upper extremity contracted at baseline and ___ strength.
Right lower extremity contracted and lifts antigravity. Left
lower extremity contracted with minimal spontaneous movement,
wiggles toes to command.

[x]Sensation intact to light touch

Wound: 
[x]Nasal packing has been removed, no drainage noted. Sanguinous
material crusted around nares.
 
Pertinent Results:
Please see OMR for relevant findings
 
Brief Hospital Course:
___ is a ___ year old male with a pituitary tumor who 
presents for elective surgical intervention.

#Pituitary tumor
On ___, an attempt was made to resect the tumor. However, the 
case was aborted after encountering a sinus infection.  

#Sinus infection
His sinuses were debrided. Right nasal packing was left in 
place. For further procedure details, please see separately 
dictated operative report by Dr. ___. He was extubated in the 
operating room and transported to the PACU for recovery. He was 
started on Clindamycin. Once stable, he was transferred to the 
floor. ENT removed the nasal packing on POD#1 without incident.

#Dispo
He was discharged home at his baseline level of function, with 
plan to follow up with Dr. ___, and a rebooking of 
the pituitary adenoma resection to be determined.
 
Medications on Admission:
Amlodipine 5mg Daily, Peridex mouthwash QAM, Oxcarbazepine 600mg 
BID, Phenobarbital 20mg/5mL BID, Tums, Vitamin D3, MVI
 
Discharge Medications:
1.  Clindamycin 300 mg PO/NG Q8H 
RX *clindamycin HCl 300 mg 1 capsule(s) by mouth every eight (8) 
hours Disp #*30 Capsule Refills:*0 
2.  Acetaminophen 325-650 mg PO Q6H:PRN Pain - Mild  
3.  amLODIPine 5 mg PO DAILY  
4.  Calcium Carbonate 500 mg PO BID  
5.  Multivitamins 1 TAB PO DAILY  
6.  OXcarbazepine 600 mg PO BID  
7.  PHENObarbital 60 mg PO BID  

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Severe sinus infection
Pituitary tumor

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Confused - always.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Out of Bed with assistance to chair or 
wheelchair.

 
Discharge Instructions:
* You were scheduled to have a resection of your sellar mass.
* This procedure had to be aborted because of a sinus infection.
* The ENT surgeon debrided your sinuses.
* You have been discharged on Clindamycin, an antibiotic to 
treat the sinus infection.
* Please take the antibiotic as directed.

 
Followup Instructions:
___

text:
Name:  ___               Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: OBSTETRICS/GYNECOLOGY
 
Allergies: 
Aspirin
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
abdominal pain
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
Laparoscopic cholecystectomy
 
History of Present Illness:
Pt is a ___ G2P1 20w3d EDC ___ referred from Dr. ___ at 
___ for evaluation by general surgery (Dr ___ for 
complaint of abdominal pain. Pt reports intermittent epigastric 
and right upper quadrant pain after meals of 3 months duration. 
Pt reports that she has pain even when taking water. She denies 
nausea, vomiting or diarrhea. No recent illness. No decreased 
appetite. She is hungry and would like to eat, despite her 
episodes of pain. She is without pain presently and has last 
eaten at 1100. She has not had pain since this am.

She has no melena or dark stools. BMs have been normal. She has 
felt fetal mvmt. She denies VB, LOF, and dysuria. She denies 
pruritis.

She had a RUQ US ___ at OSH that was significant for GB 
distension without CBD distention and without stones. Sludge was 
noted. She was evaluated by the surgery consult service and an 
abd US was repeated today. Preliminary verbal report was 
negative for stones, ductal dilatation and appendicitis. Her 
laboratory profile is normal.
 
Past Medical History:
PRENATAL COURSE
Primary OB = ___ ___
___: ___ by ___ u/s (11w5d)
PNL: O+/Ab-, CF neg, RPRNR, RI, HepB neg, HIV neg

PAST OBSTETRIC HISTORY
 year   GA   MOD  wt   M/F Comments:
 ___   SVD  9#6  F   ___

PAST GYNECOLOGIC HISTORY
denies

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY
none

PAST SURGICAL HISTORY
none
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
non-contributory
 
Physical Exam:
AVSS
GENERAL: NAD
HEENT: right pterygium with minimal corneal invasion
ABDOMEN: Gravid, mild epigastric tenderness,
         mild RUQ tenderness, negative ___ sign
FOBT negative
FHR: 130
SVE: deferred
 
Pertinent Results:
___ WBC-10.9 RBC-3.82 Hgb-12.2 Hct-34.6 MCV-91 Plt-207
___ Neuts-67.9 ___ Monos-4.5 Eos-4.1 Baso-0.3
___ WBC-9.4 RBC-3.21 Hgb-10.5 Hct-29.4 MCV-92 Plt-184
___ Glu-70 BUN-6 Cre-0.5 Na-137 K-3.6 Cl-104 HCO3-21
___ ALT-13 AST-15 Amylase-47 TotBili-0.2
___ ALT-10 AST-14 TotBili-0.2
___ Lipase-18
___ Calcium-9.6 Phos-4.0 Mg-1.7

___ URINE Blood-NEG Nitrite-NEG Protein-NEG Glucose-NEG 
Ketone-40 Bilirub-NEG Urobiln-NEG pH-5.5 Leuks-NEG

___ URINE CULTURE neg

___ RUQ ULTRASOUND
1. Small amount of sludge in the gallbladder, with no
  evidence of cholecystitis. No gall stones. 
2. Somewhat full right collecting system without overt
   hydronephrosis.
 
Brief Hospital Course:
___ G2P1 admitted at 20w3d with right upper quadrant pain, 
presumed chronic cholecystitis.
.
Ms ___ was afebrile and appeared well on arrival to labor 
and delivery. Her abdominal exam was consistent with chronic 
cholecystitis. Labs were normal and repeat right upper quadrant 
ultrasound confirmed sludge in the gallbladder with no stones or 
evidence of acute cholecystitis. She had no uterine tenderness. 
Due to her previable gestational age, she had daily fetal heart 
checks only. Surgery was consulted and initially recommended 
conservative management, including starting her on IV protonix. 
She was tolerating a regular diet with no nausea or vomiting, 
however, her right upper quadrant pain and tenderness persisted. 
The risks and benefits of elective laparoscopic cholecystectomy 
at this gestational age were reviewed with Ms ___ and she 
agreed to proceed with surgery. She underwent an uncomplicated 
laparoscopic cholecystectomy on ___. The fetal heartbeat was 
checked pre and postoperatively. She denie any 
cramping/contractions and had an uneventful recovery. She was 
discharged home in stable condition on POD#1.
 
Medications on Admission:
prenatal vitamins
 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Biliary colic
 
Discharge Condition:
Good
 
Discharge Instructions:
Please call or return if you have fever >101, severe pain, 
drainage, or anything that causes you concern
Take outer dressings off tomorrow, sterie strips underneath will 
fall off on own
Low fat diet
 
Followup Instructions:
___

text:
Name:  ___                       Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: NEUROSURGERY
 
Allergies: 
No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions
 
Attending: ___
 
Chief Complaint:
Pituitary macroadenoma
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
___ Endoscopic transphenoidal resection of pituitary 
macroadenoma 

 
History of Present Illness:
___ male presented for elective surgery to resect a 
pituitary macroadenoma which is contacting the chiasm.  In ___, an EEA was attempted with Dr. ___ aborted due to a 
sinus infection. He had visual field testing prior to surgery, 
but due to his underlying cerebral palsy, his exams have been 
unreliable.  
 
Past Medical History:
Hypertension, cerebral palsy, epilepsy, cognitive impairment 
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
Non-contributory
 
Physical Exam:
ON DISCHARGE:

Opens eyes: [x]Spontaneous [ ]To voice [ ]To noxious

Orientation: [x]Person [x]Place (BI) [ ]Time

Follows commands: [x]Simple [ ]Complex [ ]None

Pupils:  Right     ___   Left    ___

EOM: [x]Full [ ]Restricted

Face Symmetric: [x]Yes [ ]No

Speech Fluent: [ ]Yes [x]No - slow, dysarthria 

Comprehension intact [x]Yes [ ]No

Motor:
RUE ___, LUE 4 /5 except bilateral depts. ___
Does not move BLE spontaneously at baseline.

 
Pertinent Results:
Please see OMR for pertinent results
 
Brief Hospital Course:
#Pituitary lesion
The patient was taken to surgery on the day of admission on 
___ for a pituitary macroadenoma resection. Surgery was 
uneventful (No CSF leak, no abdominal fat graft) and he was 
recovered in the PACU. Absorbable nasal packing was placed. He 
remained stable on POD1 and was transported to ___. Serial 
monitoring of urine output and serum sodium were stable 
throughout his hospitalization and he did not meet criteria for 
DI. His post-operative MRI pituitary protocol was done with 
postop changes and no acute complication. He was stable for 
discharge home to caregiver on POD#3. 
 
___ on Admission:
Phenobarbital 60 mg BID  
Oxcarbazepine 600 mg BID 
Nifedipine 60 mg ER Daily - d/c'd per PCP -> Amlodipine 10mg 
daily

 
Discharge Medications:
1.  Acetaminophen 325-650 mg PO Q6H:PRN fever or pain  
2.  Docusate Sodium 100 mg PO BID  
3.  Senna 17.2 mg PO QHS  
4.  amLODIPine 10 mg PO DAILY  
5.  Calcium Carbonate 500 mg PO BID:PRN reflux   
6.  OXcarbazepine 600 mg PO BID  
7.  PHENObarbital 60 mg PO BID  
8.  Vitamin D ___ UNIT PO DAILY  

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Pituitary macroadenoma

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Slow, dysarthric speech 
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Out of Bed with assistance to chair or 
wheelchair.
 (baseline)

 
Discharge Instructions:
Transphenoidal Excision of Tumor

¨ Take your pain medicine as prescribed.
¨ Exercise should be limited to walking; no lifting, straining, 
or excessive bending.
¨ Increase your intake of fluids and fiber, as narcotic pain 
medicine can cause constipation. We generally recommend taking 
an over the counter stool softener, such as Docusate (Colace) 
while taking narcotic pain medication.
¨ Unless directed by your doctor, do not take any 
anti-inflammatory medicines such as Motrin, Aspirin, Advil, and 
Ibuprofen etc. 
¨ Clearance to drive and return to work will be addressed at 
your post-operative office visit.
¨ Continue Sinus Precautions for an additional two weeks.  This 
means, no use of straws, forceful blowing of your nose, or use 
of your incentive spirometer. 
- You may use saline nasal spray starting 5 days after surgery 
(___)

CALL YOUR DOCTOR IMMEDIATELY IF YOU EXPERIENCE ANY OF THE 
FOLLOWING 
¨ New onset of tremors or seizures.
¨ Any confusion or change in mental status. 
¨ Any numbness, tingling, weakness in your extremities.
¨ Pain or headache that is continually increasing, or not 
relieved by pain medication.
¨ Any signs of infection at the wound site: redness, swelling, 
tenderness, or drainage.
¨ It is normal for feel nasal fullness for a few days after 
surgery, but if you begin to experience drainage or salty taste 
at the back of your throat, that resembles a dripping 
sensation, or persistent, clear fluid that drains from your nose 
that was not present when you were sent home, please call. 
¨  Fever greater than or equal to 101° F.
¨ If you notice your urine output to be increasing, and/or 
excessive, and you are unable to quench your thirst, please call 
your endocrinologist. 

 
Followup Instructions:
___

text:
Name:  ___                 Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: MEDICINE
 
Allergies: 
Patient recorded as having No Known Allergies to Drugs
 
Attending: ___
 
Chief Complaint:
Abdominal Pain  
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
none

 
History of Present Illness:
___ y.o. female with h/o DM2, OSA, diverticulitis s/p 
sigmoidectomy ___, p/w abdominal pain which by report started in 
RUQ 1 day prior to admission, but now is epigastric with 
radiation to back. Pain described as dull fullness. Admits to 
constipation, last BM few days ago. Denies N/V, fever, BRBPR, 
melena. Has h/o GERD, worse in last month, recently started PPI. 
No h/o gallstones, no h/o ulcers, denies heavy etoh use.  
.  
In the ED, in initial vitals were T 99.5, BP 117/65, HR 110, RR 
16, 95% RA. KUB performed and was neg for obstruction or free 
air but revealed colon FOS. Labs revealed negative LFTs, AP, but 
lipase 280 and WBC of 16. She was admitted for further w/u and 
possible pancreatitis.  

 
Past Medical History:
-- Sleep apnea  
-- GERD  
-- Diabetes  
-- History of pulmonary hypertension  
-- Exertional hypoxemia  
-- Chronic Kidney Disease (stage III) - ___ DM  
-- Diverticulits c/b abscess and enterocutaneous fistula, s/p 
sigmoid colectomy in ___  
-- s/p appy  
-- Scoliosis since age ___ 
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
Father recently passed at age ___ with pulmonary problem. Mom 
with hypertension. 
 
Physical Exam:
 T 97.5, BP 126/71, HR 96, RR 18, 96% RA  
Gen: well appearing, no apparent distress  
HEENT: MMM, EOMI  
Lung: CTA b/l. poor air mvmt  
Heart: RRR nl S1S2, no M/R/G  
Abd: +BS, obese, soft, non-distended. Mild TTP in epigastric and 
RUQ  
Ext: No edema. 2+ DP pulses b/l  
Neuro: AAO x 3  
 
Pertinent Results:
Imaging:  
___ KUB - Marked pancolonic fecal loading likely resulting 
in constipation. No signs of small-bowel obstruction or free 
air. 

___ 05:27PM   WBC-16.1* RBC-4.01* HGB-11.8* HCT-35.3* 
MCV-88 MCH-29.4 MCHC-33.5 RDW-12.4
___ 05:27PM   NEUTS-78.2* LYMPHS-15.2* MONOS-4.1 EOS-2.2 
BASOS-0.3
___ 05:27PM   PLT COUNT-337
___ 05:27PM   ALT(SGPT)-19 AST(SGOT)-16 ALK PHOS-77 TOT 
BILI-0.5
___ 05:27PM   LIPASE-280*
.
IMPRESSION:
1. Segmental adenomyomatosis of the gallbladder.
2. Simple 1.6 cm right renal cyst.

 
Brief Hospital Course:
___ yo F with sleep apnea, Pulm htn, diverticulitis, DM, CKD p/w 
abdominal pain x ___ days.  
.  
# Abdominal Pain - lipase elevated in ED, likely pancreatitis. 
No sig ETOH history. Possible etiologies include gallstones 
(although no elevation AP, ALT, AST), hypertriglyceridemia, or 
hypercalcemia. Also on differential is PUD, gastritis, 
constipation, malignancy, or biliary obstruction, although 
pancreatitis most likely.  Given IVF and NPO initially, however, 
symptoms improved quickly and patient tolerated normal diet.  
.    
# Constipation - KUB without evidence of obstruction.  Likely 
contributed to her abdominal discomfort.    
.  
# GERD - continued PPI  
# CKD - Creatinine at baseline (1.2-1.7)   
# Sleep Apnea/PAH - continued on BIPAP at home setting  
.  
# DM: continued outpt regimen.
 
Medications on Admission:
Home O2, 2L with exertion; oxygen 4L at night with BIPAP (___)  

Metformin 850mg TID  
Lantus 60 units QPM  
Lunesta 1mg QHS  
ASA 81mg Daily  
Omeprazole 20mg Daily  
Amphetamine Salt 10 mg daily  
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Triamterene-Hydrochlorothiazid 37.5-25 mg Capsule Sig: One 
(1) Cap PO DAILY (Daily).  
2. Bisacodyl 10 mg Suppository Sig: One (1) Suppository Rectal 
ONCE MR1 (Once and may repeat 1 time) for 1 doses.
Disp:*30 Suppository(s)* Refills:*0*
3. Metformin 850 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO three times a 
day.  
4. Aspirin 81 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO once a day.  
5. Omeprazole 20 mg Capsule, Delayed Release(E.C.) Sig: One (1) 
Capsule, Delayed Release(E.C.) PO once a day.  
6. Amphetamine Salt Combo 10 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO 
once a day.

text:
Name:  ___               Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: OBSTETRICS/GYNECOLOGY
 
Allergies: 
No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
hemorrhage from cervical/cesarean scar ectopic 
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
dilation and curettage 

 
History of Present Illness:
Ms. ___ is a ___, gravida 7, para 2, who had a
known ectopic pregnancy located either a high in her cervix
or low in her cesarean section scar or both. She had
previously been admitted to the obstetric service and treated
with a multidose methotrexate injection directly into the
pregnancy sac.  After 4 doses of intra pregnancy methotrexate
injection, her HCG dropped appropriately and she was observed
in the inpatient service.  She remained stable and was
discharged home on ___.  She developed an acute hemorrhage
approximately 10 days after discharge and presented
immediately to the emergency department on ___.  On 
arrival, her
blood pressure was 77/50 and heart rate was 89.  She was
resuscitated and received 1 unit of emergency release blood
in the emergency department.  An exam at the bedside was
attempted but the cervix was not able to be visualized given
the profuse hemorrhage, an attempts to place an intracervical
Foley balloon catheter to tamponade her bleeding was
attempted, but not possible due to the lack of dilation of
her external os.  She was therefore taken emergently to the
operating room for exam under anesthesia, curettage of the
pregnancy under ultrasound guidance, and possible further
procedures including laparotomy and hysterectomy. 

 
Past Medical History:
PMH: depression/anxiety

PSH: C/S x 2, D&C x 4

GynH: no STIs or abnormal Paps

OBH: ___ - 1LTCS, CPD, term, 9lb 3oz
     ___ - RLTCS, term, 9lb 13oz 
     ___ trimester SAB with D&C x 2
     ___ trimester TAB with D&C x 2 
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
non-contributory
 
Physical Exam:
On discharge:

Gen: NAD
CV: RRR
Lungs: CTAB
Abdomen: soft, nontender, no r/g
GU: voiding spontaneously, minimal spotting on pad
Ext: non-tender
 
Pertinent Results:
___ 06:30AM BLOOD WBC-6.2 RBC-2.55* Hgb-8.0* Hct-23.7* 
MCV-93 MCH-31.3 MCHC-33.6 RDW-13.9 Plt ___
___ 02:10AM BLOOD WBC-8.4 RBC-2.73* Hgb-8.4* Hct-25.3* 
MCV-93 MCH-30.8 MCHC-33.2 RDW-13.9 Plt ___
___ 09:20PM BLOOD WBC-9.7 RBC-2.90* Hgb-8.7* Hct-27.1* 
MCV-93 MCH-30.1 MCHC-32.2 RDW-13.8 Plt ___
___ 11:20AM BLOOD WBC-7.0 RBC-3.66* Hgb-11.2* Hct-34.1* 
MCV-93 MCH-30.6 MCHC-32.9 RDW-13.3 Plt ___
 
Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ was taken from the emergency department to the 
operating room for an ultrasound guided D&C which resulted in 
the removal of the suspected gestational sac. Ultrasound showed 
a think cervical stripe and c-section scar at the end of the 
case. She was admitted for observation overnight. Her bleeding 
was minimal. Serial HCTs were drawn and were stable. She had no 
symptoms of anemia. She was discarged home on post-operative day 
#1 in good condition with outpatient follow-up. 
 
Medications on Admission:
bone
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Acetaminophen ___ mg PO Q6H:PRN pain 
do not take over 4000mg in 24 hours 
RX *acetaminophen 500 mg ___ tablet(s) by mouth q6h:prn Disp 
#*40 Tablet Refills:*0
2. Ibuprofen 600 mg PO Q6H:PRN pain 
take with food 
RX *ibuprofen 600 mg 1 tablet(s) by mouth q6h:prn Disp #*60 
Tablet Refills:*0

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
ectopic pregnancy

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___,
You were admitted to the hospital for observation after your 
procedure. Please follow the instructions below.

General instructions:  
* Take your medications as prescribed.    
* Do not take more than 4000mg acetaminophen (APAP) in 24 hrs   
* Nothing in the vagina (no tampons, no douching, no sex) for 2 
weeks
* Use a reliable form of contraception at least until you follow 
up with your primary OB/GYN doctor.
* No heavy lifting of objects >10 lbs for 2 weeks.    
* You may eat a regular diet   
 

To reach medical records to get the records from this 
hospitalization sent to your doctor at home, call ___.

___

a postpartum migraine with motor/sensory aura.

ambulating independently, and pain was controlled with oral 
medications. She was afebrile with stable vital signs. She was 
then discharged home in stable condition with postpartum 
outpatient follow-up scheduled.

Name: ___ Unit No: ___ Admission Date: ___ Discharge Date: ___ Date of Birth: ___ Sex: M Service: MEDICINE Allergies: Shellfish Derived Attending: ___. Chief Complaint: Alchohol intoxication and hypercarbic respiratory failure Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure: Endotracheal intubation History of Present Illness: Mr. ___ is a ___ year old gentleman found unresponsive in his dorm room. Per report, patient was drinking vodka last night until ~5 am, and was found approximately 12 hours later by friends in the prone position. Per EMS, the patient did have a gag and responded to a sternal rub. In the ___ ED, VS were 98.4 72 116/72 8 100%?. He received 1 liter NS and narcan, which he did not respond to. He was responsive to nasal trumplet placement. A CTH and CT c-spine did not demonstrate acute intracranial abnormality or fracture, and a CXR did not demonstrate any acute cardiopulmonary process. Patient was intubated for hypercarbic respiratory failure with an ABG of 7.29/54/401. Labs in the ED were otherwise notable for a lactate of 3.1 and a CK of 4200. Of note, the patient was a difficult intubation in the past for elective surgery. Past Medical History: Unknown Social History: ___ Family History: Unknown Physical Exam: Gen: Sedated and unresponsive HEENT: Perrla, MMM, ETT in place CV: Nl S1+S2 Pulm: CTAB Abd: S/NT/ND +bs Ext: 2+ dp b/l Neuro: Sedated and unresponsive. Intermitently agitated when propafol turned off. Brief Hospital Course: ___ year old gentleman with no significant PMH admitted for unresponsiveness secondary to alchohol intoxication, subsequent hypercarbic resp failure s/p intubation.
1. Hypercarbic respiratory failure: Patient intubated for airway protection and hypercarbic respiratory failure initially ___ to severe etoh intoxication. Pt was quickly extubated and was doing fine on room air. Repeat CXR was neg for acute changes.
2. EtOH intoxication: Patient with significant EtOH intoxication with serum EtOH of 325 on admission. Following extubation, he was maintained on a CIWA and social work was consulted. -CIWA (though noted pt not a chronic abuser) -S.W. saw pt and counselled him on etoh use. Pt denies any overt signs of alcohol dependence (neg on CAGE questionairre) and also denied any depression hx and denies SI/HI
3. Mild rhabdomyolysis: CK of >4000 and lactate of 3.1 likely represents mild rhabdomyolysis in the setting of being prone for ~12 hours. Potassium within normal limits. Plan was to continue IVF s but decided to leave AMA
4. Leukocytosis: Patient leukocytosis to 17.3 during admission, likely due to chemical aspiration while unconscious but on repeat was wnl and cxr was also neg.
5. Trauma: CTH and CT c-spine negative for acute intracranial process or fracture. -observe, no further interventions.
On day of transfer to floor, pt decided to leave AMA. Pt had capacity to make decisions, was no longer intoxicated, did not appear to be in withdrawal and realized that leaving the hospital could be potentially fatal and decided to leave AMA Medications on Admission: Unknown Discharge Medications: none Discharge Disposition: Home Facility: ___ Discharge Diagnosis: Alcohol intoxication Discharge Condition: Left AMA Discharge Instructions: Left AMA Followup Instructions: ___

Neck pain and submental swelling

I & D of submental abscess

 
History of Present Illness:
Patient is a ___ year old female seen at an outside hospital with 


neck pain and submental swelling.  Patient with a CT showing 

submental abscess.  
 
Past Medical History:
None
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
Non contributory

Vitals: 97.8  97.6  76 119/58  18  97% RA
Exam: NAD, AAOX3
HEENT: Submental region with I&D incision clean and dry.  
Packing in place.  Minimal erythema, minimal edema.  
Oropharynx: clear, no edema, no erythema

 
Pertinent Results:
___ 07:45AM   WBC-13.9* RBC-4.13* HGB-11.8* HCT-35.0* 
MCV-85 MCH-28.5 MCHC-33.6 RDW-11.7
 
Brief Hospital Course:
Patient is a ___ year old female seen at an outside hospital with 
neck pain and submental swelling.  Patient with a CT showing 
submental abscess.  Patient underwent an I&D of submental 
abscess on ___.  Submental region was packed with iodoform 
gauze and the patient was placed on IV abx (Unasyn).  Patient's 
wound was closely monitored and packing was changed on a daily 
basis.  On ___, patient is being discharged: afebrile, 
tolerating regular diet without nausea/vomiting, pain well 
controlled on oral medication, voiding, wound clean and packed. 
Submental open wound to be healed by secondary intention. 
Patient instructed to take augmentin for 10 days and follow with 
Dr. ___ in ___ weeks for evaluation of submental abscess 
and further management of possible thyrogossal duct cyst.
 
Medications on Admission:
None
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Augmentin 875-125 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO every 
twelve (12) hours for 10 days.
Disp:*20 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
2. Oxycodone-Acetaminophen ___ mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet 
PO Q6H (every 6 hours) as needed for pain for 5 days.
Disp:*30 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Submental abscess

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Seek immediate medical attention for fever >101.5, chills, 
increased redness, swelling or discharge from incision, chest 
pain, shortness of breath, or anything else that is troubling 
you. OK to shower but do not soak incision until follow up 
appointment, at least. No strenuous exercise or heavy lifting 
until follow up appointment, at least. Do not drive or drink 
alcohol while taking narcotic pain medications. Narcotic pain 
medications may cause constipation, if this occurs take an over 
the counter stool softener. Resume all home medications. Call 
your surgeon to make follow up appointment.

 
Followup Instructions:
___

text:
Name:  ___                Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: OTOLARYNGOLOGY
 
Allergies: 
Patient recorded as having No Known Allergies to Drugs
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
Anterior thyroglossal duct cyst.

 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
___: Infected thyroglossal duct cyst excision, ___ 
procedure
 
History of Present Illness:
The patient is a ___ young female who presented 
initially to the ___ for management of a submental 
abscess seen on a CT scan in ___.  She initially had a sore 
throat for approximately one week and noted a swelling under her 
chin.  Her sore throat began to improve.  However, the
swelling increased.  At ___, she was noted to have 
overlying erythema, temperature of 103, white blood cell count 
of 17,000, and a Rapid Strep culture which was positive.  She 
was transferred to the ___ Emergency
Room for further management.  Initially, she was given 10 mg of 
Decadron and 4 mg of morphine for pain.  She was seen by 
otolaryngology in the emergency room, at which time she was 
found to have effacement of the submental crease, diffuse 
omental tenderness, firm swelling with a focal area of erythema 
just
anterior to the presumed location of the submental crease. Using 
local anesthesia, a 19-gauge needle was used to aspirate 
approximately 2.5 mL of purulent material, which was followed by 
an incision and drainage creating a 1 cm incision.  The wound 
was packed with quarter-inch Iodoform and a culture was sent.  
She was admitted to the hospital and placed on Unasyn.  The 
cultures
were positive for beta hemolytic strep.  She was discharged 
three days later, afebrile, and tolerating a diet. She was 
discharged on ___ on Augmentin and Percocet.

Initially it was recommended that she undergo resection of the 
infected thyroglossal duct cyst and patient (along with mother) 
had opted for conservative management. She returned on ___ 
for infected thyroglossal duct cyst excision.

 
Past Medical History:
Patient denies. Denies surgical history.
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
Family history is significant for cancer, diabetes, and hearing 
loss.

 
Physical Exam:
UPON DISCHARGE (___):

VITALS: T 98.3 BP 102/60 P 70 R 18 O2SAT 98% RA

HEENT: Normocephalic, atraumatic. Extraocular muscles intact. 
Pupils equal round and symmetrically reactive to light. Nares 
clear. Midline cervical neck incision is clear, dry and intac 
and sutures are in place; it is well-approximated with 
Bacitracin dressing. Drain has since been removed. No active 
bleeding or hematoma, no erythema or evidence of infection. Neck 
supple.

___: Regular rate and rhythm. No murmur, rubs or gallop.

CHEST: Clear to auscultation bilaterally, no adventitious 
wheezing, rales or rhonchi.

GI: soft, non-tender, non-distended. Normoactive bowel sounds. 
No guarding.

EXTR: 2+ peripheral pulses, no cyanosis, clubbing or edema.

 
Pertinent Results:
___ CT NECK W/WO CONTRAST:
Resolution of the previously seen midline cystic lesion at the 
level of hyoid with only a small residuum of soft tissue 
density. No signs of residual cyst in the neck. Considerable 
reduction in soft tissue fat stranding involving the 
subcutaneous tissues. Reduction in the size of bilateral level 
___ nodes suggesting resolving inflammation/infection of the 
midline cystic lesion.

 
Brief Hospital Course:
NEURO/PAIN: Pain controlled with acetaminophen 650 mg PO and 
oxycodone as needed. The patient had minimal post-op pain and 
required no narcotic medication. Her head and neck exam remained 
stable post-op with no evidence of hematoma or infection. Her 
vaccinator drain in the left neck was removed on POD#1 when 
minimal (18 mL) output was recorded overnight. Her incision 
remained well-approximated, and was healing well.

CARDIOVASCULAR: The patient remained hemodynamically stable 
without issues while in the hospital. She was on no prior 
cardiac medications.

RESPIRATORY: Post-op the patient maintained her oxygen 
saturations and was encouraged to utilize incentive spirometry. 
She was ambulating POD#1. She denied any respiratory symptoms or 
dyspnea throughout her stay.

FEN/GI: She was started on clear liquids post-op and advanced to 
regular diet by POD#1 without nausea or vomiting. He IV was 
hep-locked once her PO intake was adequate. 

GENITOURINARY: She maintained a normal urine output post-op 
without need for catheterization. 

ENDOCRINE: No active issues.

HEME/ID: Patient remained afebrile and without evidence of 
infection post-op. She was maintained on Ancef 1g IV Q8 while 
the left neck vaccinator drain tube was in place, and she was 
discharged on 2 days of Keflex for antibiotic prophylaxis.

PROPHYLAXIS: Pneumatic compression boots were utilized before 
ambulation to prevent DVT, post-op. The patient ambulated on 
POD#1.

 
Medications on Admission:
No active medications.
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Oxycodone 5 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO Q6H (every 6 
hours) as needed for pain: Do NOT take this medication with 
alcohol or when you anticipate driving.
Disp:*30 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
2. Keflex ___ mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO four times a 
day for 2 days.
Disp:*8 Capsule(s)* Refills:*0*

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
infected thyroglossal duct cyst

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Please schedule follow-up appointment with Dr. ___ in 
___ weeks post-op. Office number: ___
Please see your MD or return to ER if you experience fever or 
chills, drainage from the wound, bleeding or incision is not 
healing well. You may shower with running water over incision, 
but no tub baths or soaking the incision for ___ weeks. You 
should place a small gauze and tegaderm cover over the incision 
site before you shower. You can apply bacitracin ointment as 
needed to the midline neck incision twice daily, until your 
post-op visit. Please take pain medication as prescribed. Also, 
two days of Keflex antibiotic has been prescribed; please take 
as directed.
 
Followup Instructions:
___

History of Present Illness:
___ yo G1P0 at 23 wks 4 days with known low lying placenta and 
cervical polyp presents with episode of vaginal bleeding.

Patient diagnosed with a low lying placenta at 18 weeks. She 
presented to the ED on ___ at 20 weeks with vaginal bleeding 
and was found to have a cervical polyp. She then presented to ob 
triage at 21 weeks 4 days with she felt the sensation of fluid 
in her vagina. 

Today she reports a large vaginal bleed after taking a shower. 
She put a peripad on which was saturated upon arrival to L&D. 
She denies any recent intercourse. She denies any abdominal pain 
or contraction. She reports active fetal movement.
 
Past Medical History:
PRENATAL COURSE
*) Dating: ___ ___ by IVF dating
*) Labs: O+/Ab-
*) U/S: nl FFS per patient 
*) Screening: low risk ERA per pt
*) Known Cervical polyp
*) Known h/o low-lying placenta

PAST OBSTETRIC HISTORY
G1

PAST GYNECOLOGIC HISTORY 
-remote h/o abnl pap, normal f/u paps
-no h/o STDs 

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY
- G6PD deficiency

PAST SURGICAL HISTORY 
- ankle surgery
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
non-contributory
 
Physical Exam:
VITALS: Tc 99.0, HR 83, RR 20, BP 123/80
GENERAL: NAD
ABDOMEN: soft NT, gravid, NT
EXTREMITIES: No ___ edema, NT

Speculum exam:
There is 75 cc organized clot in the vaginal vault, removed
Cervix visually closed. There is a 4 cm protruding cervical os.
Not friable. No active bleeding noted.
SVE: deferred
FHR: Baseline 140. Variability AGA. No decels
Toco: q ___

Ultrasound: 
- fetal movement seen, appropriate amount of fluid
  Breech, Low lying placenta
 
Pertinent Results:
___ WBC-11.4 RBC-3.21 Hgb-9.6 Hct-28.2 MCV-88 Plt-357
___ WBC-10.2 RBC-2.97 Hgb-8.8 Hct-26.1 MCV-88 Plt-303
___ WBC-16.0 RBC-2.73 Hgb-8.1 Hct-24.2 MCV-89 Plt-342

___ ___ PTT-27.5 ___ ___ ___ PTT-21.6 ___ ___ 11:06AM URINE Blood-NEG Nitrite-NEG Protein-NEG 
Glucose-NEG Ketone-NEG Bilirub-NEG Urobiln-NEG pH-6.5 Leuks-NEG
 
Brief Hospital Course:
___ yo G1P0 with known low lying placenta and cervical polyp 
admitted at 23+4 weeks with vaginal bleeding.
.
Ms ___ had no active bleeding on arrival to triage. She 
was hemodynamically stable and fetal testing was reassuring. On 
speculum exam, her cervix appeared closed and there was only a 
clot visible. She was initially contracting irregularly on toco, 
however, was not feeling them and they resolved spontaneously. 
___ was consulted and performed a translabial ultrasound which 
revealed a cervical length of 3.8cm and a marginal previa; no 
polyp was visualized. At 23+6wks gestation, she was given a 
course of betamethasone for fetal lung maturity (complete on 
___ and the NICU was consulted. She had a small amount of 
spotting on ___. Labs were stable and she had no contractions 
on toco. Fetal testing remained reassuring. In regards to her 
fetal testing, she had a normal biophysical profile on admission 
and then was monitored with spot checks only until 25wks. Ms 
___ did not want any intervention for fetal indications 
until 25wks, therefore NSTs were started at that time. She 
remained quite stable and was without bleeding for seven days. 
She was discharged home at 25+1wks and will have close 
outpatient followup. Of note, she has baseline anemia and her 
hematocrit ranged between ___. Hemoglobin electrophoresis was 
normal. She will continue taking iron twice a day.
 
Medications on Admission:
prenatal vitamins
iron supplement
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Ferrous Sulfate 325 mg (65 mg Iron) Tablet Sig: One (1) 
Tablet PO BID (2 times a day).
Disp:*60 Tablet(s)* Refills:*2*
2. Prenatal ___ mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO once a day: 
generic substitutions allowed.
Disp:*30 Tablet(s)* Refills:*2*
3. Colace 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO once a day as 
needed for constipation.
Disp:*30 Capsule(s)* Refills:*2*
 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
cervical polyp
marginal placenta previa
betamethasone complete ___
pregnancy 24 WGA
 
Discharge Condition:
Stable
 
Discharge Instructions:
Call your physician if you experience contractions, bleeding, 
leakage of fluid, or any other concerns
 
Followup Instructions:
___

text:
Name:  ___                 Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: OBSTETRICS/GYNECOLOGY
 
Allergies: 
Patient recorded as having No Known Allergies to Drugs
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
scheduled c/s
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
primary classical c/s via T skin incision, lysis of adhesions, 
cystotomy repair

 
Social History:
___
Family History:
non-contributory
 
Brief Hospital Course:
Pt is a ___ G1P0->1 who initially presented to Labor and 
Delivery on ___ for scheduled cesarean section for 
posterior placenta previa.  Operation was complicated by large 
endometriotic implant at the left anterior fundus, bladder with 
cystotomy at the dome, normal trigone, negative ___ flush 
after cystotomy repair, and extensive adhesions.  Due to the 
complexity of the case, a T-skin incision was undertaken.  A 
classical uterine incision undertaken to avoid an 
intraoperatively suspected placenta perceta which was later 
found to in fact be a large endometriotic implant.  Please see 
operative report for details.  Post-op course was complicated by 
the following:

1. Post Op Tachycardia: On POD #2 pt tachycardic into the 120s 
with normal blood pressure and pulse ox.  Pt never complained of 
chest pain or shortness of breath.  EKG at the time demonstrated 
sinus tachycardia.  Pt's pain was not well controlled at the 
time, and had been noted to have postpartum fever for which she 
was being treated with IV gentamicin and clindamicin x24hours 
afebrile.  Tachycardia was attributed to poor pain control and 
fever and resolved with better pain management and resolution of 
infection.  

2. Intraoperative cystotomy and repair.  The patient was treated 
with three days of cefazolin IV/cephalexin po postoperatively.  
Her foley was maintained 10 days postop.

3. Acute blood loss anemia.  Patient had a low preoperative 
hematocrit of 27.6 and was transfused 2 units pRBC for an 
intraop hematocrit of 22 with appropriate rise in her hematocrit 
to 25.6. Her hematocrit then fell postoperatively to a nadir of 
20.5, at which time she was slightly tachycardic to 104 and 
tachypnic to 24, but able to stand and ambulate without 
lightheadedness.  Pt's abdomen remained soft and urine output 
was adequate therefore active bleeding intra-abdominally not 
suspected.  A repeat transfusion of 2 units pRBC was recommended 
to the patient at that time and she was counseled extensively 
regarding the risks and benefits.  She refused transfusion, and 
her vital signs later spontaneously returned to normal.  She had 
no further clinical symptoms of anemia.

 
Discharge Medications:
1. Docusate Sodium 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO BID (2 
times a day) as needed.
Disp:*50 Capsule(s)* Refills:*0*
2. Ibuprofen 600 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO Q6H (every 6 
hours) as needed.
Disp:*50 Tablet(s)* Refills:*1*
3. Hydrocodone-Acetaminophen ___ mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO 
Q4H (every 4 hours) as needed for pain.
Disp:*50 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
4. Breast Pump     Device Sig: One (1)  Miscellaneous four times 
a day.
Disp:*1 1* Refills:*2*

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
1. term pregnancy with known complete placenta previa
2. status post classical cesearean section, lysis of adhesions, 
and cystotomy repair
3. Acute blood loss anemia

 
Discharge Condition:
stable

 
Discharge Instructions:
see d/c instructions. no swimming/baths/intercourse for 6 wks. 
no heavy lifting. no driving for 2 wks and while taking 
Percocet.
 
Followup Instructions:
___

Brief Hospital Course:
On ___, Ms. ___ was admitted to the gynecology service 
for clinical monitoring for signs of bleeding secondary to a 
hemorrhagic corpus luteum leading to hematoperitoneum. 

Her hospital course was uncomplicated. Her hematocrit was 
trended during her hospitalization and remained stable with a 
nadir of 30.7 on the day of discharge. Her vital signs were 
normal. Her abdominal exam was benign. 

Her pain was controlled with acetaminophen/ibuprofen/oxycodone.

By hospital day 1, she was tolerating a regular diet, ambulating 
independently, and pain was controlled with oral medications. 
Her hematocrit and vital signs were stable. She was discharged 
home in stable condition with outpatient follow-up scheduled.

Brief Hospital Course:
As previously mentioned, the patient was admitted to ___ on 
___ with L knee pain.  His leg was significant for extensive 
erythema extending along the anterior leg, thigh consistent with 
a left lower extremity cellulitis.  He was admitted to 
orthopaedics and placed on IV cefazolin.  

The patient was noted to have a slightly elevated WBC (11.1) on 
admission, though he was afebrile and without other signs of 
systemic infection.  He tolerated the cefazolin well, the 
erythema dramatically decreased in size and the patient was able 
to fully bear weight on his leg.  He was discharged on PO keflex 
for two weeks with outpatient follow-up.

none

day for 2 weeks.

Home

Left lower extremity cellulitis

 
Discharge Condition:
Stable

1.  Take antibiotics as prescribed.

2.  Call your doctor ___ Dr. ___ you develop fever and 
chills or if the rash worsens.  

3. You may participate and engage in all physical activities as 
desired.

Left mastectomy; sentinel node biopsy; immediate left breast

The patient is a ___ woman
with a history of left breast cancer.  She had a lumpectomy and

showed
another positive lesion which was in situ carcinoma with ductal

mastectomy on the left breast.  She was referred to me by Dr.

MCV-96 MCH-32.7* MCHC-34.1 RDW-13.3 Plt ___

Radiology Report LYMPHOSCINTIGRAPHY Study Date of ___  
IMPRESSION: Sentinel node localization study demonstrating 
tracer activity in a 
left axillary focus. 

Pathology Report Tissue: Left breast, sentinel lymph Study Date 
of ___   
Report not finalized. 
Assigned Pathologist ___. 
Please contact the pathology department, ___ ___ 
PATHOLOGY # ___ 
Left breast, sentinel lymph 

 
Brief Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the plastic surgery service on 
___ and underwent the following procedures: Left mastectomy; 
sentinel node biopsy; immediate left breast reconstruction with 
deep inferior epigastric perforator (___) flap.
The patient tolerated the procedures well. 

 

Neuro: Post-operatively, the patient received Dilaudid IV/PCA 
with good effect and adequate pain control. When tolerating oral 
intake, the patient was transitioned to oral pain medications on 
POD 3. 

 

CV: The patient was stable from a cardiovascular standpoint; 
vital signs were routinely monitored.

 

Pulmonary: The patient was stable from a pulmonary standpoint; 
vital signs were routinely monitored.

 

GI/GU: Post-operatively, the patient was given IV fluids until 
tolerating oral intake. Her diet was advanced when appropriate, 
which was tolerated well. She was also started on a bowel 
regimen to encourage bowel movement. Foley was removed on POD#3. 
Intake and output were closely monitored. 

 

ID: Post-operatively, the patient was started on IV cefazolin, 
then switched to PO cephalexin on POD#3. The patient's 
temperature was closely watched for signs of infection. 

 

Prophylaxis: The patient received subcutaneous heparin during 
this stay, and was encouraged to get up and ambulate as early as 
possible. 

 

At the time of discharge on POD#4, the patient was doing well, 
afebrile with stable vital signs, tolerating a regular diet, 
ambulating, voiding without assistance, and pain was well 
controlled. 

 
Medications on Admission:
Simvastatin, Wellbutrin, Ocuvite Lutein, fish oil,
anastrozole, and ibuprofen.

 
Discharge Medications:
1. aspirin 81 mg Tablet, Chewable Sig: 1.5 Tablet, Chewables PO 
DAILY (Daily).  
2. acetaminophen 325 mg Tablet Sig: Two (2) Tablet PO Q6H (every 
6 hours) as needed for pain, HA, T>100 degrees.  
3. docusate sodium 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO BID (2 
times a day).
Disp:*30 Capsule(s)* Refills:*0*
4. simvastatin 40 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY 
(Daily).  
5. hydromorphone 2 mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO every ___ hours 
as needed for pain.
Disp:*50 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
6. diphenhydramine HCl 25 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO Q6H 
(every 6 hours) as needed for itchiness.  
7. bisacodyl 5 mg Tablet, Delayed Release (E.C.) Sig: Two (2) 
Tablet, Delayed Release (E.C.) PO DAILY (Daily) as needed for 
constipation.  
8. senna 8.6 mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO BID (2 times a day) 
as needed for constipation.  
9. Wellbutrin XL 300 mg Tablet Extended Release 24 hr Sig: One 
(1) Tablet Extended Release 24 hr PO DAILY (Daily).  
10. cefadroxil 1 gram Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO once a day 
for 7 days.
Disp:*7 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home With Service
 
Facility:
___
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
left breast cancer s/p mastectomy and ___ flap reconstruction

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Personal Care:
1. Your incisions may be left open to air.
2. Clean around the drain site(s), where the tubing exits the 
skin, with soap and water.
3. Strip drain tubing, empty bulb(s), and record output(s) ___ 
times per day.
4. A written record of the daily output from each drain should 
be brought to every follow-up appointment. your drains will be 
removed as soon as possible when the daily output tapers off to 
an acceptable amount.
5. DO NOT wear a bra for 3 weeks. You may wear a camisole for 
comfort as desired.
6. You may shower daily with assistance as needed.
7. The Dermabond skin glue will begin to flake off in about ___ 

days.
8. No pressure on your right chest and right buttock.
9. Okay to shower, but no baths until after directed by your 
surgeon
.
Activity:
1. You may resume your regular diet.  Avoid caffeine and 
chocolate.
2. DO NOT drive for 3 weeks.
3. Keep hips flexed at all times for 1 week, and then gradually 
stand upright as tolerated.
4. DO NOT lift anything heavier than 5 pounds or engage in 
strenuous activity for 6 weeks following surgery.
5. Please perform the occupational therapy exercises as 
instructed.
.
Medications:
1. Resume your regular medications unless instructed otherwise 
and take any new meds as ordered .
2. Take Aspirin, 120 mg by mouth once daily, for 30 days after 
surgery.
3. You may take your prescribed pain medication for moderate to 
severe pain.  You may switch to Tylenol or Extra Strength 
Tylenol for mild pain as directed on the packaging.  Please note 

that Percocet and Vicodin have Tylenol as an active ingredient 
so do not take these meds with additional Tylenol.
4. Take prescription pain medications for pain not relieved by 
tylenol.
5. Take your antibiotic as prescribed.
6. Take Colace, 100 mg by mouth 2 times per day, while taking 
the prescription pain medication. You may use a different 
over-the-counter stool softerner if you wish.
7. Do not drive or operate heavy machinery while taking any 
narcotic pain medication. You may have constipation when taking 
narcotic pain medications (oxycodone, percocet, vicodin, 
hydrocodone, dilaudid, etc.); you should continue drinking 
fluids, you may take stool softeners, and should eat foods that 
are high in fiber.
.
Call the office IMMEDIATELY if you have any of the following:
1. Signs of infection: fever with chills, increased redness, 
welling, warmth or tenderness at the surgical site, or unusual 
drainage from the incision(s).
2. A large amount of bleeding from the incision(s) or drain(s).
3. Fever greater than 101.5 oF
4. Severe pain NOT relieved by your medication.
.
Return to the ER if: 
* If you are vomiting and cannot keep in fluids or your 
medications. 
* If you have shaking chills, fever greater than 101.5 (F) 
degrees or 38 (C) degrees, increased redness,swelling or 
discharge from incision, chest pain, shortness of breath, or 
anything else that is troubling you.
* Any serious change in your symptoms, or any new symptoms that 
concern you.
.
DRAIN DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS
You are being discharged with drains in place. Drain care is a 
clean procedure. Wash your hands thoroughly with soap and warm 
water before performing drain care. Perform drainage care twice 
a day. Try to empty the drain at the same time each day. Pull 
the stopper out of the drainage bottle and empty the drainage 
fluid into the measuring cup. Record the amount of drainage 
fluid on the record sheet. Reestablish drain suction.

 
Followup Instructions:
___

possible.

ambulating, voiding without assistance, and pain was well

Discharge Disposition:

___
Discharge Diagnosis:
left breast cancer s/p mastectomy and ___ flap reconstruction
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.
Discharge Instructions:
Personal Care:
1. Your incisions may be left open to air.
2. Clean around the drain site(s), where the tubing exits the
skin, with soap and water.
3. Strip drain tubing, empty bulb(s), and record output(s) ___
times per day.
4. A written record of the daily output from each drain should
be brought to every follow-up appointment. your drains will be
removed as soon as possible when the daily output tapers off to
an acceptable amount.
5. DO NOT wear a bra for 3 weeks. You may wear a camisole for
comfort as desired.
6. You may shower daily with assistance as needed.
7. The Dermabond skin glue will begin to flake off in about ___
days.
8. No pressure on your right chest and right buttock.
9. Okay to shower, but no baths until after directed by your
surgeon
.
Activity:
1. You may resume your regular diet. Avoid caffeine and
chocolate.
2. DO NOT drive for 3 weeks.
3. Keep hips flexed at all times for 1 week, and then gradually
stand upright as tolerated.
4. DO NOT lift anything heavier than 5 pounds or engage in
strenuous activity for 6 weeks following surgery.
5. Please perform the occupational therapy exercises as
instructed.
.
Medications:
1. Resume your regular medications unless instructed otherwise
and take any new meds as ordered .
2. Take Aspirin, 120 mg by mouth once daily, for 30 days after
surgery.
3. You may take your prescribed pain medication for moderate to
severe pain. You may switch to Tylenol or Extra Strength
Tylenol for mild pain as directed on the packaging. Please note
that Percocet and Vicodin have Tylenol as an active ingredient
so do not take these meds with additional Tylenol.
4. Take prescription pain medications for pain not relieved by
tylenol.
5. Take your antibiotic as prescribed.
6. Take Colace, 100 mg by mouth 2 times per day, while taking
the prescription pain medication. You may use a different
over-the-counter stool softerner if you wish.
7. Do not drive or operate heavy machinery while taking any
narcotic pain medication. You may have constipation when taking
narcotic pain medications (oxycodone, percocet, vicodin,
hydrocodone, dilaudid, etc.); you should continue drinking
fluids, you may take stool softeners, and should eat foods that
are high in fiber.
.
Call the office IMMEDIATELY if you have any of the following:
1. Signs of infection: fever with chills, increased redness,
welling, warmth or tenderness at the surgical site, or unusual
drainage from the incision(s).
2. A large amount of bleeding from the incision(s) or drain(s).
3. Fever greater than 101.5 oF
4. Severe pain NOT relieved by your medication.
.
Return to the ER if:
* If you are vomiting and cannot keep in fluids or your
medications.
* If you have shaking chills, fever greater than 101.5 (F)
degrees or 38 (C) degrees, increased redness,swelling or
discharge from incision, chest pain, shortness of breath, or
anything else that is troubling you.
* Any serious change in your symptoms, or any new symptoms that
concern you.
.
DRAIN DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS
You are being discharged with drains in place. Drain care is a
clean procedure. Wash your hands thoroughly with soap and warm
water before performing drain care. Perform drainage care twice
a day. Try to empty the drain at the same time each day. Pull
the stopper out of the drainage bottle and empty the drainage
fluid into the measuring cup. Record the amount of drainage
fluid on the record sheet. Reestablish drain suction.
Followup Instructions:
___

Normal sinus rhythm. Normal ECG. Compared to the previous

IMPRESSION: 
Mild retrocardiac atelectasis.  No pneumothorax.  Mild 
cardiomegaly. 

___ ECHO
The left atrial volume is moderately increased. Left ventricular 
wall thickness, cavity size, and global systolic function are 
normal (LVEF>55%). There is no left ventricular outflow 
obstruction at rest or with Valsalva. Right ventricular chamber 
size and free wall motion are normal. The diameters of aorta at 
the sinus, ascending and arch levels are normal. The aortic 
valve leaflets (3) appear structurally normal with good leaflet 
excursion and no aortic stenosis. Trace aortic regurgitation is 
seen. The mitral valve leaflets are structurally normal. Trivial 
mitral regurgitation is seen. The estimated pulmonary artery 
systolic pressure is normal. There is no pericardial effusion. 

IMPRESSION: Normal global and regional biventricular systolic 
function. No structural cardiac cause for syncope seen. 
 
Brief Hospital Course:
___ year old female with a PMH notable for type II diabetes and 
HTN presenting with likely recurrent syncope over 24 hours.  

ACTIVE ISSUES
#SYNCOPE: Recurrent over the 24 hours prior to admission. The 
patient has never experienced these symptoms before. She 
reported a history of a heart problem diagnosed in ___, 
however is unable to clarify. Her symptoms occurred in the 
abscence of clear orthostatsis/hypotension, however fluid may 
have been infusing during the recordings. She has a moderate 
intensity systolic murmur which augments with expiration 
suggesting a left sided lesion. Her presentation is not 
concerning for a primary neurologic event, signficant 
hemorrhage, acute coronary syndrome, pulmonary embolism or 
cardiac arrhythmia (no events on tele). The most likely 
etiologies include valvular heart lesion, autonomic dysfunction 
for DMII, orthostasis from osmotic diuresis and ACEi therapy or 
vasovagal events. Cardiac telemetry monitoring showed no events 
and EKGs were normal.  The patient had an echocardiogram which 
showed no valvular dysfunction which could lead to syncope.  The 
patient reported some stress at home at the time of these 
syncopal episodes, suggestive that her syncopal episodes may 
have been vasovagal responses. The patient was continued on her 
lisinopril since she was hemodynamically stable.

CHRONIC ISSUES
#TYPE II DIABETES: Blood glucose on addmission the ___. The 
patient denied polyuria/polydipsia at home.  The patient was 
kept on a HISS while in-house and her metformin and glimepiride 
were continued at discharge.  Repeat HbA1c was pending at time 
of discharge.

#HYPERTENSION: Patient moderately hypertensive on admission 
140s-150s.  Lisinopril continued becuse patient hemodynamically 
stable.  

*****TRANSITIONAL ISSUES*****
-Patient will need to follow-up for outpatient provider 
regarding clarification of patient's history of arrhythmia and 
further work-up.

abnormalities are no longer present.

IMPRESSION:
Mild retrocardiac atelectasis. No pneumothorax. Mild
cardiomegaly.
___ ECHO
The left atrial volume is moderately increased. Left ventricular
wall thickness, cavity size, and global systolic function are
normal (LVEF>55%). There is no left ventricular outflow
obstruction at rest or with Valsalva. Right ventricular chamber
size and free wall motion are normal. The diameters of aorta at
the sinus, ascending and arch levels are normal. The aortic
valve leaflets (3) appear structurally normal with good leaflet
excursion and no aortic stenosis. Trace aortic regurgitation is
seen. The mitral valve leaflets are structurally normal. Trivial
mitral regurgitation is seen. The estimated pulmonary artery
systolic pressure is normal. There is no pericardial effusion.
IMPRESSION: Normal global and regional biventricular systolic
function. No structural cardiac cause for syncope seen.
Brief Hospital Course:
___ year old female with a PMH notable for type II diabetes and
HTN presenting with likely recurrent syncope over 24 hours.

#SYNCOPE: Recurrent over the 24 hours prior to admission. The
patient has never experienced these symptoms before. She
reported a history of a heart problem diagnosed in ___,
however is unable to clarify. Her symptoms occurred in the
abscence of clear orthostatsis/hypotension, however fluid may
have been infusing during the recordings. She has a moderate
intensity systolic murmur which augments with expiration
suggesting a left sided lesion. Her presentation is not
concerning for a primary neurologic event, signficant
hemorrhage, acute coronary syndrome, pulmonary embolism or
cardiac arrhythmia (no events on tele). The most likely
etiologies include valvular heart lesion, autonomic dysfunction
for DMII, orthostasis from osmotic diuresis and ACEi therapy or
vasovagal events. Cardiac telemetry monitoring showed no events
and EKGs were normal. The patient had an echocardiogram which
showed no valvular dysfunction which could lead to syncope. The
patient reported some stress at home at the time of these
syncopal episodes, suggestive that her syncopal episodes may
have been vasovagal responses. The patient was continued on her
lisinopril since she was hemodynamically stable.
CHRONIC ISSUES

patient denied polyuria/polydipsia at home. The patient was
kept on a HISS while in-house and her metformin and glimepiride
were continued at discharge. Repeat HbA1c was pending at time
of discharge.

140s-150s. Lisinopril continued becuse patient hemodynamically
stable.

-Patient will need to follow-up for outpatient provider
regarding clarification of patient's history of arrhythmia and
further work-up.

text:
Name:  ___                    Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: MEDICINE
 
Allergies: 
Patient recorded as having No Known Allergies to Drugs
 
Attending: ___
 
Chief Complaint:
Chest pain
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
None

 
History of Present Illness:
Mr. ___ is a ___ with a history of cocaine use, alcohol abuse, 
emphysema who presents with chest pain for 1 month duration.  He 
notes that he has long standing intermittent chest pain and 
cannot recall when his chest pain began.  He reports that in the 
last month his substernal chest pain has become progressively 
worse, lasting at times a few seconds in duration and not 
worsened by excercise, inspiration, nor is it alleviated by 
rest, eating or leaning forward.  The chest pain is located on 
his left substernum, with pain at ___, characterized as a tight 
sensation, radiating to the neck and to the left arm, with 
numbing sensation throughout his arm.  He recently began doing 
large numbers of pushups and pull-ups, however, which has led to 
muscle soreness  He further notes that during cocaine use, he 
does not have increased chest pain.  Along with the chest pain, 
he has occasional sweating, shortness of breath, and dizziness 
but they do not always occur together.  He decided to come to 
the ED at the suggestion of his finance.  

In the ED, his vitals were: T 98.6 BP 121/76 HR 104 RR 16 100% 
RA. He was given ASA 325 mg PO, sublingual nitroglycerin 0.4 mg 
x 3 morphine 4mg IV, and first set of cardiac enzymes were 
negative. CXR was obtained which showed moderate bibasilar 
bronchiectasis and early pneumonia, so azithromycin 500mg PO was 
given. UA was positive for opiates and negative for cocaine, 
LFTs were elevated with AST of 44 ALT 64.   He was admitted to 
the floor for r/o MI. 
 
Past Medical History:
Asthma
Emphysema
depression
anxiety
GERD
hemorroids
hypercholesterolemia
hypertension

 
Social History:
___
Family History:
Father with pancreatic cancer died at age ___. 

 
Physical Exam:
VS: 97.2 120/82 75 20 98%
GEN: well developed ___ male sitting in bed in NAD
HEENT: NC/AT, PERRL, EOMI, MMM, OP clear
NECK: supple, one <1cm left-sided supraclavicular lymph node, 
normal JVP
CV: RRR, normal S1S2, no M/R/G
CHEST: CTAB, no W/R/R
ABD: soft, RUQ tenderness, ND, liver edge not felt, liver span 
at 9 cm, NABS
EXTR: WWP, no clubbing, cyanosis, edema, 2+ DP/rad pulses b/l
NEURO: AOx3, CNII-XII intact, Normal bulk and tone, ___ Motor 
strength in ___ b/l, 2+ DTR in ___.

 
Pertinent Results:
Admission: 
CK(CPK)-294* CK-MB-5 cTropnT-<0.01
CK-MB-5 cTropnT-<0.01 

URINE  bnzodzpn-NEG barbitrt-NEG opiates-POS cocaine-NEG 
amphetmn-NEG mthdone-NEG

URINE  COLOR-Straw APPEAR-Clear SP ___
___ 06:00PM URINE  BLOOD-NEG NITRITE-NEG PROTEIN-NEG 
GLUCOSE-NEG KETONE-NEG BILIRUBIN-NEG UROBILNGN-NEG PH-5.0 
LEUK-NEG

K+-3.7 GLUCOSE-76 UREA N-8 CREAT-0.9 SODIUM-139 POTASSIUM-3.8 
CHLORIDE-105 TOTAL CO2-25 ANION GAP-13

ALT(SGPT)-64* AST(SGOT)-44* CK(CPK)-373* ALK PHOS-60 TOT 
BILI-0.5

CHOLEST-163 TRIGLYCER-67 HDL CHOL-80 CHOL/HDL-2.0 LDL(CALC)-70

___ PTT-25.0 ___hest pain. Pt presented with atypical chest pain and was 
ruled out for acute coronary syndrome.  He had complaint of 
substernal chest pain radiating to the left arm and neck that 
has been longstanding, with pain lasting between seconds to 
minutes and occuring and resolving spontaneously.  His cardiac 
enzymes were negative x3, ECGs throuhout his stay were normal 
with normal sinus rhythm and no ST changes.  A stress test was 
not done given low suspicion for MI (TIMI of 1). It is unlikely 
that this was a cocaine induced vasospasm given that this chest 
pain does not coincide with cocaine use and that his chest pain 
persists despite UA being negative for cocaine and last cocaine 
use 1.5 weeks ago per patient report. Patient's vitals stable 
with occasional episodes of chest pain without signifant 
findings on telemetry or EKG. Patient also had multiple ECG 
stress tests in past few years that were all negative as well. 

# pneumonia.  Patient was found to have moderate bronchiectasis 
and early pneumonia on chest x-ray but given patient was denied 
cough, sputum production, fever, or chills and his WBC count 
being normal, antibiotic treatment was not continued.

# Substance use. Patient has a long standing history of tobacco, 
etoh, and cocaine use which per pt report has caused significant 
difficulty in his life.  He noted that he has attempted to quit 
previously without success and is interested in enrolling in 
treatment.  Social work was consulted and they were able to 
discuss substance abuse program options with him. He seemed 
motivated in enrolling in a program to quit. 
. 
# Scrotal pain. Patient presented with scrotal pain which has 
been evaluated previously and is likely a chronic issue.  A 
recent scrotal US was unremarkable.  Our physical exam was 
benign without any inguinal adenopathy, tenderness, discharge, 
or lesions. A follow-up appointment was arranged with his PCP to 
further evaluate this issue.  

# Asthma.  Patient has a history asthma which was not active 
during his stay.  He denied wheezing and difficulty with 
breathing related to his asthma. 

# STD risk.  Pt expressed concern for STD. He had unprotected 
sexual intercourse with a female with positive HIV six weeks 
ago. He had a negative HIV test 4 weeks ago. A hepatitis lab 
panel showed no signs of chronic hep B or hep C.  The patient 
was advised to follow-up with PCP to get repeat HIV test. 

# Lower back pain.   Patient complains of bilateral burning pain 
down the posterior leg.  This has been a chronic issue and would 
recommend f/u with PCP to further evaluate matter.

# GERD. Pt has history of GERD and history of zantac and 
prilosec use but is not currently taking medications.  He was 
placed on pantoprazole.

# Hypertension.  Pt reported he has hypertension but not on 
medication. BP normotensive during his stay.
 
# Hyperlipidemia. Pt reported recent diagnosis of hyperlipidemia 
but is not on medication.  Serum lipids were normal.

# Depression/Anxiety. Not active issue during his stay.  
 
Medications on Admission:
None
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Ranitidine HCl 150 mg Tablet Sig: 0.5 Tablet PO DAILY 
(Daily).
Disp:*15 Tablet(s)* Refills:*2*
2. Aspirin 81 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO once a day.
Disp:*30 Tablet(s)* Refills:*2*
3. Albuterol Sulfate 90 mcg/Actuation HFA Aerosol Inhaler Sig: 
___ puffs Inhalation every ___ hours as needed for shortness of 
breath or wheezing.
Disp:*1 inhaler* Refills:*0*

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Primary diagnosis:
atypical chest pain

Secondary:
asthma
polysubstance abuse

 
Discharge Condition:
Afebrile, vital signs stable, chest pain free.

 
Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted because of chest pain. We ran tests which 
showed you did not have a heart attack or abnormal rhythm of the 
heart. 
.
We recommended that you follow up with your PCP to ___ 
your chronic testical and lower back pain more extensively.
.  
Please stop using cocaine and alcohol. These are extremely bad 
for your health. Please use the phone numbers for substance 
abuse programs that were given to you by our social worker. 

There were no changes made to your medications.
. 
Please call your PCP or go to the emergency room if you 
experience severe chest pain, excessive sweating, nausea, 
shortness of breath, fast heart beat, dizziness, 
lightheadedness, fainting, fever over 102, or cough.  

 
Followup Instructions:
___

bilaterally.

Pertinent Results:
LAB DATA:
CBC: Mild anemia (hct 38.0)
BMP: WNL
UA: WNL
UTox: +Benzos (after Klonopin in ___
Serum Tox: +Benzos (after Klonopin in ___

 
Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. ___ arrived on ___ to the inpatient 
unit and was discharged on ___. Patient arrived with 
delusions regarding the government having cameras out to watch 
him, and causing his significant stroke of bad luck (getting hit 
by a car, falling into a hole). However for the rest of the 
admission, he seemed vague about the goverment and said he 
wasn't sure who was chasing him. He also said he was extremely 
angry at his sister for putting information out on the internet 
about him and really wanted something to be done by the police. 
He also reported that he was willing to take Abilify and used to 
take 30 mg. of it at our initial interview.

During the hospital stay, patient became significantly better. 
He was less paranoid, maintained good self-care and hygeine, and 
maintained his stance that he's extremely angry at his sister 
but he wants to be "peaceful and not violent, and I don't want 
any trouble." Patient was maintained on Abilify 30 mg. daily and 
tolerated it well. Patient seemed to brighten each day, 
interacted with other patients and communicated well with his 
primary team. He wanted to go to ___ where he has friends and 
a ___ that he has warm feelings about. He was in agreement 
to go to ___ for his partial program.  
 
Medications on Admission:

  * Ritalin 20mg BID (filled ___
  * Klonopin 2mg BID (filled ___
  * Wellbutrin XL 150mg daily (filled ___
  * Trihexiphenidyl 2mg TID (filled ___
  * Zolpidem 10mg HS PRN (filled ___
  * Abilify (per pt, unable to confirm dose)
  * Thorazine (per pt, unable to confirm dose)

(Daily).
Disp:*30 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*

day).
Disp:*45 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
4. trihexyphenidyl 2 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO TID (3 
times a day).
Disp:*45 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
I - Psychosis NOS: r/o schizophrenia, paranoid type vs
schizoaffective d/o vs mood disorder with psychotic features; 
r/o
major depressive episode or disorder
II - Deferred
III - Multiple TBIs, narcolepsy, sleep apnea
IV - Multiple/severe: homeless, poor social and family support,
financial stressors, recent trauma and injuries

 
Discharge Condition:
alert, oriented and ambulatory

 
Discharge Instructions:
-Please follow up with all outpatient appointments as listed - 
take this discharge paperwork to your appointments.
-Please continue all medications as directed.
-Please avoid abusing alcohol and any drugs--whether 
prescription drugs or illegal drugs--as this can further worsen 
your medical and psychiatric illnesses.
-Please contact your outpatient psychiatrist or other providers 
if you have any concerns.
-Please call ___ or go to your nearest emergency room if you 
feel unsafe in any way and are unable to immediately reach your 
health care providers.
 
*It was a pleasure to have worked with you, and we wish you the 
best of health.*

Name:  ___                    Unit No:   ___

Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: NEUROSURGERY
 
Allergies: 
No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions
 
Attending: ___
 
Chief Complaint:
Back Pain
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
___ Left L5-S1 discectomy

 
History of Present Illness:
Ms. ___ is a ___ with a known large disc herniation at
L5-S1. She has been complaining of back pain for many years and
was initially evaluated in ___ before seeking treatment in the
___. She was then seen by both Dr. ___ in clinic and
neurology and was strongly advised to undergo surgery but the
patient refused. Today she called in to request a refill on one
of her medications. At that time she endorsed that she
occasionally has saddle anesthesia after sitting on the commode
for an exteded period of time. 
 
Past Medical History:
none
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
nc
 
Physical Exam:
O:AVSS
Gen: WD/WN, comfortable, NAD.
HEENT: Pupils:  3->2 bilaterally       EOMs intact
Neck: Supple.
Lungs: CTA bilaterally.
Cardiac: RRR. S1/S2.
Abd: Soft, NT, BS+
Extrem: Warm and well-perfused.
Neuro:
Mental status: Awake and alert, cooperative with exam, normal
affect.
Orientation: Oriented to person, place, and date.
Motor:
___ BUE and BLE. Sensation intact bilaterally. 

Sensation: Intact to light touch

Toes downgoing bilaterally

On Discharge:
Motor: ___ throughout
sensation intact
Incision c/d/i with steris
 
Brief Hospital Course:
Patient presented on ___ for an elective L5-S1 microdiscectomy 
for a large left L5-S1 disc herniation. She tolerated the 
procedure well, was extubated in the operating room and taken to 
the PACU post-operatively to recover. She remained stable 
overnight with complaints of constipation and her bowel regimen 
was increased. On the morning of ___ she was noted to have 
urinary retention on bladder scan and had a straigth 
catheterization to assess post-void residual and was noted to 
have 900cc in her bladder. A UA was also sent which was 
negative. Overnight, foley was replaced for continued urinary 
retention. She was noted to have 2 BMs. 

On ___, patient remained intact on exam. Another voiding trial 
was attempted and patient was able to void for 500cc but bladder 
scan revealed that patient was retaining 600cc. Foley was 
replaced at this time. She has been ambulating independently and 
reported feeling unsteady on her feet, ___ was consulted and 
stated that she could benefit from outpatient ___. She was 
discharged with pain medications and told to follow up with 
urology for removal of foley. 
 
Medications on Admission:
The Preadmission Medication list is accurate and complete.
1. Ibuprofen 400 mg PO Q8H:PRN pain 

 
Discharge Medications:
1. Docusate Sodium 100 mg PO BID 
RX *docusate sodium [Colace] 100 mg 1 capsule(s) by mouth twice 
a day Disp #*60 Capsule Refills:*2
2. OxycoDONE (Immediate Release)  ___ mg PO Q4H:PRN pain 
RX *oxycodone 5 mg ___ tablet(s) by mouth every four (4) hours 
Disp #*90 Tablet Refills:*0
3. Outpatient Physical Therapy
Evaluate and treat

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
L5-S1 disc herniation

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Your large dressing may be removed the second day after 
surgery.
You have steri-strips in place, you must keep them dry for 72 
hours.  Do not pull them off. They will fall off on their own or 
be taken off in the office.  You may trim the edges if they 
begin to curl. 
 No tub baths or pool swimming for two weeks from your date of 
surgery.
Do not smoke.
No pulling up, lifting more than 10 lbs., or excessive bending 
or twisting.
Limit your use of stairs to ___ times per day.
Have a friend or family member check your incision daily for 
signs of infection.
Take your pain medication as instructed; you may find it best 
if taken in the morning when you wake-up for morning stiffness, 
and before bed for sleeping discomfort. Pain medication should 
be used as needed when you have pain. You do not need to take it 
if you do not have pain.
Do not take any anti-inflammatory medications such as Motrin, 
Advil, Aspirin, and Ibuprofen etc. for two weeks.
Increase your intake of fluids and fiber, as pain medicine 
(narcotics) can cause constipation. We recommend taking an over 
the counter stool softener, such as Docusate (Colace) while 
taking narcotic pain medication.
Clearance to drive and return to work will be addressed at 
your post-operative office visit.

CALL YOUR SURGEON IMMEDIATELY IF YOU EXPERIENCE ANY OF THE 
FOLLOWING:

Pain that is continually increasing or not relieved by pain 
medicine.
Any weakness, numbness, tingling in your extremities.
Any signs of infection at the wound site: redness, swelling, 
tenderness, and drainage.
Fever greater than or equal to 101.5° F. 
Loss of control of bowel or bladder functioning

 
Followup Instructions:
___
