text:
Name:  ___                 Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___

Service: MEDICINE
 
Allergies: 
Gadolinium-Containing Agents / Iodinated Contrast Media - IV Dye
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
anaphylaxis
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
none
 
History of Present Illness:
___ year old woman with chronic abdominal pain, presents with 
anaphylaxis after receiving contrast during a CT scan today.  
She has a history of a contrast allergy.  After receiving the 
contrast, she felt tightening in her throat and shortness of 
breath.  She received epinephrine and benadryl upon onset of 
symptoms.  Denies chest pain, headache, rash or oral swelling.

In the ED, initial VS were 98 97 132/82 22 100% RA.  No labs or 
imaging studies were obtained.  CT abd/pelvis showed no acute 
abdominal abnormalities.  Patient received methylprednisolone 
125mg, famotidine 20mg x2, lorazepam 2mg, albuterol nebulizer, 
benadryl 50mg x1 and 25mg x1, prednisone 20mg x1, maalox and 
viscous lidocaine.  Vital signs on transfer were 98.7 88 114/71 
14 95%.
 

 
Past Medical History:
was not obtained before patient left AMA
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
was not obtained before patient left AMA
 
Physical Exam:
was not obtained before patient left AMA
 
Pertinent Results:
none obtained before patient left AMA
 
Brief Hospital Course:
On arrival to the floor, patient states that she wants to leave 
AMA.  She states she still has throat swelling and difficulty 
swallowing and has been choking on thin liquids.  I strongly 
recommended she stay for observation given risk of worsening 
stridor and delayed allergic response, risk of aspiration, risk 
for dehydration and risk of death.  She understands these risks

text:
Name:  ___                 Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: ORTHOPAEDICS
 
Allergies: 
Patient recorded as having No Known Allergies to Drugs
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
Fall
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
___: s/p Application of spanning external fixator, left 
leg.
___: s/p Left leg fasciotomies with vac application.
___: s/p Removal of external fixator with open reduction 
internal fixation and vac change, left tibia.
___:  s/p Split Thickness Skin Graft left tibia
 
History of Present Illness:
Ms. ___ is a ___ year old female who fell on ___.  She 
was taken to ___ and found to have a left 
tibial plateau fracture and developing left leg compartment 
syndrome both requiring urgent surgical management.  She was 
transferred to the ___ for further evaluation and care.
 
Past Medical History:
Hypertension
Patella fracture ___
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
N/A
 
Physical Exam:
Upon admission:

Alert and oriented
Cardiac:  Regular rate rhythm
Chest:  Lungs clear bilaterally
Abdomen:  Soft non-tender non-distended
Extremities:  LLE, ___, compartments firm no pain with PROM 
toes, skin intact
 
Brief Hospital Course:
Ms ___ was admitted to the Orthopedic service on ___ for 
a left tibial plateau fracture and left leg compartment 
syndrome.  She went urgently to the operating room on ___ 
and underwent application of left leg spanning external fixator 
with fasciotomies and vac application without complication.  She 
was extubated without difficulty and transferred to the recovery 
room in stable condition.  She was transferred to the floor in 
stable condition.  There were no overnight events.  On ___, 
she was transfused one unit of packed red blood cells for post 
operative blood loss anemia.  On ___ she underwent an I&D 
of her left leg fasciotomies with VAC chanage  On ___ she 
returned to the operating room and underwent an I&D with ORIF of 
her left tibial plateau fracture with VAC change and external 
fixator removal.  On ___ she returned to the operating room 
and underwent a split thickness skin graft.  A VAC was placed 
over and she was placed on bedrest for a total of 5 days.  On 
___ the VAC was removed and she was taken off of bedrest.

She had adequate pain management and worked with physical 
therapy while in the hospital.  The remainder of her hospital 
course was uneventful.  Ms. ___ is being discharged in stable 
condition.

 
Medications on Admission:
None
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Acetaminophen 325 mg Tablet Sig: Two (2) Tablet PO Q6H (every 
6 hours).  
2. Alum-Mag Hydroxide-Simeth 200-200-20 mg/5 mL Suspension Sig: 
___ MLs PO Q6H (every 6 hours) as needed for Dyspepsia.  
3. Docusate Sodium 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO BID (2 
times a day).  
4. Bisacodyl 5 mg Tablet, Delayed Release (E.C.) Sig: Two (2) 
Tablet, Delayed Release (E.C.) PO DAILY (Daily) as needed for 
Constipation.  
5. Magnesium Hydroxide 400 mg/5 mL Suspension Sig: Thirty (30) 
ML PO BID (2 times a day) as needed for Constipation.  
6. Senna 8.6 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO BID (2 times a 
day) as needed for Constipation.  
7. Multivitamin     Tablet Sig: One (1) Cap PO DAILY (Daily).  
8. Enoxaparin 40 mg/0.4 mL Syringe Sig: One (1)  Subcutaneous 
DAILY (Daily) for 4 weeks.  
9. Lorazepam 1 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO Q8H (every 8 
hours) as needed for anxiety.  
10. Hydromorphone 2 mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO Q3H (every 3 
hours) as needed for pain.  
11. Hydromorphone 2 mg/mL Syringe Sig: One (1)  Injection Q3H 
(every 3 hours) as needed for breakthrough pain.  
12. Gabapentin 300 mg Capsule Sig: Two (2) Capsule PO TID (3 
times a day).  
13. Bupropion HCl 150 mg Tablet Sustained Release Sig: One (1) 
Tablet Sustained Release PO QAM (once a day (in the morning)).  

 
Discharge Disposition:
Extended Care
 
Facility:
___
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
1. Left tibial plateau fracture.
2. Compartment syndrome, left leg.
3. Post operative blood loss anemia.
 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - requires assistance or aid (walker 
or cane).
 
Discharge Instructions:
Wound Care: 
-Keep Incision dry. 
-Do not soak the incision in a bath or pool.  

Activity: 
-Continue to be non weight bearing on your left leg.  
-Elevate left leg to reduce swelling and pain.
-Do not remove ___ come off for daily care/hygeine

Other Instructions
- Resume your regular diet. 
- Avoid nicotine products to optimize healing. 
- Resume your home medications. Take all medications as 
instructed. 
- Continue taking the Lovenox to prevent blood clots.

-You have also been given Additional Medications to control your 
pain.  Please allow 72 hours for refill of narcotic 
prescriptions, so plan ahead.  You can either have them mailed 
to your home or pick them up at the clinic located on ___. 
 We are not allowed to call in narcotic (oxycontin, oxycodone, 
percocet) prescriptions to the pharmacy.   In addition, we are 
only allowed to write for pain medications for 90 days from the 
date of surgery.

- Narcotic pain medication may cause drowsiness.  Do not drink 
alcohol while taking narcotic medications.  Do not operate any 
motor vehicle or machinery while taking narcotic pain 
medications.  Taking more than recommended may cause serious 
breathing problems.

If you have questions, concerns or experience any of the below 
danger signs then please call your doctor at ___ or go 
to your local emergency room.

Physical Therapy:
Activity:  As tolerated 
 Left lower extremity:  Non weight bearing
 Range of motion knee as tolerated

Treatment Frequency:
Staples out 14 days after surgery

Dry dressing
 
Followup Instructions:
___

text:
Name:  ___               Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: OBSTETRICS/GYNECOLOGY
 
Allergies: 
Patient recorded as having No Known Allergies to Drugs
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
labor
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
low transverse cesarean section
bladder rupture repair
 
History of Present Illness:
___ yo G2P1 @___ GA presents with contractions.  She had 
presented the evening prior to admission and was found to have a 
cervix 1/thick/high and was sent home given no evidence of 
labor.  She returned the day of admission, ___, with 
contractions increased to q2-5 minutes.  She denied LoF, VB. 
+AFM.  Consent had been signed in advance for a trial of labor.
 
Past Medical History:
This pregnancy benign.

ObHx:
- LTCS ___ for abruption

GynHx: none

PMH: anxiety
PSH: LTCS, dental
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
NC
 
Physical Exam:
97.5, 74, 125/86, 20
SVE: ___
 
Pertinent Results:
___ 01:14PM   WBC-8.4 RBC-4.29 HGB-13.7 HCT-40.0 MCV-93 
MCH-32.0 MCHC-34.3 RDW-13.1
___ 01:14PM   PLT COUNT-265
___ 01:14PM   URIC ACID-5.9*
___ 01:14PM   ALT(SGPT)-8
___ 01:14PM   CREAT-0.7
___ 01:20PM URINE  COLOR-Yellow APPEAR-Hazy SP ___
___ 01:20PM URINE  BLOOD-NEG NITRITE-NEG PROTEIN-TR 
GLUCOSE-NEG KETONE-NEG BILIRUBIN-NEG UROBILNGN-NEG PH-6.0 
LEUK-MOD
 
Brief Hospital Course:
ANTEPARTUM COURSE:
The patient was admitted to Labor and Delivery.  She progressed 
to fully dilated.  She noted some left lower quadrant pain. Her
epidural was adjusted. She then had recurrence of pain in the
left lower quadrant. She was fully dilated, at +2 to +3
station. The fetal heart rate tracing was reassuring.
However, given her pain, the decision was made to proceed
with an urgent Cesarean section as a uterine scar dehiscence
was suspected as the cause of her pain.

INTRAPARTUM COURSE:
Repeat low transverse cesarean section was undertaken.  
Intraoperatively, the patient was found to have an obviously 
ruptured bladder with foley bulb protruding throught he bladder. 
 She was also noted to have a very thin lower uterine segment.  
Infant was a liveborn girl, wt 3505 grams, with Apgars of 8 and 
9 at 1, 5 minutes respectively.  Intraoperative urology consult 
was obtained and the bladder was closed in two layers.  Please 
see operative notes by Dr. ___ and Dr. ___ 
(___) for full details.

POSTPARTUM COURSE:
The patient was kept on L&D for 6 hours postoperatively.  She 
received 500cc bolus of IVF x1 for low urine output.  She was 
transported to the postpartum floor.  Urine output was found to 
resolve.  She received 24 hours of kefzol postoperatively for 
prophlyaxis.  She was continued to be followed by urology, who 
recommended that the foley be kept in until ___ days postop, 
at which time she would follow up as an outpatient for a 
cystogram and have her foley d/c'd.  She also developed a rash 
which was thought to be intertriginous candidiasis, and for 
which she was treated with topical clotrimazole.  The patient 
was given leg bag teaching and was discharged home in good 
condition on PPD#4.
 
Medications on Admission:
vitamins, celexa
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Docusate Sodium 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO BID (2 
times a day) as needed for constipation.  
2. Oxycodone-Acetaminophen ___ mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet 
PO Q3-4H () as needed for pain.
Disp:*31 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
3. Ibuprofen 600 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO Q6H (every 6 
hours) as needed for pain.
Disp:*50 Tablet(s)* Refills:*2*
4. Acetaminophen 500 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO Q4-6H () 
as needed for pain.  
5. Citalopram 20 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily).
Disp:*90 Tablet(s)* Refills:*2*

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
failed trial of labor
rupture of bladder
cesarean section delivery

 
Discharge Condition:
good.

 
Discharge Instructions:
per instruction sheets
 
Followup Instructions:
___

Brief Hospital Course:
Patient was admitted to the ___ Spine Surgery Service and 
taken to the Operating Room for the above two staged procedure.  
Refer to the dictated operative note for further details.  The 
surgery was without complication and the patient was transferred 
to the PACU in a stable condition.  TEDs/Pneumoboots were used 
for postoperative DVT prophylaxis.  Intravenous antibiotics were 
continued for 24hrs postop per standard protocol. Initial postop 
pain was controlled with a PCA and his pain was at times 
difficult to control because of his long history of opioid use 
for pain medication.  Diet was advanced as tolerated.  The 
patient was transitioned to oral pain medication when tolerating 
PO diet.  Foley was removed on POD#2.  Physical therapy was 
consulted for mobilization OOB to ambulate.  Hospital course was 
otherwise unremarkable.  On the day of discharge the patient was 
afebrile with stable vital signs, comfortable on oral pain 
control and tolerating a regular diet. 

 
Medications on Admission:
adderall, diazepam, penofibrate, metaxalone, oxycodone, 
oxycontin, ambien 
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Acetaminophen 650 mg PO Q4H fever, pain 
2. Adderall XR *NF* (amphetamine-dextroamphetamine) 30 mg Oral 
BID Reason for Ordering: Wish to maintain preadmission 
medication while hospitalized, as there is no acceptable 
substitute drug product available on formulary.
3. Bisacodyl 10 mg PO/PR DAILY 
RX *bisacodyl 5 mg 2 tablet(s) by mouth qdaily Disp #*60 Tablet 
Refills:*3
4. Diazepam ___ mg PO Q8H:PRN spasm 
5. Docusate Sodium 100 mg PO BID 
RX *docusate sodium [Colace] 100 mg 1 capsule(s) by mouth twice 
a day Disp #*60 Capsule Refills:*3
6. Oxycodone SR (OxyconTIN) 30 mg PO Q12H 
RX *oxycodone 30 mg 1 (One) tablet(s) by mouth twice a day Disp 
#*60 Tablet Refills:*0
7. Zolpidem Tartrate 5 mg PO HS 

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
1. L4-5 disk displacement.
2. L4-5 disk degeneration.
3. Radiculopathy.

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
You have undergone the following operation: L4-L5 fusion with 
interbody device and instrumentation, two staged procedure 
(lateral and posterior approach).  

Immediately after the operation:

     Activity: You should not lift anything greater than 10 lbs 
for 2 weeks. You will be more comfortable if you do not sit or 
stand more than ~45 minutes without getting up and walking 
around.

 

     Rehabilitation/ Physical Therapy: 

  ___ times a day you should go for a walk for ___ minutes as 
part of your recovery.  You can walk as much as you can 
tolerate. 

  Limit any kind of lifting.

 

     Diet: Eat a normal healthy diet. You may have some 
constipation after surgery.  You have been given medication to 
help with this issue.

 

     Wound Care: Remove the dressing in 2 days.  If the 
incision is draining cover it with a new sterile dressing.  If 
it is dry then you can leave the incision open to the air.  Once 
the incision is completely dry (usually ___ days after the 
operation) you may take a shower. Do not soak the incision in a 
bath or pool.  If the incision starts draining at anytime after 
surgery, do not get the incision wet. Cover it with a sterile 
dressing.  Call the office. 

 

     You should resume taking your normal home medications.

 

     You have also been given Additional Medications to control 
your pain.  Please allow 72 hours for refill of narcotic 
prescriptions, so please plan ahead.  You can either have them 
mailed to your home or pick them up at the clinic located on 
___.  We are not allowed to call in or fax narcotic 
prescriptions (oxycontin, oxycodone, percocet) to your pharmacy. 
 In addition, we are only allowed to write for pain medications 
for 90 days from the date of surgery.

 

     Follow up: 

 Please Call the office and make an appointment for 2 weeks 
after the day of your operation if this has not been done 
already.

 At the 2-week visit we will check your incision, take baseline 
X-rays and answer any questions. We may at that time start 
physical therapy.

  We will then see you at 6 weeks from the day of the operation 
and at that time release you to full activity.

 

 

Please call the office if you have a fever>101.5 degrees 
Fahrenheit and/or drainage from your wound.

 
Followup Instructions:
___

IMPRESSION:  Widened appearance of the mediastinum which may be 
an artifact, but correlation with history is recommended and if 
there is potential clinical concern for acute aortic pathology 
or other mediastinal pathology, then CT imaging could be 
considered.  Perihilar fullness suggesting vascular congestion. 

CT HEAD
IMPRESSION: Normal brain CT. Paranasal sinus inflammatory 
changes. 

CTA CHEST
IMPRESSION:  No pulmonary embolism or acute aortic pathology.

CT C-SPINE
IMPRESSION: Mild degenerative disk disease, otherwise normal 
study.

IMPRESSION: Significant chronic inflammatory change of bilateral 
maxillary sinuses. Otherwise normal study. 

___ 07:10AM BLOOD WBC-5.0 RBC-4.56* Hgb-13.2* Hct-40.5 
MCV-89 MCH-28.9 MCHC-32.5 RDW-14.6 Plt ___
UCX:  10,000-100,000 colonies bacteria

Brief Hospital Course:
The patient is ___ with unremarkable past medical history who 
was found down and transferred to the ICU for unresponsiveness 
of unclear etiology.
.
ACUTE ISSUES
#Unresponsiveness, new seizure
Patient found down with lorazepam on person. Urine and serum 
toxicology screen negative, though lorazepam and many other 
agents not screened. Initial labs demonstrated leukocytosis to 
14.5, negative UA and chest imaging not suggestive of infection. 
Other imaging including CTH and CTA which did not identify an 
intracranial process (herniation, infarction), PE, or acute 
aorta. Upon arrival to ___, patient was thought to be seizing. 
He was given a total of 4mg lorazepam and started on 
fentanyl/midazolam for sedation while intubated. An LP was 
attempted bedside but was unsuccessful. Neurology was consulted 
who recommended EEG, which was negative for seizure activity.  
The patient spontaneously emerged from unresponsiveness and 
while self extubating, injured a tooth. The patient was started 
on leviteracetam per Neurology. An MRI head was unremarkable. He 
denied any history of seizures, new medications, drug or etOH 
use, etc.

He will be discharged on keppra, and was instructed on following 
seizure precautions.  He was advised to followup for a repeat 
EEG and with neurology.  He was also told to followup with new 
PCP.

# Asymptomatic Bacteriuria:  10,000-100,000 colonies of bacteria 
seen on urine culture.  UA negative and patient asymptomatic, so 
appears to be contaminant.

# Chronic sinusitis:  Patient with symptoms, and seen on MRI.  
Advised to discuss with PCP.  

# Tooth injury:  Has loose tooth on account of self-extubation.  
Given limited number of percocets for his pain, and the number 
for ___ to arrange followup.  
 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Seizure disorder

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted after having two seizures.  You had a thorough 
evaluation by our neurologists, with a normal MRI and EEG (did 
not show seizure activity.  Nonetheless, we think that you 
should take anti-seizure medications for now.  Also, do not 
drive a car, or go swimming unattended.  PLEASE complete the 
needed paperwork so that your insurance is granted.  Our 
neurologists feel that you should have a second EEG so please 
call the number that you have been given to set this up.

Brief Hospital Course:
The patient is ___ with unremarkable past medical history who
was found down and transferred to the ICU for unresponsiveness
of unclear etiology.
.
ACUTE ISSUES
#Unresponsiveness, new seizure
Patient found down with lorazepam on person. Urine and serum
toxicology screen negative, though lorazepam and many other
agents not screened. Initial labs demonstrated leukocytosis to
14.5, negative UA and chest imaging not suggestive of infection.
Other imaging including CTH and CTA which did not identify an
intracranial process (herniation, infarction), PE, or acute
aorta. Upon arrival to ___, patient was thought to be seizing.
He was given a total of 4mg lorazepam and started on
fentanyl/midazolam for sedation while intubated. An LP was
attempted bedside but was unsuccessful. Neurology was consulted
who recommended EEG, which was negative for seizure activity.
The patient spontaneously emerged from unresponsiveness and
while self extubating, injured a tooth. The patient was started
on leviteracetam per Neurology. An MRI head was unremarkable. He
denied any history of seizures, new medications, drug or etOH
use, etc.
He will be discharged on keppra, and was instructed on following
seizure precautions. He was advised to followup for a repeat
EEG and with neurology. He was also told to followup with new
PCP.
# Asymptomatic Bacteriuria: 10,000-100,000 colonies of bacteria
seen on urine culture. UA negative and patient asymptomatic, so
appears to be contaminant.
# Chronic sinusitis: Patient with symptoms, and seen on MRI.
Advised to discuss with PCP.
# Tooth injury: Has loose tooth on account of self-extubation.
Given limited number of percocets for his pain, and the number
for ___ to arrange followup.
Discharge Disposition:
Home
Discharge Diagnosis:
Seizure disorder
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.
Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted after having two seizures. You had a thorough
evaluation by our neurologists, with a normal MRI and EEG (did
not show seizure activity. Nonetheless, we think that you
should take anti-seizure medications for now. Also, do not
drive a car, or go swimming unattended. PLEASE complete the
needed paperwork so that your insurance is granted. Our
neurologists feel that you should have a second EEG so please
call the number that you have been given to set this up.
Followup Instructions:
___

text:
Name:  ___                  Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: OBSTETRICS/GYNECOLOGY
 
Allergies: 
Sulfa (Sulfonamide Antibiotics)
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
Menorrhagia
Likely adenomyosis
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
Total laparoscopic hysterectomy
Cystoscopy
 
History of Present Illness:
___ yo P0 (2 adopted children) F with SLE with menorrhagia s/p 
Novasure endometrial ablation on ___ for long history of 
menometrorrhagia. Endometrial sampling pre-ablation was negative 
in ___.  

After endometrial ablation, she continued to have persistent and 
occasionally quite heavy vaginal bleeding, at times, quite 
heavy. Her bleeding has not abated since ___. The flow 
varies from light bleeding to heavy bleeding w/ passage of large 
clots. Her Hct in ___ was noted to be 33. She denies any 
SOB, LH, dizziness. She has mild cramping but denies severe 
dysmenorrhea or pelvic pain. She is extremely bothered by the 
chronicity of the bleeding. She states that she has not 
attempted medical mgt in the past with hormonal methods as per 
Dr. ___ recommendations. 

Recent pelvic u/s imaging from ___ showed an enlarged 
uterus, RV, measuring 9.6 x 7.2 cm w/ marked heterogeneous 
thickened myometrium w/ scattered tiny cysts consistent w/ 
adenomyosis. No definite fibroids noted. Endometrium is 
indistinct. Simple R ovarian cyst measuring 3.2 x 2.2 cm, most 
likely functional. Normal L ovary. 

She presented to Dr. ___ to discuss options for further 
management. The patient elected surgical management given the 
impact of her menometrorrahagia on her quality of life, and 
inability to use hormonal management given her underlying SLE. 
After discussion of the risks and benefits, the patient elected 
total laparoscopic hysterectomy for management of her symptoms. 
 
Past Medical History:
PGYNH:
Menarche age ___ LMP: ___
Menses irregular, see HPI
No h/o abnormal Pap tests
Last Pap: ___
Sexually active: Yes 
Sexual preference: opposite 
Current contraception: none
Prior contraceptive methods used: none
Lifetime sexual partners: 5
.
H/o infertility
H/o HSV - last outbreak ___ yrs ago
.
POBH:
TAB x 3
SAB x 2
.
PMH:
1) SLE
.
PSH:
1) Novasure endomtrial ablation ___
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
No breast or gynecologic malignancy

 
Physical Exam:
Post operative physical exam: 
T 96 (axillary) BP110/60 HR 80 RR 12 O2 Sat 100% 2L
Gen: NAD, talking, alert
Lungs: CTAB
CV: S1, S2. III/VI mid-systolic murmur lower left sternal 
border. Regular rate, rhythm. 
Abdomen: Bowel sounds present. Nondistended. Mildly tender 
around port sites, no rebound/guarding. Incisions are intact 
some small blood on umbilicus dressing. Suture for 2 port sites, 
dermabond for small 2 port sites (left lateral/right lateral). 
GU: No staining of vaginal pad. Foley in place. Blue from dye 
mixed with clear yellow urine. 
Ext: No edema, tenderness. Pneumoboots in place. 

 
Pertinent Results:
___ Bedside 12-lead EKG: Normal sinus rhythm. 
HR 81, intervals wnl, axis normal, no ST/T changes. 
Comparison: ___
 
Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ underwent an uncomplicated total laparoscopic 
hysterectomy and cystoscopy; see operative report for details.  
She received a stress dose of steroids intraoperatively and 
twice again postoperatively for her history of prednisone use.  
On postoperative day #1, she complained of feeling an 'irregular 
heart beat' after receiving dilaudid; she denied chest pain or 
dizziness. An EKG was obtained which showed normal sinus rhythm. 
Her symptoms were attributed to dilaudid administration.  The 
dilaudid was transitioned to vicodin and she remained 
asymptomatic.  Otherwise her postoperative course was 
uncomplicated.  She was discharged home on postoperative day #1 
in good condition: ambulating and urinating without difficulty, 
tolerating a regular diet, and with adequate pain control using 
PO medication.
 
Medications on Admission:
BUPROPION HCL [WELLBUTRIN SR] - 200 mg Tablet Sustained Release 
-
1 Tablet(s) by mouth once a day
HYDROXYCHLOROQUINE [PLAQUENIL] - 200 mg Tablet - two Tablet(s) 
by
mouth once a day
IBUPROFEN - 800 mg Tablet - 1 Tablet(s) by mouth three times a
day with food
PREDNISONE - 5 mg Tablet - two Tablet(s) by mouth once a day

 
Discharge Medications:
1. ibuprofen 600 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO Q6H (every 6 
hours) as needed for pain.
Disp:*60 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
2. hydrocodone-acetaminophen ___ mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO 
Q4H (every 4 hours) as needed for pain: maximum daily Tylenol 
(acetaminophen) is 4000mg, each Vicodin contains 325mg Tylenol 
(acetaminophen)
.
Disp:*45 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
3. bupropion HCl 100 mg Tablet Sustained Release Sig: Two (2) 
Tablet Sustained Release PO QAM (once a day (in the morning)).  
4. prednisone 10 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily). 
 
5. hydroxychloroquine 200 mg Tablet Sig: Two (2) Tablet PO DAILY 
(Daily).  
6. Colace 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO three times a 
day as needed for constipation.
Disp:*60 Capsule(s)* Refills:*0*

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
menorrhagia
adenomyosis

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Call your doctor for:
* fever > 100.4
* severe abdominal pain
* difficulty urinating
* vaginal bleeding requiring >1 pad/hr
* abnormal vaginal discharge
* redness or drainage from incision
* nausea/vomiting where you are unable to keep down fluids/food 
or your medication

General instructions:
* Take your medications as prescribed.
* Do not drive while taking narcotics.
* No strenuous activity and no heavy lifting of objects >10lbs 
for 6 weeks. 
* Nothing in the vagina (no tampons, no douching, no sex) for 3 
months
* You may eat a regular diet.

Incision care:
* You may shower and allow soapy water to run over incision; no 
scrubbing of incision.  No bath tubs for 6 weeks.
* If you have steri-strips, leave them on. They will fall off on 
their own or be removed during your followup visit.

 
Followup Instructions:
___

Brief Hospital Course:
___ year old year old female hx of ___ s/p liver bx 
admitted with post-procedure pain.

# Abdominal pain s/p liver bx: The patient had significant RUQ 
pain post procedure that persisted in the recovery area despite 
IV narcotics and was thus admitted. Post procedure CT showed no 
evidence of hematoma or acute bleed. There was mention of small 
dense pelvic fluid. In discussion with radiology they were 
unable to comment if this was physiologic fluid or potentially a 
complication of the procedure. She was managed with IV narcotic 
on HD1 and was pain free by HD 2 with any additional pain 
medication. Per ___ it is possible that she had a small bile duct 
leak during the procedure causing peritoneal irritation. Liver 
pathology is pending on discharge and she had outpatient  follow 
up with Dr. ___ hepatology in 3 weeks.

Dear Ms. ___,
It was a pleasure participating in your care. You were admitted 
to the hospital after your liver biopsy because you had 
abdominal pain. The radiologists believe you had a small bile 
duct leak during the biopsy that irritated the lining of your 
abdomen causing your pain. We gave you pain medication and your 
pain improved.

Please take all medications as prescribed and please keep all 
follow up appointments.
It was a pleasure participating in your care.

Pathology- liver bx pnd
Brief Hospital Course:
___ year old year old female hx of ___ s/p liver bx
admitted with post-procedure pain.
# Abdominal pain s/p liver bx: The patient had significant RUQ
pain post procedure that persisted in the recovery area despite
IV narcotics and was thus admitted. Post procedure CT showed no
evidence of hematoma or acute bleed. There was mention of small
dense pelvic fluid. In discussion with radiology they were
unable to comment if this was physiologic fluid or potentially a
complication of the procedure. She was managed with IV narcotic
on HD1 and was pain free by HD 2 with any additional pain
medication. Per ___ it is possible that she had a small bile duct
leak during the procedure causing peritoneal irritation. Liver
pathology is pending on discharge and she had outpatient follow
up with Dr. ___ hepatology in 3 weeks.
***Transitonal issue
- F/u liver biopsy results
Medications on Admission:
The Preadmission Medication list is accurate and complete.
1. Vitamin D 50,000 UNIT PO 1X/WEEK (___)
Discharge Medications:
1. Vitamin D 50,000 UNIT PO 1X/WEEK (___)
Discharge Disposition:
Home
Discharge Diagnosis:
Primary Diagnosis
1. abdominal pain
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.
Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___,
It was a pleasure participating in your care. You were admitted
to the hospital after your liver biopsy because you had
abdominal pain. The radiologists believe you had a small bile
duct leak during the biopsy that irritated the lining of your
abdomen causing your pain. We gave you pain medication and your
pain improved.
Please take all medications as prescribed and please keep all
follow up appointments.
It was a pleasure participating in your care.
Followup Instructions:
___

Name:  ___                Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   F
 
Service: NEUROSURGERY
 
Allergies: 
Codeine
 
Attending: ___
 
Chief Complaint:
Lower Back Pain
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
Lumbar laminectomy L ___

 
History of Present Illness:
She is a very pleasant ___ year old female who had low back pain 
starting in the lower lumbar spine radiating to both legs, 
primarily L5 and S1 distribution. That has been going on for at 
least a year but over the last few months, things have gotten 
much worse. She cannot walk more than 10 feet anymore. She has 
to sit down. She is using a wheelchair for longer distances and 
the walker at home. In ___, she was diagnosed with polymyalgia 
rheumatica and she was placed on prednisone and according to her 
daughter who works here, she felt a little better for a couple 
of months, but then things got worse again. Steroid injections 
helped temporarily. She opted to proceed for a lumbar 
laminectomy.
 
Past Medical History:
GERD
HL
HTN
She had two cardiac stents in ___. 
UTI
carotid stenosis
DM
Anxiety/depression
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
Non-Contributory
 
Physical Exam:
ADMISSION EXAM:
Flexion helps her symptoms. Extension makes things worse. At 
rest, she feels good without any pain or weakness. No bowel or 
bladder problems except
constipation. Cranial nerves II through XII okay. Upper 
extremities are strong. 

Exam in both lower extremities is full motorwise in all major
muscle groups. Sensory normal to light touch. SLR is negative 
for
radicular pain. Range of motion of the hips does not elicit any
pain and no other musculoskeletal issues. Reflexes 1+ symmetric.
Sensory to pinprick normal as well. 

DISCHARGE EXAM:
General: Awake, cooperative, NAD.
Skin: incision on lumbar spine C/D/I with staple closure
No motor deficit 

 
Pertinent Results:
MRI of her lumbar spine was reviewed. Severe stenosis at L4-L5 
with clumping of the roots above and below. This is a 
combination of left synovial cyst and right side ligamentous 
hypertrophy.

SPINE XRAY IMPRESSION: 
1.  Intraoperative radiograph demonstrates surgical hardware 
posterior to the L5-S1 level. 
2.  Multilevel degenerative disc disease. 
3.  Abdominal aortic atherosclerosis.  

GENERAL URINE INFORMATION Type Color ___ 
___ ___      Yellow Clear 1.013 
Source: ___ 
DIPSTICK URINALYSIS Blood Nitrite Protein Glucose Ketone Bilirub 
Urobiln pH Leuks 
___ 10:02    SM  NEG 30 NEG 40 NEG NEG 5.5 LG 
Source: ___ 
MICROSCOPIC URINE EXAMINATION RBC WBC Bacteri Yeast Epi TransE 
RenalEp 
___ 10:02    2 42* FEW NONE ___   
Source: ___ 
OTHER URINE FINDINGS Mucous 
___ 10:02    RARE 
Source: ___ 

 
Brief Hospital Course:
This is a ___ year old woman with low back pain and neurogenic 
claudication who presents for elective laminectomy with Dr. 
___. She was taken to the OR on ___ with no 
intraoperative complications. Patient was extubated post 
operatively and transferred to the PACU.

Over the course of the next days, the patient was noted to have 
difficulty voiding her bladder.  Urinalysis suggested UTI with 
associated leukocytosis for which Cipro was started for a three 
day course, with post voids straight cath on the evening of 
___ of 500cc twice. 

The patient was also noted to have some difficulty moving her 
bowels for which a bowel regimen was started.

The patient was noted to be neuro intact for the entire course 
of her stay with no focal deficit in terms of strength or 
sensation.

At the time of discharge preparation, she was trying to void on 
her own. If she is not successful, a Foley catheter will be 
placed.
 
Medications on Admission:
- Gabapentin
- Lisinoprol
- Metoprolol XL
- Ranitidine
- Simvastatin
- ASA 81mg

 
Discharge Medications:
1. Acetaminophen 325-650 mg PO Q6H:PRN headache 
2. Gabapentin 200 mg PO BID 
takes at home 
3. Lisinopril 10 mg PO DAILY 
4. Lorazepam 0.5 mg PO Q8H:PRN anxiety 
5. Metoprolol Succinate XL 50 mg PO DAILY 
hold for HR<60 SBP<110 
6. Ranitidine 150 mg PO DAILY 
7. Simvastatin 40 mg PO DAILY 
8. Bisacodyl 10 mg PO/PR DAILY 
9. Docusate Sodium 100 mg PO BID 
10. Senna 1 TAB PO BID 
11. OxycoDONE (Immediate Release)  ___ mg PO Q4H:PRN pain 
hold rr < 12 
12. Oxycodone SR (OxyconTIN) 10 mg PO Q12H pain 
takes this dose at home/hold rr < 12 
13. Ciprofloxacin HCl 250 mg PO Q12H Duration: 3 Days 
last full day of treatment will be ___. 
14. Multivitamins 1 TAB PO DAILY 
15. Calcium Carbonate 500 mg PO Q 24H 
16. Cepacol (Menthol) 1 LOZ PO PRN throat pain 
** MAY START ASA 81mg on ___ which will be one week after her 
laminectomy operation on ___.
 
Discharge Disposition:
Extended Care
 
Facility:
___
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Elective L4-L5 Laminectomy

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Lumbar Laminectomy/Discectomy
Dr. ___

 You have staples, keep your wound clean and dry until they are 
removed. They should be removed at your rehab on ___ **** 
 No tub baths or pool swimming for two weeks from your date of 
surgery.
 Do not smoke.
 No pulling up, lifting more than 10 lbs., or excessive bending 
or twisting.
 Limit your use of stairs to ___ times per day.
 Have a friend or family member check your incision daily for 
signs of infection.
 Take your pain medication as instructed; you may find it best 
if taken in the morning when you wake-up for morning stiffness, 
and before bed for sleeping discomfort. Pain medication should 
be used as needed when you have pain. You do not need to take it 
if you do not have pain.
 Do not take any anti-inflammatory medications such as Motrin, 
Advil, Aspirin, and Ibuprofen etc. for two weeks.
 Increase your intake of fluids and fiber, as pain medicine 
(narcotics) can cause constipation. We recommend taking an over 
the counter stool softener, such as Docusate (Colace) while 
taking narcotic pain medication.
 Clearance to drive and return to work will be addressed at 
your post-operative office visit.

CALL YOUR SURGEON IMMEDIATELY IF YOU EXPERIENCE ANY OF THE 
FOLLOWING:

 Pain that is continually increasing or not relieved by pain 
medicine.
 Any weakness, numbness, tingling in your extremities.
 Any signs of infection at the wound site: redness, swelling, 
tenderness, and drainage.
 Fever greater than or equal to 101.5° F. 
 Loss of control of bowel or bladder functioning

At the time of discharge, the patient was having some difficulty 
voiding her bladder.  If she can not uriante at the time of 
ambulance arrival, a Foley cathter will be placed.
 
Followup Instructions:
___

___ s/p LTCS for acute placental abruption/Pre-Eclampsia
presents after home BP check by visiting nurse was 160/110.  She 
was feeling well, and denies VC/RUQ pain.  Mild dull HA.
She did not receive Magnesium postpartum.  She was on labetalol 
300mg BID at home and has been compliant.

 
Past Medical History:

VS 99.1   85   18
GENERAL: NAD
CARDIO: RRR
PULM: CTAB
ABDOMEN: soft, NTND
incision: +steris, C/D/I, ecchymosis left mons
EXTREMITIES: NT b/l, 2+ patellar DTRs

 
Pertinent Results:
___ 04:50PM   CREAT-0.6
___ 04:50PM   URIC ACID-5.6
___ 04:50PM URINE  HOURS-RANDOM CREAT-17 TOT PROT-7 
PROT/CREA-0.4*
___ 04:50PM URINE  BLOOD-TR NITRITE-NEG PROTEIN-NEG 
GLUCOSE-NEG KETONE-NEG BILIRUBIN-NEG UROBILNGN-NEG PH-7.5 
LEUK-NEG
 
Brief Hospital Course:
On ___ The patient presented at 35 weeks and 4 days with 
elevated blood pressures as high as 180/100.  She also 
complained of mild cramping that progressively worsened to 
severe over the course of her evaluation for preeclampsia. A 
transabdominal ultrasound done for fetal well-being revealed a 
concealed large placental abruption. Given her symptoms and 
abruption, the decision was made to proceed with an urgent 
cesarean section under general endotracheal anesthesia. Her 
cesearean section was uncomplicated and the abruption was noted 
on gross observation. The placenta was sent to pathology and the 
pathology confirmed acute abruption. The Ph of the venous blood 
gas was 7.30 but the arterial blood gas sent to the lab was 
clotted and therefore not evaluated. 
Although she had >600 protein in her u/a, her urine protein was 
<6 on ___. All other pre-eclampsia/HEELP labs were within normal 
limits. The decision was made by the attending physican not to 
proceed with magnesium given unclear diagnosis of pre-eclampsia. 

Her postoperative course was complicated only by elevated blood 
pressures as high as 160/90. She was started on Labetalol 200 
BID which was titrated up to 300 BID. On ___, at discharge, 
her blood pressures were well controlled, she had no symptoms of 
pre-eclampsia and she met all postoperative goals.
*
Ms ___ was readmitted on ___ with BP 160s/110s with HA, 
and new mild transaminitis with an ALT of 46. Her Pr: Cr ratio 
was now 0.4. She received 24 of Magnesium (a 4g bolus and a 
2g/hr infusion). She was started on Nifedipine 10 mg TID which 
immediately brought her blood pressures to within normal range. 
Her headache resolved with Tylenol and sleep. She was discharged 
home on hospital day 3 on Nifedipine with well controlled blood 
pressures and no symptoms of pre-eclampsia.
 
Medications on Admission:
labetalol 300mg PO BID
Tylenol ___ mg ___ PO q6hrs PRN pain

 
Discharge Medications:
1. Nifedipine 30 mg Tablet Extended Rel 24 hr Sig: One (1) 
Tablet Extended Rel 24 hr PO once a day.
Disp:*30 Tablet Extended Rel 24 hr(s)* Refills:*2*

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home With Service
 
Facility:
___
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Pregnancy-induced hypertension, postpartum/ Pre-eclampsia

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Medications as prescribed
Monitor BPs at home, call for systolic >150, diastolic >95

 
Followup Instructions:
___

text:
Name:  ___               Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: NEUROSURGERY
 
Allergies: 
Penicillins
 
Attending: ___
 
Chief Complaint:
HNP

 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
___ left L4/5 microdiscectomy
 
History of Present Illness:
He is a very pleasant ___
___ gentleman.  Low back pain and left leg pain for six to
seven months now.  No precipitating event.  Pain is relatively
typical of neurogenic claudication with improvement when he is
leaning forward and worse with extension.  However, it is worse
when he is lying down and he has a hard time lying down.  No
bowel or bladder dysfunction.  Physical therapy is done already
and he had two steroid injections.  The patient cannot sleep
secondary to pain.  MRI showed a far left lateral L4/5 disc 
herniation displacing the L4 nerve root.  After careful review 
of the pt's history, physical exam and imaging it was determined 
that he would be a good candidate for a left L4/5 
microdiscectomy
 
Past Medical History:
back pain, R inguinal and umbilical hernia repair, appendectomy, 
tonsillectomy
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
Non-contributory
 
Physical Exam:
On admission
Neurologically intact

On discharge
Neurologically intact
Incision CDI no edema/erythema.
 
Pertinent Results:
___ - Lumbar x ray
There is moderately severe narrowing of what appears to be the 
L5-S1 disc 
space. There is a surgical retractors positioned at the level of 
this disc 
space.  No fracture seen. Alignment appears similar when 
compared to the prior 
study.  Please see the operative report for further details. 

 
Brief Hospital Course:
On ___ the patient was admitted to ___ for elective left 
L4/5 microdiscectomy.  The patient tolerated the above procedure 
well, was extubated and transferred to the PACU for further 
recovery.  He was intact on post op exam.

On ___, the patient was stable and there were no events over 
night.  He voided and tolerated a PO diet.  He ambulated in the 
halls with no issues.  He was discharged to home in improved 
condition.
 
Medications on Admission:
aspirin
dilaudid
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Bisacodyl 10 mg PO DAILY 
RX *bisacodyl 5 mg 1 tablet(s) by mouth Daily as needed Disp 
#*20 Tablet Refills:*0
2. OxycoDONE (Immediate Release)  ___ mg PO Q4H:PRN pain 
RX *oxycodone 5 mg ___ tablet(s) by mouth Every ___ hours as 
needed Disp #*75 Tablet Refills:*0
3. Senna 8.6 mg PO BID 
RX *sennosides [senna] 8.6 mg 1 capsule by mouth daily as needed 
Disp #*20 Capsule Refills:*0

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
HNP

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Your dressing may come off on the second day after surgery. 
*** Your incision is closed with staples or sutures. You will 
need suture/staple removal. Please keep your incision dry until 
suture/staple removal.
*** Your incision is closed with dissolvable sutures 
underneath the skin and steri strips. You do not need suture 
removal. Do not remove your steri strips, let them fall off. 
Please keep your incision dry for 72 hours after surgery.
Do not apply any lotions or creams to the site. 
Please avoid swimming for two weeks after suture/staple 
removal.
Call your surgeon if there are any signs of infection like 
redness, fever, or drainage. 

Activity
We recommend that you avoid heavy lifting, running, climbing, 
or other strenuous exercise until your follow-up appointment.
You make take leisurely walks and slowly increase your 
activity at your own pace. ___ try to do too much all at once.
No driving while taking any narcotic or sedating medication. 
No contact sports until cleared by your neurosurgeon. 

Medications
***Please do NOT take any blood thinning medication (Aspirin, 
Ibuprofen, Plavix, Coumadin) until cleared by the neurosurgeon. 
*** You may take Ibuprofen/ Motrin for pain.
You may use Acetaminophen (Tylenol) for minor discomfort if 
you are not otherwise restricted from taking this medication.
It is important to increase fluid intake while taking pain 
medications. We also recommend a stool softener like Colace. 
Pain medications can cause constipation.

___

typical of neurogenic claudication with improvement when he is
leaning forward and worse with extension. However, it is worse
when he is lying down and he has a hard time lying down. No
bowel or bladder dysfunction. Physical therapy is done already
and he had two steroid injections. The patient cannot sleep
secondary to pain. MRI showed a far left lateral L4/5 disc

of the pt's history, physical exam and imaging it was determined
that he would be a good candidate for a left L4/5

Name:  ___               Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: NEUROSURGERY
 
Allergies: 
Penicillins
 
Attending: ___
 
Chief Complaint:
Disc herniation
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
___ Left L4-L5 microdiskectomy for recurrent disk 
herniation, arthrodesis L4-L5, fusion L4-L5.

 
History of Present Illness:
___ elective admission for a left microdiskectomy L4-5
 
Past Medical History:
___ LEFT L4-L5 MICRODISCECTOMY 

back pain, R inguinal and umbilical hernia repair, appendectomy, 
tonsillectomy
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
Non-contributory
 
Physical Exam:
Upon Discharge:
AAO x 3
Full strength throughout.  Sensation intact throughout.
Incision closed with staples, CDI.

 
Pertinent Results:
___ 05:25AM BLOOD WBC-8.3 RBC-5.31 Hgb-10.6* Hct-33.3* 
MCV-63* MCH-20.0* MCHC-31.9 RDW-16.4* Plt ___
___ 05:25AM BLOOD ___ PTT-35.4 ___
___ 05:25AM BLOOD Glucose-105* UreaN-10 Creat-0.9 Na-136 
K-3.8 Cl-100 HCO3-26 AnGap-14
___ 05:25AM BLOOD Calcium-8.4 Phos-3.1 Mg-1.8
 
Brief Hospital Course:
Patient underwent a L4-5 microdiskectomy and tolerated the 
procedure well. He was extubated post-operatively and 
transferred to the PACU for recovery. Upon post-op evaluation, 
the patient was neurologically intact.  His pain was managed 
well with narcotic and non-narcotic analgesics.  Mr. ___ 
was transferred from PACU to the inpatient ward for further 
management.  

On ___, Mr. ___ continued to recover well.  He remained on 
bedrest until his LSO brace arrived.   He was tolerating a 
regular diet without issue.  His pain was well controlled.  

On ___, the patient's brace arrived.  He was evaluated with 
Physical Therapy and taught how to apply the brace 
independently.  During this time, his pain continued to be 
well-controlled.  Later that evening, Mr. ___ was 
discharged home in the care of his family.  He was ambulating 
independently and urinating without issue.  Per his discharge 
instructions, the patient should follow up in ___ 
clinic for a wound evaluation and staple removal.  He will also 
follow up with Dr. ___ in 4 weeks with lumbar spine 
films for post-operative evaluation.

At the time of discharge, Mr. ___ was afebrile, 
hemodynamically and neurologically intact.
 
Medications on Admission:
Aspirin 325mg Daily
 
Discharge Medications:
1. Acetaminophen 325-650 mg PO Q6H:PRN fever or pain 
2. Aspirin 325 mg PO DAILY 
3. Docusate Sodium 100 mg PO BID 
4. TraMADOL (Ultram) 25 mg PO Q6H:PRN pain 
RX *tramadol 50 mg 0.5 (One half) tablet(s) by mouth every six 
(6) hours Disp #*20 Tablet Refills:*0

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Recurrent disk herniation, left L4-L5 with instability.

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Surgery
Your incision is closed with staples. You will need them 
removed in ___ days.  See "follow-up" below.
Do not apply any lotions or creams to the site. 
Please keep your incision dry until removal of your staples.
Please avoid swimming for two weeks after staple removal.
Call your surgeon if there are any signs of infection like 
redness, fever, or drainage. 

Activity
You must wear your brace at all times when out of bed. You may 
apply your brace sitting at the edge of the bed. You do not need 
to sleep with it on. 
You must wear your brace while showering. 
We recommend that you avoid heavy lifting, running, climbing, 
or other strenuous exercise until your follow-up appointment.
You make take leisurely walks and slowly increase your 
activity at your own pace. ___ try to do too much all at once.
No driving while taking any narcotic or sedating medication. 
No contact sports until cleared by your neurosurgeon. 
Do NOT smoke. Smoking can affect your healing and fusion.

Medications
Please do NOT take any blood thinning medication (Ibuprofen, 
Plavix, Coumadin) until cleared by the neurosurgeon. You MAY 
take aspirin.
Do not take any anti-inflammatory medications such as Motrin, 
Advil, Aspirin, and Ibuprofen etc until cleared by your 
neurosurgeon.
You may use Acetaminophen (Tylenol) for minor discomfort if 
you are not otherwise restricted from taking this medication.
It is important to increase fluid intake while taking pain 
medications. We also recommend a stool softener like Colace. 
Pain medications can cause constipation. 
 
Followup Instructions:
___

text:
Name:  ___                 Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: SURGERY
 
Allergies: 
Beta-Blockers (Beta-Adrenergic Blocking Agts) / Inderal / 
Nizoral
 
Attending: ___
 
___ Complaint:
chronic recurrent diverticulitis
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
Laparoscopic sigmoid resection with primary anastomosis
 
History of Present Illness:
___ with a history of four episodes of diverticulitis in the 
last ___ years, requiring hospitalization. The first three 
episodes were uncomplicated and treated with abx, but the last 
episode (___) was complicated by an intramural abscess (seen 
on CT), and treated with 2 weeks of cipro/flagyl. Since his last 
episode of diverticulitis, the patient underwent a colonoscopy 
which revealed diverticulitis, with no other pathology. Today, 
the patient presents to discuss sigmoid resection to surgically 
manage his disease.
 
Past Medical History:
PAST MEDICAL HISTORY:
Eczema
Glaucoma
Migraines

Previous surgeries/procedures: Lap rotator cuff repair
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
FAMILY MEDICAL HISTORY:
No FH of colon cancer, or IBD. Mother had multiple myeloma.  
 
Physical Exam:
AVSS
NAD, A&Ox3, calm and comfortable, conversational
PERRLA, EOMI, mmm, OP clear
no cervical lymphadenopathy
RRR, no m/r/g
CTAB, no w/r/r
Abdomen soft, mildly distended, mild appropriate ___ 
tenderness, no rebound/guarding. laparosopic incisions well 
approximated, c/d/i.
Extremities with palpable ___ pulses bilaterally
 
Pertinent Results:
___ 04:40PM BLOOD Hct-41.7
___ 04:40PM BLOOD Na-139 K-3.8 Cl-102
___ 04:40PM BLOOD Mg-2.0
___ 07:36AM BLOOD WBC-4.6 RBC-3.80* Hgb-12.0* Hct-34.9* 
MCV-92 MCH-31.7 MCHC-34.5 RDW-12.8 Plt ___
___ 07:36AM BLOOD Glucose-121* UreaN-14 Creat-0.7 Na-137 
K-3.8 Cl-103 HCO3-28 AnGap-10
___ 07:36AM BLOOD Calcium-8.3* Phos-2.7 Mg-1.9
 
Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. ___ presented to ___ holding at ___ on ___ for 
a laparoscopic sigmoidectomy. He tolerated the procedure well 
without complications (Please see operative note for further 
details). After a brief and uneventful stay in the PACU, the 
patient was transferred to the floor for further post-operative 
management. 

On ___ (POD#2), the patient was discharged to home. At 
discharge, he was tolerating a regular diet, passing flatus, 
stooling, voiding, and ambulating independently. He will 
follow-up in the clinic in ___ weeks. This information was 
communicated to the patient directly prior to discharge. 

Post-Surgical Complications During Inpatient Admission:
[ ] Post-Operative Ileus resolving w/o NGT
[ ] Post-Operative Ileus requiring management with NGT
[ ] UTI
[ ] Wound Infection
[ ] Anastomotic Leak
[ ] Staple Line Bleed
[ ] Congestive Heart failure 
[ ] ARF
[ ] Acute Urinary retention, failure to void after Foley D/C'd
[ ] Acute Urinary Retention requiring discharge with Foley 
Catheter
[ ] DVT
[ ] Pneumonia
[ ] Abscess
[x] None

Social Issues Causing a Delay in Discharge:
[ ] Delay in organization of ___ services
[ ] Difficulty finding appropriate rehabilitation hospital 
disposition.
[ ] Lack of insurance coverage for ___ services
[ ] Lack of insurance coverage for prescribed medications.
[ ] Family not agreeable to discharge plan.
[ ] Patient knowledge deficit related to ileostomy delaying 
discharge. 
[x] No social factors contributing in delay of discharge.
 
Medications on Admission:
imitrex ___ BID PRN headache

 
Discharge Medications:
1. Acetaminophen 1000 mg PO TID 
Do not drink alcohol when taking acetaminophen 
RX *acetaminophen 650 mg 1 tablet extended release(s) by mouth 
three times a day Disp #*60 Tablet Refills:*0
2. Sumatriptan Succinate 25 mg PO ONCE MR1 headache Duration: 1 
Dose 
3. OxycoDONE (Immediate Release)  ___ mg PO Q4H:PRN pain 
Do not drink alcohol or drive when taking oxycodone 
RX *oxycodone 5 mg ___ tablet(s) by mouth every four (4) hours 
Disp #*40 Tablet Refills:*0

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
chronic recurrent diverticulitis
 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.
 
Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted to the hospital after a Laparoscopic sigmoid 
resection with primary anastomosis for surgical management of 
your chronic recurrent diverticulitis. You have recovered from 
this procedure well and you are now ready to return home. 
Samples from your colon were taken and this tissue has been sent 
to the pathology department for analysis. You will receive these 
pathology results at your follow-up appointment. If there is an 
urgent need for the surgeon to contact you regarding these 
results they will contact you before this time. You have 
tolerated a regular diet, are passing gas and your pain is 
controlled with pain medications by mouth. You may return home 
to finish your recovery.
 
Please monitor your bowel function closely. You may or may not 
have had a bowel movement prior to your discharge which is 
acceptable, however it is important that you have a bowel 
movement in the next ___ days. After anesthesia it is not 
uncommon for patients to have some decrease in bowel function 
but you should not have prolonged constipation. Some loose stool 
and passing of small amounts of dark, old appearing blood are 
expected. However, if you notice that you are passing bright red 
blood with bowel movements or having loose stool without 
improvement please call the office or go to the emergency room 
if the symptoms are severe. If you are taking narcotic pain 
medications there is a risk that you will have some 
constipation. Please take an over the counter stool softener 
such as Colace, and if the symptoms do not improve call the 
office. If you have any of the following symptoms please call 
the office for advice or go to the emergency room if severe: 
increasing abdominal distension, increasing abdominal pain, 
nausea, vomiting, inability to tolerate food or liquids, 
prolonged loose stool, or extended constipation.
 
You have ___ laparoscopic surgical incisions on your abdomen 
which are closed with internal sutures and a skin glue called 
Dermabond. These are healing well however it is important that 
you monitor these areas for signs and symptoms of infection 
including: increasing redness of the incision lines, 
white/green/yellow/malodorous drainage, increased pain at the 
incision, increased warmth of the skin at the incision, or 
swelling of the area. Please call the office if you develop any 
of these symptoms or a fever. You may go to the emergency room 
if your symptoms are severe. 

You may shower; pat the incisions dry with a towel, do not rub. 
The small incisions may be left open to the air. If closed with 
steri-strips (little white adhesive strips) instead of 
Dermabond, these will fall off over time, please do not remove 
them. Please no baths or swimming for 6 weeks after surgery 
unless told otherwise by Dr. ___.
 
You will be prescribed a small amount of the pain medication 
oxycodone. Please take this medication exactly as prescribed. 
You may take Tylenol as recommended for pain. Please do not take 
more than 4000mg of Tylenol daily. Do not drink alcohol while 
taking narcotic pain medication or Tylenol. Please do not drive 
a car while taking narcotic pain medication.

No heavy lifting greater than 6 lbs for until your first 
post-operative visit after surgery. Please no strenuous activity 
until this time unless instructed otherwise by Dr. ___.
 
Thank you for allowing us to participate in your care! Our hope 
is that you will have a quick return to your life and usual 
activities. Good luck!
 
Followup Instructions:
___

text:
Name:  ___                  Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: ORTHOPAEDICS
 
Allergies: 
Penicillins
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
RUE injury after fall

 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
R radial head replacement and R ex-fix for comminuted open

 
History of Present Illness:
 ___ year old otherwise healthy RHD man, s/p a mechanical slip
and fall from a platform at work, who tried to break his fall
with his RUE, with immediate pain and deformity of his R elbow
and wrist. No headstrike, no LOC. No numbness/tingling 
throughout
the extremity. 

 
Past Medical History:
Hyperlipidemia; s/p repair of R biceps tendon

 
Social History:
___
Family History:
nc
 
Physical Exam:
AVSS
RUE WWP, with 2+ radial pulses, and intact motor function of
M/R/U nerves. SILT throughout. Ex-fix in place, c/d/i. 
 
Pertinent Results:
___ 12:40AM   GLUCOSE-139* UREA N-22* CREAT-1.0 SODIUM-140 
POTASSIUM-3.8 CHLORIDE-105 TOTAL CO2-21* ANION GAP-18
___ 12:40AM   estGFR-Using this
___ 12:40AM   WBC-12.3*# RBC-5.20 HGB-15.6 HCT-46.1 MCV-89 
MCH-30.0 MCHC-33.9 RDW-13.9
___ 12:40AM   NEUTS-57.8 ___ MONOS-5.7 EOS-2.9 
BASOS-0.8
___ 12:40AM   PLT COUNT-306
 
Brief Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the Orthopaedic Trauma Service for 
repair of a R intra-articular DRF, comminuted R radial head and 
neck fracture.  The patient was taken to the OR and underwent an 
uncomplicated ORIF radial head replacement and placement of 
ex-fix. The patient tolerated the procedure without 
complications and was transferred to the PACU in stable 
condition.  Please see operative report for details. Post 
operatively pain was controlled with a PCA with a transition to 
PO pain meds once tolerating POs.  The patient tolerated diet 
advancement without difficulty and made steady progress with ___.

Weight bearing status: nonwb RUE.

The patient received ___ antibiotics as well as 
Fragmin for DVT prophylaxis.  The incision was clean, dry, and 
intact without evidence of erythema or drainage; and the 
extremity was NVI distally throughout.  The patient was 
discharged in stable condition with written instructions 
concerning precautionary instructions and the appropriate 
follow-up care.  The patient will be continued on chemical DVT 
prophylaxis for 4 weeks post-operatively.  All questions were 
answered prior to discharge and the patient expressed readiness 
for discharge
 
Medications on Admission:
Crestor 20mg daily

 
Discharge Medications:
1. Acetaminophen 650 mg PO Q6H 
Standing dose 
2. Docusate Sodium 100 mg PO BID 
3. Rosuvastatin Calcium 20 mg PO DAILY 
4. Senna 1 TAB PO BID:PRN constipation 
5. OxycoDONE (Immediate Release)  ___ mg PO Q3H:PRN pain 
RX *oxycodone 5 mg ___ Tablet(s) by mouth q3hrs Disp #*90 Tablet 
Refills:*0

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home With Service
 
Facility:
___
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
s/p R radial head replacement and R ex-fix for comminuted open 
fractures

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
******SIGNS OF INFECTION**********
Please return to the emergency department or notify MD if you 
should experience severe pain, increased swelling, decreased 
sensation, difficulty with movement; fevers >101.5, chills, 
redness or drainage at the incision site; chest pain, shortness 
of breath or any other concerns.
-Wound Care: You can get the wound wet/take a shower starting 
from 3 days post-op. No baths or swimming for at least 4 weeks. 
Any stitches or staples that need to be removed will be taken 
out at your 2-week follow up appointment. No dressing is needed 
if wound continued to be non-draining.

******WEIGHT-BEARING*******
Nonweightbearing RUE in splint

******MEDICATIONS***********
- Resume your pre-hospital medications.
- You have been given medication for your pain control. Please 
do not operate heavy machinery or drink alcohol when taking this 
medication. As your pain improves please decrease the amount of 
pain medication. This medication can cause constipation, so you 
should drink ___ glasses of water daily and take a stool 
softener (colace) to prevent this side effect.
-Medication refills cannot be written after 12 noon on ___.

Physical Therapy:
nonwb RUE
Treatments Frequency:
Pin site care (sterile h202/NS solution; apply to surrounding 
skin and ex-fix)
dressing change wet to dry
sutures/staples to remain in place until ___ days postop (DOS: 
___
 
Followup Instructions:
___
